site_title: HSR's 100% commission scheme raises eyebrows
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

HSR's 100% commission scheme raises eyebrows

Been done before, say industry players; bigger agencies not likely to follow suit

Published

Thu, Aug 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IN a sign of how property agencies are going all out to stimulate sales activity in the subdued Singapore residential market, HSR International Realtors has come up with a 100 per cent commission scheme for agents and touted it as a "game changer".

But the new scheme, which becomes effective from January next year, already has its detractors.

Industry players noted that such a scheme has been introduced before by other smaller agencies but without success. Hence bigger agencies are unlikely to follow suit.

Currently, the typical commission payout in the industry ranges from 70-90 per cent, depending on the experience and performance of the salesperson.

Under HSR's new scheme, salespersons earning 90 per cent commission will be entitled to a 100 per cent commission once they achieve earnings of S$38,000 in a 12-month cycle. Those currently on the entry-level 70 per cent commission will be lifted to the 80 per cent level.

HSR chief executive Anne Tong said: "We believe that the scheme will encourage our existing salespersons to grow their business together with us and thus increase their take-home income. At the same time, we believe this scheme will also attract other salespersons or new ones to join us."

According to HSR's illustration, a salesperson who earns a gross commission of S$500,000 would have received a maximum net commission of S$450,000 under the old scheme. But under the new scheme, the salesperson will take home S$496,200.

HSR said that there will be no let-up in support services for its salespersons, such as IT services, operational and administrative support, research reports, legal advice, marketing products and training.

So far this year, HSR has seen a 21.6 per cent contraction of its agents pool to 1,327 agents. Ms Tong noted that it is possible that some of the salespersons who left HSR may have left the industry completely.

According to her, more than 40 per cent of those who resigned were not active sales agents to begin with, as they had not made a single sale since they joined.

One management executive of a rival firm felt that HSR's new commission scheme "is essentially giving all its existing team managers a big pay cut".

"There may be no more incentive and purpose for these managers to recruit, train, manage and retain. It will become an every-man- for-himself culture," said the management executive who declined to be named.

Century21 chief executive Ku Swee Yong questioned if a 100 per cent commission scheme is sustainable as it requires the management to have a lot of reserves to tide through this period of very low transactions.

"At the end of the day, the agents must have enough transactions in the market to feed themselves. Then they will continue holding on to their licence and stick with the company," he said. "The reality now is many agents are leaving the agency pool and taking up full-time jobs. Although they are still holding onto a licence, some may have found work with other corporations."

Mr Ku pointed out that there are also other factors affecting how salespersons choose their agencies, including the corporate branding, systems and processes, working environment and areas of specialisation.

According to the Council for Estate Agencies (CEA), the number of licensed estate agencies and registered salespersons has "remained fairly consistent for the last three years".

On Jan 1 this year, CEA had on its rolls 1,425 licensed estate agencies and 31,783 registered salespersons, compared to 1,492 estate agencies and 31,040 salespersons on Jan 1, 2013. In comparison, there were 1,487 estate agencies and 30,577 salespersons on Jan 1, 2012.

The drastic fall in residential sales has prompted industry players to band together to share resources and leverage on one another's network.

In July, HSR formed an alliance with SLP International, OrangeTee and Dennis Wee Realty to collaborate on project marketing mainly for local projects. HSR has garnered three new residential projects since the formation of the alliance, Ms Tong said.

She added that HSR is also expanding its reach to overseas projects, such as those in Malaysia, Thailand, Australia and the UK, and has plans to diversify further into commercial properties.

India-Asean services pact still on track

Published Thu, Aug 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE assurance by Indian Commerce and Industry Minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Wednesday that her country would honour its commitment to the Asean region and is ready to sign a services and investment pact should come as a relief. This announcement came a day after she abruptly cancelled her visit to Myanmar for the India-Asean economic ministers meet where she was supposed to sign the deal.

India is already facing criticism for scuttling the World Trade Organization's (WTO) Trade Facilitation Agreement. Understandably, the no-show by the minister at an India-specific, three-day meeting in Myanmar raised concern about the country's commitment to the pact and to a global trade regime. Ms Sitharaman said last-minute domestic compulsions prevented her from attending and the official line is that she had to stay back due to the launch of a financial-inclusion scheme to provide every household with a bank account and insurance cover. However, it seems unlikely that such a scheduling mix-up could have happened since the meeting in Myanmar was planned quite a while ago and would have been factored in.

It is more likely that the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi wanted to have a closer look at the ramifications of the deal which was negotiated and agreed to under the government of the former prime minister, Manmohan Singh. India and Asean already have an FTA (free trade agreement) covering goods.

site_title: Coal derivatives market expected to boom
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Coal derivatives market expected to boom

SGX and CME recognised as dominant players

Published

Sun, Aug 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The coal industry's ongoing switch from fixed to floating prices in contracts is fuelling expectations of an explosion in the nascent thermal-coal derivatives market.

And Singapore, the base for many Asian coal traders, looks set to be the battleground for exchanges to gain market share.

When prices headed up in the few years after 2008, miners saw little benefit in hedging. But now, a bearish outlook for coal has boosted interest in hedging as coal producers, reluctant to fix long-term contracts at current price levels, are starting to use shorter-term contracts.

Buyers from China, the largest consumer of thermal coal, also prefer to make purchases in an opportunistic manner - such as when seaborne coal becomes cheaper than that which is domestically produced.

Scott Dendy, the Asia-Pacific head of coal data provider McCloskey Coal at IHS Energy, said: "There has certainly been an increase in index-related physical transaction in the Asian coal market, and this has given rise to an increase in the volumes of exchange-traded derivatives."

Although coal derivatives have been prevalent in Europe since the deregulation of the electricity market there compelled power- generation companies to hedge the costs of their coal input, hedging has been an alien practice for Asian coal players until recent years.

The Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME), the largest futures operator in the United States, was the first to mine this field, launching the Indonesian sub-bituminous futures contract in August 2011, followed by another two since; its first-mover advantage has enabled it to capture market share, said Alan Bannister, its executive director of energy products in Asia.

The Singapore Exchange (SGX) soon followed suit. Last October, it launched two futures contracts, and added two more in July this year.

With these, all key thermal coal price benchmarks with Asian centricity will be covered by the exchange, SGX chief executive Magnus Bocker said in May.

The US-based InterContinental Exchange (ICE) also carries coal futures contracts but in Asia, CME and SGX are recognised to be the more dominant players.

Asia is an important region for coal - the top five coal importers in 2012, all in Asia, are increasingly buying more.

SGX noted that Asia has gone from accounting for about half of seaborne coal demand a decade ago to three-quarters of overall demand today. However, derivatives volume represented only 4 to 6 per cent of the Asian seaborne physical market last year, SGX estimated.

As the US and Europe clamp down on the use of coal, and with both supply and demand growth expected to come from Asia in the coming decade, Singapore is increasingly seen as an important hub for the trading of coal derivatives.

CME's Mr Bannister said: "More than half the volume on our Asian coal products come from Singapore; the other big centres would be London and Geneva."

Participants of the coal derivatives market here are largely traders, power gencos and miners, said SGX.

However, compared to iron ore - another commodity in which the use of derivatives has grown rapidly in recent years - thermal coal is a more fragmented market. It has multiple source and destination markets, hence the varying price indices that have emerged.

Most of the world's traded coal derivatives currently use API 2 and API 4 as benchmarks for price settlement.

With fewer coal contracts priced using API 8 and the IHS McCloskey Indonesian Sub-Bituminous Coal index than API 2 and API 4, "liquidity of the SGX swaps is expected to be limited, even in the case of high price volatility as observed on current markets", said Xavier Veillard, director of trading and investment strategy at Accenture. "This is further supported by the fact that producers want to remain naturally exposed to coal price volatility, while utility-end buyers in North Asia typically sell electricity on a cost- plus-regulated price basis, limiting the need for hedging for both buyers and sellers in the region."

Nevertheless, Erlend Engelstad, a senior research analyst at UK commodities brokerage firm Marex Spectron, is optimistic about the growth of the Asian coal derivatives market. "The Asian coal derivatives market is still embryonic in respect of the underlying physical volumes, but there is evidence that new products are increasingly adopted among producers and consumers in the Asia-Pacific," he said.

This is also driven by the increasingly volatile prices in the thermal coal market.

Khazanah throws MAS RM6b lifeline

Published Fri, Aug 29, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Kuala Lumpur

KHAZANAH Nasional will inject RM6 billion (SS$2.4 billion) over three years to resuscitate loss-making Malaysia Airlines (MAS) under a recovery plan that includes even an Act of Parliament. Other key moves are migrating its operations, assets and liabilities to a new company (NewCo) and slashing the workforce of 20,000 by 30 per cent.

The goal is for the national carrier to start on a new slate by mid-2015. The state investment agency sees sustained profitability within three years or by the end of 2017, provided stakeholders of MAS take the prescribed "medicine or strict conditionality" that comes with the revamp, said Khazanah managing director Azman Mokhtar. He announced the 12-point plan at Khazanah's headquarters in the Petronas Twin Towers yesterday.

site_title: The Italian Connection
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

The Italian Connection

With its sheer diversity of wine styles, Italy is a strong contender in this year's competition. By Suzanne Brocklehurst

Published Fri, Aug 29, 2014 · 10:00 PM

ITALY'S art, music and fashion have always attracted global attention and its wines continue to attract plenty of interest. This is particularly the case at the quality end of production. Italy's sheer diversity of wine styles means that it should come as no surprise that of the 30 wines shortlisted in this competition, a solid contingent would be Italian, including four from Piedmont.

The sense of disillusionment among lovers of expensive top-end Bordeaux meant their gaze has been diverted to Burgundy, inevitably driving its price higher. Suddenly, the spotlight seems to have turned to Piedmont in North West Italy and, above all, the focus is on Barolo. In this manner, it seems only fitting that one of the first wines to be selected as a finalist should be a Barolo - Vietti Barolo DOCG Castiglione 2010.

The Barolo zone, which can be divided into 11 different sub-zones, covers 1,911ha of vineyards of the red grape variety Nebbiolo. Distinguished as Italy's most revered grape variety, Nebbiolo is capable of making some of the most ethereal wines in Italy. Just as Pinot Noir in Burgundy is prized for its ability to express a real sense of place, Nebbiolo is valued in the Piedmonte for that same ability. Barolo can be one of the most challenging wines to taste in its youth because of the high level of firm, assertive and often astringent tannins that coat the mouth. Nonetheless, with prudent cellaring complex layers of perfume, truffles, spice, tobacco and leather will be displayed on the nose while the flavours can be equally intricate as power and elegance combine.

site_title: Fairways across the Causeway
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Fairways across the Causeway

Three Johor courses are within an hour's drive away for S'pore golfers

Published

Thu, Aug 28, 2014 · 05:21 PM

Tropicana Golf & Country Resort

MALAYSIA'S largest clubhouse and golf resort recently underwent a RM5 million (S$1.98 million) renovation project.

Opened in 1993 by professional Australian golfer Graham Marsh, Tropicana's golf course was built over the terrain of a former rubber plantation at Petaling Jaya. Later, Australian golf architect E&G Parslow was engaged to design a new layout for the golf course, and the construction began in August 2010.

Renovation was completed on Sept 28, 2012. The same year, Tropicana was awarded the "Most improved golf course" by ParGolf Magazine, a golf publication in Malaysia and the Asian region.

Membership at the Tropicana Golf & Country Resort (TCGR) costs RM20,000 for a year, and RM53,000 for three years. The benefits of both can be extended to the member's spouse and a child below 18 years old.

Other membership options are the individual golf membership and the corporate golf membership. They cost RM200,000 each, not including a monthly subscription fee of RM179.30 and a processing fee of RM200.

The Legends Golf & Country Club

ABOUT 70 per cent of the golfers who play at the Legends Golf & Country Club (Legends) are non-Malaysians, but the resort is located in Johor, Malaysia.

Of the non-Malaysian golfers, a majority are Singaporeans, or are expatriates from Singapore, says club manager Amy Cheong. She explains: "In Singapore, unless you are a member of a club, there are very few public golf courses. A lot of these golf courses don't open their courses to non-members, unless it's a weekday. There are very few avenues for non-members to play."

Unlike Singapore golf clubs, the Legends has abandoned its membership policy, thus opening the club to the public. Also, more than 10 years ago, the Legends stopped selling club memberships. "There was a time when club memberships were being speculated on, but then the bubble burst, and people started making a lot of noise," says Ms Cheong.

There were members of the Legends who were purely speculators and did not play golf at all, she adds. But the club wanted members who bought the membership for the sake of playing golf, and not to speculate.

Secondly, Ms Cheong says, it is more expensive to play at Singapore golf courses. The rates at the Legends range from RM95-250, with the cheapest time to play on weekdays, before 10am, and the most expensive on weekend mornings. Even the more affordable golf courses in Singapore, such as Changi Golf Club, charge walk-in visitors S$90 per 18-holes on weekdays, and S$110 on weekends and public holidays - a steep rate when compared with the Legend's package rates.

An added feature of the Legends golf course is its offering of Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer designs, which are "superior". According to Ms Cheong, people jump at the chance to play at these courses.

Nicklaus and Palmer are American professional golfers and designers of golf courses around the world, but most of their designs are available in the US, with the next nearest Jack Nicklaus course in Indonesia. The Legends, just a forty-minute drive from the Tuas Second Link, is a more accessible choice for Singapore golfers.

The Legends has noticed a fall in golfers from Singapore after additional tolls were implemented at the causeway earlier this month for foreign vehicles entering Malaysia. But according to Ms Cheong, "it is a short-term effect . . . it is reactionary, after some time, they start playing again".

Beyond golf courses, the Legends offers other leisure and recreational facilities to accommodate families, such as horse-riding and lake fishing. There is also a beginners course on golf, mountain biking activities, a tree-house and a vegetable garden.

Some golfers stay over at their guestrooms as well, says Ms Cheong. They go on a Saturday, stay over, and play again on a Sunday.

Tanjong Puteri Golf Resort

JUST a 30-minute drive from the Causeway, the Tanjong Puteri Golf Resort (TPGR) hosts three golf courses.

The "Plantation" course was designed by golf architect Max Wexler, while the "Village" and "Straits" were designed by Akira Mamiya. "Straits" was designed and constructed to closely resemble the coastline of the Straits of Johor.

Singaporeans make up about 55 per cent of the resort's golf members, which totals around 2,000.

Near the end of the 1990's, TPGR stopped selling life-long full golf memberships. For those who are keen, life-long memberships may be transacted via the secondary market.

But the resort still sells term memberships for a 1-2 year period at a cost of RM3,800 per year for individuals, and RM6,800 per year for the family package. Upon purchase, members are entitled to unlimited rounds of golf and discounts on food & beverage, and accommodation.

More mid-career professionals are ditching their day jobs to jive with java and furry companions, reports RACHEL LOI

Published Thu, Aug 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

MID-CAREER blues. The lure of self-employment and a social conscience. Cats. Add them together and you have a potent combination that is fuelling one of the quirkiest lifestyle trends in Singapore today - the proliferation of pet cafes.

As trends go, this is not unique to Singapore. Pet cafes - where people pay a fee to play with the cafe's free-roaming pets - are catching on around the world. It originated in Taiwan in 1998, and has since spread to countries such as Japan, Korea, London, Paris, Melbourne and Berlin.

In Singapore, what started as a cutesy one-off novelty has grown legs - or paws - in less than a year. There are now at least five cat cafes - and one dog-centric one - in Singapore, and surprisingly, they're all started by mid-career professionals who quit the corporate race.

Volcano aviation threat could last months: Iceland

Published Thu, Aug 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[REYKJAVIK] Iceland said heightened alert levels for airlines may be in place for months as one of its biggest volcanoes continues to rumble, threatening an eruption and ash cloud that would menace flights across the Atlantic.

"It could be weeks and months" before the threat passes, said Melissa Anne Pfeffer, an atmospheric volcanologist at the Icelandic Met Office, which has an "orange" aviation warning in place, its second-highest level.

The volcano is now in its second week of rumbling as magma has spread to form a dike under the Dyngjujokull glacier, north of the volcano. Bardarbunga, which lies underneath Vatnajokull, Europe's largest glacier, has been rocked by earthquakes that have led to evacuations and road closures.

site_title: Growth in services sector sales cools in Q2
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Growth in services sector sales cools in Q2

Quarter on quarter, business receipts stayed roughly the same level as in the past two quarters

Published

Wed, Aug 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Takings in the business services sector in the second quarter continued to grow slower year on year, says the latest Business Receipts Index for Services Industries.

And they were flat against the first quarter, according to the index released on Wednesday by the Department of Statistics.

Compiled at current prices, the index exclude wholesale & retail trade and accommodation & food services.

In the second quarter, the index shows services industries like financial & insurance, real estate, rental & leasing, education and health & social services raked in 2.8 per cent more sales than they did in the same quarter last year.

But this was slower than the 4.9 per cent and 7.1 per cent growth posted respectively, in the previous two quarters.

The business receipts in the index include income from services rendered, sales of goods, commission fees as well as rental of premises and machinery and equipment.

Quarter on quarter, the second-quarter business receipts in the services sector stayed roughly the same level as in the past two quarters. Sales inched up a measly 0.2 per cent in the quarter, with real estate, rental & leasing services posting the biggest jump of 5.8 per cent.

Health & social services rose just 1.6 per cent, the second biggest increase. Financial & insurance services reported 1.4 per cent gain, while transport & storage was up 0.4 per cent.

Turnover in information & communications services remained unchanged from the first quarter.

Education services took a steep dive in the second quarter, with takings plummeting 16.5 per cent from the previous quarter. Recreation & personal services tumbled 1.4 per cent and business services excluding real estate, rental & leasing services dipped 0.7 per cent.

Compared to the same quarter in 2013, all services industries in the second quarter posted growth, except for business services excluding real estate, rental & leasing where business receipts remained about the same as a year ago.

Health & social services saw the biggest year-on-year jump in business in the second quarter, with receipts swelling 8.2 per cent. The Department of Statistics says this was "due mainly to hospitals registering higher receipts compared to the same period last year".

Among other services industries that did well were financial & insurance services (+4.5 per cent), education services (+4.1 per cent), information and communications services (+3.3 per cent), real estate, rental & leasing services (+2.3 per cent), recreation & personal services (+2.1 per cent) and transport & storage services (+1.4 per cent).

site_title: Qantas dives A$2.84 billion into the red
content:
Qantas dives A$2.84 billion into the red

Full-year loss due largely to hefty fleet writedowns, restructuring costs; analysts caught off-guard

Nisha Ramchandani

Published

Thu, Aug 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] More than a year after its much-vaunted alliance with Dubai-based Emirates, Australia's flag carrier Qantas plunged into the red with a net loss of A$2.84 billion (S$3.31 billion) for the year ended

June 30, versus a profit of A$1 million previously, weighed down by massive write-downs to its fleet and restructuring costs.

Underlying loss before tax worked out to A$646 million - vis-a-vis a profit of A$186 million in FY13 - as the bottom line suffered the impact of high fuel costs, lower yields due to excess capacity in the market as well as weak demand.

The losses shocked the market as analysts, expecting underlying losses before tax of some A$763 million according to a Bloomberg poll, were caught off-guard by the hefty write-downs.

Revenue slid 3.5 per cent year on year to A$15.35 billion partly due to stiff competition from foreign and domestic carriers pumping capacity into Australia, the carrier said.

However, the airline's chief Alan Joyce insisted clearer skies are ahead for the "Flying Kangaroo", which is now six months into its A$2 billion restructuring programme.

"We have now come through the worst. With our accelerated Qantas Transformation programme, we are already emerging as a leaner, more focused and more sustainable Qantas group," he said.

Qantas has laid off 2,500 employees to date - about half of the planned 5,000 redundancies. The group saw A$440 million in benefits from the transformation programme in FY14 and expects over A$600 million to be realised in FY15.

Meanwhile, with greater flexibility on foreign investment after tweaks to the Qantas Sale Act, the group is setting up a new holding entity for Qantas International. This is expected to make it easier to attract foreign investment.

However, as a result, the group had to write down its unit's fleet of aircraft in a non-cash charge totalling A$2.56 billion as the planes were bought when the Aussie dollar was significantly weaker than the greenback.

One bright spot, though, is that Qantas International's depreciation expenses will come down by A$200 million per year.

For the year under review, Qantas' domestic operations reported an underlying Ebit (earnings before interest and taxes) of A$30 million, plummeting from A$365 million in FY13 as it battles rival Virgin Australia for market share. Qantas International chalked up an underlying loss of A$497 million, more than doubling from a loss of A$246 million previously, hurt by high fuel costs and capacity injection by competitors in Asia and the Middle East.

Last year, Qantas struck a seemingly unlikely alliance with erstwhile rival Emirates and subsequently shut down its long-standing Singapore hub in favour of Dubai. The move was meant to streamline its operations and deliver significant savings for its bleeding international business.

Qantas' Jetstar group chalked up losses of A$116 million, versus a profit of A$138 million a year earlier as its profitable Jetstar Australia business was offset by losses in Asia.

Jetstar Asia, which reported losses of A$40 million, has suspended growth amid a "very challenging Singapore market" where capacity grew 23 per cent in FY14, the group said. But Qantas expects Jetstar Asia's performance to pick up as capacity growth in the market eases, which is already occurring.

At the same time, the group is shelving plans to establish any new Jetstar ventures while it focuses on its transformation efforts. Mr Joyce said the group will realise "the substantial value" that exists across the Jetstar airlines over time. Reports last month suggested that Indonesia's Lion Air is on the prowl to scoop up Qantas' 49 per cent stake in Jetstar Asia.

Aside from Jetstar Asia, Qantas has JVs in Japan and Vietnam as well.

It has also been trying, with little success, to set up a budget carrier in Hong Kong and continues to await the green light from regulators.

Meanwhile, Qantas' frequent flyer division - which it has decided not to sell - helped to bolster the bottom line by earning profits of A$286 million, up from A$260 million previously.

Qantas is extending its freeze on domestic capacity growth to the second quarter, which effectively means that it will add no domestic capacity in H1FY15.

CAPA - Centre for Aviation said of Qantas' overseas network ahead of the results release: "Reorientation of the network around strong regional hubs and premium partner airlines would provide Qantas with a firm footing to ensure profitability."

The group expects to swing into the black in H1FY15 with an underlying profit before tax.

Shares in Qantas surged nine Australian cents to close at A$1.385 on Thursday.

site_title: It's the Beatles redux in 2-hour stage homage
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

It's the Beatles redux in 2-hour stage homage

Dylan Tan

Published

Thu, Aug 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE members of Beatlemania, a Beatles tribute group from Scotland, may be in their 20s but they don't like being called young. "We're possibly one of the youngest acts out there but I won't write that down actually,"says Craig McGown, who plays the late George Harrison, over the phone from UK earlier this week, ahead of the band's Singapore gig.

Fresh from just playing 13 shows in six days at International Beatleweek - a festival dedicated to all things Beatles, where Beatlemania was just crowned Favourite Band - the 26-year-old has every reason to shun the tag because they are veterans of sorts, having been together for five years now.

"We take our jobs - but not ourselves - very seriously; some people are so surprised by how much effort we make that they call us lunatics," explains McGown. Together with his bandmates Joe Kane (Paul McCartney), Clark Gilmour (John Lennon) and Grahame Critcher (Ringo Starr), they will be touring here for the first time next week in a show that will span The Fab Four's short but illustrious 10-year career.

The two-hour musical journey will cover some 30 songs; beginning from The Beatles' early days in Hamburg, all the way to their iconic final concert on the rooftop of Savile Row in London. "The material we cover is very extensive," says McGown, who, like Harrison, is the youngest in the band. "And everything you see is as authentic as possible, right down to the cufflinks, so the audience can feel what it must have been like."

McGown, who has been playing the guitar since he was 12 and now runs a music school, reveals that the secret to playing his character well comes from constantly studying Harrison. "You have to always feel like you're not quite perfect and you want to get that wee percentage right; down to little things like how I move my eyebrows," he shares. "The challenge is getting the balance - George is often thought to be the quiet guy but he's actually more than that and has got an attitude so I try to convey that the best I can."

Obsessing over their favourite band is no chore for Beatlemania because its members are all "pretty much Beatles-nuts". McGown says, "We love playing their music so it all comes down to that... it's great to be able to play for people all over the world and to keep the music alive." Besides touring the UK constantly, Beatlemania has sold out shows in countries like Canada, Australia, Scandinavia, South Africa, Dubai, America and Hong Kong since 2009.

On-stage, the group not only has the grueling task of performing note-perfect renditions of classic Beatles hits but they also have to go through nine costume changes.. plus plenty of stuck-on facial hair. "You'll see that we all start off clean-shaven at first but end up all hairy by the end of the night," laughs McGown.

Company Briefs

Published

Thu, Aug 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

STATS ChipPAC confirms approaches

STATS ChipPAC on Thursday confirmed that it has been approached by two Chinese semiconductor-testing companies interested in buying the Singapore chip-testing and packaging services provider.

Jiangsu Changjiang Electronics Technology Co and Tianshui Huatian Technology Co were first reported by Bloomberg to be considering bids for STATS ChipPAC.

However, "there is no assurance that any of these approaches will result in any definitive agreement or transaction", STATS ChipPAC said in a statement. The company was responding to a query by Singapore Exchange after its shares surged on Wednesday.

OCBC gives sweetener for shareholders

OCBC Bank is giving shareholders who are also customers a sweetener for taking part in a rights issue.

The bank is offering one rights share for every eight existing shares held at S$7.65 apiece as it hopes to raise S$3.37 billion to help fund its S$6.2 billion offer for Hong Kong's Wing Hang Bank.

Shareholders who subscribe for their rights shares using an OCBC card at the bank's ATMs will not have to pay the usual S$2 ATM fee, the bank announced on Thursday. Payment for the rights issue will also count as one bill payment that can be used to receive extra interest under OCBC's 360 deposit product.

OCBC 360 Account holders who pay any three bills online or through the automated Giro system can earn an extra one per cent interest per year for the first S$50,000 in the account.

Loyz Energy posts Q4 profit of S$770,000

OIL and gas exploration company Loyz Energy swung into profitability in its fourth fiscal quarter as production in Thailand came on stream.

The company posted net profit of S$770,000, or 0.2 cent per share, for the three months ended June 30, 2014, from a year-ago loss of S$1.6 million. For the full year, however, it remained deeper in the red, with net loss of S$3.7 million, or 0.95 cent per share, compared to a S$2.5 million loss a year earlier.

Production in Thailand began on April 1, helping Loyz to turn a profit in the fourth quarter, the company said. Following the completion of the acquisition of petroleum concessions in Thailand in May, Loyz expects production to ramp up.

CosmoSteel CEO, exec director in graft probe

COSMOSTEEL Holdings fell 9.3 per cent on Thursday following news that the company's chief executive and an executive director were called in by corruption investigators.

Chief executive Ong Chin Sum and executive director Ong Tong Yang are currently out on bail in relation to an alleged offence concerning the giving of illegal gratification to an agent, CosmoSteel announced late on Wednesday. CosmoSteel said that it understands that neither man has been charged.

CosmoSteel shares fell four cents to 39 cents at the close on Thursday after 22 million shares changed hands.

Graphic novel lunges for the jugular

Published Thu, Aug 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

NINE years after Sin City assaulted our senses with its stylised look (high-contrast black-and-white punctuated by splashes of colour) and eye-popping violence based on Frank Miller's graphic novel series, the square-jawed killers and drop-dead gorgeous dames that populated the original are back for more. Sin City: A Dame to Kill For introduces a few new faces and keeps several old ones, weaving four parallel storylines into a single narrative and switching back and forth among them until someone is beaten to a bloody pulp or comes to an inglorious end.

Some things never change: the dialogue is deliciously hard-boiled and the broads are beautiful health hazards.

Assorted creeps, whores and anti-heroes slide in and out of the shadows and the fringes of society. Once again, co-directors Miller and Robert Rodriguez go straight for the jugular, drenching every other scene in red - as in blood red - the colour of choice (if there is any colour at all, that is).

site_title: Uproar over NY condo with entrances for rich and poor
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Uproar over NY condo with entrances for rich and poor

Project combines condos with luxury facilities and affordable rental units that can't share the perks

Published

Wed, Aug 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] A 33-storey glassy tower rising on Manhattan's waterfront will offer all the extras that a condo buyer paying up to US$25 million would expect, like concierge service, entertainment rooms, and unobstructed views of the Hudson River and miles beyond.

The project will also cater to renters who make no more than about US$50,000. They will not share the same perks, and they will also not share the same entrance.

The so-called poor door has brought an outcry, with numerous officials now demanding an end to the strategy. But the question of how to best incorporate affordable units into projects built for the rich has become more relevant than ever as Mayor Bill de Blasio seeks the construction of 80,000 new affordable units over the next 10 years.

The answer is not a simple one. As public housing becomes a crumbling relic of another era, American cities have grown more reliant on private industry to build housing for the poor and working class. Developers say they can maximise their revenues, and thus build more affordable units, by separating them from their luxury counterparts.

Even advocates of affordable housing are divided on the issue; some argue that developers who segregate apartments should not benefit from government incentives, while others say the focus should be on building more homes, rather than where to enter them.

"There are trade-offs," said Lisa Sturtevant, vice-president for research at the National Housing Conference, an affordable housing advocacy group in Washington. "It's really important that there's no discrimination, but there's a balance between what we can do and should do."

Administration officials attribute the two-door setup to changes to the zoning code in 2009 that Mr de Blasio voted for as a member of the City Council. He has said that the revisions, which allowed builders to put the affordable apartments in an attached segment of the building, were meant to increase housing units and that "it was not evident at the time the nuances of where the doors would be".

Developers say the configuration of one building with an attached affordable segment works better when the market-rate units are for sale, as in the case of condos. If that is the choice, the developer is required to provide two separate entrances under the current rules of the programme.

But Alicia Glen, the deputy mayor for housing and economic development, said that separate front doors were not in keeping with the administration's principles of equality, and that the city was working to change the rules to prohibit them. "Walking into a building should not be any different based on income status," Ms Glen said.

From the street, the luxury condominium tower in the middle of the debate, at 40 Riverside Boulevard, and its six-floor affordable segment seem to blend seamlessly and appear as one structure. But the lower-income renters, who will pay US$850 a month for one-bedroom apartments and US$1,100 for two bedrooms, according to the developer, will go through a door facing 62nd Street while the condo owners will come in through a door facing the Hudson.

New York and other cities use a variety of tax breaks, subsidies and additional incentives to encourage developers to build affordable housing. In the case of 40 Riverside, the developer, Extell Development Co, is using a programme called inclusionary housing, which allows it to build more square feet than the zoning code would otherwise allow in exchange for a certain number of lower-rent apartments. Those additional square feet can be used at 40 Riverside, but Extell plans to transfer them to another project, which the law allows.

The affordable units do not have to be in the same location, as long as they are within the same community district or, if in another district, no farther than half a mile away.

Gary Barnett, who is Extell's founder and president, said that having the affordable apartments incorporated into the condominium tower would have meant "giving away" the most valuable units. "We wouldn't be able to do affordable," he said. "It wouldn't make any financial sense."

New York has always been an economically diverse city, with everyday people rubbing shoulders with millionaires and Bohemian artists on the streets. But the poor-doors image taps into the anxiety of many New Yorkers that the city is becoming liveable only for the wealthy.

At the Edge Community Apartments, the affordable housing building that abuts the Edge, a glass condo tower on the Brooklyn waterfront in Williamsburg, renters also have their own entrance, just a few doors from that of the condos. Only one entrance offers a doorman, concierge and valet, but some renters said what they resented was not being able to use some of the condo tower's amenities.

"We can't even use the pool or the gym," said one renter, a 34-year-old bank employee who wanted to remain anonymous for fear of jeopardising her one-bedroom rental. "I've asked and offered to pay. It's kind of messed up."

But she and other tenants said they considered themselves lucky to have landed an apartment in the area, where everyone, rich or poor, steps out to views of the East River and Manhattan skyline and the cool energy of Williamsburg.

"Living here is a privilege," said Victoriano Oviedo, 59, a retiree who has a studio subsidised with a federal rental voucher. "Over there you have powerful people. Over here you have low-income people. I'm fine with that."

Aside from square-footage bonuses, residential developments like 40 Riverside can take advantage of affordable housing tax breaks, which some advocates argue should not be available for projects that do not fully integrate the affordable units.

"If you do choose to live in segregated developments, don't use my tax dollars to support that," said Moses Gates, director of planning and community development for the Association for Neighborhood and Housing Development.

But the repugnance is not universal. Among the roughly 500 cities with inclusionary zoning programmes, housing supporters have been mostly focused on having the affordable units built close to the their market-rate counterparts so that low-income households share some of the benefits of wealthier neighbourhoods, like good schools and public safety.

"It's so important to build as much affordable housing as possible and you always have to compromise," said Carol Lamberg, co-chairwoman of the New York Housing Conference, an affordable housing coalition. "I just think the need is so great, you don't need a fancy lobby."

The controversy over separate entrances may pit Mr de Blasio's social justice values against his need for private development, but the inclusionary programme that caused it is voluntary and accounts for only a fraction of new affordable units that are built. Since 2005, city officials said, it has generated about 5,000 affordable units.

Administration officials are preparing to start a mandatory version of the programme, to force developers of large buildings to take the deal if they want to build at all, with its own rules about how to incorporate affordable units. The administration is seeking to eliminate the use of separate entrances in both the mandatory and voluntary programmes.

"Years ago, people would be upset and say 'that's politics', but now people feel more empowered to change this," said Linda Rosenthal, a state assemblywoman whose district includes 40 Riverside Boulevard.

"It's such a visual separation," Ms Rosenthal said. "It gets at people when they see two separate doors. It's no longer theoretical. It looks and smells like discrimination." - NYT

site_title: New members resurrect old work
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

New members resurrect old work

Dylan Tan

Published

Thu, Aug 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE hard work is finally paying off for local indie band, The Observatory. All 200 first-run coloured vinyls and 80 cassette tapes of their latest album, Oscilla, have sold out in the week of its release - a rare and almost unheard of feat for a homegrown act that gets almost no airplay at all on the radio.

Overnight success it is not. The band has paid its dues over the 12 years that they have been together; touring endlessly both here and overseas, consistently recording critically acclaimed works that help them build a bigger fanbase with each release, and enduring multiple line-up changes as members come and go.

Oscilla, their sixth studio album, finds The Observatory becoming a five piece after drummer, Bani Haykal, left the band earlier this year. He is replaced by new members Cheryl Ong and Yuen Chee Wai (synth, electronics). The rest of the band is made up of founding members Leslie Low (vocals, guitar), Dharma (guitar) and Vivian Wang (keyboards).

The Observatory takes the line-up changes in its stride though Low reveals it can be a challenge trying to find people who share the band's approach towards music. Self-doubt surfaces too when people leave. "(We ask ourselves) did we do something wrong or were we being too ambitious?" he explains. "But when you step back and look at the bigger picture, it's never been easy to pursue a career in music to begin with - even among the core members, it's been an emotional roller-coaster ride so far."

Hence, the band clings onto "perseverance and discipline... to keep it going until there's nothing left", adds Low, who also has an upcoming solo album, No Such Things As Ghosts, coming out next month. It is almost a companion piece to Oscilla with the similar-looking cover artworks and the singer-songwriter penning the tunes in between recording with The Observatory.

The material is starkly different though. No Such Things As Ghosts is an acoustic album that sounds closer to Low's original group, the now-defunct neo-folk quartet, Humpback Oak. Oscilla, on the other hand, finds The Observatory at its most ambitious; venturing deep into progressive rock territory after experimenting with it on Dark Folke (2009) and Catacombs (2012).

It's for this reason Low feels the changing line-up actually helps the band to grow. "It benefits the music since we always change things up from album to album," he says.

Wang adds new members, Ong and Yuen, have brought "a certain rawness" that has never been heard before. "It's all of us reaching deep down into the core to feel and express without reservations - (something) quite hard to do, given that Singaporeans are generally reticent about overt expressiveness," she explains.

The limber but hard-hitting Ong, in particular, has injected primal energy into the The Observatory's sound; as evident from their recent live shows, in support of the album release. "She's a trained Chinese percussionist, which we know is an unusual choice but hey, we've never quite done things the expected way," says Wang of her new band mate. "Cheryl came on board shortly after Haykal's exit and had like a month and half to two months to get the entire album and its drum parts together... She's open-minded and is hungry to learn and get better - that's what being a working musician is about."

Low adds that the new recruits gave new life to the band's material which had been left in limbo after Haykal's departure. "There was a period when we were scratching our heads wondering what to do," he shares. "This new burst of life with (Ong and Yuen) was essential to push the music towards its eventual refinement and release... it's been therapeutic to see the project finally come to fruition."

site_title: Need to formalise processes to fight fraud
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Need to formalise processes to fight fraud

Companies venturing abroad will have to step up procedures to assess risks in foreign markets, reports MELVIN YONG

Published

Thu, Aug 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

COMPANIES expanding into regional markets will need to develop formal processes to identify and assess potential fraud risks in their target markets, say industry watchers.

These include having to carry out due diligence to better understand the foreign business partners and parties that will conduct business on their behalf.

"As long as people have material needs and wants, there will be fraud. The challenge for companies is mitigating the risks fraud presents to an acceptable level but they can never banish it altogether," said Owen Hawkes, partner at KPMG in Singapore.

"What is needed is a concerted effort to understand the risks a given organisation faces, to put in place a holistic suite of measures to mitigate those risks, and education and training to ensure that the board, management and staff are all actively guarding the organisation against fraud," he added.

The recently released Singapore Fraud Survey 2014 by KPMG and Singapore Management University (SMU) found that the quantum of losses suffered by companies due to fraud has jumped more than three-fold to about $22 million now compared with just three years ago. The average cost of employee fraud is $457,000.

The survey also found that internal parties are involved in 75 per cent of the reported fraud, which is harder to detect and therefore very significant.

"Internal fraud is committed by what we call 'knowledgeable insider' who know the internal controls procedures and how to circumvent them," said Associate Professor Themin Suwardy of the Singapore Management University. "The range of things they can commit is also much wider than the external fraudster," added Prof Suwardy, who is also Singapore divisional president at CPA Australia.

Specific to companies venturing abroad, two thirds of respondents felt that the risk of bribery and corruption was a key concern for Singapore companies conducting business in the region. Half of them were concerned about the need to provide payments or gifts in order to win or retain business compared with just 20 per cent in 2011 when a similar survey was conducted.

More than a third of respondents were also concerned about foreign government officials and overseas-based third parties, with more than four in 10 saying they were very concerned about interacting with foreign governments, while 36 per cent were very concerned about using third parties.

Experts say companies will need to better manage this by assessing the risks inherent in the environment in which they are intending to operate by conducting due diligence and understanding the practices in the relevant country. "Otherwise, they risk being blind-sided by practices they may never have known existed," said Mr Hawkes. Companies should also ensure that their employees, management, and even business partners understand the expectations of the organisation, he added.

The KPMG-SMU Fraud Survey also found that various approaches are being used by organisations to mitigate risks in cross-border activities. Three quarters said employees were issued guidelines for mitigating cross-border risks, two thirds have compliance programmes, while six in 10 had conducted training for their staff.

Although these are good starting points, much more will have to be done to check on fraud when operating in foreign markets. "With cross border activities, especially for the first time, the risks will be higher because you are dealing with more uncertainty. You have new people - staff, suppliers, customers and other parties - new regulations, perhaps different business practices and so forth, so it takes a while to set the culture and tone right," said Prof Suwardy.

Boards, management and employees have a vital role in combating fraud. "The board has to ensure that a framework is in place to prevent, detect and respond to fraud and exercise oversight to ensure that it is being operated effectively," said Mr Hawkes of KPMG. "Management must dedicate sufficient time and resources to addressing fraud risks and engage with fraud issues at a sufficiently granular level when they arise."

Employees have a huge advantage in assisting their company in preventing and detecting fraud.

"Because they are on the ground, they can see how business activities are undertaken, what risks arise, and how controls are operated in reality. Employees can feed back information on threats, control failures, and unusual or anomalous activities providing they are trained and empowered to do so," added Mr Hawkes.

Observers say fraud often occurs because of the lack of effective working controls.

"It is not enough to have control procedures in place but it is important to make sure they cover your risk areas and are carried out effectively," said Prof Suwardy. "All company directors and managers need to have a healthy dose of professional scepticism. Of course, you need to trust your employees but please verify."

When doing business abroad, companies need to undertake risk assessment procedures to understand and prepare for potential risks. They should carry out due diligence to understand who they are working with and who will be conducting business on their behalf.

One approach is to develop formal processes for identifying and assessing potential risks in new territories that a company intends to enter. These assessments typically include reviewing relevant business factors such as:

These processes should be refreshed periodically or during major changes to business operations. In addition, in-country personnel should be educated on such risks and on how to manage them.

The writer is general manager - Singapore, CPA Australia

MAS posts loss of RM307m for Q2

It warns of worse to come in H2 after recent tragedies

Published Thu, Aug 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

MALAYSIA Airlines (MAS) registered a loss of RM307 million (S$122 million) for the second quarter to end-June, but warned of worse to come in the second half when the "full financial impact of the double tragedies of MH370 and MH17" hits home.

The beleaguered carrier said that average weekly booking declined by a third immediately after the MH17 downing over Ukraine and also that numerous flights were cancelled. It stressed that the tragic losses of two aircraft in such a short space of time had exacerbated its financial problems and acknowledged that the airline's brand and business reputation had been severely damaged, accelerating the need to restructure the company.

The current quarter was its sixth straight quarter of losses. Although analysts had earlier projected that it would amount to some RM600 million, MAS' warning indicates that the full impact of the air disasters will likely be seen in the third quarter. Losses in the preceding quarter had been bigger at RM443 million, resulting in a first-half loss of RM750 million on a turnover of RM7.2 billion. In the first half of 2013, MAS had lost RM455 million.

Local food fest Savour heads to HK

Published

Thu, Aug 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AFTER three years of bringing Michelin star cuisine to the masses in Singapore, gourmet food festival SAVOUR is spreading its wings to Hong Kong and beyond.

SAVOUR Hong Kong will debut from Sept 9 to 1, with a line-up of celebrity chefs such as Christophe Muller (3 Michelin Stars, L'Auberge du Pont) and Emmanuel Stroobant (Saint Pierre) who will serve their signature dishes at affordable prices in conjunction with the Hong Kong Tennis Open at Victoria Park.

Some 15,000 people are expected at SAVOUR Hong Kong, says Darren Chen, executive director of Savour Events. The last three Savour events attracted about 50,000 people in total. Each event took place over three to five days and was designed to "make fine dining accessible to a larger audience within a curated, purpose-built event," adds Mr Chen. Past venues like the F1 Pit Building were turned into carnival-like surroundings where people could mingle and sample dishes by chefs like Alain Passard of L'Arpege and Alvin Leung of BO Innovation from tented stands.

"Singapore's multicultural environment acts as a natural test-bed for our F&B brands. As these companies look to expand overseas, Hong Kong as a market presents interesting learning opportunities," says Lee Yee Fung, group director for Lifestyle Business at International Enterprise Singapore, which plays a large role in supporting local F&B brands.

Mr Chen emphasises that SAVOUR is not just a dining event, "We have activities too, such as the studio kitchen, which allow guests to come in and cook with guidance from our participating chefs - something that you can't buy even if you had the money."

Other activities included Celebrity Chefs masterclasses as well as food and wine workshops and tastings.

"It was always about making fine dining more accessible to the public - quality at a good price point, value for their money," Mr Chen explains. Dishes from SAVOUR Hong Kong will cost from HK$40 (S$6) to HK$80, while admission costs HK$150. However people with tickets to the Hong Kong Tennis Open will have free entry to the event.

He points out that the event also gives back by way of promoting awareness for the participating chefs and restaurants. "People who come for the event may not even know about certain restaurants, chefs or dishes," Mr Chen says.

Mr Chen isn't about to stop at Hong Kong. "We're planning to go to Manila and other countries in the region next year," he says. The endgame, he hopes, is to have SAVOUR festival "replicate itself". He adds, "The vision is to have five or six shows in different locations every two months. This allows us to bring chefs from each country to different places, foster good relationships and bring awareness to local chefs as well."

The funds investing in the South Asian nation have returned 26 per cent this year through July, according to Eurekahedge Pte. content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Continued anaemia in Japan's economy a concern in govt

A delay in raising the consumption tax again may worsen things, say analysts

Published

Wed, Aug 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

CONCERNS are growing that Abenomics may fail to pull the world's third-largest economy out of its prolonged stagnation, despite efforts by the Japanese government and the Bank of Japan (BOJ) to put on a brave face amid adverse economic developments.

Two factors in particular are weighing on sentiment, analysts say. The first is a fear that the impact of the recent consumption tax hike could prove to be more damaging and longer-lasting than expected; the second is the failure of Japanese exports to respond to the weaker yen as positively as hoped.

Both these concerns were voiced openly this week, when the Cabinet Office said in its monthly report - cautiously-worded - that "the Japanese economy remains on a moderate recovery trend" and is "expected to recover".

The report added, however, that if the adverse impact of the national consumption tax hike on April 1 continues for an extended period, it would become a risk factor for Japan's economic growth.

"Attention should be given to the downside risks to the Japanese economy, such as a lengthening of the reaction to the last-minute rise in demand and the slowing down of overseas economies," it said.

These concerns were underscored on Wednesday by Japan's vice-minister for economic and fiscal policy Yasutoshi Nishimura, who told Reuters in an interview that he was "very concerned" about the trend in private consumption in July and August, and that it seemed that the pullback in demand after the sales tax hike was being prolonged.

His comments were seen as being more sombre than those of the minister for economic and fiscal policy Akira Amari, who said on Tuesday that it was "natural" that the economy would shrink when the consumption tax rate was raised, and that it was important to monitor how the economy recovered afterwards.

Mr Nishimura said the government needed to be cautious about going ahead with a second-stage increase in the consumption tax (from 8 to 10 per cent) planned for next year.

Analysts have said that any delay by prime minister Shinzo Abe in implementing the second hike would only add to Japan's economic dilemma, given the government's highly strained fiscal position.

Mr Nishimura also said during his interview that he hoped the BOJ would decide on further monetary easing before long, but few economists expect it to do so before the end of this year at the earliest.

Former BOJ executive director Mikio Wakatsuki told The Business Times (BT) that the only thing likely to trigger further monetary stimulus would be if the weakening of the yen goes into reverse; this is because the strengthening of the currency would lower import prices and undermine the credibility of the BOJ's commitment to end deflation.

The Japanese central bank is likely to view further monetary easing now as having diminishing marginal returns, say economists.

Meanwhile, the country's former vice-finance minister for economic affairs Eisuke Sakakibara has argued that a weaker yen resulting from further monetary easing could actually do more harm than good. He told BT: "A weak yen used to be at least partially beneficial for the Japanese economy because it increased Japanese exports and reduced imports; but the recent weakening of the yen has not resulted in an increase in exports, and imports have not declined either because of rises in the prices of energy and food."

Meawhile, minister Amari has said that fresh fiscal stimulus could be injected into the Japanese economy if the government decides to go ahead with a further hike in the national consumption tax from October 2015.

Mr Abe is expected to decide this October whether to proceed with the second tax hike, in which case further fiscal stimulus would be included in the fiscal year beginning April 1, 2015.

Japan's Nikkei newspaper has speculated that this could amount to around 1 trillion yen.

site_title: Staying on top of their game
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Staying on top of their game

BT talks to three of S'pore's top golfers about their aspirations and the future of the sport here

Published

Thu, Aug 28, 2014 · 05:21 PM

Lam Chih Bing, 37

GREG Norman was his idol growing up, but currently he is into Phil Mickelson. "He's a really good player, a very exciting player and I think a very nice guy," says Singapore golfer Lam Chih Bing, who turned professional in 2000 when he was 23.

To Lam, his biggest career highlight was in 2008's Volvo Masters of Asia. It was the final event of the season for the Asian Tour where the field was restricted to the top 65 players on the the tour's "order of merit". He was happy to even make the cut, but to eventually win the Volvo Masters of Asia made 2008 his breakthrough year.

But he has had his share of ups and downs. Singapore is not an easy place to be a professional athlete, he says.

Generally, he thinks Singaporeans are not too supportive of athletes. The country, he says, has few domestic tours, a lack of corporate sponsors, as well as good coaches.

He wanted to give himself a chance to pursue golf professionally. So instead of matriculating to a local university, he attended the University of Arizona in the US. "It was different," he says of the US. "The sports culture there is so strong. A lot of people (in the US) want to be a professional athlete. It was really good getting exposed to that kind of culture, and I was lucky enough to play with some good players from the professional golf team (there)."

Back home, golf's future is not as pretty. "I don't think it's trending the right way with the government taking back all the golf courses in the next few years," Lam says of golf's climate in Singapore. "There is less access for the general public and I see it getting more challenging.

"While it's not impossible for a player to come out, I think it will be easier if he developed his game in America or Australia or even Thailand (there is a very good programme for young Thais there, they are very closed-knit and you can learn a lot from the top Thai players)."

Looking ahead, Lam wants to play on the European Tour or the US PGA Tour. "That's where all the best players in the world play."

Quincy Quek, 27

TELEVISION and a junior golf set was what initially drew Singapore golfer Quincy Quek into the golfing arena. "I think it was '96 or '97 when Tiger Woods came onto the scene and I was watching TV," he says. It also helped that back then, his father, who was more into tennis and squash, had a couple of close friends who tried to get him to start golf.

One even gave Quek a junior golf set to start out with. "There wasn't something that really drew me towards golf," he says. "When you first start the ball in the middle of the driving range, and then at night you watch professional golfers on TV . . . I think that's where the inspiration came in."

He joined the National Youth Team in 2001, and the National Team the following year. In 2009, he turned professional. Because there were not many local events in Singapore then, as opposed to neighbouring countries such as Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand, he had to venture out to compete in South-east Asia.

That year, he took part in the Indonesia President Invitational, the Brunei Open and the Johnnie Walker Cambodian Open. The following year, he competed in the Asian Tour International, the King's Cup and once again at the Johnnie Walker Cambodian Open.

But in the middle of 2010, he injured his wrist. Everything you do in golf, you have to use your hands, says Quek. "It's very hard to keep it immobile and allow it to recover. I was missing out on events and it was quite depressing."

It was a tough period for him as a professional. It was his livelihood, yet he could not do it. Besides golf, he was not sure what else he could do. But he recovered and went on to compete in thirteen tours in 2012, winning the Asian Development Tour in the Philippines, which really gave him the confidence for future events.

In retrospect, Quek benefited from that "tough period". "That helped me appreciate the game and being out there, and made me more aware of my body and when it's my breaking point. I had been travelling quite a lot and it does take a lot out of your body."

Now, he is more aware of that and tries to pace himself a bit better.

For a young person who is turning pro, Quek has the following advice: As a pro, you want to do well, but you also want to be consistent. "Definitely have a plan - what events you want to play, how you are going to work towards those events. If you want to improve, you have to know what you are going to work on.

"As a professional, you don't have much time to plan, every week you go out there and try to earn as much money as you can. I think it will be better if you target events and try to work towards those and try to plan your schedule towards that."

To golfers in general, he advises never to give up. "You are going to hit more bad shots than you do good shots. But I think the most important thing is that you're out there and you're enjoying the game. And you must always be patient, because you never know when the next break is going to come."

Since he turned pro, every year Singapore is getting more events. According to Quek, there were at least tournaments every month for this and last year. "I think it will only get better," he says. "There are more junior golfers who actually aspire to turn professional. It also helps that there is more attention from the sponsors to develop junior players and create events."

Mardan Mamat, 46

WINNING the Singapore Masters in 2006 changed his outlook in golf forever.

When he was nine, he fell in love with the game watching people play golf on the course. At 10, he told himself he wanted to be a professional golfer. In 1994, he turned professional when he was 26. In 2004, he won the Indian Open, and the Philippines Open in 2012.

But his career highlight was winning the Singapore Masters in 2006. "To win in front of the home crowd and my family, it was a good feeling. It's tough to win a tournament in your hometown. You need to perform and I did it."

Golf's biggest challenge, he says, is that it is an individual game. "It is yourself and the golf course . . . I am very fortunate to have people support me in the golf club. I have a few people who really backed me up until now, and because of that, I become what I am now."

At the moment, whenever he is free and not playing at a tour, he tries to spend time training some young students. He thinks Singapore has a lot of up and coming golf talent, and the Singapore Professional Golfers' Association (SPGA) should try to help these youngsters develop their game. "I hope Singapore's golf will move on. I hope we can see youngsters coming up and making the country proud."

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Mapletree snaps up US property for US$70m

This is its first foray into serviced residences in its JV with Oakwood

Published

Wed, Aug 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

MAPLETREE Investments has snapped up a property in the heart of America's Silicon Valley for US$70 million, marking its maiden acquisition in the United States.

The Temasek Holdings unit will retrofit and upgrade the property, a 184-unit, freehold apartment complex in Sunnyvale, and turn it into a modern serviced residence.

The property, to be fully owned by Mapletree, will be rebranded as Oakwood Silicon Valley under Mapletree's partnership with Oakwood Worldwide, a major operator-manager of serviced apartments.

Mapletree Group chief investment officer Chua Tiow Chye said on Wednesday: "While this is our first serviced apartment venture in the US, the liquidity and transparency of the market will provide opportunities for us to participate in its recovering economy and scale up our business."

He told The Business Times yesterday that the total returns on US assets - initial yield plus growth - are expected to be around 10 per cent.

The acquired property was unaffected by the earthquake that rocked San Francisco Bay Area on Monday, he said; the epicentre of the quake is about a two-hour drive away.

Mapletree is embarking on a buying spree in the serviced residences arena, an asset class once absent in its spectrum of assets.

It had in late April entered into a joint venture with Oakwood by acquiring a 49 per cent stake in Oakwood's Asia arm. Under the tie-up, Mapletree will buy and develop serviced apartments, and is licensed to use the Oakwood brand; in turn, Oakwood will source for acquisition and development deals for Mapletree in North America.

Mr Chua said Mapletree is targeting to triple, or at least double, the number of rooms in Asia managed by Oakwood Asia Pacific (OAP) from the current 3,000 rooms.

OAP has so far inked 10 letters of intent (LOIs) for new management contracts this year; 15 other properties, for which it has secured management contracts, are being developed.

Mapletree is aiming to eventually build up a US$4 billion portfolio of serviced residences in gateway cities in Asia, the US and Europe, but it will focus its first efforts on "lower hanging fruit", said Mr Chua.

These include the US cities of Seattle, Chicago, Boston and Atlanta, where Oakwood is operating, as well as cities where Mapletree already has a presence, such as Tokyo and Osaka in Japan, and Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou, Chengdu and Chongqing in China.

Mr Chua said that Mapletree may incorporate serviced apartments into some of the mixed-use sites that it already owns in China. "We are also considering bidding for sites that are for serviced residential use."

Oakwood may manage the serviced component of Mapletree's mixed project in Vietnam called Saigon South Place, which is now in design-feasibility stage.

Mr Chua said that having the new asset class will strengthen Mapletree's ability to tender for mixed-use projects that include a hospitality component.

In Singapore, Mapletree is still on the lookout for assets to acquire and develop under Oakwood brand of serviced residences, he said.

SUBSCRIBERS

Popiah King to invest S$18.45m in Halcyon Agri

Sam Goi taking up 25m Halcyon shares, or 5.94% stake, via placement

Anita Gabriel

Published

Tue, Aug 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SINGAPORE billionaire Sam Goi Seng Hui is set to emerge with a 5.94 per cent stake in Catalist-listed rubber firm Halcyon Agri Corp once he picks up 25 million new Halcyon shares under a proposed placement that will cost S$18.45 million.

The shares will be placed out to Mr Goi at 73.8 Singapore cents a piece - a discount of 9.88 per cent to Halcyon's weighted average price of 81.89 Singapore cents on Aug 22, a day before the placement agreement was inked.

Halcyon's shares were last traded at 81.5 Singapore cents on Monday before trading in the counter was halted on Tuesday pending the announcement.

"Mr Goi's experience in successfully developing a global food processing business presents an important source of counsel and advice," said Halcyon in an announcement to the exchange.

Mr Goi, 65, was introduced to the firm for the share placement exercise by Halcyon's executive chairman and chief executive Robert Meyer.

Mr Goi, better known as Singapore's "Popiah King", is executive chairman of property firm GSH Corp, food and beverage firm Tee Yih Jia Group and Yang-zhou Junhe Real Estate Group, and also has strategic investments in listed and private entities in diverse industries from food and beverage, consumer essentials and recycling to distribution and logistics.

Halcyon said the placement is meant to shore up the firm's capital position for further growth and expansion.

Over the last 15 months, Halcyon, through the acquisition of Anson Company for which it forked out S$450 million to buy from Lee Rubber, has bumped up its licensed capacity nearly seven-fold from 110,000 tonnes per annum in 2012 to 748,000 tonnes.

Anson owns nine rubber factories in Indonesia.

"This growth in productive capacity implies a commensurate increase in working capital requirement, offset, to a degree, by the current weak market prices for natural rubber," said the firm.

More recently, it proposed buying New Continent Enterprises, a global dealer and distributor of natural rubber, for US$30 million to match its customer mix to the consumer profile of Natural Rubber. Both these acquisitions, said the firm, will transform Hal-cyon to become a top five rubber producer globally.

"At this juncture, management views it as prudent to fortify the working capital resources in anticipation of a recovery in rubber prices and further growth in produced and distributed volumes," said Halcyon, adding that the proceeds from the placement are not required to fund the acquisitions of Anson or NCE.

The firm's issued and paid up share capital will increase to 421,000 shares once the placement, which will give Mr Goi a 5.94 per cent stake in the enlarged firm, is complete.

As a result of the enlarged share base, Lynette Le Mercier, who currently owns 15.53 per cent in Halcyon, will cease to be a controlling shareholding as per Catalist rules. Her interest will be cut down to 14.61 per cent post-placement, with her still remaining as the single largest shareholder.

Halcyon also said it may consider a proposed transfer to the mainboard sometime early next year, which will position the firm appropriately and better allow it to attract institutional investors and reach out to a wider investor base.

site_title: Australia also allows mobile devices in-flight
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Australia also allows mobile devices in-flight

Published

Tue, Aug 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SYDNEY] Passengers on Qantas and Virgin Australia from Tuesday were allowed to use mobile electronic devices in-flight with limited restrictions after a relaxation of the rules by the country's aviation authority.

The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (Casa) move, which followed similar decisions by the US and European Union last year, allows passengers to have their devices on "flight mode" during taxi-ing, take-off and landing.

This disables cellular service, so passengers will still not be able to make calls or send texts.

"The results of (work done in the United States and Europe) were released late last year and earlier this year and it basically concluded that modern aircraft are not at risk of interference from modern mobile phones, tablets, e-readers and so forth," Casa spokesman Peter Gibson said.

Previous regulations banned the use of electronics during taxi-ing, take-off and landing due to fears they could interfere with an airplane's navigation equipment.

The changes took effect for Qantas' and Virgin Australia's domestic and international flights.

Qantas said that it had "conducted rigorous testing to assess the impacts of electronic devices on the safe operation of aircraft".

"We are confident that these devices are safe to be turned on, but in flight mode, for the duration of each flight," it said. Virgin welcomed the decision, noting that a "significant proportion" of its customers travel with at least one smartphone or tablet.

Other Australian-based airlines, Jetstar and Tigerair, have not yet applied to operate under the new guidelines, Mr Gibson said.

He added that he "would be surprised" if more airlines were not permitted to use mobile devices in all phases of flight in the future.

"Certainly we can say all the next-generation aircraft - the ones made in the last 10 or 15 years - won't have a problem," said Mr Gibson, adding that it was only older aircraft where interference concerns remained. - AFP
