site_title: CPF and your retirement needs
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

CPF and your retirement needs

What are the pros and cons of the changes to the CPF scheme - in particular, allowing retirees to withdraw a lump sum and the extension of the Lease Buyback Scheme?

Published

Sun, Aug 24, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Dhirendra Shantilal

Board Director & Head of Asia Pacific,

Fircroft

THE lump sum withdrawal and the Lease Buyback Scheme extension essentially put more cash into the hands of retirees. This is welcome as it gives them more control over how they would like to fund their retirement. But how the lump sum withdrawal will affect their monthly CPF payouts remains to be seen and it is unclear how the government will value the leases it purchases. The changes announced by the Prime Minister during the National Day Rally are part of a long-term effort to rebalance the CPF in the direction of greater individual choice.

While these latest initiatives largely focus on providing a lifeline to low-income groups, in the long term the fund must evolve into a wealth management tool for all its members. The key issue is not how to disburse funds but how to ensure the greatest possible accumulation of wealth. This can be achieved by turning savers into investors. While these initiatives represent a first step in this direction, in the long term more management choices earlier on is the only way forward. Greater two-way interaction between CPF and its members will be appreciated by all parties.

Lance Tay

Chief Executive Officer

Tokio Marine Life Insurance Singapore Ltd

MANY retirees will welcome a lump sum withdrawal. By capping it at, say, 20 per cent, a balance is struck between the desire of some Singaporeans to manage their own funds and securing a minimum retirement income. Singaporeans can decide if they would like to earn guaranteed interest by not touching their CPF money or to withdraw the funds for personal use.

We need to exercise this flexibility with caution and provide public education to help people make an informed decision. With rising living costs, longer life expectancy and inflationary effects, Singaporeans may not achieve their desired retirement lifestyles with CPF Life payouts alone without supplementing that with, for example, a private retirement plan that provides lifetime payouts.

The extension of the Lease Buyback Scheme is practical for those who wish to monetise the value of their flats to augment their retirement funding. This, however, compromises the wishes of those who would like to bequeath their flats to their children as part of legacy planning, and highlights how holistic financial counselling and forward planning can better prepare us for retirement.

Sam Yap

Group Executive Chairman and Co-Founder

Htwo Investment Holdings Pte Ltd

THE Prime Minister's announcement regarding the changes to the CPF scheme may appease those who want to manage their own funds. Allowing members to invest their CPF funds for higher returns is good but retirees must be financially competent and savvy to do so. How about more incentives for retirees to keep their savings with the CPF? The problem with some retirees is when they get a lump sum of money in hand, there could be a tendency to spend it too fast, leaving precious little for later years.

The extension of the Lease Buyback Scheme to four-room flats gives retirees another financing option to support themselves in old age. However, I think not many will rush on this offer as people generally cherish possession of their HDB flat. There is also a need to study what happens if retirees on the scheme outlive the 30-year lease. Hopefully, the new options provided will not generate other sets of problems that will be an issue for society or the government to grapple with in future.

Joshua Yim

CEO

Achieve Group

THE extension of the Lease Buyback Scheme to four-room flats is definitely a welcome move as it helps the HDB owner unlock the value of the property. Going a step further, I'm advocating that it should be extended to five-room flats. When a flat owner dies, those inheriting the property will stand to gain. But the retirees should be the ones enjoying the fruits of their labour while they are still around. With regard to the lump sum withdrawal, this shows that the government has, first and foremost, heard the voices of the people by releasing the money to them and, second, is making it possible for them to enjoy their hard-earned savings.

While it is a good gesture to give people autonomy to enjoy their savings, my concern, on the other hand, is on the social implications if these retirees squander away their money. Or if they fall victim to scams, given the many stories we have heard of seniors getting cheated. Policymakers should review the CPF scheme to consider putting in place some mechanism to help members safeguard their money. Perhaps there should be certain criteria or parameters in place, such as having the withdrawals capped at certain percentages and at yearly intervals.

The issue of the Minimum Sum being raised is purely mathematics. Everyone will need to retire at some point and only a small percentage of people will have recurring income from investments. Some may not even have private health insurance policies to see them through. The majority may need to rely only on their CPF savings to support themselves. During the rally, PM Lee polled the audience and it was clear that most people feel they need about S$2,000 a month during retirement. Will the Minimum Sum of S$161,000 be able to sustain a monthly payout of S$2,000 till the last day of the person's life? Thus, the raising of the Minimum Sum is absolutely necessary and, in fact, I feel it should be even higher and increased on a yearly basis to keep step with inflation. Having more money in the CPF account is a good thing, in case people live another 30 years after retiring because if the money runs out, the individual will be in a very sad situation. Some people don't believe in buying insurance so this form of forced savings is good and necessary in order to avoid any potential blowup of social welfare issues. From a macro perspective, I feel these changes are very fair and show that the government is trying to protect its people.

Magnus Böcker

CEO, SGX

DESPITE being a young nation, Singapore is well known to have one of the world's highest saving levels. We work hard for our money yet not many of us do enough to have our money work hard for us. I am supportive of the recent CPF refinements that enable retired Singaporeans to have extra funds to enjoy or put into investments. I an't stress enough the importance of financial literacy and benefits of long-term investment for a more secure retirement.

To many Singaporeans who don't have well-diversified CPF savings now, sound investment decisions can be made only if each of us is well-informed and has a strong understanding of risks and rewards. At SGX, we will therefore continue to support investors in their efforts to better protect and grow their investments.

Robin C Lee

Group COO

Bok Seng Group

WHEN it comes to the care of our senior folks, careful yet tough decisions often have to be made by the government. On the one hand, there is a need to help them stash sufficient reserves away to cover their retirement years and, at the same time, get them to understand the necessity of doing so. Yet I also feel that everyone is entitled to his or her own decisions and lifestyles. Therefore, in my opinion, the new Silver Support Bonus Scheme and the latest changes in the CPF scheme to allow a lump sum withdrawal of perhaps up to 20 per cent are well thought-through proposals that allow us to move in the right direction. It's about time we Singaporeans take responsibility for our own actions and be heedful of the consequences of early gratification by blowing away one's saving too rapidly.

The current payout based on the Minimum Sum drawdown after 65 years of age is barely going to be adequate for most amid escalating costs of living. Therefore, if needed, the Lease Buyback Scheme is a good way to enable retirees to cash-in the portion of the property that they may not get to use to obtain more cash in hand. This should, on a needs basis, eventually also extend to flats bigger than four rooms.

Nishit Majmudar

CEO

Aviva Singapore

I APPLAUD the government for leading the national dialogue to address the concerns of many Singaporeans. Financing of retirement is a challenge worldwide with increasing longevity and low interest rates. Singapore is no exception. Withdrawal of lump sum amounts provides Singaporeans with greater flexibility but they will need to demonstrate greater responsibility to ensure they do not jeopardise their long-term retirement. The long debate around such a change will hopefully serve to educate all Singaporeans to be responsible spenders of their own money. My hope is that Singaporeans will avail themselves to expert financial advice before they decide on how they spend the lump sum withdrawal. We at Aviva will work hard to provide Singaporeans quality advice and retirement solutions to enable them to be well prepared for their silver years. Overall, this change seems to be the right balance such that the government continues to provide the financing framework, while individuals have greater flexibility in the use of their money.

Christophe Duchatellier

CEO

Adecco Asia

THE world of work is evolving - people are living longer and the retirement age is going up. It is good that the government is continually addressing the changing demographics of the workforce and that it remains responsive to this. By allowing retirees to withdraw lump sum amounts, this flexibility provides CPF members with more control on managing their finances. Therefore, financial planning should be prioritised so that elderly citizens would take steps not to misuse this flexibility and to manage their lower monthly payouts. To further ensure financial security, they might consider pushing back their retirement.

From a human resource perspective, it would be good if companies take the initiative to explain career progression to their employees, thereby supporting them with a solid career path if they choose to postpone their retirement. As employers, we too need to reassure our staff that they will be taken care of in the long term.

Jack Chua

CEO

ERA Singapore

BY allowing retirees to withdraw a lump sum from their CPF subject to a limit, it gives them the option of having a capital sum at hand should the need arise - for example, a family emergency. However, by withdrawing the lump sum, these retirees would have a smaller amount in the CPF and this would mean a lower monthly payout from the CPF.

It is a good move by the government to extend the Lease Buyback Scheme (LBS) to owners of four-room HDB flats, which account for the majority of HDB flats in Singapore. So, with this extension, most HDB flat owners will now have this additional monetisation option to tap should they need to.

The Prime Minister has explained very clearly and simply the monetisation options available. The government will need to continue this communication to the masses so that they can understand all the options available.

The LBS enables the elderly, especially those who are sentimental about their homes, to continue to live in the neighbourhood they have become familiar with. Those likely to take up the LBS are the elderly with no immediate need of a sizeable capital sum and are reluctant to uproot from their current flat location. Those in need of a sizeable capital sum are likely to consider the right-sizing option - i.e. sell off their current flat and ''right-size'' to a studio apartment.

Under the LBS, the flat owners get a small lump sum upfront and also a modest monthly income stream for the remaining 30 years lease of their flat. However, this monthly sum is less than what they can get should they sublet the whole flat.

Once they have taken up the LBS, the flat cannot be sold in the resale market anymore. If they do not need it anymore, they can only sell it back to the HDB; they cannot bequeath the flat to their children. They are also not allowed to sublet the whole flat. Should they outlive the 30 years lease, an application for extension can be made to the HDB on a case-by-case basis, so there are no worries of not having a flat to live in.

Chris Comer

CEO

Castlewood Group

PM Lee Hsien Loong's announcement on the changes to the CPF scheme is a welcome shift as Singapore continues to adapt to the country's changing socio-economic structure. It is no secret that an increasing number of Singaporeans can be described as ''asset rich, cash-poor'' due to limited access to cash. I believe that for these individuals, the ability to withdraw lump sums from their CPF savings is hugely beneficial as they can fulfil long-held dreams or fund unforeseen emergencies. But there is also the risk of retirees now accessing funds at their whim, potentially ignoring long-term implications of lower monthly payouts and as a result finding themselves in a much more difficult financial situation in the years ahead.

Retirement financing is a hot topic as it is well documented that Singaporeans, like all people, are living longer and therefore require sufficient funds to support themselves through the later years. I feel that the Lease Buyback Scheme does offer a solution to retirees looking to liquidate their assets. However, no scheme is perfect so additional consideration has to be taken as the current offer of a 30-year lease in exchange for cash may not support the resident's entire lifespan. While the HDB has given the assurance that no one will be left homeless, sufficient contingency plans will need to be put in place specifically detailing what will happen if the resident outlives the reduced lease. While these changes are a step in the right direction, long-term solutions still need to be found for funding the nation's elderly for the duration of their golden years.

Scott Burnett

Managing Director for South East Asia

Towers Watson

FLEXIBILITY is one of the key benefits of the proposed changes, in particular allowing retirees to withdraw lump sum amounts, which should address recent public debate about access to CPF funds. However, taking more money out earlier means that there is less left over during retirement. Individuals need to understand the tradeoff between lifetime retirement income under CPF Life and withdrawing a lump sum which may be used up quickly. The extension of the Lease Buyback Scheme will enable a wider segment of Singaporeans to use their property to fund their retirement.

Adequacy of income in retirement is a concern for many Singaporeans. Based on a Towers Watson survey of HR professionals conducted in February 2014, almost three-quarters of some 200 respondents said they were not saving enough. The government should look into promoting other pillars of retirement savings, for example, improving the framework for supplementary employer-sponsored retirement plans.

Lim Soon Hock

Managing Director

PLAN-B ICAG Pte Ltd

CPF is a savings account. It is not an investment account. The two have different, if not contradictory, purposes. CPF members cannot expect the principal sum - i.e. the Minimum Sum - to be protected or guaranteed while at the same time enjoy high returns. As a savings account, there is almost no risk, but the returns cannot be high like with a high-risk investment account. CPF members must understand and accept these pros and cons. The government is correct to keep the goal of the CPF sacrosanct - as savings for retirement. CPF has also been generous in offering a yield or interest rate that is substantially higher than the market. Members should be appreciative of this.

I am concerned that the move to allow a lump sum withdrawal will open a Pandora's Box into the future. If more is allowed, it would negate the purpose of the CPF. I recognise that CPF funds are members' money, and, therefore, they are technically entitled to decide how they want to use it. But while this flexibility will solve a current problem or need, it will create a future problem, when savings become insufficient for retirement. As it stands today, the Minimum Sum is barely enough to support the lifestyle of the average man in the street. I am for the raising of the Minimum Sum next year. I am in favour of monetisation of assets like the Lease Buyback Scheme or reverse mortgages to generate cash to meet the needs of members, be it for pleasure, as in travel to enjoy their retirement, or to meet expenses. In this regard, members do have a choice to keep their CPF savings intact to provide a long stream of annuity payments or benefiting from a lump sum to meet cash needs. Members should resist any temptation for a short-term gain at the expense of long-term security or comfort in later years. It is prudent to let the CPF continue to be our custodian of a portion of our savings - for all we know, it may be all that we have for our retirement.

Low Lee Yong

CEO

MHC Asia Group Pte Ltd

I THINK it is a good sign of a maturing government understanding that people should be given more autonomy over their CPF savings. This will appeal most to the lower income group by allowing them flexibility to enjoy the fruits of their labour earlier. We may worry about some elderly people squandering their lump sum withdrawals - which is why having a cap of perhaps 20 per cent is a wise move.

To further prevent abuse, more public education and counselling should be provided. The system will not be perfect at the start but can be gradually tweaked with the help of public feedback as we move along. As for the Lease Buyback Scheme, more homeowners can have the assurance that they can age gracefully in their ''family home''. This definitely appeals to the Asian mindset of having a place to call home and a familiar final resting place.

Dora Hoan

Co-Chairman/Group CEO

Best World International Ltd

I APPLAUD the decision to allow a partial lump sum withdrawal for retirees. While the existing CPF measures provide for the long-term financial security of citizens, many face cash shortages for daily needs. Given such anxieties, they would not see the goodwill of our government. As a result, the CPF has become a contentious issue. Therefore, the proposed changes are timely and beneficial for both the people and the government. Nevertheless, I feel that the proposed moves can be further enhanced. For instance, instead of a 20 per cent cap, the government can consider allowing citizens a lump sum withdrawal of 50 per cent upon reaching 65 years old and then a further 5 per cent for every subsequent year, subject to a one-off payment for medical insurance. Rising medical cost is also a big concern among Singaporeans and their families; these moves will give them peace of mind for the present and future.

Ronald Lee

Managing Director

PrimeStaff Management Services Pte Ltd

I FOUND the explanation of the changes to the CPF scheme very clear and helpful, especially as many people were still unaware or confused about previously announced changes like the increase in the Minimum Sum, for example. The new lump sum CPF withdrawal should come as welcome to those who really need the money for whatever purposes, be it for a sudden family emergency or to finally go on a dream holiday. It is certainly good news for those who have already hit 65 years of age. On the flip side, however, if this is not managed prudently, retirees could end up worse off if they draw out too much, leaving too little for their monthly payouts. After all, people can easily live a good 20 or more years after retirement these days.

Anyway, more details about the lump sum withdrawal will be forthcoming so it is perhaps too early to judge right now. As for the extension of the Lease Buyback Scheme to four-room flats, this is a very timely initiative given Singapore's ageing population and growing cohort of baby boomers approaching retirement age. It is great that there is now this additional option for them to monetise their flats compared with the common suggestion of downgrading to a smaller one. Overall, I believe that these changes do go some way towards managing Singaporeans' needs and expectations.

Alfred Chia

Chief Executive Officer

SingCapital Pte Ltd

WHILE it is heartening to know that the government is listening to the people to be more flexible with CPF withdrawals, I'm concerned for members who are not careful with their finances. This is especially so if one is old and unable to work as any squandering of the retirement funds will have dire consequences.

While it is understandable that members want to have control of their money, there is another group of people who are happy to top up their CPF savings to enjoy the generous risk-free 4 per cent returns. It is important to step up financial education so that there is a balance of autonomy for CPF members and provision of retirement funding. The extension of the HDB's Lease Buyback Scheme to four-room flats provides an additional option for retirement funding. Generally, we have more options for retirement funding - which should provide comfort but not a false sense that retirement is well taken care of.

Toby Koh

Group Managing Director

Ademco Security Group

THE new initiatives put forth by the Prime Minister, particularly the lump sum CPF withdrawal, are certainly welcomed by the general public. It is a positive move for many but the government will have to consider carefully the consequences and wider impact if a big number of retirees run out of savings. Perhaps the CPF Board can even encourage more people to save by having more flexible withdrawal schemes for older citizens and enticing them with superior interest-rate returns compared with the banking sector. This may then cause one to rethink whether a lump sum withdrawal is financially rewarding when compared with leaving their funds in the CPF.

Thirumalai Chandroo

Chairman/CEO

Modern Montessori International Group

THE secret of Singapore's success, I believe, has been its sound policy implementations. The various CPF measures and the Lease Buyback Scheme may seem confusing at first, but each does extend its own benefits. The proposed lump sum withdrawal allows retirees to enjoy the fruits of their labour after years of hard work. At the same time it is important for the CPF Board to educate the public about the expected value of their CPF savings in the later years - perhaps with a personal understanding of how the scheme benefits them, the importance of securing a healthy CPF balance will be better appreciated.

The Lease Buyback Scheme is a good way for retirees to monetise the value of their real estate during their later years. The extension of the scheme to four-room flats means that a much bigger group of citizens stand to reap the benefits. These moves allow flexibility and Singaporeans have to learn to make sense of the changes. The efficacy of the policies will be seen in due course. The schemes certainly show promise, particularly that Singapore has a responsive government that takes heed of feedback. They make informed decisions and the peoples' voice certainly takes precedence.

Annie Yap

Managing Director

AYP Associates Pte Ltd

THE first advantage would be the greater flexibility that retired Singaporeans have in managing their own funds. Second, it would be the ''peace of mind'' that their hard-earned money is not ''stuck'' in the CPF and can be used to address any short-term cash-flow needs. With measures in place to prevent over-withdrawing, there are actually no ''cons'' to the changes.

However, as with every scheme, the take-up rate remains to be seen. The Lease Buyback Scheme which has been in place since 2009 has not been well taken up as the elderly may fear that they will not have a place to stay in should they outlive the remaining lease. They also tend to prefer to leave a house to their children. Hence it would be more of a mindset change in determining if the extension of the Lease Buyback Scheme would become an effective source of income for retirees.

20b yuan fund set up to boost aviation sector

Published Mon, Aug 25, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[BEIJING] China has set up a 20 billion yuan (S$4.07 billion) investment fund to help bolster its fast-growing civil aviation industry, a report said on Monday.

The Civil Aviation Investment Fund, which is led by the parent of Beijing International Airport Co Ltd, is designed to help finance new airports, aviation economic zones, budget carriers, cargo and general aviation related projects, according to a report posted on the website of the China Securities Journal.

Beijing has been investing heavily in its aviation industry in recent years to cope with its fast-growing air travel demand. A total of 754 million people took to the air last year, up nearly 86 per cent from 2008, official statistics show.

Airport construction also has been picking up speed, with a new facility in the south of Beijing alone costing US$14 billion. About 62 cities have set up aviation economic zones where plane makers have set up shop alongside parts suppliers and logistic companies. - Reuters

THE plan to allow fund managers based in Singapore, Malaysia and Thailand to carry out cross-border selling of mutual funds or unit trusts across the three markets made significant headway with the joint launch of a key framework by the securities markets regulators of the Asean countries on Monday.

site_title: Rich Africa pickings beckon Singapore urban experts
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Rich Africa pickings beckon Singapore urban experts

Fast-developing continent offers huge prospects for international planners and builders

Published

Sun, Aug 24, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The rapidly developing continent of Africa has been attracting global urban consultants to compete for building and planning projects.

These include not just the Americans and Europeans, but also the newly industrialised South Africans, the Chinese, Egyptians, Arabs, and Singaporeans who position themselves as coming from a country that went from third world to first in just 35 years.

It is a critical juncture as many African countries are only just starting to urbanise. This presents a sweet spot for urban solution experts to enter and create blueprints for their cities, so that they can develop organically and systematically, rather than haphazardly.

One such company is Surbana, which recently made further inroads into Africa with a contract to help the Burundi government draw up the master plan for Bujumbura, its capital city.

Resource-rich Burundi holds a lot of promise for economic growth, despite being stricken with poverty and social problems like HIV proliferation, it says.

This is Surbana's seventh project in Africa, following earlier ones in South Africa, Republic of Congo, Angola, Rwanda, Nigeria and Mauritius since 2005.

Among Surbana's most notable projects is its master plan for a district in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda, a country notorious for its 1994 genocide which claimed the lives of 800,000 Tutsi and moderate Hutu people.

Kong Wy Mun, CEO of Singapore Cooperation Enterprise (SCE), which is partnering Surbana for the Burundi project, said: "Our team which went to Rwanda to do a scoping visit found that the country has transformed itself and come out very strongly from the genocide.

"When the genocide happened just 20 years ago, they were really ground zero. Everything was destroyed. But you can see how resilient the society is, how keen and hungry they are, led by President (Paul) Kagame."

Besides city planning, SCE - a government outfit formed to share Singapore's development experience with foreign governments - has also brought in players to conduct airport consultancy and revamp Rwanda's workforce development policies and technical vocational education system.

Now the country is enjoying "political stability and progressive policies" under the president's iron-fist rule. Reforms have improved its business climate and the government has shown that it is serious about weeding out corruption by locking up unscrupulous ministers. Mr Kagame has not been shy about his vision to turn Rwanda into the Singapore (that is, the financial hub) of central Africa.

All this has not escaped the attention of neighbouring Burundi. "They have seen how the Singapore system helped Rwanda - that's how they became keen to use us as a service provider," said Surbana CEO Pang Yee Ean.

Louis Tay, Surbana's managing director of aviation, city management and Africa, said the continent is looking for benchmarks as it urbanises, and Singapore stands out for a reason.

"In the words of Governor (Babatunde) Fashola of Lagos in Nigeria: London and Paris were successful because they had hundreds of years to make mistakes, but Singapore intrigued him because he had seen Singapore advance to first world in his lifetime."

Burundi is among the poorest countries in the world, and therefore heavily reliant on foreign aid. Surbana's Burundi project will be funded by the United Nations, which has been helping Burundi with ethnic reconciliation, economic growth and the setting up of institutions, especially after a 13-year civil war ravaged the country and ended only in 2005.

Unlike Rwanda, Burundi has not articulated its vision for the city, but potential abounds, said Mr Pang, given its untapped mineral resources, reasonable political stability (albeit under an authoritarian government) and strategic location in the centre of Africa which makes it a "very good standoff point for the UN to influence the rest of Africa".

Another Singaporean architecture consultant, Jurong International, is currently running a master planning project for a 1,600 hectare special economic zone in Pointe- Noire, the second largest city in the Republic of Congo. It has also completed projects in Nigeria, Equatorial Guinea and South Africa, and is pursuing prospects in more politically stable countries like Tanzania, Kenya and Rwanda.

Explaining the continent's appeal, a spokesman said: "Africa is seen as the last development frontier continent. The huge young population, growing middle class and abundant natural resources are a magnet for investors and developers. The lack of infrastructure and urban planning in most of its countries means that there are vast opportunities for development."

Even though risks like biological hazards, political uncertainty, social unrest and high crime rates continue to plague its less developed countries, Africa's frontier growth is still expected to outpace frontier Asia by 2016, making it the world's fastest expanding region, according to the International Monetary Fund.

Besides Africa, other developing regions - Southeast Asia, South Asia and Latin America - also see their markets for major infrastructural projects dominated by foreign contractors, says assistant professor Oscar Carracedo Garcia-Villalba of the NUS Department of Architecture.

One academic report said both the local government and the foreign contractor are spurred by different motivations in such partnerships: economic development for the former; and profit first, then altruistic considerations (if at all), for the latter.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

S'pore eDev's former unit fails to stop S$4.2m claim

Published Mon, Aug 25, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SINGAPORE eDevelopment's old business continues to cast a shadow on growth plans, with news on Monday that a former subsidiary failed to stop a S$4.2 million claim from a previous client.

Singapore eDevelopment, the property developer formerly known as the construction company CCM Group, said that an injunction by CCM Industrial Pte Ltd to contest the claim by Pan-Asia Logistics Investments has been set aside. Singapore eDevelopment is seeking legal advice.

CCM Industrial was disposed of on May 21 as part of Singapore eDevelopment's restructuring. But the former CCM Group, together with CCM Industrial and CCM Industrial managing director Liew Sen Keong, had all given indemnities as part of a performance bond related to a contract between CCM Industrial and Pan-Asia Logistics Investments.

The contract was for the building of a four-storey warehouse and office in Tuas.

In its results announcement for the half-year ended June 30, 2014, Singapore eDevelopment disclosed that it had contingent liabilities from corporate indemnities comprising S$12.3 million, including the performance bond amount related to the Tuas contract.

Shares of Singapore eDevelopment closed unchanged at 0.3 Singapore cent on Monday.

The news about CCM Industrial came a day before Singapore eDevelopment closes the books for a rights issue.

The company is issuing 12 rights shares at 0.3 Singapore cent each for every share held, and one bonus share for every rights share subscribed for. It hopes to raise between S$3.3 million and S$129.1 million in net proceeds to fund its new business growth in development and info-communications technology (ICT).

Singapore eDevelopment chief executive Chan Heng Fai said in a statement: "Singapore eDevelopment is transforming itself via international property development and ICT. The strong trading volume ex-rights underscores the interest in our recovery and growth strategy. content:
SUBSCRIBERS

STATS ChipPAC debt rating downgraded by Moody's

Drop to Ba2 from Ba1 is due to pressure on profitability but outlook deemed stable

Angela Tan

Published

Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

MOODY'S Investors Service yesterday downgraded STATS ChipPAC Ltd's corporate family rating and senior unsecured debt rating to Ba2 from Ba1.

The credit-rating agency said that the outlook is stable, but added that the chipmaker's final rating of Ba2 benefits from a one-notch uplift due to expected support from its ultimate holding company, Temasek Holdings, in the event of stress.

"The rating action reflects our view that STATS ChipPAC's profitability will remain under pressure and that leverage will remain above levels commensurate with the company's previous rating level through 2015," said Annalisa DiChiara, a Moody's vice-president and senior analyst.

She said that this was in view of the slowing growth in the high-end communications segment and muted demand from the personal computer and consumer end markets.

Ms DiChiara noted that the chipmaker's revenues have been on a declining trend since 2011, reflecting lower revenues from wire bonding and, more recently, decelerating growth in the high-end smartphone segment, and accelerated demand for low-cost smartphones.

At the same time, operating profit was weak at 3 per cent for the last 12 months ended June 30, owing to the lower revenues and high fixed cost base.

She said that the group's debt levels have risen 20 per cent since FY2013 to US$1.1 billion by June 30, 2014, driven by investment needs for its new plant in South Korea. Debt is likely to increase by an additional US$90-120 million by year-end 2014, in part, to complete the expansion of the plant.

"The company's aggressive capital spending for the Korea project, combined with low profitability, has caused the company to consume free cash flow (FCF) and increase debt levels significantly over the last 18 months," Ms DiChiara said.

"Given Moody's expected capex of US$550 million in 2014 and US$450 million in 2015, negative FCF will likely continue through 2015 and leverage will remain in the 3.0x-3.3x range over the same period. At the same time, interest cover, defined as adjusted Ebit/Interest, will remain weakly positioned for the rating at less than 1.75x," added Ms DiChiara.

For the second quarter ended June 30, 2014, STATS ChipPAC reported a net loss of US$4.18 million compared to a net loss of US$52.25 million a year ago, which included plant closure costs of US$36.5 million. Revenue was US$409.91 million versus US$396.37 million a year ago.

site_title: Asia's bond markets need more support
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Asia's bond markets need more support

Listen to this article

Published Mon, Aug 25, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT is a curious fact that while Asia's "emerging" stock markets have become familiar to portfolio investors around the world, the issuance of local currency bond debt by companies in this region still requires a process of hand-holding by official institutions before investors are willing to cough up funds.

The latest example is the agreement by the Credit Guarantee and Investment Facility (CGIF) - established by the Asean states plus China, Japan and South Korea - to guarantee S$60 million worth of local currency bonds issued by Lao conglomerate Kolao Holdings, the CGIF's first such deal in Singapore. The need for such guarantees partly reflects the fact that while Wall Street investment bankers (aided by the World Bank and its various arms) have been only too eager in recent decades to promote international investment in emerging market equities, equal support has not been given to bond market development.

Equity investment implies a degree of shareholder participation in the ownership and control of companies receiving funds whereas investment in the debt securities of emerging markets companies (in Asia as elsewhere) involves nothing beyond a creditor-debtor relationship. To what extent the desire to enjoy such ownership and control from overseas explains the relative rush to develop emerging equity markets, and to what extent it reflects a preference by global institutional investors for short-term counters rather than long-term debt instruments, is debatable. But the fact is that this unbalanced capital market development in emerging economies in and beyond Asia has long gone unrecognised. It illustrates how smart and smooth has been the "packaging"of emerging market equities by global investment banks while bond markets have been orphaned by comparison.

site_title: Rise in global trade to benefit Singapore most, says S&P
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Rise in global trade to benefit Singapore most, says S&P

Asian nations still very dependent on exports to advanced economies

Published Mon, Aug 25, 2014 · 10:00 PM

HIGHLY trade-dependent Singapore stands to benefit more than any other Asian economy should a US-led increase in global trade occur this year, according to an analysis by rating agency Standard & Poor's which says that it is "fairly upbeat" about a US recovery in the second half of the year.

According to the S&P analysis, Asian economies are still highly dependent on exports to advanced nations despite hopes in the wake of the global financial crisis that many of these economies had become "decoupled" from mature economies and despite growing domestic demand.

"We believe that the possibility of the region's demand rising to offset weaker demand from the advanced economies is limited at best," says the report from a team led by the agency's Singapore-based Asia-Pacific chief economist Paul Gruenwald.

However, it also suggests that while Asian economies' continuing dependence on demand from outside the region is a weakness when global demand contracts, it could bring benefits now with demand set to turn up in the US, if not yet in the euro area or in Japan.

Singapore was among the worst-hit economies at the time of the global financial crisis because the contribution of external demand to its growth before the crisis was so high, and slumped so badly afterwards. But a recovery in global trade should boost Singapore in particular now, S&P says.

Thailand should benefit almost equally with Singapore but the boost to GDP growth from a recovery in global trade shades downward thereafter through the Philippines, China, South Korea, Indonesia, Malaysia, Taiwan and India with Japan gaining relatively little.

The S&P report reveals why the performance of Asian economies has been sluggish since the global financial crisis in 2008 and 2009 dealt a major blow to the US and Europe. "Intra-regional trade (which constitutes half of total Asia-Pacific exports) still appears driven mostly from outside the region, suggesting a continued dependency of Asia-Pacific economies on the advanced ones," it says.

"Intra-regional trade tracked exports to the US and Europe very closely even though the economic downturn in Asia was less severe.

"This suggests that Asia-Pacific's trade was dependent on demand in the advanced economies; in other words, demand from Asia has not de-linked from the advanced economies."

Given the relatively high trade dependency in much of the region, the slowdown in global trade "has clear implications for GDP growth", says S&P.

"Lower net exports have reduced GDP growth in Asia-Pacific by about one percentage point, from 5 per cent to 4 per cent, in the post-crisis period, and their contribution to GDP growth has fallen to zero. The effect on larger economies in Asia-Pacific has been more modest than for smaller ones."

Each one percentage point rise in growth of global trade volume translates into an increase of a 0.3 to 0.4 percentage point in real GDP of Asian economies, says S&P. "Looking forward, S&P says that "our baseline view is that despite the slow start in the first quarter, US growth will pick up toward 3 per cent by the end of this year and maintain this momentum over the next few years. Along with that, US imports should rise and benefit the Asia-Pacific region through higher growth in external demand."

But even with the projected US recovery, "we expect global trade growth to remain weak and below pre-crisis rates. Trade volume growth for Asia was about 10 per cent annually in the half-decade leading up to the financial crisis, but is now about 6 per cent, and we project it to stay around that rate over the next few years."

Canada's largest port okays US$15m coal transfer project

Published Sun, Aug 24, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[LONDON] Port Metro Vancouver, Canada's largest port, said that it has approved a new facility to transfer coal from trains onto barges at Fraser Surrey Docks, following lengthy public scrutiny of the project's environmental and health impact.

After a permitting process lasting more than two years and including environmental impact, air quality and other human health assessments, the port said that it found no "unacceptable risks" in allowing the US$15 million project to move forward.

But opponents of the project say that they will look at every possible option to challenge the decision. "There is one more permit that the project needs to move forward, and that's an air quality permit from the regional government - Metro Vancouver," said Laura Benson, a campaigner with the Dogwood Initiative, a non-profit that has been opposing the project. "We feel pretty confident that unlike the port, which is an unaccountable federal agency run like a corporation, that Metro Vancouver, which is led by our local elected officials will stand by our communities," she said.

A spokeswoman for the Fraser Surrey Docks, however, said that it viewed the permit in question as voluntary. "We are looking into applying to Metro Vancouver for an air quality permit. This is a voluntary move on our part and is not a requirement of the project," the spokeswoman, Jill Buchanan, said in an e-mail.

The Fraser Surrey Docks terminal would handle up to four million tonnes of coal from the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway Co each year, loading it on barges bound for Texada Island, north of Vancouver, where it would be transferred to large vessels for export.

Documents published last year by the port, which is a corporation established by the Canadian government, said that the expansion would bring in one more train and two barges each day. Cheap natural gas and tighter regulation has hurt coal prices in the US in recent years, prompting more producers to look overseas for customers.

Port Metro Vancouver, which handles some US$172 billion in goods traded between more than 160 countries, announced new requirements for the project last fall, including prohibiting on-site coal storage and making barges take extra measures to prevent coal dust from escaping while in transit.- Reuters

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

CenturyLink launching hybrid cloud in Asia-Pac

Service spans both public and private clouds, delivers agility and innovation but with physical standards that large firms require, reports AMIT ROY CHOUDHURY

Published

Sun, Aug 24, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] CenturyLink, a global leader in cloud infrastructure and hosted IT solutions, last week announced a new private cloud service that it says would deliver the agility and innovation of a public cloud but with the physical standards that many large enterprises require.

According to the company, which is the third largest telecommunications company in the US, each private cloud would sit within the CenturyLink Cloud network of public cloud nodes. In effect, this will give users a single interface for creating and maintaining a hybrid environment that spans both public and private clouds. The end result is greater agility for businesses across a broader range of workloads - even those that require additional security and compliance, the company says.

CenturyLink's Gery Messer told BizIT that the cloud service would be available across 57 data centres globally including Singapore, Hong Kong, and Tokyo. Mr Messer is the Asia-Pacific MD for CenturyLink Technology Solutions, which is the data hosting operating business unit of CenturyLink.

"This (cloud service) will be integrated with existing CenturyLink Public Cloud nodes which are currently available in EMEA (Europe, Middle East and Africa) and the US, and will be integrated with the Singapore cloud node once it is launched later this year," he said.

Mr Messer notes that the Asia-Pacific region continues to grow both economically and technologically. "Since 2008, CenturyLink has invested more than US$400 million throughout the region in data centres, network infrastructure and new product offerings to cater to the growing demand for co-location, managed hosting, cloud and network services across the Asia-Pacific.

"Singapore is used as a regional technology hub by many Asian and global companies due to its stable business landscape, modern infrastructure and central location in the region. Singapore houses CenturyLink's regional sales, marketing and operations headquarters, and we have doubled our headcount in the past three years."

He adds that in order to service the needs of Singaporean customers, as well as those across the region, the company has placed significant investment in Singapore.

These include two data centres which meet the strict requirements of enterprise customers such as those from financial services, one of the company's three "Follow-the-Sun" operations centres which provides 24/7 support to customers around the globe, as well as a Metro Dark Fibre Ring connecting the data centres with other industry data centres across the country, Mr Messer notes.

Expansion plan

"Our next generation cloud platform - CenturyLink Cloud, will be launched later this year, and represents another multi-million investment for the company. CenturyLink is committed to a multiple-year expansion plan. As we continue to launch new products and expand into new Asia-Pacific markets, we will add additional headcount in our regional Singapore headquarters and country offices."

Mr Messer adds that despite initially playing catch-up to EMEA and America in adoption rates, cloud computing is gaining rapid momentum in the Asia-Pacific as "organisations recognise its value in meeting their IT requirements".

IT analyst firm Frost & Sullivan has indicated that the public cloud services market in the Asia-Pacific is expected to witness strong growth momentum to exceed revenues of US$20 billion in 2018, translating into a CAGR (compound annual growth rate) of 33.1 per cent between 2013 and 2018.

One of the key differentiators of the CenturyLink Cloud platform is its opt-in managed services, which allows customers to offload critical IT functions, such as patching and monitoring of the OS (operating system) and applications.

Delivered via a pay-per-use hourly billing model, this can dramatically help reduce time and costs of managing IT.

Commenting on the CenturyLink offering, Melanie Posey, research VP, hosting and managed network services, at IDC said: "CenturyLink Private Cloud provides a frictionless hybrid cloud option for organisations that want to source private and public cloud services from a single provider and connect cloud with other IT services through an extensive Tier 1 IP network."

Mr Messer adds that one of the strong value propositions of the company's platforms is its enterprise focus. "Our cloud technologies are used by some of the largest consumer brands in the world, as well as for the daily transaction of trillions of dollars of the global FX (foreign exchange) market. Any downtime is unacceptable for these types of customers, and is often a deciding factor to select CenturyLink over other technology vendors."

The CenturyLink Cloud is available to organisations seeking cloud services in Europe and North America. "We have already signed up a number of customers from Singapore, Japan and India on our international cloud nodes, and are seeing strong interest from organizations, in Hong Kong and Australia."

CenturyLink is achieving its goal of providing business-friendly hybrid IT solutions aimed at meeting enterprise requirements, Mr Messer adds. Thanks to our global infrastructure, CenturyLink is "uniquely positioned" to tailor solutions to the varying and evolving needs of our customers.

"Our public cloud provides an affordable yet robust public cloud platform backed up by one of the best service level agreements in the industry. The launch of CenturyLink Private Cloud adds to our cloud momentum, re-enforcing our strong position in Gartner's Magic Quadrant as a visionary cloud provider," he says.

site_title: Testing options for heart problems
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Testing options for heart problems

There are now safer alternatives to the old gold standard, invasive coronary angiography

Published

Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

YOU have chest pain on exertion or you have just been told that your treadmill stress test is abnormal, and you are advised to undergo a procedure called invasive coronary angiography (ICA) which involves the insertion of specially designed plastic tubes through your leg artery to take pictures of your heart arteries using iodine based contrast media under X-ray imaging. ICA is one of the most commonly performed diagnostic tests for patients suspected to have heart disease. In light of the advances in imaging of the heart arteries over the last decade, is ICA, which has been the "gold" standard for imaging of the heart arteries, still the best choice for you?

The updated July 2014 American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association guideline for the diagnosis and management of patients with stable heart disease due to blockage of the heart artery provides answers to this question. The irony is that although ICA has been performed for decades, there is as yet no strong scientific data to provide the basis for recommending an ICA. Furthermore, the guideline states that the potential additional benefit of confirming the presence or absence of blockage of heart arteries by ICA has yet to be confirmed by well designed studies. Hence, the guideline states that there is no strong evidence to support the routine recommendation of ICA for those with suspected blockage of heart arteries. ICA has been the "gold" standard by virtue of the fact that it was the only method that could allow the visualisation of the heart arteries in the past. It was basically a case of Hobson's choice. The advancing tide of technology has gradually eroded the value of ICA as a diagnostic tool for heart artery disease in the last decade as seen through the evolution of safer non-invasive methods to visualise the heart arteries, namely the use of computed tomography (CT) scan and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

Weighing options

What should one do when chest pain occurs and there is reason to suspect underlying heart disease after clinical risk assessment? The current guidelines recommend that the most appropriate first test of choice should be a non-invasive test. Wherever practical, an exercise stress test should be the first test of choice for women with chest pain suspected to have heart disease. For women in particular, tests that involve exposure to X-ray radiation should be avoided and if these tests are necessary, these tests should not result in an X-ray radiation exposure of more than three millisieverts (equivalent to the average background ionising radiation that a person is exposed to annually)

In practice, if the results of non-invasive testing such as treadmill test, stress echocardiography (ultrasound) or stress nuclear heart scan are inconclusive or of borderline significance, it is a common practice to proceed to do ICA. While this has been a prevalent practice, advances in medical science have provided alternative options. CT scan of the heart arteries may be a more appropriate and a safer alternative than ICA in this situation. Rapid advances in CT technology have resulted in increasing indications for the use of CT scan in place of ICA. CT scan has several advantages over ICA; it can be performed as an outpatient within seconds, is non-invasive, is of lower cost, has lower radiation dosage (for new generation scanners), is three dimensional and can visualise detailed characteristics of the plaque (such as soft or hard plaque, presence and severity of calcium deposits). MRI of the heart arteries is a relatively newer modality which is less readily available but it has the advantages of being non-invasive, performed as outpatient procedure, has absolutely no X-ray radiation, and does not require any injection.

ICA carries real risks. The 2012 American College of Cardiology National Cardiovascular Data Registry CathPCI Registry recorded a 1.5 per cent incidence of complications from ICA. Complications included death, stroke, heart attacks, bleeding, infection, allergic reactions, damage to vessels, kidney damage due to contrast, abnormal heart rhythms, and emergency heart bypass surgery. The risk factors are age over 70, severe heart failure, severe valve disease, serious medical conditions, bleeding abnormalities, or allergies to contrast dye. The risk of contrast-induced kidney damage is increased in those with kidney disease or diabetes mellitus. In addition, there are at least six prospective studies that have demonstrated 5 to 22 per cent incidence of silent strokes detected on MRI of the brain following ICA. The long term consequence of silent strokes is memory impairment and cognitive decline. Hence, before ICA is recommended, the patient needs to fully understand the risks associated with the procedure and the results of the ICA must have a significant impact on management decisions. If a patient decides not to have any definitive procedure, such as bypass surgery or stent placement, performed no matter what the findings are or if the general condition of the patient makes bypass surgery or stenting of heart arteries a non-viable option, it is best not to perform an ICA , as there are safer alternatives.

So when should one consider undergoing an ICA? ICA is considered appropriate in the following situations.

However, studies published in recent years have questioned the wisdom of doing an ICA instead of using non-invasive tests such as CT scan, as published registries on ICA in the USA have shown that in the real world experience, for every 100 patients that undergo ICA, about 40 per cent have normal heart arteries and only slightly more than one third have significant heart artery disease. In other words, about 60 per cent of real world patients who underwent ICA do not need an ICA.

In the past, when the choices were limited, ICA was deemed a "gold" standard despite its significant risks and limitations. Unlike CT scan of the heart arteries which provide three dimensional assessment of the heart arteries, ICA can only allow two dimensional visualisation of the lumen of the artery and has significant limitations as the vessel wall cannot be seen. Hence, if there is diffuse disease, it is not possible to quantify the severity of vessel narrowing accurately as there may not be any adjacent normal vessel segment for comparison. Multiple studies have shown that there is significant variability in the assessment of arterial narrowing, especially overestimation of severity for visually assessed narrowing of >50 per cent. ICA is also unable to identify which plaques are likely to result in a heart attack and is also unable to define the functional significance of the narrowing.

Right decision

Hence, if you have chest pain on exertion or you have just been told that your treadmill stress test is abnormal, you should consider safer non-invasive alternatives especially if you fall into the category of those at higher risk of complications of ICA. For women and the young, tests that involve exposure to ionising or X-ray radiation should be avoided and where it is necessary, the radiation dosage resulting from the tests should preferably be not more than three millisieverts. CT scan is increasingly used by many physicians as an alternative to ICA and in this 2014 guideline, the committee explicitly wrote that CT scan is "appropriate and safer" than ICA in the diagnosis of IHD. Where expertise for MRI of heart arteries is available, it is a good alternative for the young and for women as there is no X-ray radiation. Remember, before confirming a decision on ICA, always look for safer alternatives.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Old US shipping law adds to costs of oil refiners

Published Mon, Aug 25, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] As the first US oil condensate exports head to Asia from the Gulf Coast, crude producers and refiners are exploring ways to get around a century-old law that makes it three times more expensive to ship by water between US ports than to sail to a foreign port.

The Jones Act, originally passed to protect the US maritime industry, restricts passage between US ports to ships that are US-built, US-flagged and US-crewed. If oil exports pick up pace while the Jones Act is left in place, US crudes discount to Brent will likely narrow from its US$8 average through 2014, while domestic refiners' shipping costs will remain high, putting them at a disadvantage to foreign competitors.

"For heaven's sake, if we're going to take the crude and export it all around the world, please let us export it to the US East Coast," PBF Energy executive chairman Tom O'Malley said. "We cannot do that if you can export crude oil to Europe at a cost of US$2 a barrel and we have to use a Jones Act ship which cost us US$6 or US$7 a barrel."

site_title: US jobs market still hampered, says Yellen
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

US jobs market still hampered, says Yellen

Fed chair calls for cautious approach in determining when rates should rise

Published

Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Jackson Hole, Wyoming

US labour markets remain hampered by the effects of the Great Recession, and the Federal Reserve should move cautiously in determining when interest rates should rise, Fed chair Janet Yellen said yesterday in a defence of her policy approach.

In a speech at a central banking conference here, Ms Yellen laid out in detail why she feels the unemployment rate alone is inadequate to evaluate the strength of the jobs market and why the Fed needed to move cautiously in deciding when to raise interest rates.

At the same time, she nodded to the concerns of some Fed officials who are growing uneasy with the sustained level of the central bank's monetary policy stimulus.

The jobless rate has fallen faster than expected, but Ms Yellen said that the economic disruption of the last five years has left millions of workers sidelined, discouraged, or stuck in part-time jobs - facts that are not captured in the unemployment rate alone.

Judging whether the economy is close to full employment is "complicated by ongoing shifts in the structure of the labour market and the possibility that the severe recession caused persistent changes in the labour market's functioning," Ms Yellen said in the opening address at the Fed's annual economic policy conference. "Assessments of the degree of remaining slack in the labour market need to become more nuanced because of considerable uncertainty about the level of employment consistent with the Federal Reserve's dual mandate of stable prices and full employment," she added.

Ms Yellen's speech tried to capture the dilemma faced by the central bank. She acknowledged there is a risk the Fed might misread the degree of slack in the labour market and may need to move rates quickly to catch up. But she said that there is also a chance the economy could disappoint or that pools of sidelined labourers could return to the workforce, easing any inflationary pressures. "There is no simple recipe for appropriate policy," Ms Yellen said, arguing for a "pragmatic" approach that allows officials room to evaluate data as it arrives without committing to a preset policy path.

Ms Yellen's speech included lengthy references to the possibility that labour markets may in fact be tighter than they seem, and the Fed may be at risk of having to raise rates sooner and faster than expected.

But the remarks overall marked a defence of her basic premise that the 2007-2009 financial crisis and recession damaged the economy and work force in ways that are not fully understood.

The Fed has held benchmark rates near zero since December 2008, and has said that it would wait a "considerable time" after winding down a stimulative bond-buying programme in October before raising them. Financial markets currently expect rates to rise around the middle of next year.

The debate over Ms Yellen's evaluation of labour markets - and over when to raise borrowing costs - is intensifying within the Fed's policy committee.

Some policymakers, including Kansas City Federal Reserve Bank president Esther George, the host of the conference in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, are becoming more vocal in their view that the Fed risks falling behind and should raise rates soon.

At the central bank's last policy meeting last month, some officials argued against characterising the amount of slack in the labour market as "significant", which the Fed did in its post-meeting statement. Many officials agreed that characterisation may have to change soon.

Determining the degree of labour market slack has become the central debate at the Fed. Ms Yellen wants to be sure employment has recovered as fully as possible before raising rates. Inflation "hawks" at the Fed, however, worry more months of near-zero rates will cause inflation or possible asset bubbles.

Ms Yellen reiterated that the Fed could raise rates sooner than currently expected if the labour market improves more rapidly, and it could tighten monetary policy later if the economy disappoints.

A slate of academic papers at the conference will dissect the issue over the next two days, arguing for example that the United States' job-generating ability may be on the wane.

A handful of workers in green "What Recovery?" T-shirts are also staying at the resort, hoping to press the case that many American families are still struggling. Reuters

Fewer 1st-class seats on American

Published Sun, Aug 24, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[DALLAS] Three-class cabins on international jets, once a hallmark of passenger pampering, are dwindling at the world's largest carrier.

Waning customer interest in the costliest tickets prompted American Airlines to drop first class as it adds seats to its 47 long-haul Boeing 777-200s. The aircraft will get new lie-flat business seats - plusher than coach, but lacking first-class flourishes such as pajamas, slippers and hors d'oeuvre.

"We're responding to what demand is," Casey Norton, an American spokesman, said last week. "We've looked at what the demand level is for business and also what we need in the main cabin as well. That's where we think we've hit the sweet spot."

ST Engg in Forbes' most innovative companies list

Angela Tan

Published

Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

ST ENGINEERING is the only company in Singapore to make it to Forbes' list of "The World's Most Innovative Companies".

The Singapore-listed defence-related group is ranked 87 out of 100 companies globally, and boasts of an Innovation Premium (IP) of 33.6 per cent. IP is a measure of how much investors have bid up the stock price of a company above the value of its existing business based on expectations of future innovative results (new products, services and markets).

Members of the list must have US$10 billion in market capitalisation, spend at least 2.5 per cent of revenue on research and development, and have seven years of public data.

ST Engineering is an integrated engineering group providing solutions and services in the aerospace, electronics, land systems and marine sectors.

Saleforce.com led the world's most innovative companies' list, commanding an IP of 75.9 per cent. It was followed by Alexion Pharmaceuticals, with a 71.4 per cent IP, and ARM Holdings, with a 65.6 per cent IP.

site_title: Heavy trades in energy-related stocks
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Heavy trades in energy-related stocks

Published Sun, Aug 24, 2014 · 10:00 PM

BUYING was flat while selling among directors was low for the third straight week based on Aug 18-22 filings on Singapore Exchange. Buyers outnumbered sellers with 13 companies recording 27 purchases worth S$1.4 million versus one firm with one disposal worth S$1.98 million. The number of companies and trades on the buying side were consistent with the previous week's 15 firms and 27 acquisitions. The buy value, however, was sharply down from the previous week's purchases worth S$4.05 million. On the selling side, the number of companies and trades were unchanged from the previous week. The sell value, however, was sharply up from the previous week's disposals worth S$100,000.

Besides directors, buyback activity was flat with 11 companies posting 29 repurchases worth S$8.0 million. The figures were not far off from the previous week's eight firms, 30 trades, and S$7.5 million.

There were several significant corporate shareholder trades in the week with buybacks in Chip Eng Seng Corporation and Mencast Holdings and director purchases in Centurion Corporation and Maxi-Cash Financial Services. On the funds' side, there were purchases in Frasers Centrepoint Trust and Super Group. Meanwhile, there was heavy activity in energy-related stocks with substantial shareholder trades in KS Energy Services, Linc Energy and KrisEnergy Ltd.

Chip Eng Seng Corp

Construction firm Chip Eng Seng Corporation resumed buying back at a higher price with 3.5 million shares purchased from Aug 18 to 22 at an average of 86.6 cents. The trades, which accounted for 23 per cent of the stock's trading volume, were made on the back of the 14 per cent rise in the share price since June 12 at 76 cents. The group previously acquired 2.83 million shares from June 3 to 6 at 75.5 cents each, 2.23 million shares on May 15 at 73.9 cents each and 4.78 million shares from Feb 25 to 26 at an average of 74.2 cents each. Prior to the buybacks this year, the company acquired 1.5 million shares in December 2013 at an average of 71.8 cents each, 13.8 million shares in December 2012 at an average of 55.6 cents each and 3.87 million shares from November to December 2007 at an average of 60.4 cents each. The counter closed at 89.5 cents on Friday.

Mencast Holdings

Marine and oil and gas industry services provider Mencast Holdings bought back for the first time since June 2013 with 33,000 shares purchased on Aug 22 at 50 cents each. The trade was made on the back of the 12 per cent drop in the share price since April from 56.9 cents. Despite the fall in the share price, the counter is still up since September 2013 from 42.2 cents. The group previously acquired 250,000 shares in June 2013 at 54 cents each. The repurchases since June 2013 are the company's first buybacks since its June 2008 Catalist and December 2011 SGX Mainboard listing.

Executive chairman and CEO Glenndle Sim Soon Ngee sold 196,000 shares on July 31 at 52 cents each, which reduced his deemed holdings to 70.735 million shares or 19.8 per cent. He also has direct interest of 75.600 million shares or 21.16 per cent. That is the first on-market trade by a director of the company since listing. The counter closed at 50 cents on Friday.

Centurion Corp

CEO Kong Chee Min and executive director Tony Bin Hee Din recorded their first trades in storage disc manufacturer and distributor and dormitory services provider Centurion Corporation since they joined the board in August 2011 with a combined 304,000 shares purchased on Aug 21 at an average of 63.7 cents. The purchases were made on the back of the 18 per cent drop in the share price since April from 77.5 cents. Despite the fall in the share price, the counter is still up since July 2012 from 17 cents.

Mr Kong acquired 154,000 shares on Aug 21 at an average of 63.8 cents, increasing his direct holdings by 895 per cent to 171,000 shares or 0.02 per cent of the issued capital. Mr Bin purchased 150,000 shares on Aug 21 at 63.5 cents each, which boosted his direct stake by 300 per cent to 200,000 or 0.03 per cent.

Executive director Lee Kerk Chong unloaded two million shares from May 14 to 16 at an average of 73 cents each, reducing his direct holdings to 28.376 million shares or 3.75 per cent. He acquired 1.16 million shares from March to November 2012 at an average of 19.7 cents each. The counter closed at 64.5 cents on Friday.

Maxi-Cash Financial Services Corp

Chairman and non-executive director Koh Wee Seng resumed buying shares of pawnshop operator Maxi-Cash Financial Services at a lower price with 481,000 shares purchased on Aug 21 at 28 cents each. The trade increased his direct holdings by 5 per cent to 10.303 million shares or 1.83 per cent. He also has deemed interest of 456.192 million shares or 81.08 per cent. The acquisition was made on the back of the 13 per cent drop in the share price since May from 32 cents. He previously acquired 280,000 shares on Jan 8 at 34.2 cents each. Prior to his purchases this year, Mr Koh acquired 1.32 million shares from February to May 2013 at an average of 52 cents and an initial 3.888 million shares in June 2012 at an average of 37.8 cents. The counter closed at 28 cents on Friday.

Frasers Centrepoint Trust

Schroder plc boosted its stake in retail real estate investment trust Frasers Centrepoint Trust at higher than its sale prices earlier this year with a purchase-related filing on Aug 19 of 7,000 units at S$1.96 each. The trade increased its deemed holdings to 54.930 million units or 6.0 per cent. The filing was made on the back of the 7 per cent rebound in the unit price since June from S$1.84.

The shareholder previously sold 16.7 million units from Feb 6 to May 28 at S$1.68 to S$1.90 and made a disposal-related filing on Feb 5 of 2,000 units at S$1.68 each. Prior to those sales, the group acquired a net 24.8 million units from Dec 23, 2011, to February 2013 at S$1.44 to S$1.99 each and ha an initial filing on Dec 22, 2011, of 46,000 units at S$1.44 each, which raised its interest to 5.0 per cent. Overall, Schroder's stake is up by 20 per cent since that initial filing in December 2011. The unit trust closed at S$1.95 Friday.

Super Group

Matthews International Capital Management became a substantial shareholder of convenient food products manufacturer Super Group on Aug 15 following the purchase of 1.65 million shares at S$1.38 each. The trade increased its deemed holdings to 56.572 million shares or 5.07 per cent. The initial filing was made on the back of the 31 per cent drop in the share price since January from S$2.00. The stock is also sharply down since August 2013 from S$2.45. Despite the fall in the share price, the counter is still up since December 2011 from 64.5 cents. Super Group announced on Aug 11 a 58 per cent drop in second quarter profit to S$15.647 million while earnings in the first half fell by 43 per cent to S$34.284 million. The stock closed at S$1.35 on Friday.

KS Energy Services

Pacific One Energy Ltd recorded its first trade in one-stop energy services provider (for global oil and gas and petrochemical industries) KS Energy Services since August 2013 with 58,000 shares purchased on Aug 20 at 47.8 cents. The trade increased its direct holdings to 298.637 million shares or 58.22 per cent.

The acquisition was made on the back of the 11 per cent rebound in the share price since June from 43 cents. Despite the rebound, the counter is still down since October 2013 from 61.5 cents. The purchase was also made after KS Energy announced on Aug 14 a 44.1 per cent y-o-y rise in revenue to S$59.8 million and net profit of S$46.7 million in Q2 FY14, compared with S$1.5 million in Q2 FY13.

The group previously acquired 7.62 million shares from June to August 2013 at an average of 43.6 cents each, 1.42 million shares from January to April 2013 at an average of 63.5 cents each and 1.64 million shares from January to December 2012 at an average of 91 cents each. Prior to the trades since 2012, the shareholder acquired 56.4 million shares from November 2010 to December 2011 at an average of S$1.05 each and 3.2 million shares in October 2008 at estimated prices of S$1.30 to S$0.83 each. The counter closed at 50 cents on Friday.

Linc Energy

Credit Suisse Investment Holdings (UK) unloaded more shares of oil and gas producer Linc Energy with a disposal-related filing on Aug 18 of 179,000 shares at an estimated price of S$1.30 each. The trade reduced its deemed holdings to 76.593 million shares or 12.99 per cent. The filing was made on the back of the 19 per cent rebound in the share price since May from S$1.09. The group previously sold a net 4.1 million shares from Dec 24, 2013, to April 10 this year at estimated prices of S$1.43 to S$1.32 each and a disposal-related filing on Dec 23, 2013 of 1.78 million shares at an estimated price of S$1.42 each.

Overall, Credit Suisse's stake is down by 12 per cent since Dec 23, 2013. Prior to those net sales, the fund manager acquired 3.35 million shares on Dec 19, 2013, at an estimated price of S$1.46. The group became a substantial shareholder on Dec 18, 2013, after it subscribed for an initial 83.046 million shares or 14.54 per cent in the IPO at S$1.20 each. The stock closed at S$1.28 on Friday.

KrisEnergy Ltd

The Capital Group Companies recorded its first sale in oil and gas explorer and producer KrisEnergy Ltd since it became a substantial shareholder in November 2013 with a disposal-related filing on Aug 14 of one million shares at 75 cents each. The trade reduced its deemed holdings to 62.215 million shares or 5.94 per cent. The filing was made on the back of the 11 per cent drop in the share price since July from 84.5 cents.

The group previously reported a purchase-related filing on Feb 21 of 1.28 million shares at 77 cents each and an initial filing in November 2013 of 758,000 shares at S$1.21 each, which raised its interest to 5.01 per cent. The notices by the The Capital Group Cos since November 2013 are the first corporate shareholder trades in KrisEnergy since the stock was listed in July 2013. The shareholder's sale price was lower than the IPO price of S$1.10. The counter closed at 77.5 cents on Friday.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Start-up Jetstar Hong Kong sells another 3 A320s

But it's still ready for launch once operating approval is granted: CEO

Published Sun, Aug 24, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[HONG KONG] New budget airline Jetstar Hong Kong has sold a total of six of its aircraft because it is taking longer than expected to get a licence to operate. The airline, which is a joint venture between Australia's Qantas, China Eastern Airlines and Hong Kong-based Shun Tak Holdings, applied for regulatory approval in 2012 in the southern Chinese city.

An airline will be given an operation licence only if its principle place of business and centre of its decision-making is in Hong Kong, according to local laws. "Jetstar Hong Kong can confirm the sale of a further three aircraft, now a total of six Airbus 320s, with three remaining in the fleet for launch," the airline's chief executive officer, Edward Lau, told AFP.

The airline sold three A320s this month, and three in April.

"This has been an unfortunate but prudent business decision made by the Jetstar Hong Kong board as the regulatory approvals are taking longer than initially expected," Mr Lau said, adding that the sale doesn't affect the firm's readiness once approval is given.

Mr Lau said that Jetstar is working "closely" with the government and is "confident of gaining all the necessary approvals".

The catalogue price of the latest sale of three A320s this month is US$281.7 million, according to Dow Jones Newswires.

The regulatory approval for the airline has also faced opposition from the city's flag carrier Cathay Pacific, which says the airline is not based in Hong Kong.

"The whole Jetstar network is part of an Australian entity and certainly can't pass the test of being principally based here in Hong Kong," Cathay chairman John Slosar had said earlier this month, Dow Jones reported.

Qantas owns the Jetstar brand and has other joint ventures in Japan, Singapore and Vietnam.

Shipping and property giant Shun Tak Holdings, founded by Hong Kong tycoon Stanley Ho, bought a third of Jetstar Hong Kong for US$66 million in June of last year, helping its bid to set up locally.

Hong Kong-listed Shun Tak is run by managing director Pansy Ho, daughter of Mr Ho, who is also a Macau casino mogul.

The low-cost carrier plans to fly to destinations in China, Japan, South Korea and South-east Asia. - AFP
