site_title: Singapore, Australia to share more jihadi information
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Singapore, Australia to share more jihadi information

Published

Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

AUSTRALIA and Singapore vowed yesterday to enhance intelligence sharing in the face of growing fears about the threat posed by jihadi citizens returning home after fighting in Syria and Iraq.

Ministers from both countries warned of the rising risk posed by the returning fighters who are radicalised and have developed sophisticated skills to carry out terror attacks.

"In this context of counter-terrorism and counter radicalisation . . . we felt that we could exchange more information because these threats, if they materialise, will affect all citizens of all races and all religions," Singapore Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen said at a joint press conference with Australian Foreign Minister Julie Bishop.

Senior Australian government officials led by Ms Bishop are in Singapore for bilateral meetings.

Ms Bishop said Canberra is "also in discussions with our counterparts in Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines as this is not an issue that is isolated.

"If these foreign fighters, as they are called, come back to Australia, come back to our region, then they pose a threat," she said.

"They are hardened, experienced extremists who have undertaken, in a number of instances, terrorist activities overseas," she added.

Australia's Assistant Defence Minister Stuart Robert said the enhanced information sharing with Singapore will cover "the areas of terrorism, extremism, foreign fighters and the growth of homegrown extremism".

The US and Australia this month agreed to take concerns about jihadi foreign fighters in the Islamic State terror group to the United Nations.

The group has overrun parts of Syria and Iraq, and has declared a Muslim caliphate in those areas.

As many as 150 Australians are said to be fighting alongside the group overseas, including at least one Sydney man and his young son who have posed for photos with a severed head.

Prime Minister Tony Abbott's government is hardening laws to make it more difficult for citizens to travel from Australia to fight in the Middle East, and easier to arrest them on their return.

In July, Singapore said it was aware of two Singaporeans currently fighting in Syria along with their families.

Authorities in October 2012 detained a man who attempted to travel to Syria to join the jihadis, while two others have had their movements restricted after their attempts to contact the militant groups.

Neighbouring Malaysia has detained 19 Islamic State-inspired militants who had allegedly plotted to bomb pubs, discos and a Malaysian brewery of beer producer Carlsberg.

In Indonesia, the world's biggest Muslim-majority nation, authorities estimate that 60 of its citizens have joined the fighting in Syria and Iraq.

The deputy chief of the Malaysian police counter-terrorism division, Ayob Khan Mydin, told AFP on Tuesday that the detained Malaysian suspects and their supporters had visions of establishing a hardline Islamic caliphate spanning Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines and Singapore. AFP

site_title: More startups choose to start on digital track
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

More startups choose to start on digital track

But having a physical outlet remains an option to showcase unique strengths

Published

Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

A BIGGER and more diverse crop of Singapore startups have been taking the digital track to sell their wares instead of setting up brick-and-mortar outlets - even though it is not necessarily a more cost-effective way, say observers.

Startups used to have to knock on doors, connect with retailers, distributors or influencers, and make pitches to get their product on store shelves; these days, it seems they just need to be "cool" in the digital space to pull in followers and customers.

Take for instance, Zimplistic, the homegrown startup behind the popular roti-making machine, Rotimatic. It recently sold out its first pre-order batch in Singapore and the US within a mere week of raising the virtual shutters of the Zimplistic website.

It made about US$5 million in that time, selling out nearly 8,500 units of Rotimatic.

Its product demonstration video on YouTube has garnered some three million views since last October - an impressive number, given that more than half (53 per cent) of YouTube's videos have under 500 views, said video advertising platform TubeMogul.

Zimplistic's co-founder and chief executive officer Rishi Israni told The Business Times: "Zimplistic's current strategy is to sell the Rotimatic online. The fact that our pre-order batch sold out so fast demonstrates that this strategy works well."

A digital strategy was also successful for local tech startup Ractiv and its flagship product, Touch+, a gadget that turns any flat surface into a multi-touch one that controls computer functions.

Ractiv's crowdfunding campaign for Touch+ raised more than US$180,000 on Kickstarter last September, exceeding its goal of US$100,000. The startup has since shipped the first batch of Touch + to its backers.

Ractiv ran a dedicated channel on YouTube for videos demonstrating the diverse uses of Touch+; the most recent video amassed some 66,000 views in just a week.

Ractiv's chief executive officer Darren Lim said he is selling the product only via its website for now, because it is easier and it is still early days in terms of sales.

"Selling online, including via crowdfunding, enables us to sell to consumers directly and relatively painlessly, and validate their demand too. It helps us reach the audience we want - technology users and early adopters - more effectively than retail channels," he said.

Singapore-based wearable tech startup, T.Ware, also chose the digital path, despite having a somewhat unique target audience for its product - a wearable-tech vest providing customisable deep-touch pressure hugs that calm individuals who are feeling anxious or stressed.

The award-winning T.Jacket is sold and shipped worldwide. Only customers in Singapore and Japan who want to try on the jacket before purchasing it can do so, as T.Ware has distributors only in these two places.

T.Ware's chief executive James Teh said: "Digital channels play an important role in complementing physical sales, such as for marketing purposes."

The startup's website has an easy-to-use e-cart system, customer testimonials, product demonstration videos and even a jacket-sizing chart, to make it easy for online shoppers.

Still, despite the merits of digital channels, none of these startups has yet ruled out having brick-and-mortar shops.

Zimplistic's Mr Israni said he is looking into the possibility of a physical store.

T.Ware's Mr Teh said that, even if the startup were to have a physical store, it would be where its potential customers are, such as in therapy organisations, special-needs schools or shops in hospitals.

Racti's Mr Lim said he will eventually push Touch+ through physical distribution and retail channels; it is just that the process of arranging for distribution will take time.

"With physical distribution, one has to go through different entities - either a distributor or a retailer or both - and negotiate arrangements such as technical support, credit terms, logistics and price," he said.

That said, brick-and-mortar shops offer a company more exposure and sales volume than online sales can.

"Even for something like Touch+, its most compelling sales pitch is an in-person demonstration, which is something you can't possibly do online. Physical retail lets you experience technology in an up-close and personal way, which is why people would still purchase television sets or Touch+s at a retail store. Physical familiarity is always more reassuring than information familiarity," said Mr Lim.

Traditional retail channels will thus not be obsolete anytime soon, though they may perhaps be re-purposed and re-imagined, he added.

Leading retailers in the US have already coined the term "omnichannel" to describe the future customer journey, said Ken Timsit, partner and managing director at BCG Singapore.

Shoppers will do their research online, browse the physical store's aisles to get excited about the product or simply as a form of weekend entertainment, and then place their order for it through their smartphones while on the go, or back at home.

Mr Timsit said: "This makes brick-and-mortar shops still highly relevant everywhere in the world - even in countries with high to very-high e-commerce penetration like the US, UK and Germany." He pointed out that, contrary to popular belief, it is not always cheaper to sell online than in a physical store. While physical stores face pressure from rising rents and the labour crunch, online stores must bear the costs of home delivery and the ever-increasing cost of being featured on the Google's results page of consumers searching for specific products.

He said: "If delivery costs S$5-S$10, depending on speed, and customer acquisition costs up to S$30 per sale for relatively-hot search terms, the cost of online sales can amount to a lot, relative to a product that is low-value."

But for most companies, the promise of e-commerce is not simply lower distribution costs. It is also a matter of building a deeper and more meaningful engagement with customers.

Mr Timsit cited Amazon as an example. The diversified e-commerce company knows what its customers buy or don't buy, what they look at and what similar customers have bought. It interacts with its customers much more frequently - at least twice a week - and offers far more relevant suggestions than even the neighbourhood shop.

For many years now, Singapore has shown extremely high Internet and smartphone penetration, relative to other countries - well above 80 per cent.

Yet, its e-commerce penetration remains one of the lowest among developed countries, an estimated 1-3 per cent of retail expenditure, said the BCG executive.

This perhaps represents a gap that can be plugged and an opportunity that bodes well for Zimplistic, Ractiv and T.Ware, and the likes who have chosen to go the digital way first.

content:

Jaya in the red for FY14

Published

Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

JAYA Holdings (Jaya), which recently completed the sale of its assets, yesterday posted a full-year loss of US$13.8 million for the 2014 financial year, compared to the US$46.1 million made last year.

However, Jaya's profit from discontinued operations before taxation for the year was US$48.4 million, 6.6 per cent higher than the US$45.4 million the year before. The group reported that its loss from the disposal of subsidiaries was US$60.8 million, contributing to its net loss position for the year. Jaya had sold all its assets for its offshore & marine business to Mermaid Marine earlier this year for S$625 million with the sale completed in June.

Jaya paid out an interim dividend of S$7.7 million to shareholders on Feb 12 with a special dividend of S$482.3 million paid out on June 23. The provision amount for capital reduction of S$123.4 million was paid out on July 14.

Since the sale has now made Jaya a cash company, the group said in a separate statement to the SGX yesterday that it is considering various options available to maximise value for its shareholders. This, Jaya revealed, includes the sale of its listed shell. While the group acknowledged that it will inform its shareholders once a decision has been made, it also said that there is no certainty that it will not be delisted after a period of 12 months in accordance with Rule 1018(2) of the SGX-ST Listing Manual. The counter closed unchanged at 6.4 Singapore cents yesterday.

content:

CapitaLand Treasury prices S$500m 3.8% fixed-rate notes

Mindy Tan

Published

Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

CAPITALAND Treasury Limited, a wholly owned subsidiary of CapitaLand, has priced the offering of S$500 million, 3.80 per cent fixed-rate notes due 2024.

This marks the largest single tranche SGD issuance for corporates in 2014. It is also the largest SGD bond issuance from a real estate issuer in recent years, noted Clifford Lee, head of fixed income at DBS Bank.

"This is the first SGD senior bond issuance for CapitaLand since 2010 and the first bond issuance since 2012, highlighting the scarcity value of CapitaLand paper," added Mr Lee.

The transaction, which had an oversubscribed order book in excess of S$2 billion, attracted more than 115 accounts. About 59 per cent were from financial managers, institutions and banks; while 33 per cent were from private banking accounts. The geographical breakdown was 85 per cent from Singapore, 8 per cent from Hong Kong and 7 per cent from other countries.

This is the first bond issuance since CapitaLand streamlined its organisational structure through the sale of its stake in AustraLand and the privatisation of CapitaMalls Asia.

"Despite a normally quiet period in the market, CapitaLand was able to access strong investor liquidity and take advantage of the low interest environment. At this coupon it has repriced CapitaLand's credit curve," said Mr Lee.

DBS Bank Ltd and The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation Limited have been appointed joint bookrunners and lead managers for the issue of the notes. The issue date of the notes is currently expected to be on Aug 28.

The net proceeds will be used to refinance existing borrowings and to finance the investments and general corporate purposes of CapitaLand and CapitaLand Treasury Limited.

CapitaLand's counter rose 4 cents yesterday to end trading at S$3.37.

They find other ways to continue working as the Ebola crisis spreads

Published Sun, Aug 24, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Singapore businesses with a presence in Ebola-stricken West Africa are cutting down on their employees' non-essential travels and finding alternative ways to continue working without travelling. Most are also taking other precautionary measures to protect their staff's health.

RSP Architects, acquired by the mainboard-listed Rowsley last year, currently has a building project in Ghana in West Africa which is "still at a very upstream stage" and so does not require staff to be physically there, director of business development Hasan Malik told BT. "In the long term, when the project gets off the ground and goes into construction mode, that will be a more fundamental problem but we don't anticipate the Ebola situation to drag out for that long," he added.

Its client has hired local consultants to perform the day-to-day supervisions so it does not actually have to be on the ground. "Besides, in this day and age there are other ways to keep tabs on the project: the local guys can send us photographs of the progress."

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Pretty little Mazda

The new Mazda2 gets neat styling and a fuel-efficient powertrain. By Samuel Ee

Published

Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE latest Mazda2's sharp styling is a reflection of the Japanese carmaker's newfound confidence as it puts years of losses behind it and embraces profitability with yet another new model. The small hatchback is the fourth new-generation product since 2011 to embody Mazda's Kodo design and Skyactiv technology.

It follows the CX5 sport-utility vehicle, the Mazda6 mid-sized sedan and the Mazda3 compact sedan to feature curvaceous styling and a fuel-efficient powertrain within a light but rigid body.

The fourth-generation Mazda2, which completes the marque's lineup by having a model in each segment, is a core model for the Hiroshima-based manufacturer. More than 2.4 million versions have been sold worldwide since it was introduced in 1996.

Unlike its predecessor though, the new hatch still packs the essentials of a contemporary Mazda with its sophisticated functions despite a smaller package. They include going beyond the image of this segment as well as good driveability, both in the city and over long distances. Some of the equipment offered are the MZD Connect infotainment and connectivity system with a centre display and controller knob; and the i-Activesense safety technology incorporating a camera and near-infrared laser. But the most interesting aspect of this new sub-compact hatch is the way it drives because of the completely rebuilt chassis and body. The new car is slightly longer and taller, with the wheelbase extended by 80 mm to 2,570 mm.

The pretty hatch gets the deep family-look front grille - large for the diminutive hatch but not disproportionately so - and headlamps with a penetrating stare. The tail lights are especially sleek but what Mazda designer Ryo Yanagisawa is especially proud of is the profile's "pouncing motion". Like a cheetah preparing for an explosive start, the Mazda2 has interesting sheet metal for a car in this class.

Most mainstream city cars have a one-box shape for maximum cabin space and utility. But Mazda decided to make the A-pillars more upright and positioned the cabin at the rear of the body. In other words, a similar architecture to the bigger Mazda3 with just as sporty a design.

Underneath, the suspension continues to utilise front MacPherson struts and a rear torsion beam but both are newly developed, with the former's caster angle increased for straight-line stability while the latter is better able to absorb impact shock for greater ride comfort.

In line with Mazda's "car and driver as one" philosophy, the vehicle dynamics are geared towards predictable vehicle behaviour and ride smoothness that even tries to minimise passenger discomfort under braking and acceleration.

Three new engines and two new transmissions were developed for the Mazda2 - a 1.5-litre turbodiesel, and two naturally aspirated petrol units with 1.3 and 1.5 litres; plus a six-speed manual and a six-speed automatic.

In the cabin, dramatic design changes mean there are now five styles to choose from, with glossy or matt trim finishes and varying seat patterns and colours.

Most of the design cues are taken from the Mazda3. In the Mazda2, the "cockpit area" flanks the driver and steering wheel with two round air vents. There is another circular vent at the other end for the front seat passenger plus one more hidden in the centre of the dashboard for a cleaner look. The fascia itself and the lower centre console wings can be leather-lined and when done so in a contrasting colour, the interior is especially striking.

With these sweeping changes, the new Mazda2 has raised the bar for city cars.

site_title: Blooming business
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Blooming business

Used to buying flowers on-line? That may change. Tay Suan Chiang meets a few creative florists catering to a growing demand for bespoke flower arrangements

Published

Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

BESPOKE is the new buzzword for all who seek an alternative to mainstream retail. Even as people opt for customised shoes, bags, travel experiences and even cake, why wouldn't flowers be far behind? Sure it's a lot easier to pick something off the website of a major floral gift shop, but there's nothing like having something that's designed with your own personality in mind.

Even as the flower business is dominated by major players and high-end floral designers, a small but growing number of independent florists have appeared in the market, each offering a unique spin on flower arrangement. They're hard to find, though, given that they're such tiny outfits. Most don't even have a website, but the web-savvy will be able to find them through their Facebook or Instagram accounts.

Amy Yap is one such florist. You can find the owner of One Olive on her social media account one_olive, or at her shop in Tiong Bahru. A majority of her clients ask for bespoke bouquets and table arrangements, she says. "Clients share with me the recipient's details, such as what flowers they like, and then I personalise the bouquet with the right colours and textures." With bespoke bouquets, more exotic flowers such as proteas, pincushions and scabiosas can be used.

Marketing director Maria Lee, is one who's sold on bespoke flowers. She used to choose her mother's birthday bouquet from an existing selection at her florist. But no more. "My mum loves pink and white flowers, and she created a bouquet using a mix of pink and white hydrangeas," says Ms Lee. "The bouquet is so much prettier and mum knows that it was specially created for her."

Enjoying all the creativity

Yilian Ng

www.facebook.com/yilianng

instagram.com/yilianng

YILIAN Ng spends her working hours putting together a fashion magazine. At night, and on the weekends, she is putting together flowers. The fashion news editor for the local edition of an international fashion title runs a floral business on the side, and she gets a real kick out of doing both.

"Completing an issue of a monthly magazine is immensely satisfying, especially when you know how much there is to do to just get an article completed," says Ms Ng, 31. "With flowers, it is very fulfilling to know you have made someone's day."

She began dabbling in the floral business earlier this year. Her extended family has been in the flower wholesale business for the last 30 years, and "I've been playing with flowers since my primary school days, so going into the floral business is a natural progression".

She describes her style of arrangement as "a bit of wild foliage touch to tightly packed arrangements. I'm generous with the quantity of flowers because I like the way they look when they are packed together. There is a lot more statement and impact aesthetically."

Nearly half of her clients are corporate clients who want flowers for their events or VIPs. She does a mix of both hand and table arrangements. "Both have different challenges but table arrangements are actually easier because they provide a base for you to work with while hand bouquets have to be perfected while the entire arrangement is in your hand, which can be quite literally a handful," quips Ms Ng. She charges from S$135 for a hand bouquet and from S$155 for a table arrangement.

Some of her favourite blooms include David Austin roses because of their sweet scent, lavender, peonies and hydrangeas. "Most florists shy away from chrysanthemum balls but I love using them because of their symmetry and they are fun to look at and are very lasting," she says.

While clients indicate their colour and flower preferences, they give Ms Ng free creative rein when it comes to arranging. "I love the arts, fashion and design so I'm sure my interest in these areas have influenced my floral designs one way or another," she points out.

Recently, a client wanted her to create an arrangement that was inspired by fashion so she picked out a Chanel Fall/Winter 2014 look and created an arrangement influenced by it.

Ms Ng confesses that she has never had any formal lessons nor attended workshops in floral arranging. "I just enjoy putting stuff together, just like my day job. It is ironic now that I conduct a monthly floral workshop at The Beauty Candy Apothecary in Cluny Court," she says.

Despite Ms Ng's belief that she can make a better living by going into the floral business full-time, she has no plans to do that. "Right now, I'm still enjoying all the creativity I get in both my day job and as a florist. I think when you are a truly creative person, you'll want these sources to be present at all times so you can continuously be stimulated and inspired. It's a very pleasurable feeling, to be inspired and creative on most days."

Vintage and rustic feel

Flower Girl

www.flowergirl.com.sg

BIRTHDAYS, anniversaries, weddings . . . these are just some occasions when people order flowers. For Catherine Strickland, one of the funniest reasons a client ordered flowers from her was "an apology for getting drunk and spoiling book club", quips the founder of Flower Girl.

The granddaughter of a floral artist, Ms Strickland was regularly doing floral arrangements voluntarily for her children's school chapel, friends and charity functions. "I noticed a real demand for my relaxed natural style using Australian natives and European blooms. It was then that I decided to open the business formally," she says, adding that she has a family love for flowers, as it is something that she has grown up with.

"I studied design for many years, and worked in interior design firms. Flowers, design, your home - they are all linked," she says. "I undertook floristry training, and now spend my time using beautiful flowers to complement designs of private homes and events."

She has both private and corporate clients, and her orders range from hand bouquets to large arrangements for private homes and cocktails and dinner party events. A hand bouquet starts from S$90. Ms Strickland also gets requests to create fascinators for ladies attending the Australian Melbourne Cup lunches.

"My style is loose, natural with a vintage and rustic feel," says Ms Strickland. Paying tribute to her roots, she uses Australian native flowers, "for their exciting shapes, textures and longevity in the tropical heat". Some of her favourite blooms include Lucedendron, Kangaroo paws, Pincushions, and Queen and King Proteas.

Clients can choose an existing range of arrangements from her website, or get bespoke bouquets. It can be as simple as having "a little bit of blue for a baby boy or Mum's favourite hydrangeas, and I'll come up with a bespoke bouquet", she says.

She also offers floristry workshops, but what's also popular is her "Little Flower Girl" parties, for girls aged seven to 13, where they learn the basics of floristry and make their own floral headpieces.

"There is great satisfaction in creating something unique - and even more satisfaction seeing faces of the recipients or attendees of an event when it looks so beautiful. I feel very privileged to hear so many messages of love, thanks, kindness and joy that accompany a bouquet," says Ms Strickland.

Uncompromised beauty and style

Hu.ey

www.facebook.com/hu.eyblooms

instagram.com/hu.ey

JASMINE Chan considers herself her toughest customer. When she creates a floral bouquet, not only must it be tailored to the recipient, it has to be a bouquet that Ms Chan herself is happy to receive. "This, to me, is what makes flower arrangement fun," she says. "How do I make an all-pink bouquet not cloyingly sweet, because I am not such a person? Or how do I make a bouquet that I would like out of red roses, a flower which I am not fond of?"

A lawyer by day, Ms Chan's venture into floristry was borne out of a hobby of playing with flowers and gifting bouquets to friends and family. She toyed with the idea of marketing and selling her bouquets, and started Hu.ey this year. Hu.ey is colloquial speak for flowers.

Ms Chan, 28, picked up floral arranging skills from workshops. "Beyond this, the entire process of putting together an arrangement has been self-taught. Knowing what works in a bouquet is essentially an exercise of style and aesthetics, so it's the process of creating various arrangements that has taught me the real lessons," she says.

Of course, it helps that clients typically start by letting her know the recipient's personality, such as whether they are fiery or ladylike. Ms Chan describes her bouquets as unconventional yet arresting. "Unconventional as there may be unexpected combinations of colours and textures. At the same time, I do not think that beauty and style should be compromised. So even though they're not conventional, they get your attention with their style and elegance." A hand bouquet costs from S$80.

"I get my inspiration from the flowers available in the nurseries, and select blooms for my bouquet from there. The spontaneity of working with whatever is available each day helps ensure that all my bouquets are unique, and adds to the creative process," she says.

She spends about an hour at the nursery each time, just picking out flowers, which is why she limits herself to a few orders each weekend. "This gives me a lot of freedom to work with individuals and have fun with their ideas," she adds.

Her latest challenge is making arrangements for men. "I have received queries, and am hoping to come up with something that even the male species would be happy to receive," she says.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

S$22.1m net loss for FJ Benjamin in FY14

The group puts this down to a slowdown in luxury spending and rising costs in Singapore

Published Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

FASHION retailer and timepiece distributor FJ Benjamin (FJB) has posted a net loss of S$22.1 million for its financial year ended June, with a record operating loss of S$12.9 million in the fourth quarter.

The group attributed its lacklustre financial performance to a slowdown in luxury spending in North Asia, coupled with rising costs in Singapore.

For FY2014, group turnover dipped 1 per cent to S$368.2 million; operating expenses inched up by 2 per cent to S$167 million. Its cost-to-revenue ratio was 45.3 per cent, up from 43.8 per cent in the last financial year.

The company's chief executive Nash Benjamin said: "The fourth quarter was the worst we've seen in decades. We faced pressures on all fronts, with falling demand and rising costs."

Overall, turnover in the group's fashion business rose 5 per cent to S$275.2 million; its timepiece business fell 16 per cent to S$92.1 million.

A fair-value loss of S$1.5 million for the group's investment in St James Holdings Ltd and impairment of fixed assets of non-performing stores of S$1.4 million also contributed to the total loss.

For the year, loss per share was 3.89 cents. The board has recommended a first and final dividend of 0.25 cent per share, to be paid out on Nov 19.

The group announced that its business in Singapore, its largest market, was hampered by slower tourist arrivals. The depreciation of rupiah had made shopping more expensive for Indonesians.

The MH370 incident in March also dampened tourist arrivals and spending, which depressed demand for the group's portfolio brands in the fourth quarter. In the first five months of 2014, tourist arrivals from China, the second biggest source market for Singapore, fell 27 per cent.

The group announced that by the end of FY2015, its number of stores in Singapore would be cut back to 35 from the current 40. It will instead focus on expanding to the large, growing markets of Indonesia and Malaysia, raising the number of stores from the current 185 to 202 by FY2015; of the 17 new stores, 16 will be in Indonesia.

Indonesia held up well, with domestic sales there rising by 13 per cent and gross margin remaining constant; however, the depreciation in the rupiah led to a negative share of result from associate of $1.7 million.

Full-year revenues for Hong Kong, China and Taiwan, where the group operates a timepiece distribution business, were also down - in Hong Kong by 33 per cent, in China by 43 per cent and in Taiwan, 45 per cent. This was contributed by the loss of sales from Girard Perregaux, following the expiry of the distribution agreement in February.

Mr Benjamin said: "Looking ahead, we don't expect a meaningful upturn in sentiment and consumer spending in the near to medium term."

But the company believes that its strategy of expanding in Malaysia and Indonesia, and strengthening its brand portfolio in the region will improve operating results.

FJ Benjamin's shares last closed at 19.3 cents on Thursday.

site_title: At least 3 bids for M'sian football league deal
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

At least 3 bids for M'sian football league deal

Contending groups lured by strong viewership and potential ad spinoffs

Published

Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AT least three groups have submitted bids for the privatisation of the Malaysian football league in a deal that will involve exclusive broadcasting rights and which could be worth as much as RM70 million (S$27.6 million) a year to the Football Association of Malaysia (FAM).

According to industry officials, the three are Malaysian satellite-television provider Astro Holdings Malaysia in collaboration with Fox Sports; Zenith Media in a joint venture with IMG Worldwide; and integrated media and television group Media Prime together with Telekom Malaysia.

Fox Sports is a division of US-based Fox Broadcasting Corporation. Zenith Media is the Malaysian unit of global media group Zenith Worldwide while IMG Worldwide creates and manages events, organisations and people in sports, fashion and the media.

Media Prime is a listed Malaysian media conglomerate that owns, among others, the NST Press Holdings and various free to air television stations that include TV3, TV8 and TV9. Telekom Malaysia is the country's national telecommunications carrier that also, through its broadband services, offers Internet-protocol television.

The FAM sanctions competitions like the Super and Premier leagues, the FA Cup and the Malaysia Cup, and Astro, which is listed on the local stock exchange and controlled by billionaire T Ananda Krishnan, has had the exclusive television rights for the past four years. That right, for which Astro had been paying around RM40 million a year to the FAM according to industry officials, expires at the end of the year, which explains the interest shown by the three contending parties.

That anyone would be interested in the local football league speaks volumes about the fascination and keen interest ordinary Malaysians display for the sport. Malaysia's latest ranking in the Fifa (Federation Internationale de Football Association) is a lowly 155th but that has hardly dampened the interest in the local league.

Indeed, matches are normally sold out within an hour of sale openings - the FAM gets to keep 10 per cent of gate collections. More recently, merchandising - caps, badges, even mufflers in equatorial Malaysia - has become increasingly important in increasing revenues.

Standout statistic: on average, 1.7 to 2 million Malaysians watch Malaysia-league football matches. In comparison, an English Premier Cup game, also exclusively aired by Astro, attracts 400,000 to 600,000 viewers, according to industry officials.

It is that viewership - and its potential advertisement spinoffs - for Malaysian football that the contending parties are interested in.

"You can slice and dice it in a number of ways," an industry official told BT. "And with merchandising, it gets better."

Whether the quality of sport itself will improve, however, is anyone's guess.

site_title: Helping the lower-income in their retirement
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Helping the lower-income in their retirement

One way is to set up a National Savings Plan for them, says ARTHUR LEE

Published Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

PRIME Minister Lee Hsien Loong's National Day Rally speech last Sunday brought home the importance of retirement planning. Considering Singapore's ageing population, his message would have caught the attention of many.

As a country, we've done well over the past 49 years. Progress since Independence has brought different challenges. One is the widening income gap. Success attracts skills and wealth which keep us growing. And our safe and clean city is a favourite choice for many foreigners to come here to live or invest.

The rising cost of living is a fair complaint - but that comes with an open, competitive economy that encourages high skills, talent and matching wages. This, however, makes it difficult for the older generation and the less capable to retire gracefully. Many are less educated, earning low salaries, and unable to move into more skilled jobs that pay well.

The government has recognised this and come up with the Pioneer Generation Package and MediShield Life.

At the Rally, PM Lee also announced extending the lease buyback scheme to four-room HDB flats. Putting on the hat of a financial planner, he spent some time on the challenges of retirement.

The rise in living costs and a widening income gap are here to stay as we progress to developed-nation status. Well-educated, highly skilled people earn high salaries, and the rich can leverage on their wealth to create even more wealth.

This will continue to affect a section of society, especially those who are less capable. As a caring society, we should alleviate their burden.

The Central Provident Fund (CPF) and retirement costs have been in the limelight recently. Some people have proposed that the amount available for housing be reduced to allow for more funds in later years.

This idea has its merits but funds drawn down for property need to be paid back with interest when the property is sold - in effect making it a form of investment.

Still, property investment is cyclical and much influenced by market forces. Reducing the quantum of finance available for housing makes for fewer options on where to live but also lower risks if prices fall.

Inflation

Whether housing is an effective hedge against inflation depends on global peace and our nation's continued progress.

Another argument is for the government to issue inflation- linked bonds.

This may look like an attractive option but does not directly benefit the poor unless we place investment and trading restrictions on them. Both would have the effect of reducing liquidity.

The biggest challenge is how to consistently generate returns that beat inflation. The amount of funds can be very large if there are no restrictions and we add existing CPF balances to it. When returns fall below the moving average interest rate, underwriting the shortfall will impact our Budget allocations.

Some argue for higher interest on CPF balances. CPF is already paying more than double the rate of the 10-year SGS bond yield on the first S$60,000 in our accounts. Another group argues for more liberalisation for members to invest their CPF funds. This option is perhaps viable for a minority of members who are well educated and able to absorb losses. Returns are proportional to risks and, in practice, many members may not be able to do better. I have a colleague with an MBA who lost money during the Lehman Brothers crisis!

Any effort to make retirement more comfortable for lower-income and less capable Singaporeans must be simple, sustainable, and place responsibility on the individual.

One suggestion is a National Savings Plan open only to low-income earners. It can also offer fixed deposit options with attractive returns for savers to think long-term.

The maximum amounts saved can be capped at a reasonable figure. Both savings schemes can pay interest above what the banks pay and act as a good savings complement to the CPF.

Annual income can be verified through the IRAS database. Full-time housewives and aged parents may also benefit as relatives place funds in their names.

To make it more equitable, the interest rates can be tiered on a sliding scale to benefit the really poor and elderly.

While not quite like inflation-linked bonds, the purpose would be the same, without the onerous promise to match the inflation rate. It would offer better returns in simple banking terms to those in the lower stratum of society.

Thrift and saving for the future should be encouraged - particularly among lower-income Singaporeans, to help them retire more comfortably and with greater peace of mind.

site_title: Atlantic City hit by impending casino closures
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Atlantic City hit by impending casino closures

Revel Hotel adds to city's growing empty gambling space concern

Published

Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[ATLANTIC CITY] Inside the towering oval atrium of the Revel Casino Hotel, visitors are greeted with a plain printed sign at the base of a four-storey escalator, noting simply that the building will "cease operations" at 5am on Sept 2.

The impending shutdown of Atlantic City's newest casino, after little more than two years in business, will be another blow to what used to be the unchallenged gaming mecca of the East Coast. Not even the popularity of "Boardwalk Empire", the historical drama series on HBO, could stem the decline of the big-casino tourist attractions along the shoreline.

Revel's closing adds to a growing pile of empty gambling, hotel and resort space that the city will be left with when two other casinos close, as scheduled, by the end of September.

In addition to 127,000 square feet of gambling space abandoned at Revel, there is nearly as much at the adjacent Showboat casino-hotel, which is scheduled for closing at the end of this month. And then there is 87,000 square feet at the Trump Plaza, which is scheduled to shut on Sept 16.

Together with 75,000 square feet that was left vacant when the Atlantic Club shut in January, the closings total 413,700 square feet of gambling space, or almost a third of the city's total, according to the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, a state agency that uses gambling revenue for investment projects.

Internet gambling, which became legal in New Jersey last year, so far has not been a significant threat to the casinos. After initially forecasting that online betting could increase industry revenue by US$1.2 billion in the first year, state officials sharply revised down forecasts for both revenue and expected tax receipts, which were scaled back to US$34 million from US$180 million.

"It hasn't come close to what their projections were," said Anthony Graziano, executive director in the Coastal New Jersey office of Integra Realty Resources, a national real estate valuation firm.

Competition from out of state, especially in Pennsylvania, has been the main threat to Atlantic City, overshadowing any issues from the recession or Hurricane Sandy in 2012. Customers in eastern Pennsylvania now have a choice of gambling halls in Philadelphia, Bethlehem, Chester or Valley Forge, removing the need to drive an hour or more out of state.

With Atlantic City gambling revenue in free fall, government and industry officials are turning their attention to how or whether the vast empty gambling halls, and thousands of hotel rooms that support them, might be reused. Revenue at the city's 11 operating casinos dropped 6.6 per cent in July compared with a year ago.

Ideas for reuse include hotels and condominiums, non-gambling resorts, teaching space for local colleges, entertainment venues and "boutique" casinos that offer limited gambling in spaces that are smaller than the large floors that characterise the current generation of properties.

"The one-size-fits-all gaming-floor model is not working," said Curtis Bashaw, co-managing partner at Cape Advisors, a real estate developer, and a former head of the development authority. "It was slot-driven, and slots have been encroached upon all around the market."

Mr Bashaw, who owns a boutique hotel in Atlantic City, argued that the younger customers sought by the city are less interested in "pulling levers" on slot machines than in social forms of gambling that involve more intimate environments.

The city could also build on its history as a traditional resort town that offered beaches, restaurants and entertainment long before gambling was legalised there in 1978, Mr Bashaw said.

"There's a middle path here," he said. "If Atlantic City leverages its resort roots, and looks at gaming not as a commodity where people are bused in, thrown on to a floor, herded into a buffet, and thrown back on to the bus, it can work."

Others contended that purpose-built casinos are not easily remade, and so should be demolished or revived with new capital.

"Casinos are not great conversions to other uses," said Paul Steelman, principal of Steelman Partners, a Las Vegas-based architecture firm for the entertainment industry. "They are custom-designed buildings that are very expensive to operate and maintain."

Mr Steelman said he knew of no successful conversion of a large resort casino anywhere in the world.

He said Trump Plaza should be demolished but Revel and Showboat should be bought by a major gambling corporation and reopened as casinos. Together, they would anchor one of three distinct casino districts within Atlantic City, allowing Revel to overcome criticism that it has failed to attract enough customers in part because it is isolated at the northern end of the city's boardwalk.

Revel has filed for bankruptcy twice since opening in 2012. In July, its revenue plunged 36 per cent from a year earlier, the biggest decline of any Atlantic City casino, according to the New Jersey Division of Gaming Enforcement.

The Revel, a US$2.4 billion building with a 47-storey hotel tower and a complex of wavelike lower floors, has also been criticised for a vertiginous series of escalators leading to the reception desk at the top of an 11-storey atrium.

"Having the lobby on the 11th floor makes no sense," said Gus Sotiriou, 56, a customer who was paying just US$69 a night for his recent stay. "You're going up 11 storeys on three escalators with no guard rails." But he predicted that the building would find a buyer that would correct its design problems. "Somebody will buy it, and make it like it's supposed to be," said Mr Sotiriou, a pension consultant from New Hyde Park, New York.

John Palmieri, executive director of the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, expressed hope that Revel would reopen as a casino, and that Showboat and Trump Plaza could be redone for some other role.

"I would like to think that in the coming months, Revel will find a buyer, and that Showboat and Trump Plaza will find uses," Mr Palmieri said. "It's not as though the casinos have built facilities that can't be repurposed."

He cited the Claridge, a former casino whose gambling floor is now being used as a performing arts centre.

Two weeks before Revel's scheduled closing, vacationers were sunning themselves on an 11th-floor pool deck lavishly planted with grasses and shrubs to resemble a natural shoreline.

Eric Pastuy, 42, a sales manager with an office technology company, said he had stayed at the Revel several times because of its good service and modern amenities.

Mr Pastuy, from West Milford, New Jersey, attributed the shutdown in part to Revel's failure to offer poker, a game that he said would have attracted a younger clientele, and said it already had a reputation as a place where gamblers found it hard to win.

"This wasn't known for being a hotel where you could make a lot of money," he said. - NYT

site_title: Indian state to tap S'pore investment in 6 areas
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Indian state to tap S'pore investment in 6 areas

Published

Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The Indian state of West Bengal has signed an estimated US$500 million in business contracts with Singapore-based companies and investors, including GIC, by the end of yesterday. However, the state's economic architect is still courting the Republic for more investments in six key sectors.

According to Amit Mitra, the West Bengal Minister of Finance, Commerce and Industries, a total of 13 letters of intent (LOI) and commercial contracts were signed yesterday on the fourth day of the West Bengal delegation's visit to Singapore.

Led by Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee, the delegation of 12 West Bengal government officials and 52 business leaders have been in Singapore since Monday on a five-day trip to court investors.

Dr Mitra revealed that GIC has committed to a US$32.5 million infrastructure investment through the private equity HDFC Property Fund in the Kolkata Riverside Development project. Singapore-based infrastructure development company InfraCo Asia also issued an LOI yesterday to Keventers Agro Intra Company for a US$165 million investment for a food park at Dankuni in Hooghly district of West Bengal.

Changi Airport International (CAI) has also revealed to Ms Banerjee that it will increase its stake in Bengal Aerotropolis Projects in West Bengal's Durgapur city to 32.3 per cent from 26 per cent to set up a new airport with the township project.

"The aviation turbine fuel tax is 30 per cent for Kolkata airport, 25 per cent for Delhi and 25 per cent for Mumbai. Changi (CAI) will pay zero taxes when it starts its flights (in Durgapur). They (CAI) were so delighted that yesterday they increased their equity they hold . . . and I believe they will go to 49 per cent and majority (eventually)," Dr Mitra said yesterday at a dialogue organised by the India Club.

Local urban developer Surbana, which is involved in the Durgapur township project, also signed three new LOIs this week with three large West Bengal companies, Dr Mitra revealed.

Singapore-based ports designing company Compass Group yesterday signed a joint venture with Axis Technologies from Bengal. Dr Mitra told The Business Timesthis is likely to lead to an estimated US$20 million deal to enhance port efficiency and automation in the state.

Dr Mitra also revealed that Sanderson Group of Australia, which has a holding company in Singapore, will be establishing a joint venture with Ravi Auto Group from Kolkata to set up a world class amusement park.

Including the current and future value of all these deals, Dr Mitra expects their cumulative value to add up to about US$500 million.

However, he noted that the state of West Bengal is still looking to tap Singapore for more investments. Specifically, he told BT, it is targeting investments in six key sectors - urban development, construction, infrastructure investments, tourism and hospitality, human resource development, and manufacturing.

He hopes this will be catalysed by the setting up of the West Bengal-Singapore Business Centre in Kolkata, which Ms Banerjee announced after her meeting with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong this week.

But the state is not just looking at Singapore as a source of investments but also as a gateway to the rest of the Asean region, particularly Malaysia, Indonesia, Brunei, Thailand and the Philippines.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Central Pattana delays M'sian mall opening

Its first shopping centre in the country will open in 2017

Published

Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[BANGKOK] Thailand's largest department store developer, Central Pattana Pcl, said yesterday it would delay the opening of its first mall in Malaysia to 2017 from 2016 as it needs more time to study the market.

The Malaysian mall will be the first overseas shopping centre to be opened by the company over the next five years as part of a drive to tap into strong growth in South-east Asia.

The company is also keen to open new shopping centres in Indonesia and Vietnam, but cancelled a plan to open a mall in China after a study showed returns may be below target, Naparat Sriwanvit, executive vice-president for finance, told reporters.

"We are working on a construction plan and model for the Malaysian mall. We need to study it carefully," she said, adding Central Pattana will eventually open in two more locations in Malaysia by 2020.

In 2013, the Thai firm signed a joint venture deal with Malaysia's I-Berhad to build CentralPlaza i-City in Shah Alam, Selangor with estimated budget of 5.8 billion baht (S$226.6 million).

Central Pattana aims for average annual revenue growth of 15 per cent over the next five years and plans to spend a combined 48 billion baht over the period 2014-2016 to open more stores in Thailand and overseas, Ms Naparat said.

"We aim to invest about 15-16 billion baht a year to open about three to four new stores a year," she said.

Central Pattana, part of the unlisted retail conglomerate Central Group, is majority owned by the Chirathivat family, Thailand's richest family, according to a ranking this year by Forbes Magazine.

The company competes with unlisted Mall Group, which owns Siam Paragon and Emporium shopping malls in Bangkok and others elsewhere in Thailand. - Reuters

site_title: Maersk Line, MSC to launch vessel-sharing service in Jan
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Maersk Line, MSC to launch vessel-sharing service in Jan

Published

Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SHANGHAI] Maersk Line plans to launch its new vessel sharing service with MSC Mediterranean as early as January next year, and expects to notify customers of the network and transit times by September.

The world's largest container shipper, part of Denmark's AP Moller-Maersk, and Swiss firm Mediterranean Shipping Co (MSC) last month reached an agreement on ship-sharing, a month after China's Ministry of Commerce blocked a larger plan by the two firms and France's CMA CGM due to competition concerns.

The global industry has been battling overcapacity since the financial crisis because new vessels ordered before the downturn have flooded the market. With freight rates still in the doldrums, the companies hope that their new effort at pooling ships will help them reduce operating costs.

The container shipper gave notice of the new, so-called 2M vessel sharing agreement to China's Ministry of Transport in July, Maersk China's managing director, Jens Eskelund, told reporters in a briefing in Shanghai on Wednesday.

Mr Eskelund said that unlike the earlier plan, known as P3, the 2M service did not need approval from the commerce ministry. The two partners were only required to file details of the deal with the transport ministry.

The Ministry of Commerce had said earlier that they rejected the P3 alliance because the three firms would have had more than 40 per cent of Asia-Europe and trans-Atlantic trade, crucial paths in the global trade of goods.

Director-general of the Commerce Ministry's anti-monopoly bureau, Shang Ming, said in an interview with China's state broadcaster last month that he was still worried the 2M alliance could erode the bargaining power of China's import-export firms against big shipping companies.

Mr Eskelund, though, said that the market share to be held by Maersk Line and MSC on the Asia-Europe route would be similar to what other shipping alliances held. "Other alliances have been able to operate similar market shares to the ones that we will have on Asia-Europe," Mr Eskelund said.

Analysts said that 2M would give the shippers less than 30 per cent capacity share on the Asia-Europe shipping route.

Other alliances operating on the Asia-Europe route include G6 - made up of six shippers including Neptune Orient Lines and Nippon Yusen KK.

The CKYHE alliance - made up of shipping companies from China, Taiwan and South Korea - also operates on the route. - Reuters

Jasper warns of potential default of US$165m senior bonds

Published Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE board of Jasper Investments Limited yesterday warned of the potential breach of financial obligations under the five-year US$165 million senior secured bonds issued by its subsidiary Jasper Explorer plc.

The breach could happen as soon as Aug 31 as Jasper Explorer had failed to secure bondholders' approval for waivers and relief of its financial obligations.

Jasper Explorer - whose vessel has not generated any revenue since coming off-hire at the end of February - had asked for a waiver of the maintenance of a minimum liquidity by Jasper Offshore (Cyprus) Ltd and its subsidiaries of at least US$10 million, and for the extension of the due date of the payment to the bondholders of an aggregate US$11.1 million in interest, due Nov 27.

Jasper Investments said that the management continues to seek the support of bondholders and is seeking the sale of and/or contract opportunities for the Jasper Explorer vessel. However, if it fails to secure waivers or other reliefs and is unable to obtain funds from other sources, Jasper Investments anticipates that the liquidity obligation will be breached by the end of this month and the interest payment obligation will be breached in late November.

In the event of a breach of obligations, the bonds will be declared to be in default, and the Jasper Explorer vessel would probably be realised at a significant discount to its FY2014 audited net book value of US$358 million.

The board also highlighted that it might potentially breach the payment obligation for the converted Jasper Cosmopolitan Vessel, which will in turn trigger a cross-default under the terms and conditions of the bonds.

It is anticipated that Jasper Cosmopolitan Pte Ltd will not be able to raise sufficient funds to take delivery of the vessel by Aug 31. In such an event, YiuLian Dockyards (Shekou) Limited will be entitled to sell the vessel to recover the amounts owed.

The company's controlling shareholder, Morton Bay (Holdings) Pte Ltd, has expressed its intention not to provide further financial support of the group's financial obligations.

Jasper shares were last traded at 2.8 cents apiece.

content:

Aircraft lessor Awas plans to add more planes to meet Asia demand

Published

Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Awas Aviation Capital Ltd, the aircraft-leasing arm of Terra Firma Capital Partners Ltd, plans to add more jetliners next year to meet surging demand for budget travel in the Asia-Pacific region.

"The growth in Asia in absolute terms will be enormous for us," Ray Sisson, chief executive officer of Dublin-based Awas, said. "Probably the single biggest factor driving additional Asian demand is the growth of the low-cost carriers. It's created a whole new class of travellers."

Among Awas's biggest customers are Singapore Airlines Ltd and Qantas Airways Ltd, owners of the low-cost Scoot and Jetstar brands, together with Malaysia's AirAsia Bhd and PT Lion Mentari Airlines of Indonesia, Asia's leading discount operators.

The Irish company mainly buys used jets from other lessors and plans to increase acquisitions of such aircraft "significantly" at the start of next year, Mr Sisson said. It has more than 300 planes in service with in excess of 110 operators.

"We tend to focus on having smaller exposures spread around the globe," Mr Sisson said. "There's something inherently valuable in a diverse customer base."

Awas's assets of more than US$11 billion are expected to increase to US$16 billion in 2016, Mr Sisson said. At least 45 per cent of its aircraft will be operated in Asia by the end of next year, compared with 41 per cent now.

Low-cost carriers in the region account for about 20 per cent of seat capacity there, versus 2 per cent 10 years ago, Mr Sisson said. About 10 more new budget airlines are expected to start this year, adding to 47 already in operation, he said.

Mr Sisson said that he's open to partnering Chinese companies as they begin to seek opportunities overseas. "We will be very interested and actively seek to work with these Chinese lessors to help them go abroad," he said. "Awas has the ability to be a partner to them that doesn't actually create competitive tension because we're really set up to be a clearing house for other lessors. Many Chinese lessors specialise in brand-new aircraft."

Awas has asked for second-round bids for about 100 of its newer aircraft on sale for as much as US$5 billion, people familiar with the matter said earlier this month.

Asia's richest man Li Ka-shing is seeking to buy some of the planes in what would be the billionaire's first major investment in aircraft leasing, his Cheung Kong Holdings Ltd said on Aug 4. Mr Sisson declined to comment on the sale.

SMBC Aviation Capital Ltd and Hong Kong Aviation Capital Co are also among bidders for aircraft being sold by Awas, people familiar with the matter said on Tuesday. A number of other lessors in the region have indicated ambitions for expansion.

China Aircraft Leasing Group Holdings Ltd last month became the first Asian player to publicly list. While reliant on China for most of its business, the company said that it is looking to increase business abroad.

Hong Kong Aviation Capital Co, the lessor whose shareholders include China's HNA Group, ordered 70 Airbus Group NV planes worth US$7.7 billion last month. China's Avic Capital Co, the financing arm of Aviation Industry Corp of China, said last week that it's in talks with "relevant parties" to buy Dublin-based aircraft-lessor Avolon Holdings Ltd.

Awas is studying options for a sale or initial public offering as its private-equity owners consider an exit, Mr Sisson said in May. - Bloomberg

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Kong was 'focused on capitalising Xtron to fund wife's career'

Published

Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE prosecution yesterday charged that Kong Hee, the founder of City Harvest Church, had set up an events-management company to do the bidding of the church, and then sought to capitalise it to facilitate the financing of the church's Crossover Project using the church's monies.

Kong, 49, had testified that he had been involved in the 2003 setting up of Xtron Productions, the company established to manage the secular singing career of his wife Sun Ho under the Crossover Project.

Prosecutor Christopher Ong tried to poke holes at the reason for setting up Xtron, citing an Aug 30, 2006 e-mail between Kong and co-accused Tan Ye Peng.

The correspondence had detailed Xtron's cashflow projections in 2007 and 2008; in particular, there were projections that Xtron would need to collect advance rental from the church to solve its cashflow shortfall, and projections that Xtron was to return the church the advance rental.

Mr Ong questioned the need for Xtron to return the church the advance rental; if the services it rendered to the church were real, there would not have been a need for it to return the money.

Kong maintained that the cashflow projections were for planning purposes.

Mr Ong later suggested that Kong had been concerned only with capitalising Xtron so that he could pump more church funds into financing the Crossover Project, aimed at evangelising through Ms Ho's secular music.

Kong disagreed with this.

He admitted being involved in the capitalisation of Xtron, but pointed out that using advance rental to achieve this was "legal and legitimate". He stressed that the services provided were real, not "mindless".

In another e-mail dated Aug 7, 2007, co-accused Serina Wee had proposed how the Xtron bonds could be drafted.

Mr Ong said the flow of funds described the execution of a plan - similar to the projections the court was shown earlier - under which advance rental paid to Xtron from the church was used to cover the costs of producing Ms Ho's album in the United States.

Separately, the church bought S$13 million in Xtron bonds, with part of this money going towards paying Unusual Productions, which leased Singapore Expo to the church.

Kong said he did not know whether this was carried out, and added that if he had been aware of this, he would have asked Wee to seek the opinion of lawyers and auditors to address Xtron's needs.

The six church leaders are being accused of misusing the church's building fund monies to boost Ms Ho's singing career. Four of them also face allegations that they round-tripped monies through Xtron and glassware manufacturer, Firna, via sham bond investments.

SUBSCRIBERS

Showcase of dance in 3 stances

Helmi Yusof

Published Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

MASTERPIECE In Motion, the Singapore Dance Theatre's annual triple bill of established choreographers, returns with the Singapore premiere of Val Caniparoli's Swipe, described by SDT's artistic director Janek Schergen as a "fast-paced, enjoyable, kick-in-the-head ballet".

Caniparoli, a leading American choreographer, created Swipe by borrowing and blending movements from the classical, modern and contemporary vocabulary, as well as hip-hop. The work itself is inspired by Gabriel Prokofiev, a London-based composer who is the grandson of the late and great classical composer Sergei Prokofiev.

Caniporali says: "I was inspired first and foremost by Gabriel's music, and used all of these dance forms and melded them into my own style. Of course, this work could not be performed by any other than a very strong classically trained ballet company that is also very versatile and open. And SDT is definitely that - the perfect company to be performing Swipe."

Staying amid plush velvets, silks

Published Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

FIRST-TIMERS to Bordeaux could do worse than to immediately base themselves at the 130-room Grand Hotel de Bordeaux & Spa. The only five-star hotel in town, it was built in the late 18th-century by Victor Louis, the same architect who designed the equally grandiose Grand Theatre, home of L'Opera National de Bordeaux, across the square, La Place de la Comedie. The generously proportioned rooms are furnished in plush velvets and silks and extravagant trompe l'oeil wallpaper, while bathrooms are kitted out with Nuxe and Guerlain toiletries. Some suites are specially tailored to families travelling with children - they're outfitted with Bonpoint accessories, while a Concierge des Enfants is on alert for the most mundane child-related query. Ask for a room facing the opera house. The rooftop Nuxe Spa with its Jacuzzi terrace and wraparound views of Bordeaux is a real treat.

Other spin-offs on the way

Published Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE Les Amis group is on a roll. The local F&B group is slated to open five new outlets by year-end, including two brand new concepts. The first is Spanish restaurant, Terry's, which will open in October in a 1,200 sq ft space on the second floor of the newly renovated Shaw Centre.

The 70-seater will be run in collaboration with Juan Carlos de Terry, a Manila-based stalwart of Spanish cooking who owns a chain of restaurants, delis, a winebar and a food and wine distribution in the Philippines capital.

At the Singapore branch, diners can pick from an array of hot and cold Spanish tapas, along with signature main courses such as prawns grilled with butter and browned garlic and served sizzling hot in earthenware bowls at the table, and a range of lamb and beef-topped arroz, or Spanish risotto. Prices have yet to be finalised but will be "similar to what you pay at La Strada or Bistro Du Vin", says a group spokesman.

Macan magic

The Porsche Macan with a 2.0-litre engine is currently one of the most popular Cat B models. By Samuel Ee

Published Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LOOK no further than the Porsche Macan if there is still any doubt that Category B COE premiums will continue to stay firm in the near future. The baby Porsche, together with the new Mercedes-Benz C-Class, are currently stoking interest in the market here, and both are doing it with their smallest engines. The Macan 2.0 is the first time in a while that a Porsche has a four-cylinder engine under the hood and which also happens to be inline (the last was the Porsche 968 from the early 1990s).

This is actually the same engine as the one found in the cheaper Volkswagen Golf R but with slightly less maximum power and torque, although the Porsche achieves both earlier than the Golf (both brands are part of the Volkswagen Group).

As a result, the Macan's torque of 350 Nm is available from just 1,500 rpm, thus making this compact SUV extremely responsive despite the small displacement. Mated to a seven-speed PDK dual-clutch transmission instead of the Golf R's six-speeder, the all-wheel-drive Macan also has a wider spread of ratios.

site_title: Prosecution accuses Kong Hee of controlling all CHC-linked entities
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Prosecution accuses Kong Hee of controlling all CHC-linked entities

Minutes of Xtron meeting show Kong being listed as the firm's 'invisible' manager

Published

Fri, Aug 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE founder of City Harvest Church had full control over not only the church but also church-linked entities, including Xtron Productions, the vehicle used to round-trip monies, said the prosecution.

Prosecutor Christopher Ong made the assertion as he grilled Kong Hee, 49, over several documents and e-mail correspondence between the latter and his team.

In particular, the court heard that in the minutes of an Xtron meeting in 2008, Kong was listed as the firm's "invisible" manager, while the church's chief operations officer Suraj was its "ghost" director.

Testifying for a tenth day, Kong said that he was not aware of the Xtron minutes and that as a senior pastor and church founder, he was an "invisible patron" to many organisations.

In 2007, the church invested S$13 million in Xtron bonds.

The prosecution's case is that Kong and five deputies misused millions of the church's building fund monies under the guise of "sham bond investments" made in Xtron and glassware manufacturer Firna, to boost the music career of singer Sun Ho. Four of the six face additional charges of round-tripping monies through the two firms to cover up the misuse.

To add on to his point, Mr Ong referred the court to an e-mail dated May 2, 2006, from American album producer Justin Herz who asked Kong to transfer additional funds to the US for the Crossover Project there. The project aimed to reach out to non-believers through Ms Ho's secular music.

Four minutes into receiving Mr Herz's request, Kong said that he would wire another US$250,000 by the next day.

Mr Ong then questioned the involvement of the Xtron directors, given that Kong has maintained that the directors were the final approvers of these matters.

"Where is the involvement of the Xtron directors? Your Honour, they were the signatories. If they don't sign, the money will not be sent," explained Kong.

Another point brought up by the prosecution - that accounting firm Advante - set up by co-accused Serina Wee, was part of Kong's plan to hide the fact that the six church leaders were channelling church monies through Xtron to fund the Crossover Project.

Wee had said in a July 2007 e-mail to co-accused Tan Ye Peng that she came up with the plan for a new accounting firm, Advante. She added that it would handle the accounts of church-linked entities including Xtron, Attributes Pte Ltd and Urban Entertainment Pte Ltd.

So Mr Ong put it to Kong that the set-up of Advante was "really intended to create separation" between the church and related entities, "as well as to create separation, even between those organisations".

But Kong disagreed. He said that the move was "to better service" some of those organisations. He dismissed Mr Ong's claim that there was something "sinister" and maintained that the bond investments were "legal and legitimate", that the bond proceeds were channelled into the Crossover Project and that the church benefited as a result.

site_title: What effective risk management involves
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

What effective risk management involves

Use it as a strategy to spur your growth objectives, not as a compliance tool. By MELVIN YONG

Published

Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

COMPANIES need to fundamentally shift their thinking about risk management and use it as a strategy to spur their growth objectives, say experts.

"Risk management should not be viewed as a compliance tool to satisfy regulatory, disclosure or reporting requirements," said Neo Sing Swee, a partner with EY, who advises the professional services firm's clients in risk management practices.

"This gives the perception of having to deal with overwhelming mundane risk reporting activities with little or no linkage to business operations or performance."

Rather, an expanded risk management approach should be seen as something that can bring opportunities for companies to grow and improve their performance.

"If successfully integrated and understood, risk management can and should be an enabler to expansion strategies - providing the agility and confidence to move forward through well-defined risk appetite and the necessary checks and balances through risk review, escalation and monitoring," said Irving Low, partner and head of risk consulting at KPMG Singapore.

Critics of an expanded risk management regime have long complained that companies, especially smaller ones, are overwhelmed by the amount of work required for managing risks that they do not enjoy any benefits from such investment.

In two recent studies, however, EY found that companies with more mature risk management practices generated the highest growth in revenue and earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA).

And companies in the top 20 per cent risk maturity generated three times the level of EBITDA as those in the bottom 20 per cent.

But recent KPMG studies show that many Singapore-listed companies are still challenged in determining what and how much to disclose on their risk management processes.

In an April 2014 study, KPMG found that 31 per cent of all queries issued by the stockmarket regulator related to risk management and internal control disclosures.

Of those queries, 29 per cent did not disclose the "effectiveness" of risk management and internal control systems, and 29 per cent failed to even mention "risk management systems".

Strong risk culture a must

Experts suggest that having a strong risk culture and robust governance, risk and compliance system in place is essential.

This should be driven by the right tone from the top, establishing clear roles and responsibilities and empowerment, investing in competencies and capabilities, and integrating risk management into existing processes so that it is not a standalone exercise.

Observers also say before organisations start implementing any risk management activities or framework, they should first ask: "Why are we doing this?"

"If they are just ticking the box because the law or rules say so, then clearly the intention to do it is misplaced," said Mr Low of KPMG.

"Confidence in the organisation will be lost, and to kick-start would require much more effort than the first attempt," he added.

Companies should also actively find the balance between effective risk management and business expansion, noted EY's Mr Neo.

For instance, they can develop a risk-enabled performance management programme that involves integrating risk management into the rhythm of the business.

This means risk management is within the flow of strategic and business planning, operations, oversight and monitoring that runs from the board to line management.

"Companies should require that risks and the uncertainties that drive them are tied directly to business objectives, quantified to identify a realistic range of potential outcomes, and used to challenge or validate the assumptions that go into analysis and solutions," suggested Mr Neo.

There are several practical ways for organisations to assess how much risk coverage they need as well as to optimise their risk management coverage.

In a risk-enabled view of the business, EY suggests organisations will need to ask:

The answers will provide a good view of the company's risk profile, such as how the types, levels and potential impact of the aggregate risk exposures are represented in the organisations' current plans, said EY.

"This allows the actual risk and reward levels to become clearer, and management is able to see the uncertainties and challenges inherent in its choices and investments. This is often a breakthrough moment," said Mr Neo.

KPMG advises its clients that in coming up with an effective risk management framework, organisations will need to establish their risk parameters or risk boundaries.

This sets limits and defines what are considered to be low- and high-risk events. These risk parameters are both quantifiable (such as financial risks) and non-quantifiable or qualitative (such as the impact on reputation).

Once these are defined by management and approved by the board, risks can then be identified and assessed consistently, based on the clearly defined risk parameters.

"This simple approach will help organisations focus on risks which are assessed to be high, rather than all other risks," said KPMG's Mr Low.

"As economic resources are limited, the allocation of such resources should be diverted only to those areas that are more deserving and clearly to those which have a higher impact on the organisation and which may prevent it from achieving its strategic or business objectives," he added.

The writer is general manager - Singapore, CPA Australia

site_title: Raffles Education full-year profit doubles on divestment gain
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Raffles Education full-year profit doubles on divestment gain

Published

Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

RAFFLES Education Corporation yesterday said its net profit for the fiscal year ended June 30 doubled to S$55.37 million from S$26.67 million on gain from divestments.

While revenue fell one per cent to S$127.39 million, other operating income rose 53 per cent to S$102.49 million.

Raffles enjoyed a gain of S$45.5 million on divestment of 490 mu (326,700 square metres) of land and properties in Oriental University City (OUC), and a S$40.8 million gain on disposal of 50 per cent equity interest in Value Vantage Investment and Management (Hangzhou) Co Ltd.

In addition, the group received compensation income of S$4.1 million confirmed by Langfang city government in China in October last year, as OUC had assumed certain liabilities on their behalf in prior years.

Raffles said its other operating expenses also halved to S$63.4 million, in the absence of the net reversal of government grant receivable of S$57.1 million in relation to OUC land restructuring, and on a decrease in rental expense of S$1.4 million.

The group also recognised fair value gain of S$7.3 million comprising S$5.5 million from investment properties in OUC, S$1.5 million gain from land in Raffles University Iskandar, Malaysia, and S$0.3 million gain from investment property in Bangkok.

Consequently, the group's earnings per share were at 5.40 cents, up from 2.66 cents year ago.

A one cent per share final cash dividend has been declared. A year ago, it did not pay out any dividend.

Looking ahead, Raffles said it continues to see positive outcomes from implementing new "transformational strategies" in China, where its college revenue is stabilising. It also sees positive outcomes from its expansion strategy beyond China, while it continues to look at opportunities in other education-related investments to achieve sustainable growth.

Raffles shares ended unchanged at 35.5 cents yesterday.
