site_title: Trouble in a vanilla paradise
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Trouble in a vanilla paradise

Published Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

DYSTOPIAN societies - those bleak places in the future where independent thinking is suppressed and everything is characterised by a sinister soullessness - are all the rage in the movies these days. Whether it's a space station studded with luxury homes (Elysium, 2013), earth in the aftermath of an apocalyptic event (Oblivion, 2013) or a nation ruled by ruthless leaders (The Hunger Games, 2012), it doesn't bode well unless you're sitting at the council table as a member of the privileged elite.

And so it goes in The Giver, the latest in a long line of movies aimed at young adults - those members of the movie-viewing public most likely to partake in unbridled spending at the popcorn counter. Much like the society it depicts, the film - directed by Phillip Noyce, written by Michael Mitnick and Robert B Weide and based on the novel of the same name by Lois Lowry - is depressingly bland.

The pristine community in The Giver has risen from the ashes of some unnamed war and is so devoid of character that it is depicted in black and white. That's because everyone - including teenagers and firm friends Jonas (Brenton Thwaites), Asher (Cameron Monaghan) and Fiona (Odeya Rush) - has a plain vanilla view of life. That's the world they were born into, and that's the way the elders want it. Anyone who can't live up to the standards set by the Elders is "released" to a placed called Elsewhere.

The Chief Elder (Meryl Streep) presides over an annual ceremony where young graduates are assigned specific roles in society. Fiona is tagged to be a nurturer (babies are given to pre-determined parents), Asher is to become a drone pilot (the Community's borders must be protected) and Jonas has been selected to be a Receiver - the person charged with keeping the Community's memories.

No one else has memories of any kind - mandatory daily injections erase them - so Jonas has to train with the incumbent receiver of memories (Jeff Bridges), a sagely type who lives on the edge of town and mumbles to himself a lot. As Jonas learns the history of the world from the Giver, he sees colours, feels emotion and even dreams of Fiona for the first time.

Naturally, he now sees the Elders in a different light and begins resisting their ideas in favour of more radical thinking - like passing on the ability to have warm and fuzzy feelings to others. For personal reasons, the Giver encourages the subversive behaviour and points Jonas towards an outer boundary at the far reaches of the Community. Breach that, and he will free everyone's memories.

Science fiction with a social studies bent is a favoured tool for bashing audiences over the head. The message is simple and straightforward: don't try to change the social order because nothing good ever comes of it. In taking the conformist view, The Giver doesn't come close to being different or creating boundaries of its own. Instead of standing out from the crowd, it's just one more entry in a sea of sameness.

Rating:

C

Where TV cartoons meet contemporary art

Helmi Yusof

Published Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AT one point, a shower of 100 sharp darts appeared from behind the backdrop and rained on the stage. The audience in the first row panicked visibly, and got ready to bolt.

But the "death-by-darts" crisis quickly dissipated as it became clear that the darts - close as some came to the audience - were aimed to hit only the stage. It was a high point in the chaotic carnage that is Mystery Magnet, a theatre-cum-performance art piece staged at the ongoing Singapore International Festival of Arts, which is proving to be as full of surprises as Mystery Magnet.

Audiences might have guessed they were in for a strange treat when Mystery began with a fat security guard inexplicably lying on the floor, face down, in what appeared to be a pristine museum space. When he got up, he was greeted by the sight of strange figures in black jumpers and bulbous wigs. These mysterious visitors were up to no good, carrying out one prank after another.

China factory growth at 3-month low

There are concerns about increasing softness in economy

Published Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[BEIJING] Growth in China's vast factory sector slowed to a three-month low in August as output and new orders moderated, a preliminary private survey showed yesterday, reinforcing concerns about increasing softness in the economy.

The HSBC/Markit Flash China Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 50.3 from July's 18-month high of 51.7, missing a Reuters forecast of 51.5.

It was the lowest reading since May, though the PMI stayed above the 50-point level that separates growth in activity from contraction for a third consecutive month.

site_title: Parkson Retail's Q4 earnings down 36%
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Parkson Retail's Q4 earnings down 36%

Fall in same-store sales in Vietnam, adverse currency effects cited

Nisha Ramchandani

Published Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

DEPARTMENT store operator Parkson Retail Asia reported a near 36 per cent year-on-year drop in net profit to S$3.17 million for its financial fourth quarter ended June 30. This was due to negative same store sales growth (SSSG) in Vietnam, initial losses from new stores and adverse currency translation effects.

Revenue slid 4 per cent to S$99.18 million due to negative SSSG in Malaysia and Vietnam as well as the weaker Indonesian rupiah. Earnings per share for the period worked out to 0.47 Singapore cent, down from 0.73 a year earlier.

During the quarter under review, total expenses fell nearly 2 per cent to S$100.46 million, while total gross sales proceeds were S$246.05 million, down 2.2 per cent.

Share of losses of an associate was S$15,000 versus a share of profits of S$35,000 for the corresponding quarter a year ago.

Its Malaysia operations continued to face a challenging retail environement, chalking up a flat SSSG of -0.8 per cent on subdued consumer sentiment, while its Vietnam operations registered SSSG of -5.4 per cent on weak retail spending in the market. In Indonesia, however, it saw SSSG of 4.3 per cent as consumer sentiment remained robust.

For the full year, net profit was 12.5 per cent lower at S$34.56 million while revenue edged 3.3 per cent lower at S$432.04 million.

The board has recommended a final dividend of 2.5 Singapore cents per share.

"We continue to expand our retail footprint across South-east Asia by opening new stores in our key markets as well as emerging economies such as Sri Lanka and Myanmar," said group chief executive Toh Peng Koon. "We are building on our prime assets, department stores, by continually refurbishing and renewing their offerings such as brand mix and store size. Prudent cost management achieved through economies of scale in our markets, particularly in Indonesia, will allow us to maintain our healthy margins."

The stock closed at 83.5 Singapore cents yesterday, down 4.5 Singapore cents. Parkson released its results after the market closed.

site_title: Living inside a graphic novel
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Living inside a graphic novel

Published

Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

JUST what would an artist have to do for over two days that would justify the time to watch a performance? You'll find the answer in Nikhil Chopra's 50-hour performance art piece, Give Me Blood and I Will Give You Freedom because it's the kind that separates the nominal art-goer from the serious enthusiast.

But it must be said those whose interest was piqued by the effort, and dropped by for even 30 minutes a day to catch this "work-in-progress" from Friday night to Sunday night (Aug 7-9), were immensely rewarded.

Chopra's work demanded only one's time, while it gave back much more in terms of a visceral experience. To witness his durational performance art piece was like stepping into the pages of a graphic novel, watching the story unfold before you - in painting, animation, light and sound, with one solo artist-performer as the main creator of this tale.

Not a single word was spoken, but yet one saw and "felt" the narrative unfold, as paintings were layered on one another of World War II in Singapore and Malaya.

Chopra's work, commissioned by the Singapore International Arts Festival, entailed looking for where the artist's background intersected with Singapore, and it was in the historical event of the Indian National Army during World War II - an army mobilised by Indian Nationalist Subhas Chandra Bose to fight with the Japanese against the British in Singapore and Malaya.

Essentially, the visual arts-trained performer painted on the white walls and the floor (covered with white paper) within a white 330 sqm room. But he wasn't only a mural artist. He married that with performance art as he put on the persona of three different characters for the duration. What really created the magic though were the image projections and animation on the walls.

The clock for Chopra started ticking at 7.05pm on Friday night, when he entered the white room, naked except for boxer shorts, and started painting himself white. An hour later, he mixed black ink, and painted a line across the four walls. He then put on the wig, dress and make-up to transform into "Michelle", which, from demeanour, belonged to the upper crust of society. For over an hour, she dined at leisure as the projection on the wall turned the room into a fancy Mughal-style restaurant with arches and elaborate mosaic, complete with the sound of dinner chatter and the clinking of cutlery and glasses.

If the first night's proceedings were heavy on performance art - with long sessions of silent posing and one moment of "interaction" when Michelle served wine-filled chocolates to everyone in the room - the action unfolded the next morning.

"Michelle" did go to bed (on a mattress in the room) as part of the performance, and on Saturday, awoke to have breakfast, in the midst of a lush, tropical landscape. She set to work soon after, drawing over the projected landscape, sometimes as if tracing it and using it as a template. Sitting in this room, the scene complete with the sound of birds and the breeze, the mood was vastly different from the night before. The calm mood was underscored as well by the "domesticated" sight of a genteel lady, painting a landscape, en plein.

This time, viewers began to appreciate how Chopra had set the stage the night before, that slowly drew us into another world created inside a white box. By the early afternoon, low drones of one or two planes could be heard, and seen, as planes started flying across the landscape while "she" continued to paint .

The action was practically popping later on, as "Michelle" became "Sipahi Seva Singh", a soldier, with a deliberate costume change. In the animation, one plane became two, and then distant sounds of guns firing and muffled blasts, as "Sipahi" painted ominous clouds hanging heavy over the landscape on one side of the room. On another wall, he drew tanks and bomber planes, again, tracing their projections on the wall. Give Me Blood was very much about seeing the process of a story being told, through painting; and who the protagonist-painter was, held pregnant meaning.

From Saturday to Sunday, the black ink-on-white-wall "war scene" took shape and got more menacing - along with the changing animation and light projections - as "Sipahi" also starting blackening the floor.

Audience members - unfortunately, too few - who popped in and out during intervals were often wowed by the dramatic painting and colourful animation unfurling before them on the painted walls. In one unmistakable allusion to the Japanese flag, for example, the red rays of the sun emanated from a corner of the wall.

If you stayed on however for hours at a time, like I did, and saw Chopra in action, aided by the light and sound, then that's when one felt like Alice, fallen into a black hole and transported to another world. The narrative that Chopra painted and performed grew on you, and its impact was greater with the gradual build up.

As a performer, Chopra himself remained aloof and apart - he didn't talk nor make eye contact with the audience. So you felt a little invisible, like a fly on the wall, watching the whole proceedings.

As the performance wound down on Sunday, and the mood changed from destruction to its aftermath - cascading walls of black and then columns of green light streaming down from top to bottom of the walls, blurred faces projected onto the black paint as if caught behind bars - it became clear how Chopra had poetically and judiciously mapped out his entire performance.

For the finale, he methodically taped up the paper on the floor - the central part bounded by bicycle tyre tracks, and painted with a writhing mass of black swirls - creating the outline of a spider web. And the stage was now set for Chopra to change into that role of Kali, the black Hindu Goddess of Death, as he painted himself black all over and stayed in character till the end.

Give me Blood and I Will Give You Freedom (the title based on Bose's rallying call) was performance art at a very accessible level, length of time notwithstanding, where one easily grasped the story and saw the method and process of art-making taking shape.

Kudos must also be given to his collaborators and the "white box" of the theatre space within 72-13, which was also a perfect stage for the work with its dramatic high-ceilinged volume, and enclosed space to facilitate the sense of that world which Chopra was creating.

Organisers too, it must be said, thoughtfully arranged for a pop-up cocktail bar outside, and even arranged for special set meals at the nearby Chop Suey - to "ease" the audience's journey with the artist.

Chopra was wonderfully restrained, and that made his narrative - drawn out in monochromatic message - even stronger. For three days and two nights, mural painting met animation art which made you feel caught in movie set, and the passing of 50 hours - once one breached the first night's performance - became of little consequence.

Crowded places form theme of Archifest '14

Tay Suan Chiang

Published Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

YOU'VE heard it before. With Singapore's population at 5.2 million people, the country has indeed gotten crowded. That could well have inspired the "Crowd" theme of this year's Archifest - a Festival of Ideas for the City.

The annual architecture festival kicks off on Sept 26 for two weeks, to explore the idea of "Crowd" in its different meanings and contexts, specifically in the categories of Collective Intelligence and Community Capital. That is, how people and ideas are connected through places they share to produce a greater impact, and leverage on social capital in building better places for everybody. Archifest, now in its eighth year, is organised by the Singapore Institute of Architects (SIA).

Some of the key highlights this year include a pop-up cafe in collaboration with Toby's Estate; a conference headlining international and local speakers; a series of installations, workshops, tours and sharing sessions showcasing architecture projects; and other fringe events.

site_title: S-E Asia economic integration could worsen inequality: study
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

S-E Asia economic integration could worsen inequality: study

Published

Wed, Aug 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[JAKARTA] A plan by South-east Asian countries to establish a European Union-inspired single market next year could worsen inequality and is likely to benefit men more than women, a new study warned yesterday.

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) has set 2015 as the target to create a single economic market across the 10-nation bloc that is home to some 600 million people.

It is aimed at improving the flow of goods, services, investment and labour around the region, whose economic powers have long faced criticism for failing to work together more effectively.

The single market could add an extra 14 million new jobs and boost South-east Asia's annual growth to 7.1 per cent by 2025, according to the joint study by the UN's International Labour Organization and the Asian Development Bank.

However, the study also warned that the gains may not be evenly distributed, and the plan could increase already large gaps between the rich and poor across the region.

"Unless decisively managed, this could increase inequality and worsen existing labour market deficits - such as vulnerable and informal employment, and working poverty," the study said.

It called for South-east Asian countries to develop policies that support "inclusive and fair development" and to improve social protection.

The study also found that under the plan, the share of new jobs going to women across the region would be smaller than those going to men.

Sukti Dasgupta, an International Labour Organization economist and researcher on the study, said this was due to the sectors that were likely to be boosted by integration, such as construction and transport.

The study found that integration would benefit Cambodia, as well as other lower-income countries the most, while hitting Indonesia, South-east Asia's top economy, the hardest.

Growth in South-east Asia's economies has been impressive in the past 50 years and helped spawn millions of new middle class workers and attract foreign investment to the region.

However, wealth gaps are huge within the Asean bloc. - AFP

SUBSCRIBERS

Bharti Airtel facing tougher battle

Published

Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SINGTEL's Indian associate Bharti Airtel may be facing keener rivalry as British telco Vodafone added 1.62 million mobile subscribers in India in June, closing in on Bharti Airtel as the market leader.

Trade news website Total Telecom yesterday reported that Vodafone accounted for a third of the Indian market's 4.77 million net additions in mobile connections in June, according to new figures from the Telecom Regulatory Authority of India.

This puts Vodafone still in second spot as a mobile operator serving 169.9 million customers or 18.6 per cent of the Indian market, behind Bharti Airtel's 209.2 million connections, or 22.9 per cent share as at June.

Bharti Airtel added 1.01 million subscribers in June, but it is set to boost its customer base with its recent acquisition of smaller player Loop Mobile which had 2.84 million customers at end-June, the article said.

In SingTel's latest concluded first quarter ended June 30, Bharti Airtel's "sharply improved" performance with strong growth in voice and data together with higher margins in India helped offset some of the Singapore telco's decline in core business earnings.

The Indian associate contributed S$191 million to SingTel's share of pre-tax results of associates and joint ventures, which is just under a fifth of the group's overall profit before tax. SingTel owns 32.4 per cent of Bharti Airtel.

In a very detailed report last week, CIMB had reiterated its "upbeat" outlook on Bharti Airtel amid rising voice tariffs and its market share gains led by data in India. Voice tariffs are mobile service rates that a telco charges for calls.

CIMB is expecting a 10 per cent Ebitda (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation) compound annual growth rate for Bharti Airtel from FY14 to FY17, bolstered also by growth in Nigeria which makes up about 36 per cent of its revenue.

This view was echoed by PhillipCapital analyst Colin Tan who wrote last week that he expects "continued strong performance from (SingTel's) regional mobile associates, particularly Airtel, driven by increased customer base and higher mobile data revenue".

Anita Gabriel

site_title: China art in a state of flux
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

China art in a state of flux

Published Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AT first glance, Chinese contemporary artist Yang Yongliang's works look like traditional Chinese ink paintings, complete with smoky majestic mountains and quaint fishing villages. But look closer, and those "mountains" turn out to be clusters of grey high-rise buildings, while the "fishing villages" are actually construction cranes.

These works express the 34-year-old artist's view of China's urbanisation and have become some of his most recognised pieces. They can be seen at the ArtScience Museum till November this year, as part of a group photography exhibition titled Flux Realities, which features 63 photography and video works by seven Chinese contemporary artists including Yang, as well as Zhang Dali, Wang Qing Song, Liu Xiaofang, Ma Liang, Wang Ningde and Wei Bi.

"(Yang) is from a generation that saw China change with a snap of a finger - with tall buildings and the development of the landscape," explains the exhibition's curator, Gwen Lee. "And he's trained in ink painting, so to him, it's like this work is preserving the traditions of Chinese painting using new media."

content:

Hamburg port adds jobs as cargo handling hits record levels

More employed in handling terminals than in 2008 boom

Published Wed, Aug 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[FRANKFURT] The Port of Hamburg, Germany's gateway to the Baltics and China, is adding jobs as a surge in sea freight boosted cargo handling to record levels in the first six months of the year.

Europe's third-largest commercial harbour handled 4.8 million standard containers, or TEUs, an increase of 6.8 per cent, Port of Hamburg Marketing said in a statement on Monday. General cargo handling rose 8.8 per cent to 51.6 million tonnes, the highest on record for the first half.

"There are more workers employed in the handling terminals than in the boom year 2008," said Ingo Egloff, a member of the executive board. "The port economy is specifically seeking and employing more workers." Freight volume is picking up as the shipping industry comes to grips with the overcapacity that triggered the worst price slump since containerisation became global in the 1970s.

Around Town

Published Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Pick of the Week

INSPIRATION often strikes when you're not actually looking for it. For Chinese artist Deng Cheng Wen, it struck seven years ago, while on his university graduation trip around China. He saw a group of young people walking down the street, and suddenly came up with the idea to do a series of art works titled Blind Walking. Starting this weekend, 20 pieces of oil paintings and watercolour paintings from this series will be on display at the Ode to Art Platform.

"I wanted to showcase the mental state of youth in China, and how it is controlled by society," says the 33-year-old artist. "They lose their direction, encounter dishonest people whether in business transactions or personal relationships. I hope to highlight how they should question things and be more suspicious so they will look for the truth."

site_title: Japan exports up 3.9% as overseas demand picks up
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Japan exports up 3.9% as overseas demand picks up

This will help offset weakness in domestic spending, support 'Abenomics'

Published

Wed, Aug 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[TOKYO] Japan's exports rose in July for the first time in three months in a tentative sign that overseas demand is starting to recover, which could raise hopes that exports can offset a slump in consumer spending.

The export data will be a relief for the Bank of Japan, which has predicated its economic growth and inflation forecasts on a rapid rise in exports as part of the government's "Abenomics" plan to energise the Japanese economy.

"The BOJ can say with more confidence that it will keep its monetary policy on hold," said Hiroshi Miyazaki, senior economist at Mitsubishi UFJ Morgan Stanley Securities. "The government has already announced some steps to support corporate activity. Now it is simply a matter of reflecting these policies in next fiscal year's budget."

July's 3.9 per cent annual rise was roughly in line with a 3.8 per cent increase expected by economists in a Reuters poll. It followed a revised 1.9 per cent decline in the year to June.

Growth in exports was driven by increased shipments of cars to Europe, metal processing machinery and items such as liquid crystal displays, the data showed.

Japan's exports have struggled with weak demand in Asia for much of this year and a growing shift in production overseas - which has disappointed officials in the BOJ and the government.

Evidence that exports are finally starting to recover suggests the economy may rebound from a sales tax hike in April, which would ease pressure on policymakers to do more to support growth.

Exports to Asia, which account for more than half of Japan's total exports, rose 3.4 per cent in July from a year ago as automobile shipments grew, finance ministry data showed yesterday, marking the first increase in three months.

Exports to China, another important market for Japan, were up 2.6 per cent in July due to gains in shipments of metal processing equipment and car parts, the data showed.

Exports to the US rose an annual 2.1 per cent as Japan shipped more car parts.

However, exports of cars to the US market tumbled 10.3 per cent from a year ago, the fourth straight month of declines, as Japanese companies shifted production to the US and other countries, a finance ministry official said.

"The data shows exports are recovering moderately as a trend, so external demand may offset some of the weakness in domestic demand ahead," said Takeshi Minami, chief economist at Norinchukin Research Institute. "But export growth is unlikely to accelerate much from here. Europe's economy lacks momentum and this will weigh on growth of Japan's big Asian export markets like China."

Prime Minister Shinzo Abe updated his economic growth strategy in June with a plan to lower the corporate tax rate and offer incentives in special economic zones to encourage companies to expand operations in Japan.

Japan's imports rose 2.3 per cent in the year to July, compared with a median forecast for a 1.7 per cent annual decline, as energy imports grew. That brought the trade balance to a deficit of 964 billion yen (S$11.7 billion).

The economy shrank an annualised 6.8 per cent in April-June, its biggest slump since the March 2011 earthquake, stoking fears that consumer spending had weakened more than expected after the April sales tax hike.

Exports also fell in the second quarter, showing that both domestic and external demand weakened.

Economists expect Japan's gross domestic product to grow around 4 per cent on an annualised basis in the current quarter, but many policymakers say exports must increase to ensure the economy remains on track.

The BOJ, however, has warned that the relocation of factories offshore, particularly for making cars, means that Japan may not be able to ramp up exports at will. - Reuters

site_title: All abuzz over Made-in-Singapore festivals
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

All abuzz over Made-in-Singapore festivals

Homegrown festivals are on the rise as event organisers, some of them first-timers, showcase the hipster side of Singapore to positive public response, reports GEORGINE VERANO

Published Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WITH the gentrification of old neighbourhoods reaching saturation point, it's only a matter of time that the hipster side of Singapore needed to find itself a new home.

The spillover can already be seen in homegrown festivals put together by individuals who are eager to share and showcase everything cool and trendy in music, retail, art, food and more - sometimes all in a single event - to the public.

"Singaporeans are bored with shopping malls and these kinds of events offer something different," explains Lu Yawen, from The Local People, which is curating the market component of the Singapore Art Museum's Night Festival.

There are also first-timers taking the plunge by organising their own events - Sarah Lek and Gabriel Tan are working on Cafe Fest, where 12 cafes will congregate under one roof; while The Ate Group is planning Creatory, a two-day arts and crafts, F&B, music and retail fest featuring about 60 of Singapore's most innovative tastemakers from various fields.

Incidentally, organising a festival wasn't the first thing most of these individuals set out to do; rather, it was an evolution of things that they were already involved in.

"Our initial startup was an e-store... (where) designers (have) a platform to sell their wares and get monetary returns for their original work," says Ms Lu, who adds The Local People's market for the Singapore Night Festival is created with the same purpose of its online store - to promote homegrown products and designers.

Similarly, Ms Lek explains that Cafe Fest was born of her and Mr Tan's experience in organising events for their clients. "We decided to start something for ourselves and go through the full process of conceptualising and executing an event in an industry that we're truly passionate about," says the 27-year-old, who adds that the birth of Cafe Fest was inspired by a magazine article about how cafe-hopping has become the new bar-hopping because new joints pop up every week in Singapore. "Our vibrant cafe culture deserves an event like this (and) we wanted to create the ultimate cafe-hopping experience for consumers."

Likewise, Creatory is set to be a double celebration of sorts as the event also coincides with The Ate Group's eighth birthday. Its executive director, Sharon Chong, notes that local artists are now more eager to show their works so there is a need for more homegrown festivals. Ms Lek believes that the support of government initiatives such as the Singapore Tourism Board's Kickstart Fund would further boost this uptrend and the momentum picked up from other successful events will allow the newer ones to flourish.

Public reception has been more than positive - Kranji Countryside Association (KCA) saw an overwhelming 4,000 turnout at its inaugural Farmer's Market festival in June; while the Singapore Night Festival's attendance swelled from 100,000 in 2008, its first year, to about half a million in 2013.

"For us now, it's not just about size anymore, it's also about keeping it exciting (because) Singaporeans have short attention spans," jokes Singapore Night Festival creative director Christie Chua, before adding on a more serious note that the event has brought a buzz to the Bugis-Bras Basah districts and increased the amount of nightlife in the area.

The positive public reception is integral in attracting participants to come onboard as Ms Chong has found with Creatory already pulling in over 60 partners - despite being an inaugural event - and taking up all eight floors of the building where the festival will be held.

She observes that Singaporeans are beginning to acknowledge the talent in their own backyard; just like how more local music acts are headlining and pulling in the crowd at the Singapore Night Festival. "The festival-goers are thrilled; I think they want to see that it's not just overseas (acts) that can create such hype," confirms Ms Chua.

Jewellery maker Carolyn Kan, founder of her own label Carrie K, adds that she has seen a rise in number, diversity and quality of Singapore designers and artisans since creating Keepers: Singapore Design Collective festival, and running a five-month pop-up retail store in the heart of Orchard Road. Furthermore, a small but increasing number of them are starting to make in-roads internationally, she adds.

KCA executive secretary Manda Foo says that participants should grab opportunities like these to showcase local roots because "even foreigners participate, looking to discover a deeper layer of Singapore from mass consumerism". The industry itself also stands to benefit because she feels it keeps planners on their toes to come up with new ideas and experiences for visitors.

With homegrown festivals looking set to be a win-win situation for everybody involved, Ms Chong sums things up by saying: "It's a great way for Singapore talents to grow organically and attract larger audiences."

site_title: Loaded issues on light feet
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Loaded issues on light feet

Published Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LOADED issues on light feet - that is what the dance doublebill I Stand Corrected/Hatched will be about when it plays next week, with South African dancer/performer Mamela Nyamza and British writer/performer Mojisola Adebayo taking to the stage.

Both artists see art - one using dance, the other using text - as a way to raise issues and awareness, which led to their recent collaboration about very pressing and present issues of corrective rape, racism, rape, child abuse, poverty, patriarchy, tradition and homophobia.

All these issues have been experienced and enveloped in Nyamza's life as a single divorced mother and lesbian in South Africa. "My work is fundamentally informed by my life experiences as a black South African (female) artist, as a divorced single mother, and indeed, by my personal identity as a lesbian woman," she explains.

Inspired by extreme prejudices and discrimination faced by her community - be they women, children, elderly people, disabled people - Nyamza sees her art as dealing with human rights, justice and socio-economic matters in South Africa and beyond.

"My work is not only on one subject matter, it is indeed about a host of other issues," she adds. "And I tackle them to honour our triumphs as artists over adversity."

Nyamza learnt classical ballet when she was eight, and later on won a life-changing scholarship to study at the Alvin Ailey School of Dance in America. "(It) made me regain my confidence as a classical ballet-trained dancer, and be brave to deconstruct all that I was taught in the ballet classes as the normative alpha and omega," she declares.

I Stand Corrected deals with the issue of corrective rape - a growing concern in South Africa. Nyamza's mother was herself a victim of a violent crime of rape and murder, and her tragedy, Nyamza notes, was being too ahead of her times. "Her death shook my world to the core, and caused me to question gender stereotypes in society."

Corrective rape is when men have raped lesbian women, and gay men, or transgenders, in the belief that this will "cure" them of their homosexuality.

The second piece in the double bill, Hatched, sounds autobiographic, mirroring Nyamza's evolution as an artist and her life. Her son, 14, joins her in this piece.

Adebayo, meanwhile, started rapping in the streets as a 13-year-old. Her love for music and poetry led her to study drama at Goldsmiths College, which she hated, until she came across Augusto Boal's Theatre of Oppressed. "That excited me, what theatre could do. I toured with them, and that was a huge influence in my life and theatre-making," says Adebayo.

That experience led to physical theatre which is part of double bill. With her strengths in text, Adebayo seems to have been the dramaturg for the double bill. I Stand Corrected, for instance, looks at this contradiction of what is "correct" behaviour. "We realised that corrective rape isn't about sexuality, but gender and making the 'right kind of woman'," she explains.

That exploration in the dance piece is infused with humour, as the narrative is based on a woman coming back from the dead and trying to find out how to behave "correctly" in the world.

"There is humour in the performance, and interaction; we've found a way to explore heavy subjects. Art can give a safe distance and reflect back in a way that feels accessible," she says. "In London, for example, or other parts of the world where corrective rape isn't an issue, it still has raised all kinds of conversations about equality that hasn't been achieved yet."

Double Bill: 'I Stand Corrected/Hatched', will be held from Aug 28-30, at 72-13 Mohd Sultan Road. The mature theme is for those 18 years and above.

site_title: Somali pirate kingpin arrested: security sources
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Somali pirate kingpin arrested: security sources

Mohamed Garfanji once hijacked giant vessels

Published

Wed, Aug 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[MOGADISHU] Somali security forces have arrested one of the country's most powerful pirate chiefs, who once hijacked giant vessels earning him multi-million dollar ransoms, security sources said.

Mohamed Garfanji was seized late on Sunday in the capital Mogadishu along with several of his well-armed bodyguards, according to foreign and Somali security sources.

There was no official confirmation from the internationally-backed government, and sources could not confirm if he was still being held.

Both the United States and the Seychelles reportedly want to question him for his alleged kidnapping of citizens from both nations.

However, last year President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud offered an amnesty to junior pirates in a bid to end attacks off the Horn of Africa nation's coast, but said it was not open to their leaders.

It was not clear if Garfanji - who was arrested during a disarmament campaign and not for piracy - had received an amnesty.

The notoriously elusive pirate once commanded a small private army. Ships he captured allegedly include the South Korean supertanker Samho Dream, which was released after nine months in 2010 for a record US$9 million ransom.

Garfanji is not the first Somali pirate commander to be arrested.

Last year Mohamed Abdi Hassan, better known as "Afweyne" or "Big Mouth", was arrested by Belgian police after he landed at Brussels airport on charges of kidnapping and piracy. He was lured to Belgium in a sting operation, believing he was to take part in a film on piracy.

Pirate attacks off Somalia have been slashed in recent years, with international fleets patrolling the Gulf of Aden and Indian Ocean, as well as armed guards being posted aboard many vessels. - AFP

site_title: Political instability may cost Selangor dearly
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Political instability may cost Selangor dearly

Published

Tue, Aug 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

GENERALLY, it would not make much of a difference how political wrangles in Malaysia play out, especially at the state level. Indeed, the country's political system seems prone to plunging into a crisis every now and then. Yet, for all the drama and excitement, things usually straighten out quickly.

Unfortunately, the current tussle for power in Selangor - and it is nothing more than that - threatens to stretch out until November when the state legislative assembly is scheduled to meet next.

Embattled Menteri Besar Abdul Khalid Ibrahim has indicated that the loss of support of 30 members of the 56-seat chamber would not make a difference to his administration unless he loses a vote of confidence in the assembly. Clearly, he is fighting for time and hoping for some horse-trading to tilt the balance between supporters and opponents between now and November. This means that the imbroglio in Selangor may have consequences for the national economy.

Selangor is the most industrialised state in the country and accounts for no less than 23 per cent of Malaysia's GDP. (Kuala Lumpur, which is under federal administration, accounts for another 15 per cent of GDP and, together, they form the Klang Valley industrial heartland of Malaysia.)

The state has enjoyed growth in excess of 7 per cent in the last few years and has been projected to grow 6 per cent this year. There is practically no unemployment. On the flip side, the region has suffered from a prolonged drought, which resulted in water rationing earlier this year.

Water levels in its dams are still low. According to the Selangor Water Management Authority, the Sungai Selangor and Sungai Tinggi dams stood at around 32 per cent and 45 per cent capacity respectively last week.

The Sungai Selangor dam supplies water to meet the needs of more than 60 per cent of Klang Valley - with all that it implies for factories located in the region.

Rationing has been put off for the moment but there are some restrictions on water usage and further curbs are in the works. More importantly, the fate of a water agreement signed with the federal government to pipe in additional supplies is likely to hang in the balance until the political issues are settled. Then there was the proposal to build a new toll road system to ease the infamous traffic snarls in Klang Valley. That too will now have to be put off until the political situation becomes clear.

More significant than delayed government projects is the investment climate. Deputy Finance Minister Ahmad Maslan rightly expressed concern over the state's economic and investment climate. "From the economic standpoint, we want Selangor's stability to return as it is important for investors," he said.

Certainly, continued instability would have a far-reaching impact on the national economy. Parties in the dispute should put the nation's interests before their own.

site_title: From the 'new normal' to a 'secular stagnation'
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

From the 'new normal' to a 'secular stagnation'

New e-book looks at how sluggish growth might be taken as the norm

Published

Tue, Aug 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

ARE the United States and Europe suffering from more than the aftermath of a major financial crisis? Might they be stuck in an unusual and prolonged equilibrium, in which frustratingly slow economic growth is the norm?

These are the crucial questions addressed in a new e-book from the Center for Economic Policy Research (CEPR) that I would recommend to policymakers, academics and investors alike.

In 2009, when I was working at the investment company Pimco, my colleagues and I argued that economic growth in the West would fail to bounce back sharply, as it typically does after a crisis-induced downturn. Instead, Western economies would face unusually sluggish growth and persistently high unemployment. We called it the "new normal". The notion was initially dismissed by many as "unrealistic" and then as too "fatalistic".

Now the idea is being reinforced in a major way under the moniker "secular stagnation" - brought to public awareness by the Harvard University economist Larry Summers.

In the book, the CEPR brings together respected economists from different schools of thought - including Prof Summers, Paul Krugman and Barry Eichengreen - to discuss the various possible explanations, which tend to involve three elements: structural headwinds from ageing populations, poor infrastructure, heavy debt burdens, slow productivity growth and inequality; demand that is poorly distributed around the world and, in many cases, inadequate as people channel money towards paying down debt instead of spending; and a "sclerosis" effect in the labour market as persistent unemployment erodes skills and youth joblessness threatens to create a lost generation.

One disturbing finding is that policy measures such as central-bank stimulus may be ineffective in simultaneously delivering high growth, robust job creation, price stability and financial soundness. As Prof Summers puts it, if the macroeconomic goals are attained: "There is likely to be a price paid in terms of financial stability."

Given the enormous stakes for current and future generations, the book rightly argues that serious thinking should be devoted to developing alternative policies. These involve pro-growth initiatives such as investing in education and infrastructure - ideas that have broad support among economists but have been stymied by political dysfunction. A second part looks at more controversial proposals for economic rethinks and institutional revamps, such as increasing central banks' inflation targets or raising the retirement age.

Even today, there are people who believe that Western economies are suffering just from flesh wounds. Others feel that the ongoing period of gradual healing will prove sufficient to achieve economic lift-off, supported by the steadfast policies of central banks. Only a minority believe that something more worrisome may be in play, which is why the CEPR's contribution is so important.

Hopefully, by demonstrating why new economic thinking is needed, the book will raise awareness and catalyse innovative analysis. In any case, the work is extremely relevant to markets, where much of today's pricing seems to assume that the old thinking is still valid. - Bloomberg

Dublin-based Awas (in June 2004, Ansett Worldwide Aviation Services officially changed its name to Awas) has asked for second-round bids for about 100 newer aircraft from its fleet that it's selling for as much as US$5 billion, said one of the people, who asked not to be identified as the process is private.

SMBC Aviation, controlled by Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, and Hong Kong Aviation, the plane lessor whose shareholders include China's HNA Group, are vying with Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing's Cheung Kong Holdings for the assets.

Cheung Kong said on Aug 4 that it submitted a preliminary offer for Awas aircraft.

Hong Kong Aviation Capital declined to comment. A spokesman for SMBC Aviation couldn't immediately be reached.

Awas's assets are valued at about US$11 billion and are expected to increase to as much as US$17 billion in 2016, chief executive officer Ray Sisson said in May.

Terra Firma bought Awas from Morgan Stanley in 2006 for US$2.5 billion and later merged it with Pegasus Aviation Finance, which it took over for US$5.2 billion in 2007.

Asian leasing companies are boosting their fleets as the region is set to overtake the US as the world's largest plane market, spurred by demand from China, India and South-east Asia. Last month, China said it will encourage its lessors to look for opportunities overseas.

SMBC Aviation last month said it will buy US$11.8 billion of planes from Airbus Group in the largest single-aisle aircraft order ever placed by a leasing company, while Hong Kong Aviation ordered 70 Airbus planes worth US$7.7 billion the same month.

A group led by Sumitomo Mitsui's banking arm bought Royal Bank of Scotland Group's aircraft leasing unit for US$7.3 billion in 2012 and renamed it SMBC Aviation Capital. - Bloomberg

site_title: Midtown Manhattan losing rental shine
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Midtown Manhattan losing rental shine

Published

Wed, Aug 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] The lustre is fading on some of midtown Manhattan's shiniest skyscrapers.

Buildings in Midtown, from 30th Street to Central Park South at 59th Street, have more vacant blocks of contiguous office space than at the height of the recession in 2009, as landlords face increased competition from buildings downtown and at Hudson Yards on the far west side, according to a study by Savills Studley Inc, a New York-based real estate brokerage.

"The epicentre of this city has shifted several times before and is in the process of shifting again," Michael Cohen, tri-state region president of brokerage Colliers International, said in an interview. Midtown is "the hole in the doughnut", where landlords are vulnerable to extended vacancies and rents that probably won't rise dramatically.

The area, traditionally the most prestigious and expensive US office market, has turned into one where landlords must market space aggressively, pour money into renovations and seek early lease renewals to retain tenants. The technology and media companies that have driven New York's leasing in recent years have clustered in midtown south, between Canal Street and 30th, or moved to lower Manhattan in search of cheaper rents.

At the end of June, 35 blocks of at least 150,000 square feet of contiguous space each were on the market in Midtown, compared with 31 available in mid-2009, according to Savills Studley. Vacancies may rise next year as tenants continue to consolidate, Keith DeCoster, the study's author, said in an e-mail.

Publisher Time Inc is moving from the Time & Life Building on 50th Street to Brookfield Place in lower Manhattan, while Conde Nast Publications is relocating from 4 Times Square to 1 World Trade Center. Both buildings will need new tenants.

Financial companies are also heralding change. JPMorgan Chase & Co, the biggest US bank, is considering moving its headquarters at 270 Park Ave to the World Trade Center or the far west side, though no decision is imminent, according to a person with knowledge of the matter. Citigroup Inc is relocating its main offices from 399 Park Ave to buildings it occupies on Greenwich Street in lower Manhattan.

New York tenants are opting for value over prestige, said Craig Lemle, a senior managing director at Savills Studley. About 54 per cent of the Manhattan office space available as of June 30 was considered Class A, the highest quality.

Until late 2012, that share had never exceeded 50 per cent in data going back to the beginning of 2000.

"There's enough supply in Midtown to keep a lid on rents for the foreseeable future," said Mr Cohen of Colliers.

Midtown has 270 million square feet of office space, and about 57 per cent is considered Class A. In lower Manhattan, from the foot of the island to Canal Street, about 42 per cent of the 95 million square feet of offices are top-quality.

"Traditionally, the better spaces get rented first," Mr Lemle said in a phone interview. "But in these days of managing costs, we're finding more and more tenants are looking for space that's, quote, a better deal, than for space with better views or more prestige or higher in buildings."

Owners of older properties are competing for tenants amid Manhattan's biggest surge of office construction since the late 1980s. Downtown, more than two million square feet are unrented at 1 and 4 World Trade Center, and another two million square feet are available at 3 World Trade Center, now being built.

Not all of Midtown is weighed down by large vacancies. The Plaza District, home to some of the country's highest office rents, "remains the preferred location" for private-equity and hedge-fund firms, which can afford the costs, according to Savills Studley.

Most tenants shopping for space now aren't set on a particular location and are more interested in the building itself, according to Scott Rechler, chief executive officer of RXR Realty Corp.

"Historically, they'd say 'I want to be on Park Avenue,' or 'I want to be on Sixth Avenue,'" he said. "They're now willing to look at the whole spectrum of submarkets at what buildings specifically meet their needs." - Bloomberg

site_title: Action ashore needed to eradicate piracy
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Action ashore needed to eradicate piracy

Incidents in S-E Asian waters show that menace is not restricted to West African region

Published

Tue, Aug 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

PIRACY has become a fact of life for the shipping industry, to the extent that it is now difficult to remember the time when piracy was almost unheard of. Actually, it was not really that long ago that piracy was almost exclusively something for the history books.

Now, unfortunately, it most certainly is an issue in the 21st Century.

The shipping industry has treated piracy in the same way it faces up to every new challenge. It has found practical ways to carry on with the minimum disruption. It has no other choice but we need to be careful not to regard piracy as just another "peril of the sea". In the past it was virtually eradicated by robust action by governments. The same needs to happen again.

And, just in case piracy is seen as something that happens off the coast of Africa, there is a growing problem in the seas close to Singapore.

The International Chamber of Commerce's International Maritime Bureau (IMB) has just produced its half yearly figures. It says that, globally, 116 incidents of piracy and armed robbery against ships were reported to its Kuala Lumpur-based Piracy Reporting Centre in the first six months of 2014, down on the 138 incidents for the corresponding period for 2013. This year, 10 vessels were hijacked, seven fired upon, 78 boarded and 21 vessels reported attempted attacks against their vessels. Two crew members were killed, 100 taken hostage and five were kidnapped from their vessels.

In a sense, that is the "good news". Overall piracy statistics show a decline. Actually, of course, it is intolerable that any ships at all are hijacked, let alone any seafarers killed.

There are, though, two items of really bad news. One is the awful situation off West Africa. The other is that more small tankers are being hijacked for their fuel in South-east Asian waters. Six such cases of coastal tankers being hijacked for their cargoes of diesel or gas oil have been reported since April, sparking fears of a new trend in pirate attacks in the area. Until then, the majority of attacks in this region had been on vessels, mainly at anchor, boarded for petty theft.

"The recent increase in the number of successful hijackings is a cause for concern," says IMB director Pottengal Mukundan. "These serious attacks have so far targeted small coastal tankers. We advise these vessels to maintain strict anti-piracy measures in these waters, and to report all attacks and suspicious approaches by small craft," he adds.

Captain Mukundan's words are always measured and he does not go in for hyperbole. In the current circumstances, owners and parties involved in the tanker trades need to take his words as a very strong warning. There is no doubt that the authorities in the region are also cranking up their anti-piracy patrols.

Then of course there is West Africa, where 23 incidents were reported to IMB in the first half of the year, with Nigeria accounting for 10 of these reports. Four vessels were hijacked, including a product tanker taken off Ghana in early June and under the control of suspected Nigerian pirates for a week.

Noting that Gulf of Guinea piracy was particularly violent, Capt Mukundan gives an example of an incident in which one crew member was killed and another injured during a shoot-out with armed pirates when they boarded a vessel off the coast of Nigeria at the end of April. A further three vessels came under fire from Nigerian pirates during this period. It is thought that numerous incidents still go unreported in West African waters.

So the region is actually even more dangerous than it seems from the figures. Moreover, the use of armed guards, which has been one of the keys to keeping a lid on Somali pirate activity, appears to have been ruled out in West Africa, at least in Nigerian waters.

By contrast, the number of Somali pirate attacks continues to remain low with 10 incidents reported including three vessels fired upon. No vessels were boarded. However, Capt Mukundan warns, "While we welcome the continued decline in the number of Somali incidents, the risk of piracy has not completely diminished. Ship masters are reminded to remain vigilant and apply the Best Management Practices guidelines."

Created by industry bodies with input from navies, the Best Management Practices assist masters in transiting the dangerous waters in the Gulf of Aden and off the coast of Somalia. But they do not and cannot actually eradicate the problem. That is an issue for governments, and largely depends on effective action being taken ashore.

site_title: Edgy China works
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Edgy China works

Catch the China-banned Ai Weiwei work Untitled among other controversial Chinese artists in Beyond Stuff, reports RACHEL LOI

Published Thu, Aug 21, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AN art installation made up of stools and sunflower seeds might not send a political message; until combined with government intervention, that is.

That's exactly what happened to Chinese artist Ai Weiwei's untitled installation work at the Chinese Contemporary Art Award (CCAA) ceremony in April this year.

It started out as an innocent piece about the history and growth of the Chinese contemporary art scene, but that changed just one day before the ceremony. Chinese government officials showed up at the exhibition venue and forced the removal of the artist's work, as well as any mention of his name, from the entire exhibition.

Singaporeans will soon be able to see what the fuss was all about when the China-banned work comes to the Mizuma Gallery at Gilman Barracks later this month.

It will be part of a group exhibition titled Beyond Stuff, alongside some of Ai's other works, as well as the works of four other Chinese contemporary artists - He Yunchang, Li Mingzhu, Xia Xing, and Zhao Zhao.

Most of the art works will be on sale, and are priced between S$13,000 and S$350,000. Says the gallery's director Sueo Mizuma: "This is the first time the public can see (Ai's) Untitled work, although now the meaning of it is already changed. The thing is, even though it was originally not political, it is now because they shut him down based on his past records. That makes the work very political."

He goes on to explain that while not every single one of Ai's works are critical of the Chinese government, the ones that are, have earned him a reputation as a political activist. One example is an artwork that Ai created in response to how thousands of children were killed by the collapse of schools after the 2008 Sichuan earthquake.

"The artist made a commentary to say the government was supposed to pay attention to how the buildings were built, so the children wouldn't have died," says Mr Mizuma. "The government took it quite seriously because they didn't like Ai Weiwei making such a public commentary on them."

The other four artists taking part in the same exhibition are also controversial in their own ways, according to Mr Mizuma.

He, for example, is a Chinese performance artist, whose work, One Meter of Democracy, involved a doctor cutting a metre-long line on his body - from his shoulder down past his knee - without any anaesthetic.

When asked why he selected these controversial artists for his exhibition, Mr Mizuma explains, "My gallery may be a commercial gallery, but sometimes we want an exhibition with a strong message, to show the artist's mind and soul. Plus, these are major artists and I feel they are important, so I wanted to introduce them to people."

site_title: Diesel cars in vogue now
content:
Diesel cars in vogue now

Fuel efficiency, lower pump prices and improved low-end torque also pull factors

Published

Tue, Aug 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Carbon emissions-based vehicle scheme (CEVS) rebates and the COE recategorisation are fuelling the growth of diesel-engined cars, which has been rising even as the overall car population is slipping slowly.

The population of diesel-powered cars has been increasing by a minimum of 40 to 50 cars per month in 2013, but has since advanced to more than 100 in the last four months.

As at end-July 2014, there are 2,097 diesel passenger cars. Although this number is small compared to the 5,484 petrol-electric hybrid cars and the total population of 609,245 petrol-engined cars, it is significant as diesel cars used to be a rarity on Singapore roads.

That changed in recent years with the advances in engine technology and corresponding reductions in the diesel tax. As diesel engines became cleaner, the government cut the diesel surcharge progressively to 40 Singapore cents per cubic centimetre currently.

But the biggest boost to diesel was the CEVS, and the reclassification of COE Category A for small cars.

CEVS was introduced in January 2013 to make green vehicles more attractive by offering ARF rebates of up to S$20,000 for low carbon emissions. At the same time, vehicles with high carbon emissions have to pay a registration surcharge of up to S$20,000.

Then from February 2014, Cat A for cars under 1,600 cc was re-categorised to include an engine output limit of 130 hp. The aim was to keep luxury models out of this small car category and ensure the Cat A COE premium did not continue skyrocketing.

Together, the two measures helped to make diesel cars a price-competitive alternative. Diesel engines produce lower horsepower and exhaust emissions than petrol engines, so they qualify for cheaper Cat A COEs as well as higher CEVS rebates.

The growing popularity of diesels contrasts with its previous image as a pollutive fuel.

"By and large, diesel is an accepted technology as far as the Volvo brand is concerned," says Sabrina Sng, general manager of Volvo dealer Wearnes Automotive. "It is no longer a major obstacle."

Volvo's foray into diesel models was actually precipitated by the fact that its petrol models' high power rating pushed them out of Cat A. In order to continue offering Cat A cars, Wearnes imported diesel alternatives.

Today, a Volvo V40 D2 with a 1.6 turbodiesel costs S$149,000 including COE, or about S$15,000 less than a V40 T4 with a 1.6 turbocharged petrol engine.

Then there are the advantages, such as increased fuel efficiency, lower pump prices and improved low-end torque. Ms Sng says that all of this makes diesel a more compelling offer.

While there are more hybrids than diesel cars, the population of the former is growing at a slower pace because CEVS benefits only small hybrids, making them more affordable than big hybrids with more expensive components that attract higher registration taxes due to the progressive ARF or additional registration fee structure.

The reason for the relatively large population of hybrids is the previous Green Vehicle Rebate scheme introduced in 2001. GVR gave a 40 per cent rebate on OMV or open market value. GVR was replaced by CEVS in 2013.

At Porsche, diesel models are doing better than their hybrid counterparts.

"The CEVS rebate may be substantial for a small Japanese hybrid but not for a S$500,000 Porsche Panamera hybrid," explains Jason Lim, general manager for Porsche dealer Stuttgart Auto. "Whereas the price of a Cayenne diesel is more acceptable and you enjoy the drive because of the torque."

There is also less concern now driving across the Causeway because of the fuel quality there, according to Mr Lim. This is because Euro 5 diesel is now available at selected stations. He adds: "Those who are more informed about diesel and have experienced it abroad because of travel or studies are able to accept this technology."

SUBSCRIBERS

FAA bars American airlines from flying over Syria

Published

Tue, Aug 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[LONDON] The US Federal Aviation Administration has barred all American airlines from flying over Syria, saying the ongoing conflict poses a "serious potential threat".

The FAA had previously warned American carriers to avoid flying over Syria. The new rule requires operators to contact the FAA before operating in the airspace.

The agency said the move was taken after "updated assessment of risk" and a lack of airlines wishing to fly in the airspace. "The ongoing armed conflict and volatile security environment in Syria poses a serious potential threat to civil aviation," the FAA said.

Airlines have been paying close attention to flight paths over conflict zones since Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17 was downed by a suspected surface-to-air missile last month while flying over eastern Ukraine, where pro-Russia separatists are fighting Ukrainian troops. Syria is in the middle of a civil war in which 170,000 people have been killed since 2011.

The FAA also said "opposition elements" had warned civilian airlines not to provide service to Syria. Armed extremist groups in the country are known to be equipped with anti-aircraft weapons that could threaten civil aircraft, the agency said.

The ban applies to all US-registered planes, commercial operators and FAA-licensed pilots. It makes an exception for flights operated with US government permission and US-registered aircraft operated by foreign carriers.

"Due to the presence of anti-aircraft weapons among the extremist groups and ongoing fighting in various locations throughout Syria, there is a continuing significant potential threat to civil aviation operating in Syrian airspace," the agency said. The FAA this month also restricted US airlines from flying over Iraq while armed conflict raged and the US launched air strikes. - Reuters

site_title: Awaiting the first commercial satellite
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Awaiting the first commercial satellite

New ST Electronics' facility to launch TeLEOS-1 in Q4 2015

Published

Tue, Aug 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Activity in space is hotting up, and Singapore wants to stay abreast of the action.

The global space economy shot past US$314 billion last year, translating to an average growth rate of 6.5 per cent a year for the past five years, noted Minister in the Prime Minister's Office S. Iswaran yesterday.

The minister, concurrently the Second Minister for Home Affairs and Trade and Industry, was at the opening of ST Electronics's new Satellite Systems Centre, a high-tech facility kitted out to support the full cycle of satellite design and development.

The S$60 million centre has a 1,000 sq m clean room for working with sensitive equipment. Up to two satellites can undergo assembly, integration and testing at any one time in the facility, which has laboratories for development work on areas such as satellite altitude control, intelligent power control and ground station infrastructure.

With the facility, ST Electronics is a step closer to its goal of launching TeLEOS-1, Singapore's first commercial Earth observation satellite, in Q4 next year.

ST Electronics has 23 years of experience as a supplier of ground-based satellite communication network and systems. The 400kg TeLEOS-1 marks its expansion into producing equipment for use in space, including satellite components and whole satellites.

ST Electronics also intends to sell the high resolution images taken by TeLEOS-1 as it orbits near the equator, where there are now far fewer satellites in orbit than at the planet's poles. The satellite's orbit, near the equator, takes it round Earth approximately once every 100 minutes.

TeLEOS-1 will thus enjoy the advantage of having the highest revisit rate among satellites, which will pave the way for more up-to-date haze monitoring and maritime surveillance, among other applications.

The Singapore government has been keen on developing the space industry, which creates high-value jobs for PMETs (professionals, managers, engineers and technicians).

To that end, it set up the Office for Space Technology (OSTin) last year. This office comprises agencies such as the Economic Development Board (EDB) and various government ministries, which will grow the sector, using a S$90 million set aside for this purpose.

Mr Iswaran, noting the government interest in the industry for small satellites, said: "Driven by growing Asian demand for satellite-enabled applications... small satellites are expected to become ubiquitous within the space industry."

The opening of the satellite centre is thus an important milestone for the industry. Kelvin Wong, the assistant managing director at EDB, said: "As the first local commercial satellite design and manufacturing facility for small satellites, the centre will enable ST Electronics to leverage its competencies to develop and export new small satellite solutions to the world."

ST Electronics will continue to play a key role in driving the growth of the local satellite ecosystem. Already, it has trained and certified five small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) as suppliers of space-qualified components.

Mr Iswaran said: "Over time, this will allow our SMEs to break into the lucrative global-supply chain for space-qualified components."

Singapore has stepped up the pace of launching satellites into space. With the launch of two last month, the Nanyang Technological University (NTU) continues to lead the way, with four satellites in orbit. It fired up its first only in 2011.

SINGAPORE-BASED BOC Aviation made a net profit of US$163 million for the six months ended June 30, comparable to the corresponding period last year. The aircraft leasing firm, which is wholly owned by Bank of China, had a fleet size of above 250 for the first time as at end June. The reputation of Mr Chan and his team is outstanding and the blend of local talent and international brand equity has spurred the business to tremendous growth in recent years."

He added: "The future looks bright as we expand our services into the office and retail sectors, and support our fund and equity clients with asset-management services."

SWIBER Holdings will fly the Mexican flag on five of its vessels in Mexico to entrench its position in the rapidly growing market.

"With our fleet flying the Mexican flag, the group will be in an advantageous position to offer immediate integrated solutions to fulfil the requirements of the Mexico market," said Antonio Villegas, president of Swiber Offshore Mexico, a subsidiary of the Swiber group.

site_title: Windfall for Gol Linhas' bonds investors
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Windfall for Gol Linhas' bonds investors

Returns up 21% as airline flies record number of travellers

Published

Mon, Aug 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes SA's planes have never been more filled with passengers. That's translating into a windfall for bond investors in the biggest airline in Brazil.

Its US$500 million of notes have rallied since Aug 13, when Gol beat analysts' sales estimates for a fifth quarter and said a record 81.2 per cent of seats on its planes were occupied in June and July.

That's pushed returns on the Sao Paulo-based airline's bonds to 21 per cent this year, triple the average in emerging markets, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

Two years after laying off about 20 per cent of its workers and reducing flights by 15 per cent, Gol has narrowed net losses by more than half.

Moody's Investors Service raised its outlook on Gol to positive this month, saying it may lift the company's rating from B3, the sixth-lowest junk rating.

"The company has been doing its homework and they're on a positive trend," Carlos Gribel, the head of fixed income at Andbanc Brokerage LLC, said by telephone from Miami.

Yields on Gol's US$300 million of notes due 2020, which have fallen to 8.5 per cent from a high of 14.3 per cent last September, may decrease one percentage point more if results continue to improve, according to Mr Gribel.

"The movement of the bonds reflects the improved outlook for the company," Gol chief financial officer Edmar Lopes said. "It shows we're on a different level now."

The airline said its net loss shrank to 174 million reais (S$95.8 million) in the second quarter from 715 million in the same period two years ago. Revenue rose to 2.4 billion reais, beating analysts' estimate for 2.2 billion reais.

The company carried more passengers on its planes during the World Cup, when analysts were concerned that a drop in business travellers would leave more empty seats.

Carlos Legaspy, who oversees about US$350 million in emerging-market debt at InSight Securities, said fuel costs are among the reasons he's shunning Gol's bonds.

Gol's costs increased 20 per cent in the second quarter from a year ago after a 13 per cent jump in fuel prices, a slump in the real and a pick-up in inflation.

"I stay away from the airlines," Mr Legaspy said. "It's a confluence of a fairly elastic demand, a high percentage of fixed costs and a really volatile input, which is fuel. All of those things can conspire in a really bad squeeze."

In an Aug 7 report, Moody's said Gol has implemented "significant capacity adjustments" that balanced its revenue amid weaker economic growth in Brazil.

Latin America's biggest economy will expand 0.8 per cent this year, versus 2.5 per cent in 2013, according to the median estimate from analysts in a central bank survey last week.- Bloomberg

Geo Energy wraps up US$55m acquisition of coal mine

Move will raise its coal reserve bank to more than 40 million tonnes

Published

Mon, Aug 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

INDONESIAN coal-mining specialist Geo Energy Resources has completed its acquisition of a 66 per cent stake in Borneo International Resources (BIR) for US$55 million.

By acquiring BIR, which through its Indonesian subsidiaries owns the new concession (SDJ) in South Kalimantan, Singapore-listed Geo will increase its coal reserve bank from about 11 million tonnes to more than 40 million tonnes.

Geo already owns a 4,570-hectare coal mining concession - PT Bumi Enggang Khatulistiwa (BEK) - in East Kalimantan. The acquisition will expand its presence in the region.

The indirect acquisition of SDJ forms part of Geo's overall strategy to diversify and expand its range of production.

It will also help the group to enhance its product offering. SDJ, which spans a total area of 236.1 hectares, will contain coal with an average calorific value of 4,038 kcal/kg Gross As Received (GAR), comparatively higher than Geo's current BEK concession, which contains coal with an average calorific value of 3,470 kcal/kg (GAR).

This product enhancement is a significant move for the group, which has also targeted shifting its focus to include coal with calorific value ranging from 4,000 to 4,200 kcal/kg (GAR) as it opens up new markets for them.

Coal of this range are highly versatile as it meets the requirements of power plants in India, China and Indonesia.

"With an increase in coal reserves of more than three-fold and a higher quality, we believe that this would be significantly positive to the group's future revenue," said Mark Zhou, Geo's chief investment officer. "Increasing our coal reserve bank is akin to increasing land bank for property developers; this will help us with a solid reserve to be able to take advantage of future upswings in coal prices. Expansion strategy will also be on the diversification of our coal product mix so that Geo will be able to grow both as a international as well as a domestic supplier to the market."

The group also recently announced that it had entered into a mining services contracts and mining cooperation agreement with CV Mandiri Makmur Citra Tambang.

Under the terms of the agreement, it will provide mining services, comprising overburden removal, including land clearing and dewatering, in the concession, also in South Kalimantan, spanning an area of 190.7 hectares.

Geo will also purchase the coal from the concession owner at US$35.35 per tonne, and has contracted for 1.9 million tonnes of coal with a calorific value of 4,100 kcal/kg (GAR).

Geo shares, trading of which was halted yesterday, closed at 27 cents last Friday.

site_title: Foreign planters cast wary eye on Indonesian bill
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Foreign planters cast wary eye on Indonesian bill

If passed, it will cap foreign ownership of palm oil estates

Published

Mon, Aug 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Planters with large holdings in Indonesian plantations, already buffeted by the declining price of crude palm oil (CPO), now have to keep watch on a draft law that could hurt their operations and earnings.

The shares of plantation companies Sime Darby, IOI Corporation, and Kuala Lumpur Kepong slipped between 0.2 and 0.4 per cent yesterday, while Genting Plantations and Felda Global Ventures slid 1.7 per cent, following last week's reports that passage is being sought for the bill proposing to limit foreign ownership of plantation companies to 30 per cent - from the existing 95 per cent.

The draft law is aimed at maximising land usage, protecting the homes and livelihoods of Indonesians and achieving better environmental controls.

Reuters reported that the world's largest palm oil producer, also intends the bill, if passed into law, to have a retrospective effect.

Affin Investment analyst Ong Keng Wee said: "It is a potential negative which will further dampen sentiments already affected by weakening CPO prices."

He pointed out, however, that it was still early days, and that the bill might not be passed, given its potential to hurt foreign investor sentiments.

Maybank Investment also offered this view in a client note: "This development poses regulatory risk, but we believe it may be more politically driven and doubt it would be passed, for it would have negative repercussions on Indonesia's investment climate."

Maybank noted that the bill would hit Malaysia- and Singapore-listed groups with estates in Indonesia, along with Indonesian-listed companies substantially owned by foreigners.

If the bill becomes law, the damage would be considerable. Affin Investment said that, not only would the 30-per-cent limit reduce the growth prospects of the affected companies and hurt their valuations, those valuations would be further hit by the need to sell down.

One option for affected planters would be to look into merging with their Indonesian peers to reduce their equity stakes, although the Indonsian side would wield greater bargaining power under the circumstances.

The bill, which Indonesia's lawmakers are reportedly attempting to push through before president-elect Joko Widodo takes office, proposes to give affected companies five years to comply with the ruling.

Reuters reported that companies which fail to do so can be fined, temporarily suspended or have their licences revoked.

A previous proposal by Indonesia to cap the land bank of foreign-owned planters in the country at 100,000 ha was less damaging to planters.

With the amount of land for oil palm cultivation shrinking in Malaysia over the years, many of the country's planters have sought land in Indonesia to expand their operations; more recently, some have headed to Africa.
