site_title: Analysts downgrade some STI stocks
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Analysts downgrade some STI stocks

Poor profits, stock price run-up and slowing revenue growth cited

Published

Mon, Aug 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE recently-concluded earnings season has not been too kind to a number of Straits Times Index (STI) component stocks. Eight stocks out of these 30 largest and most liquid stocks on the Singapore Exchange were hit by at least two analyst downgrades each.

They are ComfortDelGro, Genting Singapore, Golden Agri-Resources, Hutchison Port Holdings Trust, SIA Engineering, StarHub, ST Engineering, and UOB Bank.

The downgrades came because of different reasons: poor earnings, slower than expected revenue growth, or a run-up in stock price.

OCBC head of research Carmen Lee told The Business Times yesterday that companies that disappointed her included Noble Group, Olam International, Sembcorp Marine and Sembcorp Industries.

But the downgrades were more because of company or sector-specific reasons than a general downturn, she said. The three local banks did well and most property stocks also came in within expectations, she said.

One of the more dramatic downgrades in the earnings season came from Maybank Kim Eng Research's analyst Derrick Heng. He downgraded SIA Engineering from "buy" to "sell" and slashed his target price by 27 per cent from S$5.75 to S$4.20.

The aircraft maintenance and repair play had posted a 22.5 per cent reduction in quarterly net profit to S$53.5 million due to weak contributions from associates and joint ventures.

In a July 29 report, he noted that management had turned bearish on their outlook. "Sinister signposts" include a decline in heavy maintenance workload after a recent expansion in the Philippines and a persistent weakness in shop visits for Rolls-Royce engine shops, he said.

Three other brokers also downgraded the stock to a "sell". SIA Engineering fell from around S$5 on July 28 to S$4.55 yesterday.

Telco StarHub also experienced four downgrades from analysts who shifted their recommendations from "buy" to "hold".

Among them was Phillip Securities analyst Colin Tan, who said that lacklustre earnings, due to lower pre-paid mobile revenue and broadband price competition, were not expected to improve in the second half of the year. He lowered his price target from S$4.50 to S$4.30.

Some analysts also downgraded UOB Bank to "hold" or "sell" after a run-up in price from as low as S$20 at the beginning of the year to S$24 by end-July. Quarterly net profits had missed average estimates and tighter regional liquidity is showing up in lower net interest margins, deteriorating asset quality and a lack of deposit growth, said JP Morgan analyst Harsh Wardhan Modi.

"These issues will likely persist, leading to lower quarterly earnings, at least for the rest of the year," he said as he downgraded the stock to "underweight" with a target price of S$22.

Out of the three local banks, DBS remains most favoured by analysts due to its relatively cheaper valuations. It has 24 "buy" calls, three "hold" calls and no "sell" calls.

DBS joins Keppel Corp and CapitaLand as the only three STI stocks with no "sell" calls.

Said Credit Suisse analyst Anand Swaminathan in a recent note: "Q2 results bolster our view that DBS should have the best earnings momentum over the next few quarters ... UOB's outperformance could potentially reverse in the second half."

Meanwhile, container port play Hutchison Port Holdings Trust saw a downgrade by AmFraser to "hold" given decreasing margins until the shipping industry turns around.

And aerospace and defence conglomerate ST Engineering was downgraded by DBS Group Research to "hold" due to weak profitability especially in the marine and land systems segments. "Overall group profit before tax margin of 10.3 per cent was the weakest since Q1 2011," analyst Suvro Sarkar said.

site_title: Eratat unit forged 577m yuan bank statement: CBRC
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Eratat unit forged 577m yuan bank statement: CBRC

Unit's representatives might have posed as staff of Agricultural Bank of China

Published

Mon, Aug 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE trail of missing cash at mainboard-listed China fashion company Eratat Lifestyle has led to more concrete evidence of fraud.

The Fujian office of China's bank regulator China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC) has found that an Agricultural Bank of China (ABC) bank document purportedly showing a cash balance of 577 million yuan (S$117 million) in an Eratat subsidiary bank account was forged by the subsidiary.

Even more egregiously, representatives of the subsidiary might have impersonated as ABC bank staff to reassure visiting independent auditors and company directors that everything was okay.

They apparently used the bank's Jinjiang Chendai Branch premises earlier this year, verifying the forged bank statement as true. They even informed the visitors that the Eratat subsidiary concerned was a good customer and did not have any loans with the bank.

Eratat's interim judicial manager Hamish Alexander Christie of restructuring specialist Borrelli Walsh disclosed the CBRC findings in an announcement on the Singapore Exchange yesterday. He is seeking legal advice and "preparing further enquiries of the CBRC and/or application for a review of this opinion of CBRC in Fujian by the state CBRC".

The news is likely to hit retail investors, who own about three quarters of the company. Eratat had a market valuation of almost S$50 million before trading was suspended in January.

A subsidiary of well-known Hong Kong finance company Sun Hung Kai and Co has also lent 134 million yuan to Eratat last June in a bond issue.

It was the failure of Eratat to make a coupon payment of 4.2 million yuan last December that triggered this chain of events.

Eratat former CEO Lin Jiancheng had assured directors and the bondholder that the payment was coming and that Eratat had cash balances of 640 million yuan as at Jan 24. But he was unable to satisfactorily explain why the payment could not be made, audit committee chairman Lim Yeow Hua said in end-January.

As a result, the audit committee called for a trading halt in Eratat shares on Jan 27 and suspended the CEO from his duties.

Auditors and directors then made an impromptu visit to ABC's branch in Jinjiang Chendai where they supposedly met ABC staff. They were subsequently stymied in their attempt to clarify inconsistencies on the purported Eratat subsidiary bank statement.

Eratat then approached ABC Bank's Beijing headquarters, which informed them that the Eratat subsidiary, HMW, only had a balance of 73,321.63 yuan (S$15,000) at end-2013.

ABC Beijing added that HMW also had bank borrowings of 34 million yuan as well as trade bills of 30 million yuan at end-2013.

In a May 30 announcement, Eratat said it lodged reports with CBRC and Singapore's Commercial Affairs Division. It was unable to raise funds to pay for a special audit. Interim CEO Ho Ker Chern, who was chief financial officer since 2007, also quit. The bondholder applied successfully to Singapore's High Court to appoint the interim judicial manager to manage Eratat's affairs to see if a better solution rather than a winding-up can be found.

For now, investors are left wondering how the investment community had got the company so wrong.

Eratat listed as a sports footwear company in 2008, reporting growing revenues and profits. But Eratat executive director Ye Sanzhi sold off his entire 6.77 per cent stake for S$4.44 million last August.

Last November, Eratat was awarded runner-up in the "Most Transparent Company Award 2013, Mainboard Small Caps Category", by the Securities Investors Association of Singapore. The same month, with the company trading at about nine cents a share, Voyage Research had an "increase exposure" call on the company with a target price of 28 cents a share.

Eratat shares last changed hands in January at 10 cents.

site_title: Further monetary easing seen helping EU nations
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Further monetary easing seen helping EU nations

Published

Mon, Aug 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE European Central Bank is facing increasing calls from economists, the Financial Times, Bloomberg and other media to urgently boost liquidity to counter potential recession in Europe as growth falters in major European Union countries.

The calls for quantitative easing (QE) - bond and other asset purchases to flood bank reserves - followed worse than expected second quarter growth in Germany, France and Italy and a slide in production in Europe. ECB president, Mario Draghi has already announced interest rate cuts and attractive loans to banks to encourage them to lend more money to businesses. But economists and the media want full scale QE to regenerate contracting and stagnant economies.

In particular they are fretting that EU sanctions against Russia and its counter sanctions against EU agricultural products, will drag economies downwards. Poor second-quarter economic results illustrate that business sentiment and direct investment in job creating factories, plant and equipment have deteriorated. Germany's GDP contracted by 0.2 per cent in the second quarter this year, France has experienced zero growth in the first and second quarters and Italy has been in recession in the first half of the year . All three countries are especially vulnerable to Russian sanctions and counter sanctions. Germany, in particular, is highly dependent on oil and gas flows from Russia and prices may rise in the northern hemisphere winter.

"Europe now needs full-blown QE," trumpeted the Financial Times. "It is hard to imagine how much more evidence European policy makers need before conceding their eurozone growth plan is not working."

"Since the eurozone crisis began in 2010, the authorities have been consistently late to grasp the true nature of the issue and slow to respond," complained the FT. "Their tardiness has caused unnecessary economic pain across much of the continent. This week's alarming new evidence that the eurozone is sliding towards deflation and stagnation must persuade governments and the ECB to get ahead of the problem once and for all."

The belief that QE is on the way, boosted European markets towards the end of last week, but markets fell from their peak on worries that Russian forces would help rebels in eastern Ukraine.

Critics of QE such as Brendan Brown, head of Economic Research at Mitsubishi UFJ Securities International, maintain that QE at best would be a mere palliative. Mr Brown notes that despite extensive US Fed QE that economic recovery in the US has been relatively weak. Excess liquidity has poured into US and global financial assets.

But since business people have feared that stock market booms would falter and crash and lead to recession, they have refrained from boosting job creating capital investment, Mr Brown says. Moreover in Europe, the German Bundesbank, the nation's central bank, has so far opposed QE, according to currency strategists.

Meanwhile, austerity policies aggravated by geo political events, notably the Ukraine crisis, the EU's Russian sanctions policy and fears about Iraq and Iran, are causing businesses to hold back on expansion and investment, economists say.

The ZEW Indicator of Economic Sentiment for Germany declined significantly in August for the eighth consecutive time and tumbled to its lowest level since December 2012.

Dr Frieder Mokinski of ZEW, Germany's Centre for Economic Research, said that ongoing geopolitical tensions had "markedly reduced industrial production". "Incoming orders suggest markedly reduced investment activities on the part of German firms against the backdrop of uncertain sales prospects."

Inflation has also fallen sharply in the region and could decline further as Russia is banning food imports from the EU, thus causing a glut of produce within Europe. The fear is that falling prices will turn into a deflationary spiral, where consumers and businesses delay purchases because they expect prices to fall further. This in turn would cause companies to fail and unemployment to rise, leading to a further economic downturn.

Since tax revenue would decline in those circumstances, government deficits would increase. The eurozone's massive debt burden would then worsen, leading to another euro crisis in the coming year or two, economists warn.

site_title: Global rubber glut seen tumbling in '15
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Global rubber glut seen tumbling in '15

Demand expected to expand while production drops amid falling prices

Published

Mon, Aug 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[BANGKOK] The global surplus of natural rubber will shrink 46 per cent next year as demand expands and farmers reduce tapping because of decreasing prices, according to the International Rubber Study Group.

Production next year will outpace demand by 202,000 tonnes against 371,000 tonnes this year and 650,000 tonnes last year, the Singapore- based body said in an e-mail on Aug 13. The group said in May that the glut this year would exceed the 714,000 tonnes in 2013 after it increased output estimates for Thailand, the biggest shipper.

Futures plunged 28 per cent this year, declining to the lowest level in almost five years in June. Supply increased after record prices three years ago spurred output, while demand slowed as the pace of economic expansion decelerated in China, the biggest buyer.

The glut is now contracting as profits decrease for small farmers who represent 80 per cent of world supply amid forecasts for record global car sales.

"Small growers across producing regions have started responding to a consistent decline in prices," said Lekshmi Nair, senior economist at the group.

Farmers are showing less enthusiasm for tapping while tyre demand is boosting usage, she said in the e-mail. The inter-governmental group has members from producing and consuming nations and industry.

Futures in Tokyo, the global benchmark, plunged to a five- year low of 190.3 yen (US$1,858 a tonne) on June 5 after reaching a record 535.7 yen in February 2011.

Global stockpiles are still expanding. Inventories will reach 3.79 million tonnes by the end of this year and 4.33 million tonnes by next year, according to The Rubber Economist Ltd. Reserves will increase to the equivalent of 3.9 months of consumption at the end of 2014 from 2.5 months a year earlier, the London-based independent researcher said by e-mail on Aug. 15.

"We don't expect to see an end of ample supply," Carsten Fritsch, an analyst at Commerzbank AG in Frankfurt, said in an e-mail. "Demand growth will find it hard to catch up. We do not see a major scope for prices to recover."

World inventories were 2.9 million tonnes at the end of 2013 from 2.26 million tonnes a year earlier, study group data show.

"The continued decline in natural rubber prices and a slower-than-expected recovery in global demand as well as increased supply have led to an inventory buildup," Ms Nair said.

Production from growers representing 93 per cent of global output dropped 1.1 per cent to 5.83 million tonnes in the first seven months from a year earlier, the Association of Natural Rubber Producing Countries said on Aug 6. The group represents the top producers including Thailand, Indonesia and Vietnam.

Global sales of light vehicles, weighing less than six tonnes, are set to climb 4 per cent to a record 90.5 million units next year, according to LMC Automotive Ltd, a research company in Oxford, England. Sales across Asia will expand 5.4 per cent in 2015, it said in e-mail.

World production will rise 2 per cent to 12.275 million tonnes this year and increase to 12.635 million tonnes in 2015, the study group said. Demand will expand by 4.5 per cent to 11.904 million tonnes in 2014 and grow to 12.433 million tonnes next year. - Bloomberg

site_title: New spring coming for Jurong Lake's gardens
content:
New spring coming for Jurong Lake's gardens

Next-generation Science Centre will be jewel in Jurong: PM Lee

Published

Sun, Aug 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The Jurong Lake gardens and a new Science Centre will be the focal points of a makeover for the Jurong Lakeside district, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said yesterday during his National Day Rally Speech.

"There should be more to Jurong than shopping malls and industries," PM Lee said.

The plan is to make the parks and attractions in the neighbourhood integrated into residents' living spaces. The National Parks Board will seek design ideas in 2015.

"Make it a people's garden," PM Lee said.

More Housing Board flats will be built in the north of the lake, and industrial land around the Pandan Reservoir in the south could be converted to residences as their leases run out over the next 20 to 30 years.

A new Science Centre will be built on the north of the lake near the Chinese Garden MRT station to replace the 37-year-old attraction now standing at the south shore of the lake. The new centre is targeted for completion around 2020.

"It will be the jewel in Jurong," PM Lee said.

To improve traffic in the area, the Ayer-Rajah Expressway could be moved southwards to create more space next to the lake for lakeside housing.

The Jurong Lake District has also been proposed as a possible site for the terminus of the proposed high-speed rail line between Singapore and Kuala Lumpur.

Singapore had earlier considered Jurong East, Tuas West and the city centre as possible locations for the terminus and all three are still up for consideration; PM Lee's speech narrowed the Jurong East option to the Jurong Lake district.

The focus on the lake area of the district comes after the Jurong Gateway neighbourhood around the Jurong East MRT station had already experienced significant growth in the past few years with the opening of a number of malls.

Singapore-listed CapitaMalls Asia operates the Westgate and JCube malls in the Gateway area, while Australia's Lend Lease runs JEM.

But the gardens and parks have not kept up with the shopping centres.

PM Lee recalled that when he visited the Japanese and Chinese gardens in June, they looked the same as when he previously visited 30 years ago.

The number of visitors to those attractions also pale in comparison to other community parks such as the Bishan-Ang Mo Kio Park.

"I felt we could do so much more with the gardens," PM Lee added.

Terence Wong, head of research at DMG & Partners, said the speech "puts the area under the spotlight".

"Plans for improvement have been spoken of, but now it makes the details a little more concrete. It puts interest in the western part of Singapore," Mr Wong noted.

He said developers might now take a closer look at the area and be willing to pay more for sites, but prices in the short term are unlikely to change much, especially with improvement projects also expected elsewhere in Singapore.

"Many parts also have catalysts," Mr Wong added. "Whether it's the north and closer ties with Malaysia, Tanjong Pagar with the waterways, or the east ... just about everywhere there's something going on."

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

PM Lee's call for culture shift lauded by employers, unions

Published

Mon, Aug 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Employers and unions applauded the Prime Minister's call to look beyond paper qualifications, but said stakeholders must find ways to offer diverse paths to success.

"Some employment mindsets are still steeped in the fact that a university degree holder is better qualified than one without a degree," Courts Asia chief executive Terry O'Connor said. "There should be a shift in employment practices that will holistically take into consideration an individual's abilities and aptitude, not only during the hiring process, but also when promotions and remuneration are being considered."

Singapore needs a culture shift that allows workers to advance regardless of whether they hold a university degree, PM Lee Hsien Loong said on Sunday in his National Day Rally speech.

A committee that comprises government, employer and union representatives will be created to help Institute of Technical Education (ITE) and polytechnic graduates with job placement and career advancement.

Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will chair the body, which will implement recommendations by the Applied Study in Poytechnics and ITE Review (Aspire) group set up in 2013 and led by Senior Minister of State for Education Indranee Rajah.

Employers and employees welcomed the message.

Speaking at the sidelines of the launch of the Young Engineers Leadership Programme on Monday, union chief Lim Swee Say said Labour is fully behind PM Lee's message.

Speaking in Mandarin, he said it is critical to create diverse paths to success. Workers who prefer to go back to school should have that opportunity, but companies should also offer in-house improvement programmes for those who are more inclined towards on- the-job learning.

Roland Ng, managing director of crane operator Tat Hong Holdings, said most of his workers are non-university graduates.

"We have to recognise that non-graduates can also play a part in our national evolution," he said.

Tat Hong, which operates in a highly technical industry, has found success working with polytechnic interns partly because the company exposes them to different aspects of the business, Mr Ng added.

"They have to get the students early exposure to companies, give them early internships so that they have a better understanding of what they can do," he said.

Successful people share qualities, not qualifications, said Tay Poh Choo, spokeswoman for mail carrier Singapore Post, which employs about 5,000 people.

"The employee has to be self-motivated, tenacious, hard-working and committed - all ingredients that are necessary for anyone to succeed, with or without a university degree," she said.

But Ms Tay said a key challenge is making more appropriate funding available for upgrading.

For Courts' Mr O'Connor, PM Lee's message holds personal meaning. Mr O'Connor joined Courts 21 years ago with only O-level qualifications, and just last week was awarded an honorary doctorate from the University of Stirling.

"A remarkable achievement in itself, a university degree is not the be all and end all of a person's professional development, and paper qualifications should never be the sole defining benchmark for a successful career," Mr O'Connor said.

site_title: Singapore shipping - the ports, products and plays
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Singapore shipping - the ports, products and plays

GEOFF HOWIE explains the links between shipping, coal and iron ore derivatives on SGX

Published

Sun, Aug 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AT ANY one time there are about a thousand vessels in the Singapore Port. Statistics show that every two to three minutes, a ship leaves or departs to, or from, 600 ports across 120 countries.

Shipping is a global business sensitive to the state and swings of the world economy. It connects ports and countries for many companies pursuing activities like importing raw materials and exporting to new consumer and wholesale markets.

Economic efficiency has become an important by-product of global trade. The World Trade Organisation (WTO) postulates that global trade provides for a more prosperous, peaceful and accountable economic world.

Trade is also measured and gauged like economic growth. In the International Monetary Fund's World (IMF) Economic Outlook update released on July 24, world trade volume growth for 2014 was revised slightly downwards to 4 per cent, with the 2015 outlook remained unchanged at 5.3 per cent.

Nevertheless world trade growth remained in line to outstrip world economic growth, which is forecast to be at about 2 to 3 per cent this year.

While most of the world's financial activities are facilitated through banks and exchanges, freight carriers facilitate most of the world's physical trade. The efficiency sought in physical trade has led to the development of supply chains using multiple countries, also referred to as value chains.

Hence, the process of importing and exporting has evolved into a multilateral activity, rather that a simple trade between two countries. The need for supply chain management, intermediate trade and transshipment have all played roles in Singapore becoming one of the busiest trade ports in the world. Another keynote statistic is that, annually, more than 120,000 ships call at Singapore.

Global seaborne trade has become an important part of Singapore's economy, as have commodities, which together have helped to generate Singapore's trade hub status. Hence it is natural that commodity and freight markets have also become an important part of the products and services offered by Singapore Exchange (SGX).

Freight rates and the price of shipping

Freight rates refer to the price of transporting cargo from one place to another. More than 90 per cent of today's trade is transported by sea.

Seaborne cargo is categorised into containerised, dry or wet cargo. The majority of the shipments across seas are in the form of containers which ferry mostly the finished products in large container vessels.

However, the raw materials are shipped around from its origin to places where they are consumed and processed on dry bulk vessels or wet tankers.

Raw materials that command the most weight on the seas are oil, iron ore, coal and grains.

Ultimately seaborne freight rates depend on the type of ship used, the distance to be travelled between ports and the weight of the cargo.

Freight rates can also differ on the direction of the trip and season of the year. For example, during the grains season in South America, significant capacity of dry bulk vessels is locked in shipping grains from west to east over longer journeys. This results in sharply reduced supply for other commodities, leading to freight rate volatility.

Among the dry bulk segment, iron ore makes up more tonnage on the seas than grains because the world's biggest iron ore importer, China, is shipping in its iron ore from afar.

Approximately 50 per cent of its imports come from Australia and 20 per cent comes from Brazil.

The most popular vessel used to ship iron ore is the Capesize, which can typically transport above 150,000 long tons of deadweight. Long tons of deadweight - abbreviated as DWT - are commonly used to explain the carrying capacity of a vessel.

Larger Capesize ships that can carry up to 400,000 DWT are also known as Very Large Ore Carriers (VLOC) and are also available in the market to transport iron ore.

Typically larger vessels are used to transport iron ore due to the greater economies of scale that can be achieved over lengthy times at sea.

It takes approximately six weeks for iron ore to be shipped from Brazil to China and approximately three weeks for it to be shipped from Australia to China.

An example of a freight rate would be US$7.77 per metric tonne for a capsize vessel to ship 160,000 metric tonnes of iron ore from Western Australia to Qingdao in China over a three week period.

This implies a cost of US$1.2 million for the journey. Like any other price, this freight rate fluctuates daily based on the fundamental forces of demand for and supply of such vessels.

Assuming a miner intends to ship 160,000 tons of iron ore from Australia to China, they could consider hedging potential fluctuations in Capesize time charter rates.

Commodity traders and participants hedge for a number of reasons. Key among them is when their costs are tied to the average rate for the month or when they have locked in a profit based on delivered price of the underlying commodity.

In the first scenario, hedging using freight derivatives based on time charter contracts neutralises the volatility. And for the second scenario, traders can protect their trade margins by converting a variable freight rate into a fixed freight rate using freight derivatives.

Freight derivatives

Freight derivatives are financial instruments based on a range of shipping routes. These products are used to manage freight rate risk and also to gain exposure to the freight market.

The Singapore Exchange (SGX) offers a suite of freight products comprising of freight futures and Forward Freight Agreements (FFA).

An FFA can be traded either for the transportation of a specified amount of commodity between ports (voyage) or for a specified time period of the voyage (time charter).

The difference between the contract price and the settlement price is multiplied by the cargo size or the voyage duration (expressed in terms of days) to determine the profit or loss from the contract.

For a specified time charter, the freight futures available are based on four different vessel sizes in descending order: Capesize, Panamax, Supramax and Handysize.

For the example discussed above, the miner could take a long position on the Dry Bulk Voyage FFA contract for the Capesize Route C5. The C5 route is Western Australia to Qingdao.

Other popular routes that are available for this contract are Tubarao to Qingdao (C3) and Bolivar to Rotterdam (C7). As noted above, at the time of writing, the C5 contract is trading at US$7.77 per metric tonne. The miners can also choose from FFA contracts that are based on day rates or half-day rates, expressed in US dollars per day.

Iron ore

Iron ore is the most shipped commodity in the world after oil. Singapore has grown to be the main global trading centre for iron ore over the last five years.

An eclectic mix of global iron ore traders are based here.

These participants include about 30 Chinese steel companies, which make up about one-third of the approximately 100 metals and mining trading firms in Singapore, major iron ore miners and international traders.

SGX was the first exchange in the world to offer clearing of OTC (over-the-counter) iron ore swaps. Currently, SGX offers trading and clearing of iron ore futures, swaps and options on swaps.

SGX iron ore swap and futures contract specifications are similar in most aspects, except that the contract size for futures is one-fifth that of the swaps.

Iron ore is a fundamental raw material for the production of steel. In turn, steel is fundamental to multiple forms of infrastructure. China is the world's largest steel producer, rolling out approximately half of global output.

Recently on June 16, the price of iron ore traded as low as US$89 per metric tonne. For the remainder of June, the price of iron ore then moderately recovered to end the month at US$94 per metric tonne.

This was amidst strong Chinese steel output and relatively lean mill inventory. SGX iron ore volumes in June reached 55.9 million metric tonnes with open interest averaging 55.8 million metric tonnes. Both monthly volume and open interest were more than double their levels for June 2013.

The majority of turnover conducted in the SGX iron ore swaps and futures contracts is from industry participants seeking a hedge.

However, the dynamics of the commodity, in addition to the associated trading relationship, make iron ore and associated freight rates markets of interest to professional investors.

The prices of the iron ore futures are available on a delayed basis on the derivatives page under SGX Market Information on www.sgx.com.

Commodity futures are categorised as Specified Investment Products due to their associated risks and more complicated nature than stocks.

Coal

Coal is also one of the world's most shipped commodities. In Asia Pacific, thermal coal is the primary source of power generation.

In China, 81 per cent of its power production is from thermal coal followed by Australia (69 per cent) and India (68 per cent), according to World Coal Association (WCA).

It is mined and converted to electricity domestically and also shipped for exporting to other countries. According to the WCA, of all the total thermal coal produced in 2012, approximately 84 per cent was absorbed domestically while the remaining 16 per cent was shipped for exports.

Hence, like iron ore, coal needs to be shipped across the globe, mostly from Indonesia, Australia and South Africa to China, India, Japan and Europe.

How coal is transported to where it will be used depends on the distance to be travelled, according to the WCA. Short distance coal transportation is generally carried out by conveyor belts or trucks, or trains and barges for longer distances within domestic markets.

Alternatively coal can be mixed with water to form coal slurry and transported through a pipeline.

Ships are commonly used for international transportation, in sizes ranging from Handysize, Panamax and Capesize.

Unlike thermal coal which is used to generate energy, metallurgical coal or coking coal is used to produce steel.

While Indonesia has overtaken Australia as the world's biggest export of thermal coal, Australia maintains its position as the world's biggest exporter of coking coal.

Because of the different grades of thermal coal and coking coal, the latter trades at a premium to the former. Currently coking coal trades at US$119.20 per metric tonne versus US$ 65.65 per metric tonne for thermal coal.

Both numbers refer to the delivered price in August 2014 of the material on a CFR (cost and freight) basis into China.

New thermal coal products (based on South African and Australian coal price markers) and coking coal derivatives (based on China and Australian coal price indices) have commenced trading on August 4. The prices of the coal futures are available on a delayed basis on SGX's market information page under derivatives.

US fastest-growing shale play lacks pipelines, low-cost trucking

Permian basin producers miss out on first exports of light crude

Published Mon, Aug 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] Washington's decision to allow exports of an ultra light crude offers a potential boon to US producers that will bypass drillers in the Permian basin, because the country's fastest-growing shale play lacks pipelines or affordable trucking.

The first exports of condensate have been from the nearby Eagle Ford Shale, a formation served by pipelines and rail, enabling producers to transport condensate to the coast.

Pioneer Natural Resources Co, a leader of the crusade to get Washington to allow the first condensate exports, has examined the economics and decided to ship from Eagle Ford, chief executive officer Scott Sheffield said. "(There are) no plans to export Permian condensate from plants," Mr Sheffield told Reuters in a recent interview. "By the time we truck it, it's not worth the economics of exporting it. We would need pipelines to make it economic."

site_title: Help seniors make informed CPF decisions
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Help seniors make informed CPF decisions

Published Mon, Aug 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

PRIME Minister Lee Hsien Loong, in his National Day Rally address on Sunday, gave what a number of Singaporeans seem to want: the ability to withdraw more money from their Central Provident Fund (CPF) accounts. As part of the move to introduce more flexibility into the system, he announced that the government would allow those aged 65 and above to take out a portion of their CPF savings in a lump sum.

He stressed that it wasn't a decision that was taken lightly, and rightly so. Those who choose to exercise this option will have to cope with less in their accounts for their retirement needs, at a time when more people are expected to live longer and the cost of living is going up.

While people should have a right to access their CPF savings, which is their own money, they should at least be given some help in making an informed decision. The CPF Board and other relevant stakeholders could perhaps ensure that members, especially those who are not financially savvy, get all the necessary information and counselling well in advance of making big withdrawals. Ultimately, of course, the final decision rests on the CPF members themselves and how they would like to utilise their money, be it to go on a vacation, fulfil some other lifelong dream or pay for a family emergency, although one hopes that they would use it wisely and not squander it away.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Halt isolation of Ebola nations: Iata

Published

Mon, Aug 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[JOHANNESBURG] Airlines should maintain services to Ebola-hit regions which need connections with the outside world in order to fight the disease, the International Air Transport Association (Iata) said yesterday, after more carriers put flights on hold.

The industry needs only to screen passengers at airports in infected areas, apply rigorous procedures, including isolation, when handling suspected cases, and fully disinfect planes afterwards, it said, citing World Health Organization advice that aviation constitutes a "low risk" for Ebola transmission.

"They have been very clear that travel and trade bans are unnecessary," Raphael Kuuchi, Iata's vice-president said in Johannesburg. "Unless this advice changes, we hope that countries working hard to eradicate Ebola continue to benefit from air connectivity."

Iata issued the plea after Kenya Airways, Africa's third-largest carrier, said over the weekend that it would stop flying to Liberia and Sierra Leone - which together with Guinea are the focus of the Ebola outbreak - from today on the advice of the Kenyan health ministry. That is after Korean Air Lines said that it would end flights to Nairobi tomorrow because of the risk of infection spreading there via services from West Africa.

Cameroon also said on Saturday that it would no longer allow flights from Ebola-hit states. - Bloomberg

Foreign banks find the going tough in Saudi Arabia

Many cancel licences as they succumb to restricted activities

"International banks have found this market more challenging to find their edge and differentiate themselves enough to build a viable business," Boutros Klink, CEO of Standard Chartered Capital Saudi Arabia, said in an Aug 14 interview in Dubai. Some international banks have started shrinking in Saudi Arabia even as the kingdom plans to open its US$577 billion stock exchange to direct international investment. Barclays Saudi Arabia cancelled its licence to conduct securities business in June, the same month that Goldman Sachs Group ended its licence for custody, underwriting and dealing as an agent.

site_title: AirPooler, Flytenow not operating legally: FAA
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

AirPooler, Flytenow not operating legally: FAA

Published

Sun, Aug 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[WASHINGTON] The trend in sharing services that was popularised by Uber Technologies Inc and Airbnb Inc will take longer to gain a foothold in the world of aviation, if at all. The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has reviewed its rules and determined that AirPooler Inc and Flytenow Inc, which connect pilots with passengers willing to split fuel costs and other travel expenses, are not operating legally.

The decisionis a barrier to extending the so-called sharing economy into air travel. Car-hailing service Uber and room-rental firm Airbnb have faced similar legal hurdles as traditional industry competitors - and the legacy rules that apply to them - confront technological changes in the way customers seek to use and pay for day-to-day services. AirPooler CEO Steve Lewis said: "It's much more than a fad for the shared economy because you have all these assets around that are being underutilised."

Investors including Goldman Sachs Group and Google Ventures are pouring cash into the market for sharing apps, including those that let users order taxis and cars or share rides. Uber raised US$1.2 billion in funding in June, giving it a value of US$17 billion. Airbnb was valued at about US$10 billion after its last round of fundraising.

In the AirPooler case, the FAA's legal interpretation rejects the idea that the air-travel service simply amounts to cost-sharing rather than a commercial aviation operation. The service is equivalent to charter flights and would require additional licenses and regulatory oversight, the FAA said in an Aug 13 letter to a lawyer for AirPooler.

The pilots orfirm may face FAA enforcement action if they continue. AirPooler will ask the FAA to reconsider the decision and will study ways of adjusting the service to make it legal within existing regulations, Mr Lewis said.Both companies plan to continue discussions with the FAA to see whether there is a way for the business model to operate within the agency's regulations. - Bloomberg

site_title: Early Aug's downward trend could resume
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Early Aug's downward trend could resume

This week may be stormy as odds are reset on likely date of Fed rate increase

Published

Sun, Aug 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LAST week, shares rebounded somewhat from the August doldrums as a lull on several fronts allowed investors to focus on US growth prospects.

This week promises to be a stormy one, however, as traders reset odds on the anticipated date of the Federal Reserve's interest-rate increase.

The ceasefire in Israel and an agreement to allow a Russian humanitarian convoy into Ukrainian separatist areas represented tentative diplomatic progress in the eyes of traders last week. Stocks dipped and oil prices spiked on Friday when Ukraine said it destroyed some Russian military vehicles in a contretemps with the aid convoy. The US, meanwhile, was flirting with another ground force landing in Iraq.

From a cold economic perspective, such conflicts touch American lives mostly in the form of higher petrol prices. Last week, prices of energy commodities were flat to down as traders focused on the glut in supplies produced by extensive "fracking" in the US.

"The conflicts in Russia and the Middle East continue to be regional - they have not impacted natural gas or oil prices from a supply perspective," said Oliver Pursche, president of money manager Gary Goldberg Financial Services.

The main reason Mr Pursche is optimistic that the Standard & Poor's (S&P) 500 can finish the year at a record high is his conviction that the bloom has returned to the US economy. Not only was second-quarter economic growth of 4 per cent higher than almost anyone expected but the details of the report also made the pace look sustainable.

"You didn't see business inventories being overly high and that's very important because it shows that the second-quarter business activity wasn't simply inventory restocking - there was more to it than that," explained Mr Pursche.

A booming economy has a downside for a stock investor. A boom soon leads to inflation and inflation soon leads to a rate hike. That will not only hurt spending by consumers and businesses by increasing borrowing costs. The Fed is still gradually weaning markets from "quantitative easing", the bond purchases designed to keep interest rates down. But the central bank would have to move more quickly if prices started spiralling higher.

Some investors are not sure the stock market is even ready for the end of Fed stimulus yet. For most of the past five years, the Fed has supported markets with some form of rate-cutting stimulus. Every time former chairman Ben Bernanke removed these props, stock and bond markets collapsed. The economic environment may be a little more favourable this time around, but stocks could sell off in October when the current programme tapers off to nothing.

For now, most analysts believe the Fed will pull off the "tapering" gambit and that the post-financial crisis era of monetary stimulus will end without a stock-market crash. One brokerage summed up the central preoccupation of the collective mind of Wall Street last week in one word: "When?", Credit Suisse's analysts wrote, in a note to clients. "Our economists' view is that the Fed will raise rates in the third quarter of 2015 (versus a market view of June 2015)."

Still, the Credit Suisse analysts said the Fed could move sooner if the second-quarter economic growth pace holds.

"Job openings, National Association of Home Builders (NAHB) surveys, CEO confidence and fiscal policy are all consistent with 3 per cent plus GDP growth, with the additional boost of improving bank-lending intentions and (a reduction in private-sector debt)," they added.

This week, analysts anticipate another relatively strong reading from the NAHB homebuilder survey and an increase in used-home sales. For stocks to build on last week's gains , the actual data will have to hew close to the estimates. Anything too hot or cold could make traders lose their appetite for stocks, being almost as afraid of a boom as they are of a bust.

Macy's launched the retailers' quarterly reporting season, which comes a month after the rest of the sectors, on a sour note, as the department store cut its fiscal 2014 projection for sales open a year or more. That adds to other mounting concerns in the retail sector after several luxury stores hinted they had been forced to cut prices to entice shoppers.

Another reason the downward trend of early August could resume relates to the laws of probability.

"We've now gone 34 months without a 10 per cent correction," said Ryan Detrick, a technical analyst for investment research website See It Market. "This is one of the longest stretches ever without a 10 per cent correction and it has many traders on edge."

The August sell-off could easily mushroom into an official 10 per cent correction, according to one strategist. But it's hard to see it go much further, he added.

While there are may things for investors to worry about "we believe that a softening of US earnings-per share and GDP growth projections are not among them," said Sam Stovall, equity strategist at S&P's Capital IQ. "We, therefore, continue to advise that dips be bought, as declines of less than 20 per cent have historically taken an average of only four months to get back to breakeven."

Major CPF policy shift on the way

Govt to allow partial withdrawal in lump sum for those 65 and above

Lee U-Wen

[SINGAPORE] The government plans to allow those aged 65 and above to withdraw a portion of their Central Provident Fund (CPF) savings in a lump sum.

The exact cap will be revealed at a later date, but Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said that the amount to be taken out "cannot be excessive". One possibility he mentioned was limiting it to 20 per cent of a member's total CPF funds.

Outlining this major policy shift for the country's compulsory savings scheme for workers, Mr Lee said that he made the decision after considering it for "a long time" and discussing it with his colleagues.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

T-Mobile flop won't deter SoftBank: analysts

Published

Sun, Aug 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[TOKYO] Japanese mobile carrier SoftBank's failed bid for T-Mobile marked a rare defeat for its brash billionaire founder, but few analysts expect it to sideline a man intent on building "the world's numberone company".

After years of scooping up companies big and small, Masayoshi Son's voracious appetite for acquisitions hit a snag amid reports earlier this month that the firm's US unit had abandoned a US$32 billion offer for T-Mobile in the face of regulatory opposition.

Mr Son never confirmed his plan to scoop up T-Mobile. But he repeatedly said that he wanted a stronger number-three carrier to take on US market leaders Verizon and AT&T, after last year's monster US$21.6 billion acquisition of Sprint.

The T-Mobile acquisition was seen as key to that strategy.

The 57-year-old Mr Son - one of Japan's most colourful entrepreneurs, who by his telling grew up poor, scrounging food from his neighbours to feed to the family's livestock - is rarely at a loss for words.

But he had little to say when asked about the T-Mobile flop.

"SoftBank does not discuss whether or not we intend to purchase particular firms," he told reporters in Tokyo.

"I have never made an official comment on this, and I will not have an official comment today." However, he added: "I am always exploring various options." - AFP

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

China aircraft lessor ICBC aims to double jet deliveries

It aims to supply more than 300 planes by end-2016

Published

Sun, Aug 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[BEIJING] ICBC Financial Leasing Co, China's biggest domestic aircraft lessor, aims to deliver more than 300 planes to customers by the end of 2016, nearly double current levels, a senior executive said.

ICBC's drive into a market still dominated by global players comes as Chinese leasing firms, backed by state lenders, play an increasingly important role in the growing domestic aviation business. Nearly 6,000 new commercial jets, worth US$780 billion, are expected to be delivered over the next 20 years, according to aircraft maker Boeing Co.

"Local companies have been expanding quickly and the growth potential is huge," Mark Jiang, managing director of aviation finance at ICBC Financial, told Reuters. ICBC Financial is backed by Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Ltd, while Bank of China Ltd and other state lenders support other lessors.

ICBC, which signed a US$1.1 billion deal with Embraer SA for 20 E190-E2 jets during Chinese president Xi Jinping's visit to Brazil in July, owns and manages 384 planes, up from 60 planes three years ago, according to Mr Jiang.

Even though International Lease Finance Corp, part of AerCap Holdings NV, and Gecas, a unit of General Electric, still dominate the market, local lessors led by ICBC and CDB Leasing, backed by China Development Bank, have managed to win over a big chunk of new business in recent years.

Collectively, Chinese lessors now handle 80 per cent of all new domestic leasing business, up from next to zero five years ago, said Mr Jiang. ICBC now has 17 domestic clients and 34 overseas clients.

By 2018, they are expected to corner 55 per cent of the Chinese market overall, up from 38 per cent last year, according to industry consultancy Ascend.

"Chinese firms have shown the ability to go into the market in a very significant way," said Illya Ivashkov, senior director at Fitch Ratings. "Some of them have placed sizeable orders."

Growth prospects in China's expanding leasing market also helped China Aircraft Leasing Group Holdings Ltd raise nearly US$100 million at an initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong last month.

More IPOs are possible, industry observers say, but a more common approach for the leasing arms of big Chinese banks may be to set up subsidiaries in the recognised international aircraft financing hubs of Singapore and Dublin to raise funds. - Reuters

site_title: Indonesian economy: The Jokowi boost
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Indonesian economy: The Jokowi boost

How do you see Indonesia's economic prospects under the new Jokowi administration? What opportunities for Singapore businesses would there be?

Published Sun, Aug 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Max Loh

Country Managing Partner

Ernst & Young LLP

THE outlook for the Indonesian economy remains positive with consumer confidence generally high, core inflation below 5 per cent and the rupiah showing some recent strength. The Jokowi administration looks set to build on this through a pragmatic and pro-business approach and via key reforms. The immediate challenge is the current account deficit, which is expected to increase due to low coal prices, the implemented ban on certain mineral ore exports and high oil imports. Sustainable cuts in fuel subsidy will provide the incoming government with more scope to increase spending on services and infrastructure.

The key lies in enhancing GDP growth in the medium term through speeding up structural reforms. The incoming administration's economic priorities and focus on infrastructure improvements, public services, law enforcement and labour relations should bring more business opportunities for foreign investors and Singapore businesses, particularly in the consumer, oil and gas, automotive and transportation, healthcare and media sectors.

Yeoh Oon Jin

Executive Chairman

PwC Singapore

JOKOWI is seen by many as a business-friendly leader who will take a pragmatic approach to introduce economic reforms. Known as one of the more visionary and successful leaders in recent Indonesian political history, he has a good track record of implementing constructive changes as a governor. This bodes well for Indonesia's ambition to become a developed country by 2025.

It will take time for Mr Joko to work through the traditional power structures but businesses will welcome this move in the right direction. Singapore businesses can certainly contribute to Indonesia's development strategies in infrastructure and consumer-related sectors to tap into a large, rapidly growing middle class.

Low Lee Yong

CEO

MHC Asia Group Pte Ltd

THE sleepy giant has awakened. Joko Widodo's win shows that the Indonesian people has awoken with a new and open mindset. They are ready to bring about change in their country. Under the Jokowi administration, we expect economic reforms to be made. But as his track record shows, we can also be confident of a stable business environment while reforms are being implemented. These are key factors for businesses to thrive.

In the healthcare sector, Indonesia has launched its universal healthcare insurance programme, BPJS. This is a mega project covering about 250 million people. Most importantly, we see the will of the administration to carry this through. For MHC, we have already partnered with Siloam Hospitals of the Lippo Group to link up providers in Indonesia. This is exciting as it brings about many opportunities for us to tap on.

George Chang

Vice-President

Southeast Asia & Hong Kong

Fortinet

WHEN Joko Widodo was finally named the winner of the general election, the sense of relief from the business community was palpable. Pro-business and industrious, he had an unrivalled track record of success in running Jakarta. His electoral win was a feather in the cap of other good news emerging from Indonesia recently - successful cutting of fuel subsidies that will return the economy to health, growth of the country's realised foreign direct investments by 16.9 per cent in the second quarter, and Indonesia's rise to become the second fastest growing G-20 economy after China.

We in the IT industry are optimistic. A vibrant business environment is the first step to greater technology investment, which will in turn further boost business outcomes. Many opportunities exist for Singapore and international companies, as local firms look for competent overseas partners to meet the demands of a fast-growing middle class. Judging from the way Jokowi ran Jakarta - cutting red tape, promoting business and constantly looking for ways to over-achieve - we are confident that Indonesia will take on a sheen not seen in a while.

James Tay

CEO

Logicalis Asia

INDONESIA's prospects have never looked better. A stable and pro-business Jokowi government would augur well for Singapore companies and MNCs investing into the country. Jokowi, with his background as the mayor of Solo, will continue his predecessors' push for development of the regions beyond Jakarta.

This geographic expansion will fuel a massive growth for the tech sector as businesses invest in technology infrastructure to support reaching into remote location across the vast country. This rising ICT penetration is a big draw for Logicalis and foreign companies providing technology infrastructure, network and cloud computing services.

Rosalynn Tay

CEO

Dentsu Singapore

IN many ways, it wouldn't have mattered if Jokowi or Prabowo won the elections: Indonesia's economy is a train that has left the station. No matter who the conductor is, it will keep going. The Indonesian middle class is growing, and their spending power and hunger to consume is something that Singapore businesses can definitely profit from provided you've set yourself up right.

International brands like H&M and Ikea are opening stores in Jakarta this year - when these behemoths arrive, others will follow suit. I see great opportunities in the digital arena in the archipelago. The country has come online at the speed of light, almost exclusively on small screens. An advertising network like the one I head in Singapore is, as we speak, exporting digital expertise to our network colleagues in Jakarta to set ourselves up to win in that field. Singapore companies that combine regional power with deep local Indonesian knowledge will come up winning in this fascinating market.

Philippe Huinck

Regional Managing Director, South and South East Asia

International SOS

PRESIDENT-ELECT Jokowi's economic and infrastructure growth plans certainly bode well for businesses and deliver renewed optimism. As the first true businessman to become president of Indonesia, Jokowi brings with him a highly pragmatic, pro-business mindset, having recently appointed a high-powered advisory team to address issues such as building investor confidence, eradicating poverty and accelerating infrastructure development. Key industries that are expected to benefit from proposed policy reforms include consumer and oil and gas, where Singapore companies have expertise.

International SOS established its very first clinic 30 years ago in Indonesia. Headquartered in Singapore and London today, we continue to play a proactive role in helping hundreds of companies protect their expatriate staff living and working in Indonesia, providing medical, security and travel assistance services through our Jakarta assistance centre and clinics in Bali and Jakarta. In my view, close Singapore-Indonesia bilateral ties and stronger cross-border collaboration are an obvious win-win for the two neighbouring countries. Specifically, we see plenty of opportunities in the medical, security and travel assistance sectors.

Lim Soon Hock

Managing Director

Plan-B Icag Pte Ltd

I HAVE always considered Indonesia to be Singapore's hinterland, not China or India. We are already benefiting much from our current trade and other economic activities with Indonesia. When the new president succeeds in reinvigorating the economy, in particular to develop the infrastructure, streamline an unwieldy bureaucracy and remove obstacles to foreign and local investment, it will unlock the full potential of doing business in Indonesia for Singapore companies. It is almost like a turbo being built into the economic engine of this vast market, whose geometric rate of growth can only further boost Singapore businesses, leveraging on our own success.

The new Indonesia will be able to create more clones of Singapore in not only the major cities, but also in all cities in this vast archipelago, tapping on the large population and encompassing all spheres of economic activities from infrastructural development to healthcare, education, manufacturing, hospitality, consumer and retail industries, to name a few. What Singapore has can be replicated. This spells myriad opportunities for Singapore businesses.

Jokowi won on a platform of democratic reform, which is the flavour of the day in many countries. He and his administration must not create opportunities for the Prabowo opposition to polarise and divide the citizenry. Indonesia cannot afford to degenerate into a situation like that of the prolonged stand-off between the red shirts and the yellow shirts of Thailand, as this can only destabilise the political climate and put a dampener on her economic growth. Singapore companies will need to maintain a close watch on this political risk before entering or investing in the market in a big way.

Anthony Gan

Executive Director

Singapore Retailers Association

INDONESIA's retail market is one of opportunity, and we are sure a popular business-friendly president will have a positive effect on the economy. Indonesia's retail sector has been attracting foreign direct investments in recent years, and with new infrastructure developments, a vibrant economy and growing disposable incomes, many retailers view the Indonesian market as one of great promise. We have to look only at the Indonesians' penchant for shopping in Singapore to realise that their domestic market has opportunities which we cannot ignore.

With efforts to combat corruption a priority for the incoming president, and his desire to give Indonesians everything they aspire to, the retail industry will develop rapidly within the country. Businesses are reassured the country is now in a safe pair of hands.

Rene Piil Pedersen

Director, Group Public Affairs, Asia Pacific Region

Maersk

THE Maersk Group sees much potential in Indonesia, one of the countries in South-east Asia which has been experiencing good growth in recent years. Maersk has had shipping and logistics businesses in the country for more than 50 years. There also lies potential for our other businesses, say in ports and terminals or others which are active in upstream oil production, towage services, offshore supply services, to enter and start operations in Indonesia.

Over the years we have focused on enabling increased trade to and from this largest archipelago in the world. Exports are growing as Indonesia has been one of the countries to benefit from the shift of manufacturing from China to South-east Asia. Imports are also rising due to a growing middle class and a large, young population who are consuming more. The Asean Economic Community which starts next year will also bring about more opportunities for trade.

However there is a dire need for improved infrastructure to bring about greater connectivity and a more efficient supply chain. Better infrastructure will also attract more foreign direct investments, which will drive further economic growth. We welcome news from Jakarta that this will be a priority for the new government.

Sam Yap

Group Executive Chairman and Co-Founder

Htwo Investment Holdings Pte Ltd

JOKOWI has been quite vocal about the need for Indonesia to address its shortcomings in infrastructure, manufacturing, and the need to invest more in human capital. His agenda once in office would be to boost the country's economy in order to revitalise it and build up its image in the region. To spur economic growth, the Jokowi administration will come up with new initiatives and reviews of various sectors focusing on strengthening its infrastructure capability, the manufacturing sector and investments in human capital.

In the short and medium term, there would not be much change to the existing market situations and opportunities. Changes, if any, would likely be in the introduction of more business-friendly policies making Indonesia more open and competitive.

In line with its interest in investing more in human capital, I see potential growth in the educational and training sectors with the entry of new service providers. With strong political support, chances are good that the Jokowi administration could achieve its targeted economic growth.

Richard Hong

CEO

TÜV SÜD PSB ASEAN

PRESIDENT-ELECT Jokowi has a business-friendly reputation and is supportive of foreign investment. There is also anticipation that his administration will boost basic infrastructure spending in roads, education and health. If these take off, businesses in Singapore such as TÜV SÜD ASEAN, which are well-placed to lend expertise in second- and third-party testing, inspection and technical due diligence, will benefit.

The huge vote of confidence in Jokowi by the Indonesian people has already driven a sense of optimism among the business community and sparked proactive business actions. Jokowi's team has indicated plans to raise local wages. This may mean higher costs for Singapore businesses but will also help to develop businesses further. Higher wages translate into higher spending power and with Indonesia's burgeoning middle class, this leads to stronger domestic demand especially in consumer products.

We are in the product, system safety and quality assurance business - so the domestic boost spells potential. Our business in Indonesia has been established for more than 11 years so we are close to the ground. We will continue to monitor our business in Indonesia and are ready to invest further when the opportunity presents itself.

Wahab Yusoff

Vice-President, South Asia

McAfee, part of Intel Security

LEADING the 10th largest economy in the world presents many challenges, but Joko Widodo also enjoys the prospect of bringing to fruition the country's huge growth potential. Indonesia's economic prospects are indeed very promising. The country needs a two-pronged approach: 1) attract more foreign direct investments and multinational companies to set up offices in Indonesia; and 2) enable Indonesian firms to expand overseas as well as in the home market. Both can only be achieved with good infrastructure - and in this day and age that certainly includes a reliable and protected communications and information network.

Singapore businesses will certainly look at the opportunities in Indonesia but will have a close eye on how bottlenecks like transport and communications networks will be improved, and on the assurance of safety and security - especially in the digital landscape - to guarantee connectivity, data privacy and confidentiality.

Pang Yee Ean

CEO

Surbana International Consultants

WITH the economic reforms proposed by the Jokowi administration and his strong past track record in implementing changes, we can expect to see many business opportunities in infrastructure development in Indonesia for Singapore businesses. The Indonesian construction industry recorded healthy growth from 2009-2013, expanding by an average annual rate of 7 per cent in real terms. While the pace of expansion may be subject to circumstances, we should see even more urbanisation and infrastructure projects being rolled out progressively over the next few years.

Singapore's successful track record in urbanisation will give infrastructure-related businesses such as real estate developers as well as engineering and design companies a competitive edge when they enter the Indonesian market.

Jean-Pierre Felenbok

President Director & Managing Partner

Bain Indonesia

WE are cautiously optimistic about the long-term prospects for the country and its economy and feel that the election results reinforce the odds of success. Indonesia has very strong fundamentals, a large and young population, increasing GDP per capita and a real opportunity to further develop its manufacturing sector for domestic consumption and export, partly substituting for China. Nevertheless, there are both substantial short-term and long-term challenges to address.

If the new administration manages well in the next few months, Indonesia should trend towards a new and more sustainable "normal", characterised by lower growth compared to the past few years (but still much higher than most world economies) and a rupiah value probably closer to its "true value". This will require managing the current account deficit more aggressively, in particular through further cuts of the fuel and energy subsidies. The bolder reform agenda needs to address the structural barriers that will drive long-term sustainable growth - including infrastructure, improving public services and more efficient regulatory frameworks, and creating flexibility in the labour market.

Thirumalai Chandroo

Chairman/CEO

Modern Montessori International Group

AS the largest economy in South-east Asia and the world's third largest democracy, Indonesia has the potential to influence the prospects of South-east Asia's business landscape. Jokowi's triumph points to the future of Indonesia's imminent developments and the region's commercial prospects with optimism.

Jokowi's strengths in leading the necessary radical reforms are still to be seen and the key to his success rests with his choice of Cabinet. A multitude of decisions that may well take years to implement - and very likely are filled with challenges - await him. Some of these decisions will touch on the neighbouring countries like Singapore where businesses are keen to get their ventures to Indonesia. A self-made businessman, Jokowi has earned his spot in politics with his smart policies that have given good results. His thoughts on being an open democracy and his bid to rein in the nation's toughest issues instil a sense of confidence among potential investors.

As a vote of confidence in the new administration, the Modern Montessori International Group recently set up a teacher training centre in Indonesia, adding to two franchise centres that have been around since before the July election. Indonesia has always been a rising star in the making and under the Jokowi administration, infrastructure investment and new economic reforms will stand for a renewed attraction of foreign investment inflows. This may make for significant positive change to the relationship between Singapore and Indonesia.

Natalie Shuman

Senior Vice-President, General Manager - EMEA & APAC

Kelly Services

INDONESIA is projected to continue achieving economic growth of over 5 per cent in the next years. With any newly installed administration, there will be special focus on various business and industrial sectors with the objective to drive economic growth. Similarly in Indonesia, in order to further boost the economy, proposed programmes include revitalising the energy industry, overhauling infrastructure and encouraging a business climate that will continue to attract foreign investment into the country. All these will translate into a need for stronger talent in the sectors of focus. It creates opportunities for labour mobility and exchange of workforce ideas and solutions not only within Indonesia but across the region.

One of the key human resource management events in Asia Pacific - the 41st ARTDO International Leadership and HRD Conference and Exhibition and the 6th Indonesia HR Summit jointly held in Yogyakarta this September - cements the importance and further integration of the Indonesian workforce into the APAC region. Kelly is glad to be part of the event and with our wide range of services and our regional presence, we will be able to adequately address the talent requirements and demands of our clients in the focus sectors.

Alick Chia

Director, Business Support

RSS Asia Pacific Pte Ltd

INDONESIA is a very important neighbour to Singapore both for regional peace as well as economic development. We have worked well with different presidents over the past decades. We should continue to cultivate our good relations with the new president Widodo. In fact, we should endeavour to give him as much as assistance as possible. This is a new era in Indonesian politics and it would be good if he succeeds in bringing about peace and prosperity for Indonesia in the years to come.

It would be good if we could take some initiatives on our part to provide assistance to Indonesia to help develop its education system and the technical and vocational skills of their people so as to attract manufacturing investments into their country. A peaceful and economically vibrant Indonesia would be good for Singapore and the region.

Dora Hoan

Co-Chairman/Group CEO

Best World International Ltd

WITH rich natural resources and abundant manpower, Indonesia has all along been a market full of potential. Nevertheless, in any country, bureaucratic red tape has always discouraged foreign businesses from investing. A more efficient system would have encouraged foreign investment as well as funds and technology for the local businesses.

Fortunately, with Jokowi's commitment to pro-business policies, I think we can look forward to greater latitude in conducting businesses in Indonesia. Once the processes are improved, there would be more opportunities for both Indonesian and Singaporean businesses to explore.

David Leong

Managing Director

PeopleWorldwide Consulting Pte Ltd

THE "Jokowi effect" is a wild card and may have a "Joker effect". Jokowi is a pragmatic and hands-on politician pushing through reforms and combating corruption and deals with local issues such as the local business environment and infrastructure in Solo and Jakarta. Singaporean companies that already operate in Indonesia on the lines of the old relationships and patronages may expect certain changes. The new administration is likely to change key appointments and as such, the cards on the table will be reshuffled - hence the "Joker effect".

Going forward, it may be easier for Singapore companies to forge ahead on a corruption-free agenda. Indonesia's economy is still fragile with large current account deficits heavily impacted by the US Federal Reserve cutting back on its stimulus programme. This drying up of global dollar liquidity will affect the stock markets of emerging economies, particularly Indonesia, due to their reliance on external financing. Jokowi has to deal with this looming weakness in its financial system and Singapore companies dealing there must accept these systemic risks.

On the back of its natural and manpower resources, if Jokowi can overcome its weak financial status with aggressive attraction of foreign companies to shift production from higher-cost China to Indonesia, Indonesia can be the next big thing in Asia. When Indonesia is the next big thing in Asia, Singapore will enjoy the spillover effect and can be instrumental in Indonesia's next leap of growth.

Annie Yap

Managing Director

AYP Associates Pte Ltd

IT has been challenging for businesses to enter the world's 10th biggest economy. However, under the new Jokowi administration, Indonesia's economic prospects are definitely bright. Jokowi's unprecedented move of making his advisory team known signals his resolve in advocating greater openness. More importantly, his successor, Basuki Tjahaja Pumama, will be the very first ethnic Chinese to become governor of Jakarta. This also bodes well in terms of the willingness for Indonesia to accept cultural diversity and move away from the closed mindset against local Chinese and foreigners.

As Indonesia gradually becomes more receptive to cultural diversity, it would also benefit the country as it attracts more foreign investments. Singapore businesses can capitalise on the opening up of Indonesia and expand into the region. Furthermore, with our proximity to Indonesia and as members of Asean, it would be strategic for Singapore businesses to expand into Indonesia.

Christophe Duchatellier

CEO

Adecco Asia

SINGAPORE and Indonesia have always enjoyed the mutual benefits their strong relationship brings and we look forward to opportunities and growth. Clearly, the new administration will embark on initiatives to rebuild the infrastructure and strengthen efforts to woo foreign investors and business. Opportunities include growth in oil & gas as well as consumer markets, be it in finance or services. Singapore has built a name for itself as the regional hub for IT, financial services and oil & gas, and investors can look forward to prospects in Indonesia.

As Indonesia rebuilds itself and realigns its overall mission, it would be heartening to know what the two governments can do to better boost both economic and business partnerships.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Darts group takes aim at Asian market

This weekend, Singapore hosts a major competition where the world's top eight players will vie for a US$100,000 cash prize

Published

Fri, Aug 15, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

ONCE played in pubs by working class folk over copious mugs of beer, the game of darts has evolved into a glitzy affair - with world championship events, big prize money, and millions of television viewers worldwide. The beer, however, has thankfully remain unchanged.

This weekend, Singapore plays host to the World Series of Darts for the first time. The world's top eight players have flown in, and are competing for a cash prize of US$100,000 at the Singapore Indoor Stadium tonight.

"People tend to dismiss the game until they learn that the top guys earn easily over £1 million (S$2.08 million) a year. Then their eyes open wide, and suddenly they're interested," said Matthew Porter, chief executive officer of the Professional Darts Corporation (PDC) - the organisation behind the inaugural Singapore Darts Masters.

And building a global interest in darts is exactly what PDC has in mind. While traditionally played and watched by fans in the UK and Europe - in Britain, it is the second-biggest televised sport behind soccer - the game of darts is gaining popularity in other parts of the world, including the Middle East and Asia, Mr Porter said.

"Asia is really our biggest development region. The key is to get events like these out here, to get audiences and sponsors excited. It has already been done in Britain and Europe, where the game has grown to a level where it's recognised as a professional sport," he added.

PDC sells over 500,000 tickets worldwide annually, and organises live darts events 70 days a year. The rewards are enticing - in 2014, a total of £7 million is up for grabs.

"It's a genuine career option," said Mr Porter, who is hoping to capture the imaginations of Singaporean darts followers - estimated at around 10,000.

Said Matt Bennett, partner at Shield Sports Asia, which is staging the event in association with Radar Sport & Entertainment: "If you think about it, Singaporeans would be great at this. You need good numeracy in your head, sound strategy, and enormous mental strength and nerve. There's no reason why a Singaporean player couldn't make the world circuit."

Cue the name Paul Lim, who isn't as well-known as he perhaps should be.

In 1990, the Singapore-born player became the first person to achieve a nine-dart finish in a world championship, completing a perfect game of darts - similar to a 300-point game in bowling - in front of a televised audience of millions.

The feat earned him the nickname "The Singapore Slinger" and a £52,000 bonus - more than the eventual tournament winner, Phil Taylor, who received £24,000.

Mr Lim, who now lives in the United States, is unable to attend this weekend's event although Mr Taylor - the world's top- ranked player - is competing.

But the fun isn't confined to the players; darts competitions are known for their Oktoberfest- style atmosphere. Rambunctious audiences heckle as much as they cheer, and there is also a free flow of beer.

This year, Shield Sports Asia expects a crowd of at least 2,000 people, split evenly between expatriate and local attendees. The competition will also be beamed across the globe to a television audience of up to 10 million.

"It's a new event here, so 2,000 (attendees) may not sound like a lot. But there's certainly the possibility of growing the event beyond that. UK crowds number over 10,000, and that's been developed over 20 years," said Mr Porter. In fact, he believes this weekend's event could become an annual one in the future.

As for the sceptics, Mr Porter has this to say: "They should just go and watch the competition. I would bet myself to give anybody a good time."
