site_title: In the driver's seat
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

In the driver's seat

The CEO of famed Danish furniture maker Carl Hansen & Son talks to Tay Suan Chiang about his ambitious plans to expand the business

Published

Fri, Aug 15, 2014 · 10:00 PM

KNUD Erik Hansen says that when he joined his family business, Carl Hansen & Son in 2002, "there was no special feeling; it was like any other company that I had worked at before".

But, he adds, "it has grown on me".

Mr Hansen, 63, is the third-generation owner of the famed Danish furniture maker. His grandfather is the late cabinet maker Carl Hansen, who started his bespoke furniture workshop in 1908.

It was by coincidence that Mr Hansen joined the family business as its CEO 12 years ago. He had previously worked as a shipping trainee for the now defunct East Asiatic Company, and was later the managing director for Tempur mattresses, before he sold off the company. From 1998 to 2002, Carl Hansen & Son was headed by Mr Hansen's elder brother, Jorgen Gerner. Of his elder brother, Mr Hansen says: "We are very different in the way we manage the company. My brother had very little interest in expansion."

The younger brother had plans to start his own business, and asked to sell his shares to his older brother. "But he asked me to buy his shares instead, and to take over the company," says Mr Hansen. "I agreed, because I saw that the firm had potential."

Since taking over, Mr Hansen has expanded the firm from 17 to 250 people, invested in new machinery and recently bought two new factories in Denmark.

Mr Hansen has ambitious plans for the business. He says the firm will make more than S$100 million in sales worldwide this year, and over the next three years, the company will double in size. Nearly 85 per cent of the products are exported overseas, with Japan being its biggest market outside of Denmark.

Carl Hansen & Son's most famous piece of furniture is the Wishbone chair, with some 40,000 pieces sold annually. It was designed in 1949, by then unknown Danish architect Hans J Wegner, who was approached to collaborate with Carl Hansen & Son, when Mr Hansen's father, Holger, saw the need for the company to work with architects and designers for it to expand.

The Wishbone chair has a characteristic Y-shaped back and the hand-woven seat consists of more than 120 metres of paper cord, which takes a skilled craftsman an hour to weave.

Wegner went on to design other iconic pieces, including the Shell chair, the Easy chair and the Sawbeck chair. "Some of Wegner's pieces, such as the Shell chair, was considered too avant-garde for its time - it is only in recent years that it has taken off," says Mr Hansen.

To mark the 100th anniversary of Wegner's birth, Carl Hansen & Son is launching Wegner's CH88 chair - a 1955 design that has, to date, existed only as a prototype.

In Singapore, Carl Hansen & Son is sold at Space furniture store.

Mr Hansen has no background in design, but his childhood home was next to the company's factory. "In a way, design and furniture did interest me," he says. His home is naturally filled with pieces from the company. "I've got a big house, and there's lots of space to display about 70 to 80 chairs." He describes his grandfather as a kind and quiet man, and "people loved working with him as he was honest".

On Wegner, Mr Hansen says: "He was a very quiet man, and he would come to our summer house and fly his giant kite."

In the past, Carl Hansen & Son only worked with Danish designers, with Wegner as its most celebrated. Mr Hansen wants to shake things up by collaborating with non-Danish designers, one of whom is Japanese architect Tadao Ando. "I see Carl Hansen & Son as an international company, so it was only right to start working with designers outside of Denmark," says Mr Hansen. Since Japan is their biggest export market, Mr Hansen began his search for a designer there. "And who else would you pick in Japan besides Tadao Ando," he asks.

The Dream chair, which was launched last year, is Ando's first foray into furniture design. The chair, which appears to be floating, is made entirely of three-dimensional veneer. "Architects have been snapping them up, and the public will probably take it up about six months later," says Mr Hansen. He quips: "Ando is the first living designer that I've worked with."

Despite him having no design background, Mr Hansen has a clear idea of what good furniture design is, and why Danish design has been so well regarded. "Something that will last in people's mind and that will last physically," he says. "It must not be fashion. It should be a piece that you are still happy with 30 to 50 years later."

Mr Hansen is prepared to hand over the business to the next generation. His two sons, who are 20 and 21, have shown an interest. "I hope they will take over, but I won't force them to do so."

He has no plans to retire as yet, but when his sons do take over, Mr Hansen says he will definitely step down. "The previous generation stepped down when the next generation took over. I will do the same."

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Parked United B747 punctured in collision with towed plane

But no one hurt in accident near O'Hare Airport hangar

Published

Sun, Aug 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[WASHINGTON] A United Airlines jumbo jet's hull was punctured in a Chicago airport collision with another plane last month, four people familiar with the matter said, grounding the Boeing 747 for weeks of repairs. No one was aboard.

The parked B747, one of only 24 jumbos at the carrier, was sliced open by the wing of a wide-body United jet that was being towed, said the people, who asked not to be identified because the details are private.

A spokesman, Christen David, said that the accident occurred on July 28 near an O'Hare Airport maintenance hangar but declined to elaborate.

Incidents such as this are rare, with damage far beyond the dings known in the industry as "ramp rash" and are tracked closely by the US Federal Aviation Administration. The agency will monitor the fixes to the B747 to ensure they meet US standards, said a person familiar with agency operations.

"Usually, tow accidents are a broken tow bar piercing the skin, not aircraft-to-aircraft violence," said Robert Mann, a former American Airlines executive who is now an aviation consultant based in Port Washington, New York.

United's Chicago-based parent, United Continental Holdings Inc, hasn't publicised the collision, which occurred away from the terminals at the second-busiest US airport.

The B747 involved in the collision is ordinarily operated by United on charter flights, and repairs by Boeing are still under way, said Ms David. The other jet was a B777, a wide-body model used on long-haul international routes.

The B747 suffered damage to its radome, which houses radio antenna equipment in the nose, as well as a punctured pressure bulkhead, one person said. The fixes will cost almost US$4 million, another person said.

The bulkhead is crucial because it seals the front of the plane from the atmosphere, ensuring proper air pressure at high altitudes. Faulty repairs to a bulkhead at the rear of a Japan Airlines B747 were blamed for a 1985 crash that killed 520 people, according to the Aviation Safety Network website.

"Replacing a pressure bulkhead would be a major repair, pretty expensive", with a bill running into the millions of dollars, said Mr Mann.

While rare, ground accidents with significant damage do occur. In 2003, a single-aisle Airbus A319 owned by Northwest Airlines ploughed into one of the carrier's B757s at a gate at New York's LaGuardia Airport. The A319, which was being taxied by mechanics, also struck a concrete jetway support, shearing off its nose gear.

About six metres of the B777's wing required repairs, two people said. The aircraft model is the world's biggest twin-engine jetliner.

The B777 has been fixed and returned to commercial service, Ms David said. United substituted other aircraft for the long-haul jet, and was able to avoid disrupting the flight schedule, she added.

The 18-year-old B747 is the airline's only jumbo dedicated to ferrying troops under a US military contract, two of the people said.

Ms David declined to identify any charter customers for the plane. The airline is using other jets to fulfill its charter flights while the jumbo is being repaired, she said. - Bloomberg

"One authority to coordinate all of the agencies . . . and single-mindedly focus on service delivery," Mr Lee said.

"We have to do better to bridge these interagency boundaries," Mr Lee said.

But citizens can also play a part in making Singapore a better home by giving feedback.

Mr Lee noted a number of technological solutions adopted to improve communication between the government and the public. Those include the Land Transport Authority's MyTransport service that offers bus arrival information, among others, and the National Environment Agency's myENV service that allows the public to report issues such as litter or construction noise.

site_title: Fresh US$60m funding to boost Foodpanda's reach
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Fresh US$60m funding to boost Foodpanda's reach

Published

Sun, Aug 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] With a fresh US$60 million fund injection, food delivery site Foodpanda continues its march towards global domination.

The company, which is owned by German super incubator Rocket Internet, has just announced the latest investment round, which brings its total funding raised to date to just over US$100 million.

Just two years old, Foodpanda is already available in 40 countries across South-east Asia, the Middle East, Africa and Latin America. In Asia, it is in countries such as India, Thailand, Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, Brunei, Vietnam, Taiwan, Hong Kong and the Philippines.

Foodpanda CEO Ralf Wenzel told BizIT during a visit to Singapore that the plan is to keep breaking new ground in markets where online food delivery isn't mainstream.

The company has found that even in most first-tier cities, there isn't a dominant food delivery site that works with a variety of restaurants, and it's hoping that it can quickly move in to this space.

"In every market, food delivery is pretty much offline still, so we want to be the first mover," Mr Wenzel said.

Foodpanda works by providing its delivery order system to restaurants. The company takes orders from consumers via its website or mobile app and passes the orders along to the restaurants. It takes a cut from the restaurants on each order.

The site's additional value proposition to food places is the stream of hungry visitors to the website that may be attracted to ordering from a new place.

Parent company Rocket Internet's modus operandi is to take e-commerce business models that have done well and replicate them in emerging markets, often rapidly expanding its footprint from the get go. Its other businesses such as Zalora and Lazada are headquartered in Singapore, and operate in the region from this base.

Despite Foodpanda's youth, it already has 800 employees globally, with its engineers and central marketing team in Berlin. Its 20 staff in Singapore generally work to acquire more restaurants under the Foodpanda umbrella. They also help with technical installations for restaurants which have their own systems but also want to integrate with the Foodpanda network.

Mr Wenzel explained that with larger chains such as Sarpino's Pizza in Singapore, these players often have their own point-of-sale (POS) systems. In order to help win over restaurants, Foodpanda's software works with existing POS systems, so restaurants don't have to abandon the hardware they've already invested in.

For smaller restaurants which don't have their own systems, Foodpanda has its own order printer that it places within restaurants. This allows kitchens to take orders from customers on Foodpanda and indicate when orders have been dispatched.

Till recently, online food delivery has been a luxury service reserved for users with easier access to Internet connectivity, but the proliferation of smartphones is changing that, said Mr Wenzel.

"In the beginning, I didn't expect the (spread) of mobile usage to be so fast. In Western Europe, we're doing more on the Web, like buying travel tickets. But in emerging markets, the (desktop) is bypassed, and buyers are going straight to the mobile," he said.

And in emerging markets in Asia, this momentum is fast outpacing that of developed markets, where users are still accustomed to going to their desktops as a first contact point with e-commerce, he added. Asian users are going straight to the mobile phone because that's also become the first gateway to the Internet for many.

"The smartphone is a luxury that people can afford earlier in life than apartments, or cars, or TVs, even. You can expect someone to have a smartphone in countries like Senegal or Bangladesh, before they get a TV," he noted.

Foodpanda has shifted gears and plans to pour in a larger proportion of its engineering hours into the mobile, as a result of this trend, he added.

"Initially, we thought of mobile as an additional channel to the Web, but we now see that more users are on the mobile. Mobile growth rates are also twice that of Web, and mobile retention rates and average basket sizes are higher too. This is true across all the countries we're in," he said.

Being available on the mobile, however, doesn't solve the issue of cashless payments, where far fewer people have credit cards in emerging markets than that of developed peers.

Jana, a mobile advertising platform, conducted a survey last year that revealed an average 32 per cent credit card usage across Asian, South American and African emerging markets, for instance.

This lower accessibility of cashless payment poses a challenge for e-commerce businesses.

But Foodpanda remains confident of its prospects in these markets, said Mr Wenzel, who insisted that there are plenty of ways around credit cards such as cash-on-delivery, e-wallets with telcos and scratch cards.

Foodpanda is positioned as a commodity service, not a luxury, he said.

The company, which adds hundreds of restaurants to its roster every day across the globe, has 25,000 restaurants on the site right now. By the end of next year, it wants to reach 100,000 restaurants, he said.

Its volume of orders grows 15 per cent week-on-week, he said. "Eventually, I want us to be the standard for food ordering. Like how WhatsApp is synonymous with messaging."

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Japfa ends first-day trading on firm note

Published

Fri, Aug 15, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

INDONESIA'S agri-food company Japfa ended its stock trading debut on Singapore Exchange (SGX) yesterday at 84.5 Singapore cents, up 5.6 per cent from its initial public offering (IPO) price of 80 Singapore cents.

The mainboard counter, which opened at 84 cents and then traded between 86.5 cents and 81.5 cents, was the day's third most active stock with 68.7 million shares changing hands.

Japfa sold 248 million shares - an international offer of 231.2 million shares and a public offer of 16.8 million shares - raising S$198.4 million.

Its public offer was about 9.7 times subscribed while the international offer - which received robust demand from institutional and other investors - received interest of about 5.1 times the shares available.

Owing to the overwhelming response from institutional investors, the joint global coordinators, joint issue managers, joint bookrunners and underwriters have fully over-allotted 37.2 million shares to the international offer, Japfa said on Thursday.

"We are optimistic about our prospects and will forge ahead with our strategy of expanding across multiple protein segments in our five high-growth emerging Asian markets," said chief executive Tan Yong Nang.

Japfa went ahead with its listing despite Samudra Energy pulling the plug on its own IPO, citing market volatility. Japfa, which produces milk, poultry and beef in Indonesia, has established a similar industrial farming business model in Vietnam, Myanmar and India for poultry, and in China for dairy products.

It intends to use the IPO proceeds to build a five-farm hub in Inner Mongolia. The funds raised will also go towards growing its business in China and the Indochina region and paying off borrowings, including pre-prepayment charges.

Last year, the group registered a net profit of US$41.8 million, declining 22 per cent from 2012 while revenue increased 16 per cent to US$2.7 billion.

site_title: Developers hard-pressed to price projects modestly
content:
Developers hard-pressed to price projects modestly

Kalpana Rashiwala

Published Fri, Aug 15, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

LATEST official statistics showed that developers' housing sales continued to languish last month, but the focus now is on the likely launches for the rest of the year and how much room developers have to price them attractively to get potential buyers into making a commitment.

Many developers paid high prices for 99-year private housing sites at state tenders in the past couple of years as they sought to replenish land following strong home sales at the time.

"Those with a high breakeven cost but who need to launch a project are likely to adopt a "Star Buy" strategy for inferior stacks of units in the development to draw out initial take-up to drive confidence in the launch," a seasoned developer told BT yesterday.

"Developers who worked in a potential price drop in their land bids would be in a better position today to trim end-unit prices and encourage buyers to consider making a commitment amid the current soft market," said Chia Siew Chuin, director at Colliers International.

"But even those who paid high land prices and left with less room for price adjustment may be willing to lower their price expectations. This could enable them to clear some units and generate cash flow - rather than maintaining the status quo and doing nothing as market conditions deteriorate further."

There will be heightened competition for buyers as more property launches are expected by developers who had bought residential land after December 2011. These developers are required to complete the projects and sell all units within five years, otherwise they would have to pay a hefty additional buyer's stamp duty on the land price with interest, Ms Chia noted.

Even amid the weak July developers sales stats released yesterday by the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA), evidence is surfacing of developers successfully drawing out buying demand through attractive prices, highlights SLP International executive director Nicholas Mak.

"For instance, Wheelock released The Panorama in Ang Mo Kio in January this year, posting a median price of S$1,343 psf for sales in that month. But since it reduced prices in May to the S$1,200-plus psf level (median price), this project has been among the top sellers every month," he said.

"This goes to show that developers can revive sales at existing launches with meaningful price cuts. What remains to be seen, however, is whether this will result in a price war, which could be triggered, for instance, if one player were to sharply cut prices relative to other projects in the vicinity."

URA's July data also revealed that the remaining 37 units at The Vermont on Cairnhill, which was completed last year, were sold at S$2,113 psf median price in July. This is 8.6 per cent below the S$2,313 psf median price, based on caveats data, for all previous sales in the project by its developer, said OrangeTee research head Christine Li.

"Vermont's brisk sales show many high-end buyers are on the sidelines waiting to enter the market once prices become attractive," she noted. "In the private housing market as a whole, a 10-12 per cent price cut is typically enough to draw buyers in droves."

Last month, developers sold 484 private homes excluding executive condos (ECs), just two more than the 482 units they moved in June. In July last year, the figure was also 482 units.

Developers also offloaded 51 EC units last month, compared with 49 in June and 112 in July 2013. The weak home sales mirrored their strategy of holding back on major launches.

There were only four new launches last month - of which three were in the city fringe.

The top seller was City Gate on Beach Road, with 89 units transacted at a median price of S$1,809 psf. Near Kitchener Road, the developer of The Citron Residences found buyers for 23 units at S$1,585 psf median price. In the West Coast, 11 units were sold at Bijou at S$1,969 psf.

In the first seven months, developers sold 4,893 private homes and 354 EC units. For the whole of last year, the figures were 14,948 private homes and 3,588 ECs.

For the rest of the year, predicts Ms Li, EC sales will gather momentum and probably overshadow sale of mass-market private condos. There has not been a single new EC project launch in nearly a year, which means pent-up demand can be expected to manifest for five expected EC launches by year-end.

Some market observers expect genuine buyers to increasingly head for the resale market to pick up a completed property, including units in newly completed projects.

"These buyers can pick up something in the spot market, and within a short period either move in or rent it out," noted Savills Singapore research head Alan Cheong.

"Of course, the advantage of buying at a new launch from a developer is that buyers can make progressive payments for their property purchase, based on the phase of the project's completion. And in the case of leasehold property, they get an almost fresh lease term on their investment."

site_title: Catfights galore in The Women
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Catfights galore in The Women

Helmi Yusof

Published

Thu, Aug 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

ARE women really their own worst enemies? The classic 1936 play The Women by Clare Boothe Luce certainly portrays them so.

Staged countless times on Broadway and adapted onto film three times (the most recent 2008 production starring Meg Ryan), the play centres on catfights and backstabbing among women over - what else? - men. But it also reaffirms certain bonds between women that are good, kind and unbreakable. And it remains one of the few plays in modern theatre's canon that features a large all-female cast of characters.

Now The Women is set to be staged at the Esplanade Studio in a Malay translation directed by the talented Alin Mosbit. And she's assembled a cast of mostly popular TV actresses who, unknown to many, actually started out in theatre before venturing into TV. They include Siti Hajar Gani and Nadia Din - as well as the priceless stage actress Nora Samosir.

The Women tells the story of society wife Mariam (Siti Hajar) who discovers, through the malicious machinations of her own friends, that her husband is having an affair with a perfume shop assistant. While preparing for a divorce, Mariam finds herself embroiled in circumstances that allow her to get her husband back.

The story was originally set in 1930s New York high society. But director Alin has transposed it to 1950s Singapore where well-off women in kebayas and bling bling jewellery roam the society scene.

Alin says: "There was a certain bourgeoisie mentality then. Many of these women were connected to old money or Malayan royalty. They didn't work and spent their time gossiping and poking into other people's business. I thought it made for a perfect backdrop for The Women."

Alin is best known for her humane and hilarious feminist plays such as Beautiful Fish and . . . And Three Virgins Fly To The Moon, and has adapted the script to include many local references and humour.

She says: "Even when transferred to the Singapore context, The Women maintains its kernel of truth about women - that women are often their own source of inspiration and sabotage. We could be more supportive of each other's happiness and successes, instead of diminishing each other."

Lead actress Siti Hajar concurs: "There's a lot of talk these days about how social media sites and dating apps are affecting marriages and relationships, because they've made it easier and faster for strangers to connect. But it's not the technology we should be blaming - it's our own human fallibility we need to look at."

The Women (Wanita) by Clare Boothe Luce will be staged at the Esplanade Theatre Studio from Aug 28 to 31 at 8 pm, with weekend matinees. Standard tickets at $30 are still available from Sistic for Aug 31. Other slots are sold out.

SUBSCRIBERS

Nissan Nouveau

The new Nissan Qashqai gets sportier styling and a direct injection engine. By Samuel Ee

Published

Fri, Aug 15, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THERE is a new Nissan Qashqai and it has suddenly transformed itself into a sharper, less cuddly-looking crossover. The previous version of this UK-made model by Japan's second biggest carmaker had softer and more amorphous styling. But the new car gets more masculine lines for a much sportier stance.

The front end with its "3D" clamshell bonnet and full LED "boomerang" lights is purposeful, while the flanks are distinctively sculpted. Big 19-inch wheels that come as standard equipment also add to the newfound machismo.

All these make the new Qashqai look bigger but it isn't; it is only 50mm longer at 4.38 metres with its 2,646 mm wheelbase extended by 16 mm. It is also 15 mm lower at 1.59 metres high, but Nissan has managed to improve headroom by lowering the hip point.

The interior is also slightly plusher, with a dashboard in dark tones and ambient lighting in the lower centre console.

Also improved is the boot opening, which is now wider with better tailgate clearance.

Under the more curvaceous bonnet, the naturally aspirated four-cylinder engine gets a new feature - direct injection. This two-litre unit is mated to the latest-generation Xtronic continuously variable transmission (CVT) featuring what Nissan calls Active Lock-Up Control. What this does is improve responsiveness by reducing the CVT's so-called rubber-band effect, where engine and road speeds do not match and the clutch feels and sounds like it is slipping.

As a result, the non-turbo engine's 144 hp and 200 Nm are more potent than they sound and the Qashqai is pretty brisk. The option to "shift" the seven-step CVT manually using the gear lever adds to the Nissan's sportiness.

Like its predecessor, the Qashqai's handling feels more European than Japanese and Nissan has introduced several features to enhance its driveability.

For a start, the redesigned Electronic Power Assisted Steering reduces the overall steering ratio by 5 per cent for improved responsiveness.

At the same time, Active Trace Control improves the Qashqai's dynamic ability by applying the brakes to each wheel to correct the cornering line, although this is done only at lower speeds.

Another braking feature is Active Ride Control. It monitors the wheel speed to detect bumps which could upset the ride and applies subtle braking to individual wheels to increase body control and hence, ride comfort. To reduce braking effort, a feature called Active Engine Brake can be selected using the multi-function display. This employs the CVT to increase engine braking while cornering for greater control and less pedal effort.

Together, these driving aids complement the new and more dynamic styling pretty well.

Published Sun, Aug 17, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE buying rose while the selling among directors fell for the second straight week based on filings on the Exchange from Aug 11-15. A total of 15 companies recorded 27 purchases worth S$4.05 million versus one firm with one disposal worth S$0.10 million. The buy figures were up from the previous week's nine companies, 24 purchases, and S$2.86 million. The sales, on the other hand, were sharply down from the previous week's four firms, four disposals, and S$4.57 million.

While the buying by directors rose last week, the buyback activity fell with eight companies that posted 28 repurchases worth S$7.2 million. The figures were down from the previous week's seven firms, 38 trades, and S$16.1 million.

With the low sales by directors, the bulk of the significant trades last week were purchases with rare buys in GSH Corporation, Nordic Group, MTQ Corporation, and Manufacturing Integration Technology. Also positive was the chairman of Serial System as he resumed buying after the company released its first half results. On the buybacks side, there were significant repurchases in Sinjia Land and Xyec Holdings.

Tat Hong Q1 profit down

Published

Thu, Aug 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

CRANE supplier Tat Hong Holdings reported a 28 per cent fall in net profit, to S$5.96 million from S$8.24 million last year, for its first quarter ended June 30. Revenue fell 6 per cent to S$164 million.

The company managed to reduce operating expenses by 7.6 per cent to S$48.4 million. Earnings per share fell to 0.93 Singapore cent from 1.28 Singapore cents.

Once again, with the exception of tower crane rental, all business divisions reported lower revenues. The distribution division, which makes up nearly two-fifths of Tat Hong's business, contributed a significant portion of the decline. The division saw revenues drop 14 per cent, largely due to falling sales of excavators in Indonesia.

Tower crane rental remains the bright spot as its revenues jumped 21 per cent on the back of China's massive urbanisation efforts. The division, which now makes up 15 per cent of Tat Hong's revenue, looks set to grow further. The Chinese government is increasing its spending on rail infrastructure, while nuclear power plant projects are also resuming, raising demand for tower cranes, said the company. Tat Hong shares rose one cent to close trading at 84.5 cents yesterday.

site_title: CDL steps up diversification plan
content:
CDL steps up diversification plan

Q2 profit falls 33% to S$137.9m due to absence of divestment gains

Kalpana Rashiwala

Published

Thu, Aug 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Faced with challenging headwinds in the Singapore property landscape, City Developments Ltd (CDL) will focus on new geographies and products.

It is actively looking at Japan and Australia and hopes to establish platforms in these markets by year end. In addition, CDL is seeking to develop fund management products, its top brass said yesterday as the group posted a 32.8 per cent drop in second-quarter net earnings to S$137.86 million. First-half net profit also fell 24.9 per cent to S$257.53 million.

On fund management, where the group lags behind its Singapore peers such as CapitaLand and Keppel Land, CDL's strategy will be to initially monetise some of its existing assets. This would build a track record, giving for instance fixed returns to investors while providing long-term capital appreciation. In the longer run, CDL will not rule out a "discretionary" model, as is adopted by many private-equity outfits, of raising cash from investors first before purchasing assets.

"If you look at our competitors, many of them have multi-billion-dollar funds management businesses. Subject to market conditions, I don't see a reason why at some point, a five to 10-year horizon, we would not be targeting that type of business," said Grant Kelley, who was appointed CEO of the company earlier this year. He was formerly from Apollo Global Management and Colony Capital.

Kwek Leng Beng, CDL's executive chairman, said the group has not taken full advantage of its hotel portfolio, held under its London-listed subsidiary Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C). He floated some possibilities. "One day if it is prudent and viable, why don't we throw all our hotels into a Reit (real estate investment trust) and make this the biggest Reit ever in Singapore? As another example, why don't we get all our provincial hotels in the US plus UK, put them into a Reit? That is another model."

As for expanding Down Under and in Japan, CDL's strategy is likely to be dominated by hotels, commercial and residential - the three asset classes it is best at in the Singapore market. "We are actively looking at a number of opportunities currently ... In the next 12 months, we hope we'll have some concrete and exciting investments that will be consummated," said Mr Kelley, declining to give details.

Late last month, Australian Financial Review reported that CDL and Australia's Stockland Group are considering bidding for Leighton Holdings' US$7 billion residential and commercial property portfolio. The Leighton Properties business is expected to fetch up to A$500 million (S$580 million), according to the report.

At yesterday's briefing, CDL also gave an update of the headway it has made in other overseas markets: China and UK. It has picked up six freehold properties in UK since last year for £157 million (S$326 million): two in Knightsbridge and one each in Chelsea, Belgravia, Croydon and Reading. The intention is to reposition them predominantly as residential projects to tap the undersupply in the London housing market.

Said Mr Kwek: "I personally believe that now with Middle East in bad shape, more and more funds and rich individuals will park their money and buy something" in London.

Later this year, the group could launch its first major China project - Eling Residences in Chongqing.

In Singapore. the group may release a 124-unit freehold condo, New Futura, on Leonie Hill Road in Singapore in the second half of this year, subject to market conditions.

One-fifth of the 500,000 sq ft of offices at its South Beach Tower in Singapore has been committed. Besides Rabobank, tenants clinched include De Lage Landen, TMF Group and Bain & Company; advanced negotiations are going on with a few more major potential tenants. The 34-storey tower is expected to be completed by year-end and CDL hopes to pace out leasing activity to ride on rising office rents.

The drop in CDL's Q2 and H1 bottom lines was due to the absence of significant divestment gains which had boosted the same year-ago periods. In Q2 2013, CDL sold 100G Pasir Panjang, after selling strata units in Citimac Industrial Complex, Elite Industrial Buildings 1 and II in Q1 2013.

CDL's revenue rose 5.9 per cent to S$861.15 million in Q2 and edged up 0.4 per cent in H1 to S$1.595 billion. Shareholders will receive a special interim dividend of four cents per share, down from eight cents in H1 last year.

Earnings per share fell to 14.5 Singapore cents in Q2 2014 from 21.8 cents in Q2 last year. The counter ended 27 cents lower at S$9.78 yesterday. CDL released its results before the stock market opened.

site_title: Old-timers blow up the big screen again
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Old-timers blow up the big screen again

Dylan Tan

Published

Thu, Aug 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IN Singapore, when you hit your 60s, you look forward to the day when your Pioneer Generation pack arrives in the mail.

In Hollywood, you just rely on your six-pack - what muscleman action star Sylvester Stallone has been doing since 2010 after the 68-year-old hit pay dirt with The Expendables.

The old school shoot-em-up has become a lucrative franchise with a growing list of ageing action heroes coming on board for each sequel.

Joining The Expendables 3 are "newcomers" Wesley Snipes, Mel Gibson, Antonio Banderas, Harrison Ford and surprise, surprise, comedian Kelsey Grammer; while Jason Statham, Jet Li, Dolph Lundgren, Randy Couture, Terry Crews and Arnold Schwarzenegger return from the previous instalments.

There is also an obvious attempt to broaden the franchise's reach to a younger crowd with the violence noticeably toned down to PG-13 (compared to the original film's M-18 and first sequel's NC-16) which has been replaced by some humour instead.

Besides less gore and more punchlines, there is also an injection of fresh blood with younger faces such as Twilight alumnus Kellan Lutz, MMA star Ronda Rousey, boxer Victor Ortiz and television actor Glenn Powell added to the cast.

Other than that, it's more of the same once again because why fix something if it ain't broken. After all, the franchise was written for a specific audience - the kind that are also fans of the Grand Theft Auto video games - so it's only natural the story by Stallone (and co-written by Creighton Rothenberger and Katrin Benedikt) adopts a shoot-first-talk-later approach.

The bad guy this time is Stonebanks (Gibson), a rogue ex-member and co-founder of The Expendables, who has since become a ruthless arms dealer. He's supposed to be dead after Ross (Stallone) killed him but shows up out of the blue and vows to exterminate The Expendables.

He fires a warning shot by injuring the group's barrel weapons specialist, Caesar (Terry Crews). Fearing for the lives of the other members, Ross disbands the group and instead hires a bunch of youngsters who are a little more up to date with modern warfare to help him take on Stonebanks.

But when the new Expendables are captured by the bad guys, it's up to Ross's old boys to step in and save the day.

Among the newbies, Banderas is most memorable as a motormouth Spanish sharpshooter who gets on everybody's nerves with his incessant yakking. His humorous turn comes also as a breath of fresh air compared to Stallone and gang's deadpanning.

Gibson - no stranger to playing loose cannons in the Lethal Weapon and Mad Max films - goes the whole nine yards and looks like he's having fun playing a full-blown psychopath for a change; while Ford, who replaces Bruce Willis as the CIA agent, could have done with a meatier role and better lines.

The Expendables 3 is big and dumb because boys will be boys and retiring to play golf clearly isn't this pioneer generation's idea of fun.

Rating:

C+

site_title: Facing Goya defies all opera traditions
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Facing Goya defies all opera traditions

Director Ong Keng Sen confirms his reputation as an iconoclast, says HELMI YUSOF

Published

Thu, Aug 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

EXUBERANT or exasperating? Feat or flop? The brand new Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) raises its curtains with Facing Goya, a radical boundary-bashing opera directed by Ong Keng Sen, who is also, not coincidentally, the festival director of SIFA.

Composed by British composer Michael Nyman, with a libretto by Victoria Hardie, Facing Goya takes the audience across three time spans to examine how the skull of Francisco Goya, Spain's legendary painter, is being used by eugenicists to create the perfect human being.

The science-based opera is heavy on discourse, outlining the ethical debate on social engineering as it is first used by Nazi scientists to promote the Aryan race, and then by a modern-day biotech company for genetic manipulation.

For this and other reasons, Facing Goya is as far from the romantic worlds of Puccini, Verdi and Strauss as you can get. And the sooner you discard any expectation of traditional opera, the better you can appreciate this work.

The music by Nyman is neo-baroque post-minimalist, characterised by melodic passages that can abruptly give way to outbreaks of atonality. Hardie's libretto combines the arguments for and against eugenics with an off-kilter sense of humour.

Similarly, Ong does not attempt to portray the events in a realistic manner. With deliberately spare blocking and a generous Brechtian distance, the actors face the audience and sing their lines as if they were delivering a lecture. The set is a white backdrop on to which gorgeous images are projected, while costumes are fittingly eclectic.

This is contemporary opera beyond John Adams' Nixon In China and closer to Philip Glass and Robert Wilson's avant garde Einstein on the Beach. It's neo-baroque meets Brecht meets borderline insanity.

While I am a lover of classical opera, I am also a fan of Ong's cutting-edge art, having championed his works before, including his last four productions, Fear of Writing, Lear Dreaming, National Broadway Company and Goh Lay Kuan & Kuo Pao Kun. His oeuvre has been as wonderfully diverse as it has been divisive.

But I must also point out that while his works are often conceptual and challenging, they have rarely been this anarchic before. There was method and clarity in the style of the previous four works; Goya, in contrast, feels stylistically incoherent.

In the first half of the opera, Goya is sombre as it depicts the sinister efforts of Nazi craniologists in determining Aryan superiority. But in the second half, Goya becomes giddy and campy as it portrays the scientists in a modern-day lab trying to uncover the genetic code for genius.

Here, the multimedia design derives inspiration from contemporary art and scrambles the projection screen with gorgeous abstract images often spliced with Damien Hirst's famous diamond-studded skull - also physically replicated here to represent Goya's skull.

The second problem I have with Goya is the fact that the opera has been trimmed from its original 2.5-hour run to its present two-hour duration. The cuts here seem less than judicious, since it's hard to understand why Goya's skull was stolen, how it came into certain hands, and what the main character of the Art Banker (Suzanna Guzman) stands for.

With Facing Goya, Ong confirms his status as an eccentric iconoclast, unafraid to split his audiences' opinion down the middle, and draw cheers and jeers simultaneously. Unfortunately, some audience members are obviously not clued in on the conceit - which explains why some didn't return to their seats after the intermission, and the man next to me briefly snored.

I did not make that statement to insult the artist or overstress the importance of the audience reaction over the work's merits - only to point out how Ong as an artist has always raced past prevailing theatrical conventions without looking back. Sometimes, even long-distance runners lose their stamina.

site_title: Little elbow room for premium airlines in budget-conscious India
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Little elbow room for premium airlines in budget-conscious India

Stiff competition in all sectors will result in fewer airlines in country, say analysts

Published

Thu, Aug 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW DELHI] A decade after low-cost carriers (LCCs) led India's air travel boom, full-service airlines are gearing up for a battle for premium passengers that only the deep-pocketed are likely to win.

Flag carrier Air India, which has offered only premium travel, will face more competition from second- largest airline Jet Airways, which on Monday said it would ditch its budget unit and focus on the full-service market amid mounting losses.

The carriers are also bracing for Vistara, a venture between Singapore Airlines and conglomerate Tata Sons, which will start flying in October.

The competition in the full-service sector is heating up with no guarantees there will be enough passengers willing to pay higher prices to sustain three carriers in a market where low-fares dominate and where airlines struggle to make a profit.

"There will be a bloodbath. The competition is only going to become more intense," said Amber Dubey, head of aerospace and defence at consultancy KPMG.

A large, and increasingly affluent, population makes India one of the world's most attractive air travel markets. Passenger numbers have risen 13 per cent a year since 2003 - a rate analysts say outpaces most other markets.

But intense competition and higher operating costs mean Indian airlines lost a combined US$1.77 billion last year and are projected to lose up to US$1.4 billion this year, according to data from industry consultancy CAPA - Centre for Aviation.

That compares with the US$18 billion profit airlines globally are expected to make this year, up from last year's US$10.3 billion, International Air Transport Association (Iata) data shows.

Low-cost carriers such as Indigo, SpiceJet and GoAir have cornered two-thirds of the domestic market, and were joined this year by a joint venture between Malaysia's AirAsia and Tata Sons.

Full-service carriers compete for the remainder one-third domestically, and with foreign carriers such as Emirates, Qatar Airways, British Airways, SIA and Lufthansa on international routes.

Increasingly, they must also battle one another. "There is demand at the upper end in India but it is nothing like the demand at the bottom end," said Kapil Kaul, chief executive for South Asia at CAPA. "You now have three airlines competing for the same customer."

Air India is the most unprofitable carrier, but is also the one most likely to survive the battle for passengers because of government support.

The carrier, which received a US$5.8 billion state bailout in 2012, halved its operating losses for the 2013-2014 fiscal year to 21.2 billion rupees (S$433 million) by restructuring its operations over several years and cutting costs. It retired older aircraft and introduced fuel-efficient planes such as the Boeing 787, and plans to add new Airbus A320s and Boeing 737s.

Air India also finally joined the Star Alliance group of carriers this year, allowing it to leverage the network of, and traffic feed from, partners such as Lufthansa, United Airlines and All Nippon Airways.

"The Indian government owns us. Just like any other promoter, they will pump money into their investment," said a senior Air India executive who did not want to be named as he was not authorised to speak to the media. "Do you think the government will allow us to fail after investing so much money?"

Jet Airways, which has yet to turn a profit since 2007, said that it would focus solely on full-service to gain market share. It barely survived a battle with Kingfisher Airlines, which folded in 2012, and its balance sheet is shored up by Abu Dhabi's Etihad Airways, which bought a 24 per cent stake this year.

The intense competition across all sectors will probably result in fewer airlines in India, analysts say. "We expect consolidation over the next 12-18 months," said Mr Dubey. "At the current level of air travel penetration, the Indian market can only support at the most four strong pan-Indian airlines." - Reuters

SUBSCRIBERS

Schizophrenic biopic of a flawed Indonesian patriot

Published Thu, Aug 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THERE are moments when Soekarno - a biopic about the rise to political prominence of Indonesia's first president Sukarno (the film uses the Indonesian spelling of his name) during the country's Dutch colonial period and subsequent occupation by the Japanese in World War II - resembles a cross between a stodgy retelling of history and a roiling soap opera about a charismatic leader and the women in his life.

In the course of trying to present a larger-than-life historical figure as a man of the people on a mission to unite a country who (by the way) also happened to have a keen eye for the ladies, neither his public persona nor his private one is fully examined. It's as if the film, directed by Hanung Bramantyo, couldn't quite make up its mind about which aspect to focus on.

Given the external issues the filmmakers had to deal with (see accompanying story) and also perhaps as a result of decisions made in the editing room, it's not surprising that Soekarno ended up with a split personality. Despite its flaws, the film is aided to some extent by a sense of shared destiny with our neighbour during the period covered, especially during the war years. Students of history and anyone old enough to remember those turbulent times will find some interesting material to digest here, although they may have to endure stiff melodrama to get to it.

site_title: Dubai's top two builders turn to bank borrowings
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Dubai's top two builders turn to bank borrowings

Bill delays, cost overruns to blame; working capital coming under pressure

Published

Thu, Aug 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[DUBAI] Dubai's two biggest builders are turning to bank borrowing to help fund projects as a rise in late payments from their customers takes the shine off a booming construction market.

Arabtec Holding PJSC, the contractor that helped push Dubai stocks into a bear market in June, said that money owed by clients rose to 8.8 billion dirhams (S$2.98 billion) through the second quarter from 7.2 billion dirhams at the end of last year. Drake & Scull International, the emirate's second-largest publicly traded builder, took two term loans totalling about 199 million dirhams in the first half, according to its financial statements.

While both builders are benefiting from rising orders, the need to borrow from banks means costly interest payments and could slow the completion of projects, according to analysts. A rapid expansion of Arabtec's backlog has added to the company's arrears, while delays for redesigns and cost overruns in Saudi Arabia are hurting cash flow and profitability at Drake & Scull.

"The payment situation for contractors hasn't improved since the beginning of 2013" even as the Dubai economy strengthens, said Taher Safieddine, an analyst at Shuaa Capital in Dubai, on Wednesday. "Working capital is continuously under pressure, which is forcing contractors to go to the banks to cover the shortfall."

Calls and emails to Arabtec seeking comments on their funding needs were not returned, while a public relations executive for Drake & Scull declined to comment.

Both Arabtec and Drake & Scull are getting term loans, facilities and overdrafts from their banks, Mr Safieddine said. Arabtec's debt climbed by 392 million dirhams in the second quarter to 1.29 billion dirhams.

"The majority, if not all, bank loans extended to contractors tend to be tied to specific contracts and projects," said Artur Uluc, director of corporate finance at Mashreq Bank in Dubai, on Wednesday. "The loans are typically more expensive than those provided to other types of companies because recovery on a specific project can be tricky if a contractor isn't paid."

Short-term loans to builders can be priced at 275 basis points to 425 basis points over the benchmark Emirates interbank offered rate, or Eibor, Mr Uluc said. The three-month Eibor fell to 0.72 per cent yesterday, close to a low reached on July 12, data compiled by Bloomberg showed.

Arabtec will probably need to raise cash through debt or equity "within months" because existing authorisations to increase capital expire by the end of the year, Allen Sandeep, a Cairo-based construction analyst at Naeem Brokerage, said in a note to clients. Delaying fundraising into 2015 would create the need for new approvals from the board and the regulator, he said.

Arabtec's backlog has surged by 70 per cent to more than 23.8 billion dirhams since the end of last year, putting pressure on the company's working capital at a time when a "good amount of subcontracting" requires the company to commit cash, Mr Sandeep said.

"The issue is new projects that have come into the backlog in past year and half but haven't turned into revenue yet" for Arabtec, Alia El Mehelmy, a Cairo-base equity analyst at CI Capital Holdings, said by phone. "The challenge is kick starting these projects."

At Drake & Scull, "significant" delays on projects in Saudi Arabia as well as cost overruns in general contracting in the first half are affecting operational margins and profit, chief financial officer Mukhtar Safi said in a statement on Sunday. - Bloomberg

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

The science of protection

When it comes to sun protection, the higher the SPF number the better, right? And what does the PA+ stand for anyway? L'Oreal's expert in photoprotection lays bare the facts. By Cheah Ui-Hoon

Published Fri, Aug 15, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SO here are the definitive guidelines: You want to apply sun protection of at least SPF15 but it need not be higher than SPF50. You also want to look for creams or lotions that screen out UVA besides UVB, especially in Asia where the sun is more intense.

By now, sun protection is such a norm, especially in the tropics, it's surprising to find out that SPF standards came out only about 30 years ago. Even though the first commercial product was brought to the market in the 1930s, introduced by the founder of L'Oreal.

It's just in recent years though, that scientists are getting a better understanding of UVA just now, as opposed to just UVB. "Now, the need to be protected against UVA radiation is much clearer," says Dominique Moyal, Technico-Regulatory expert in photoprotection, L'Oreal Research & Innovation.

There are two parts to UVA, she points out, which accounts for up to 95 per cent of the solar UV radiation reaching the Earth's surface. UVA is known as the ultraviolet with a longer wavelength, but there is short UVA and long UVA.

UVB stops at 290-320 nanometres, and short UVA comes right after, between 320-340 nm. Then long UVA goes up to 400 nm - and this is the one which causes pigmentation and wrinkles.

UVA in general is less harmful in terms of cellular and DNA damage than UVB.

"But it is more damaging in terms of pigmentation and wrinkles," points out Dr Moyal.

Think of UVA as rays which age, and UVB as rays which burn.

In Asia, skin cancer such as basal carcinoma or melanoma is less frequent in the population compared to Europe or Australia. "In Asia, the percentage of skin cancer is really low probably due to the genetics of the skin but also to the different behaviour in terms of sun exposure," says Dr Moyal.

Asian skin, with its naturally high levels of melasma and phototypes 3, 4, or 5, is more sensitive to UVA however, and the consequence is pigmentation. Asians are especially prone to problems with hyperpigmentation spots, or melasma.

However, even though UVA causes wrinkles, Asians are genetically less sensitive to wrinkles, Dr Moyal notes, with wrinkles appearing later in Asians compared to Caucasians.

Wrinkle problems result from UVA penetrating more deeply into the dermis, attacking the dermis' fibres, causing wrinkles. "With UVA exposure, there is a photo oxidation of the melanin. So you have immediate darkening. After one hour in the sun, you get darkening. That's why you must protect against UVA," advises Dr Moyal, who was in Singapore recently for the launch of the La Roche Posay Anthelios XL Ultra-Light Fluid SPF50+ designed especially for the Asian tropics.

As for selecting SPFs, it's all a question of skin colour. For the Asian phototype 3, an intermediate skin colour, between SPF15 and 50+ is required, says Dr Moyal. "But even if you have darker skin, you always need to have UVA protection. An SPF30 with a UVA 15 or higher for dark skin it is the best solution," she suggests.

For "normal" skin, which means skin without problems recovering from DNA damage, then the SPF50 is maximum number you need. "SPF 100 is for people very sensitive to UVB or with a problem of DNA repair. It's not useful in Asia, because based on genetics, there is no big issue of repair to the DNA," she adds.

She says that there are very few countries having regulations allowing SPF of 100. It's 50+ in Japan, Korea and Asean, and 30+ in China. "Because SPF100 are for people who are very sensitive to UV light or with skin cancer, for example, when you are talking about pathology."

She adds: "It is more important to have a good balance of protection between UVA and UVB. SPF protection has both short UVA and UVB protection and globally, SPF mainly offers UVB protection."

And really, SPF is related to the time you spend outside.

"If you spend only one hour in the sun, SPF 15 is enough. But if you spend more time exposed, you have to increase the factor according to the amount of time you spend in the sun," reiterates Dr Moyal. Applying it uniformly is another important practice.

Normally, when applied in a uniform layer, for about six hours, a single application of a SPF50+-PA4+ (PA++++) is sufficient. For longer exposure, re-application would be needed depending on the sun's intensity.

site_title: Behind closed doors
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Behind closed doors

Exclusive, password-required events are popping up around Singapore. TAY SUAN CHIANG offers a glimpse into these 'secret' gatherings

Published

Thu, Aug 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

PSST . . . have you heard? The trend of supperclubs is going strong in Singapore, but those password-required, location-unknown events have gone into the design and music scene as well.

Hipster store The Redundant Shop has held two by-invite only events for design folks and customers. Since June, the shop at Everton Park has held two Back Door Access events, so called because guests enter via the shop's back entrance. And yes, a password is needed before entry is granted.

Watson Lee, founder of The Redundant Shop and design publication The Redundant Magazine, came up with the idea for Back Door Access after attending similar private events in Shanghai, such as a motorcycle launch in an abandoned warehouse.

"I was struck by the secrecy of the event, its invitation-only guest list and especially the location of the event - an abandoned warehouse that no one took notice of," says Mr Lee. "I had to walk through back lanes of houses to get passwords and directions from the residents before arriving at the venue."

He now holds monthly Back Door Access events, where about 50 people turn up each time to meet and listen to designers talk about their work. The vibe is fun, with a DJ spinning music, free-flow of drinks and often a workshop, where guests can get crafty.

Jeffrey Koh, founder of creative firm Flab Slab, has also been holding secret events at his studio in Commonwealth. Friends and family get invited to his F**king Friday events, where they are welcome to doodle on his studio walls.

"It is an opportunity for pals to come and spend some time together," he says. He is open to having members of the public join in as well.

F**king Fridays take place so randomly that Mr Koh is not able to say when the next one is. He has held six since he started the event last November. "I usually announce that I will be having one a week or so in advance. Those who want to come will start scrambling to change their plans or make it after dinner," he says.

Meanwhile, an increasing number of people are turning up at strangers' homes to listen to music instead of heading to clubs and performance venues.

Sofar Sounds, which started in London in 2010, is now in 86 cities across 37 countries. Sofar Sounds Singapore began last year. What happens is music fans turn up at private gigs, usually held in a local resident's living room, to listen to a band play.

Sofar Sounds co-founder Rafe Offer and two friends came up with the idea after noticing that many people in a bar were talking or fiddling with their phones during a musician's set. "We thought how crazy it was that great music was ignored - even when people bought a ticket. We thought there must be a better way to experience this," says Mr Offer.

The appeal of Sofar Sounds, says Mr Offer, is that the event is focused on the music, and nothing else. A list of gigs playing in the different cities is put up on the website, and guests sign up for a gig in their home city.

"You don't know the acts until you show up, and you don't even know where it will be until the night before, so it is a bit of an adventure," says Mr Offer. "We are also obsessed with getting a range of great music on, so you might just hear 'the next big thing' - but in someone's living room."

He adds that Sofar Sounds aims to create a richer, more intimate experience for fans and also the musicians.

While some organisers are keen to get the word out on their events, Mr Lee prefers to keep his guests list tight. "We want Back Door Access to be exclusive, so that we can focus on the right target audience," he says, adding that space is limited, hence the invitation list cannot be extensive. "I think by keeping it private, there will be more interest, or should I say curiosity, about the event."

Enter via password

THE invitation to The Redundant Shop's by-invitation only event comes with an advisory - "Don't be shocked that our shutters are down when you try to come through our front door."

Instead, guests enter by the back, hence the event name, Back Door Access. The Redundant Shop's founder Watson Lee says many underground parties in the United States are like that. "The Redundant Shop in Everton Park has an unique back door area that you don't see a lot of anymore in Singapore," he says. "So we thought why not use the back door as the entrance, since Back Door Access starts only after the shop closes and when the shutters comes down."

The store has held two Back Door Access events since it started in June. At each one, a designer talks about his works and inspirations. Award winning Singaporean designer Melvin Ong of Desinere, known for making vases and paper weights using the pleating technique, was the first speaker. Last month, Mr Lee flew in Mexican designer Guillermo Juarez of Cazapapeles for Back Door Access. Mr Juarez is best known for his cardboard creations, which include life-sized sculptures of polar bears and wolves. Incidentally, Cazapapeles means paper hunters in Spanish.

At Back Door Access, Mr Juarez not only showcased his works, which are cardboard sculptures used to put across a message, but also did a live demonstration of how he creates a wolf using cardboard.

"There are no restrictions in who we want to invite, but rather, we are constantly looking for passionate people who might need a platform to share to a very targeted audience group as well as for the group of new talents to expose their work to our audience," says Mr Lee.

He adds that Back Door Access is not just a platform for talks, but "we hope to encourage more independent artists, aspiring designers, or even publishers to launch their work through the monthly event."

The third Back Door Access will be held later this month, and it will be a book launch.

Those who get invited include shop customers, business partners as well as people from the design industry. Entry to the event is via a password, which will be made known upon RSVP.

"But of course we welcome anyone who is interested and who knows someone from The Redundant Shop network to come join us," says Mr Lee.

Back Door Access is more than just a monthly gathering event, says Mr Lee. "It was intended to allow our customers to understand the inspiration as well as the face of the creators behind some of the products we sell at The Redundant Shop."

Chilling out over art and toys

WHAT happens when you put a group of doodlers and toy collectors in a room? Crazy stuff, such as having all the walls doodled on, which is essentially what happens at a F**king Friday event.

"As the farcical name F**king Friday implies, this is really just an excuse for people who are into art and toys to hang out on a Friday evening with free flow of Redbull and whatever drinks they can find in our fridge," says organiser Jeffrey Koh, founder of creative firm Flab Slab. "We see this as a gathering of like-minded people to get together and have fun. It is an excuse for us to invite people over to our studio one Friday a month."

F**king Friday, started last November, and takes place almost once a month. On its name, Mr Koh says that Friday is the day that every working adult looks forward to, and it is also the time when people start thinking about what to do and where to party. "So what better way than to start off the weekend by proclaiming it F**king Friday."

It started with a handful of Mr Koh's friends turning up, coming by to chill and chat till the wee hours of Saturday mornings. Soon, friends started bringing their friends and the circle widened. There would be about 30 people at each F**king Friday, "but the number can grow to 100 when we have overseas artists in town visiting us," says Mr Koh.

The gathering takes place at the Flab Slab studio at Commonwealth after office hours, when other tenants in the office building have left. The security guards are informed there will be a late night party happening.

Mr Koh explains that at each F**king Friday, the folks from Band of Doodlers and Tell Your Children come over to doodle and draw on the studio walls. "Those into toys will sometimes transact or trade with each other. We'll also talk about what is hot and what's not and what's happening in the scene in general."

Mr Koh says he does this out of a personal interest in art and toys. "I don't make any money out of it at all. It is tough to find a place in Singapore where you can hang out with friends and strangers without any pressure to buy anything. I also see this as an opportunity for people to make new friends and collaborate on projects some time down the road."

While it has been friends and family who come, Mr Koh welcomes the public too. "Since it is usually held in the studio and we can put together the event quite quickly, we don't have fixed dates. The best way is to check out our facebook page at www.facebook.com/flabslab or send an email to mastermind@flabslab.com to find out more details," he says.

Ultimately it is all about people coming together. "The only yardstick is that everyone should have fun. You don't have to pay for anything, not even a cup of coffee since drinks are always on the house."

Enjoying live music at strangers' homes

A CONCERT hall isn't the only way to enjoy a live gig. What about going to someone's home instead?

Sofar Sounds is exactly that - listening to live music from the comfort of one's living room. It was an idea that took root in 2010 in London, and to date, it has spread to 86 cities in 37 countries.

Here's how it works: You sign up on the website, and each month, you receive a list of gigs and the cities they will be in. Sign up for the gig that you want, and the exact location will only be revealed the day before the gig.

Depending on the response, you could be in an intimate group of about 20 people listening to some original music.

The Singapore branch of Sofar Sounds was started last April by Sam Drury, a Londoner who works in foreign exchange. Ms Drury hosted the first Sofar Sounds at her home in Serangoon. Since then, there have been six gigs held here.

Some of the musicians who have performed include Inch Chua, Monster Cat, The Good Life Project and The Sam Willows.

Ms Drury says, while response has been encouraging, it can be better.

She cites the example of how sometimes it can be difficult to find bands willing to be a part of Sofar Sounds, which means fewer gigs available.

Interested bands have to audition before they are accepted. "We do want to have the best bands play," says Ms Drury. She is part of a team of volunteers who review bands live and through video and sound clips. "It is the same in other cities. Only when a band gets positive reviews, are they then invited to play."

She adds: "We like original, high quality music. Nothing that is over produced or too formulaic."

Most bands do unplugged sets. "Even for the punk bands, which is a chance to see them in a different setting, and you get to see them upclose too," says Ms Drury.

Apart from bands, Ms Drury hopes to see more people coming forward to volunteer, to be reviewers or to help in sound and videography. All gigs are video recorded and put online, so fans can watch the musicians whenever they like. Currently, Flutter Sound Studio, a recording company and boutique media production firm, Cat on a Ledge, have been great supporters of Sofar Sounds, by providing their services.

Gigs are mostly held in a living room. "Hosts only need to provide a space. The sound crew will come by earlier in the day, to see the best place for the band to be in. We tell guests who are coming to bring their own drinks," says Ms Drury. Each gig is free.

"Coming to a Sofar Sounds gig lets you listen to music in a new environment. You don't know the lineup till the day, so there's a bit of mystery in it, and you get to meet like-minded people," she says.

The biggest satisfaction she gets out of doing this? "When I see the audience around the living room, nodding their heads to the music."

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

SingTel's Q1 profit down 17.4%

Bottom line hit by one-off items and weaker regional currencies

Nisha Ramchandani

Published

Thu, Aug 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] South-east Asia's largest telco operator Singapore Telecommunications (SingTel) has posted a 17.4 per cent year- on-year slide in net profit to S$834.6 million for the first quarter ended June 30, hit by one-off items and translation effects from weaker regional currencies.

SingTel, which gets the majority of Ebitda (earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation) from outside Singapore, saw its bottom line under pressure as the Singapore dollar strengthened against currencies in markets where the group or its associates operate.

Revenue was down 3.4 per cent at about S$4.15 billion as the Australian dollar weakened 5.4 per cent year-on-year against the Singapore currency, although revenue would have been stable if currency fluctuations were stripped out.

The Indonesian rupiah declined 18.5 per cent against the Singapore dollar while the Indian rupee fell 7.2 per cent, SingTel said.

Underlying net profit dipped 1.8 per cent to S$881 million, missing analysts' expectations for S$916 million, according to a Reuters poll of four brokerages. Without currency fluctuations, underlying net profit would have been up 5 per cent.

Earnings per share worked out to 5.24 Singapore cents in Q1 FY15, down from 6.35 Singapore cents in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

The quarter's results felt the impact of staff restructuring costs of S$27 million and a S$17 million share of India's Bharti Airtel's exceptional loss for various disputes and provisions.

The corresponding quarter last year was also lifted by an exceptional gain of S$150 million from the dilution of its stake in Airtel.

SingTel's unit Down Under, Optus, reported a 1.8 per cent slide in net profit to A$164 million (S$190.2 million) due to exceptional items relating to a provision for workforce restructuring. Otherwise, underlying net profit rose 12.3 per cent to A$187 million.

Rival operator Telstra yesterday unveiled a strong set of results, reporting a 14.3 per cent rise in full-year post-tax profit to A$4.28 billion and announced plans for a A$1 billion share buyback.

Meanwhile, SingTel's share of associates' pre-tax profits grew 7.6 per cent to S$622 million with strong earnings growth from Airtel. Excluding currency translation effects, it would have been up 19 per cent.

In Singapore, SingTel's mobile revenue rose 2 per cent to S$518 million, while SingTel's pay-TV service mio garnered more than 100,000 home subscribers for the 2014 Fifa World Cup, with mio TV revenue up 65 per cent at S$63 million. Excluding 2014 World Cup revenue, mio TV revenue would have been S$53 million.

Revenue for the group's enterprise segment was more or less flat at S$1.56 billion, as higher mobile and ICT revenue in Singapore was offset by lower revenue in Australia. Ebitda fell 7 per cent to S$510 million with margins coming under pressure.

Its group digital life segment earned revenues of around S$48 million, up 61 per cent, with higher advertising revenues. However, negative Ebitda for Q1 FY15 widened to S$45 million.

SingTel said it expects consolidated revenue and Ebitda for the full financial year to be stable.

Meanwhile, CIMB analysts expect that negative foreign currency effects should abate in the coming quarters as associate currencies have stabilised.

"Operationally, associates performed within expectations; Bharti was the star performer, with strong revenue growth and margin expansion," they said in a research note.

OCBC Investment Research analyst Carey Wong said yesterday that results and guidance were mostly in line with OCBC's forecast. However, given the rally in the stock price in recent months, Mr Wong downgraded his call on the stock to "hold", opting to buy at S$3.85 "or better".

In the stock market, SingTel shares were four cents lower yesterday at S$3.87.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

MOH: No suspected case of Ebola in S'pore

Published

Thu, Aug 14, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Following reports yesterday that the first suspected Ebola victim has been identified in Singapore, the Ministry of Health (MOH) has released an official statement assuring the public that Singapore remains Ebola- free.

According to The Straits Times, the suspected victim - a Nigerian woman in her 50s believed to have flown into Singapore recently - arrived at Gleneagles Hospital's emergency department yesterday morning with complaints of a fever. She was then identified as a suspect of Ebola and sent to the Communicable Diseases Centre at Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) immediately after being isolated.

In response, an MOH spokesman said: "The MOH wishes to clarify that there is no suspect case of Ebola in Singapore at present. The case in question was indeed referred to Tan Tock Seng Hospital, but she does not fit the case definition."

TTSH's chief executive officer, Philip Choo, was also reported as saying that the woman in question has "no contact with any suspect or confirmed patients". The woman has since been discharged.

Ebola is a deadly viral disease that has taken over 1,000 lives in West Africa recently. The crisis has been declared by the World Health Organization as a global health emergency. Ebola is transmitted through direct contact with the blood or bodily fluids of an infected person or though exposure to objects, such as needles contaminated with infected secretions. The disease has no specific cure yet.

A spokesman for the ministry said: "MOH will continue to closely monitor the situation, and continually assess and calibrate its measures."

KS Energy's Q2 earnings soar on disposal gain

Published

KS ENERGY'S second-quarter net profit rose from S$1.5 million a year ago to S$46.7 million. The better earnings attributable to equity-holders were in part due to a gain of S$54.4 million arising from a disposal of plant and equipment.

For the April-June quarter, revenue rose 44.1 per cent, from S$41.5 million to S$59.8 million.

The drilling segment posted the largest increase of 57.4 per cent, from S$35.7 million to S$56.1 million. This was mainly generated by the commencement of charter contracts in Indonesia and Vietnam. Revenue contribution from the drilling business made up about 93.9 per cent of the group's consolidated revenue for Q2.

Meanwhile, revenue from the engineering business dropped 80.8 per cent, from S$5 million to S$963,000. Revenue contribution from the engineering business made up 1.6 per cent of the group's consolidated revenue.

Earnings per share were 9.11 cents compared with 0.29 cent a year ago.

For the six months ended June, net profit rose from S$2.4 million to S$46.9 million. Revenue rose 41.9 per cent from S$74.5 million to S$105.7 million.

Kris Wiluan, chairman and CEO of KS Energy said: "In the first half of 2014, our drilling business secured charter contracts valued at over US$118 million and took delivery of a new Friede & Goldman Super M2 design jack-up drilling rig. This has strengthened our operating performance. Additionally, our drilling business ordered the construction of a jack-up drilling rig based on the Friede & Goldman JU-2000E design. This rig is scheduled for delivery before the end of 2016 and should contribute to our future growth."

Its counter ended trading up one cent, at 47 cents yesterday.
