content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Foodpanda gets US$60m in fresh funding

Published

Mon, Aug 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Global food delivery platform Foodpanda, along with its affiliated brands hellofood and Delivery Club, announced a fresh financing of US$60 million, bringing its total funds raised to over US$100 million since its inception in 2012. It previously secured US$28 million in funding in 2013

and US$20 million early this year. This round of funding came from a group of investors including existing investors such as Rocket Internet - Foodpanda's parent incubator firm.

Speaking with regards to the new round of funding, Ralf Wenzel, global managing director of Foodpanda, said: "We are very pleased by the sign of confidence and the acknowledgment of our current success."

"The new funding will be invested in continuous growth in our existing markets, by partnering with even more restaurants in more cities and further improving customer service."

The homegrown brand is already one of the leading online food delivery firms, offering services to over 40 countries over the world. It is one of the fastest expanding startup under its German incubator firm.

Foodpanda's concept is a simple one - an online service, offered via website and mobile application, where customers can search for restaurants and place an order. Foodpanda then sends the order directly to the restaurant, which then delivers the meal to the customer. To generate revenue, Foodpanda takes a percentage success fee - a cut out of every order made via their online platforms.

Competitor, Delivery Club, was also recently acquired by the Foodpanda group, making it the leading food delivery site in Russia.

Given the recent spate of events surrounding Russia, it seems unusual for businesses to venture into the market. The country has been sanctioned heavily following an ongoing conflict involving Ukraine.

However, Foodpanda is not fazed.

"The sanctions imposed by Russia will not have any impact on our business since we are not exporting or importing any goods but, rather, focus on providing a smooth and hassle-free food delivery service to customers and restaurants within Russia." Chinmay Malaviya, managing director of Foodpanda Singapore and Hong Kong, explained through an e-mail interview.

Entrance into the Russian market should not be taken to mean that further expansion plans are right around the corner. In fact, expansion seems to have taken a backseat for now.

Mr Malaviya said: "Currently, Foodpanda operates in more than 40 countries across four continents and instead of focusing on just expanding to more countries, we plan to position ourselves as the market leader in our existing markets by various approaches . . . and ultimately to further strengthen and uphold the identity of Foodpanda as the online marketplace for restaurants and a trustable online food ordering platform to customers."

site_title: RBS said to be giving up half its space in HK's Central district
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

RBS said to be giving up half its space in HK's Central district

Some will move to Lincoln House in the eastern district of Quarry Bay

Published

Mon, Aug 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[HONG KONG] Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc, the UK lender scaling back its investment-banking business, is planning to reduce the office space it rents in Hong Kong's Central business district by half, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.

The bank leases about 60,000 square feet in the AIA Central building, the people said, declining to be named because the information isn't public. It plans to keep half of that for Coutts & Co, its private banking unit, and most of the other employees will move to Lincoln House in the eastern district of Quarry Bay, where RBS already leases space, by the end of the year, they said.

Office rents in Central, where banks such as HSBC Holdings Plc and Goldman Sachs Group Inc have their regional headquarters, are falling as foreign financial firms continue to downsize or relocate to cut costs. Tenants in the city on three-year leases expiring this year may be able to negotiate on average rents that are 20 per cent lower than current leases, according to Cushman & Wakefield Inc.

Alexander Chu, the Edinburgh-based bank's country executive for Hong Kong, declined to comment on the move.

Rents in grade-A office buildings fell 1.8 per cent in the first half and may decline 3 per cent this year, according to a Cushman report last month. Rents in the greater Central area, which slid 0.5 per cent this year, will remain stable for the next six months as demand is supported by mainland Chinese financial firms and smaller tenants, it said.

Grade-A office rents in greater Central were HK$96.30 (S$15.50) per square foot a month in the second quarter, compared with HK$45.20 a square foot in Hong Kong East, where Lincoln House is located, according to data from Cushman. AIA Central was developed by AIA International Ltd and Lai Sun Development Co Lincoln House, which also has Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd and Lenovo Group Ltd as tenants, is owned by Swire Properties Ltd.

RBS, the UK's largest state-owned lender, is shrinking its investment-banking units around the world as it strives to revive profits. The UK government owns a majority of the bank after its bailout during the global financial crisis.

In Asia, RBS has already sold most of its investment banking business in the region to CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, Malaysia's second-largest bank by assets.

site_title: China game makers see S-E Asia as a springboard
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

China game makers see S-E Asia as a springboard

Looking to expand from the saturated home market, they want to test out games and monetisation models before taking them West, reports VICTORIA HO

Published

Sun, Aug 10, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AN increasingly saturated games scene in China has prompted a wave of Chinese game developers to seek new audiences, said the organiser of China's largest mobile game conference.

"Although the Chinese market is extremely big, it's also saturated. About 100 games are published each day," said Maxim de Wit, who leads international business for the Global Mobile Game Confederation (GMGC).

"The companies that have made a lot of money are looking to expand, and many of our members have asked for events to be organised in South-east Asia. They see the region as a convenient springboard out of China, with a long history of business done here, and a relatively smaller market (to tackle) compared with Western markets."

GMGC organises an annual global mobile games developers' conference, and monthly gaming events throughout China. Mr De Wit, who is based in Beijing, said the events reach out to various players in the Chinese mobile games ecosystem, which include analytics companies, payment providers and messaging firms.

GMGC was in Singapore in July with a delegation of Chinese developers, keen to explore the South-east Asian landscape.

Chinese developers targeting Western markets are keen to test their theories here, because of the relatively Western tastes in games here, said Mr De Wit. This includes casual games like "Candy Crush Saga" which have worked in Western markets, and are very popular in South-east Asia.

Also, compared with Chinese users who are more tolerant of badly placed ads, Western users are more likely to uninstall a game if an ad pops up at an inopportune time during the game, for instance, he said.

Chinese developers are also keen to test different monetisation models here. This includes figuring out the optimal price and mix of in-app purchases within free games, or whether a game should carry ads instead.

Notwithstanding the overseas push, the Chinese games market is huge, with the potential audience growing every day as more and more people buy their first smartphones in the country, said Mr De Wit.

According to Superdata Research, China's mobile games revenue is expected to reach US$3 billion this year, and is expected to cross US$3.2 billion next year.

Gartner's tracker shows China's smartphone sales grew 86.3 per cent in 2013, and IDC expects 420 million smartphones will be sold over 2014.

Mr De Wit noted that the Chinese market is too big for developers globally to ignore. He said that the first thing developers should figure out going into China is what the taste of the audience there is. Currently, card collection games like Blizzard's "Hearthstone: Heroes of Warcraft" do well, as well as casual games from Tencent.

Role-playing games

There is a growing move towards role-playing games which are more demanding on phone hardware, because of the advancements in phone processors and improving 4G connectivity in China, he added.

The market is also heavily Android-dominated, at about 80 per cent of the smartphone market, so companies should funnel more investment and effort into prioritising Android first, compared with Western markets where most developers release iOS and Android at the same time, or iOS first, he said.

Freemium does well, and local players are quite likely to pay for premium content in the games if they like the basic game. They are also fairly accepting of in-app advertising if it means they don't have to pay for the game.

The final, critical step to success is figuring out the right games publisher, said Mr De Wit. "You should take your time to find the right publisher, and examine the agreement that it spells out clearly which entity takes care of which tasks in promoting the game," he said.

Unlike Western markets, which rely on Google's official Play store, there is a multitude of third party app stores in China because of easier payment methods afforded by the latter group. This proliferation of app stores makes marketing a complicated task and a good publisher with a good game plan is needed to tap the market, he said.

"It is possible to be successful in China without physically being in China, but your publisher needs to be there. User acquisition and getting a game noticed can cost a lot of money," he said.

Published

Sun, Aug 10, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WAS the sudden, sharp drop in the Tokyo stock market last Friday a knee jerk reaction by investors to news that US President Barrack Obama had authorised fresh air strikes in Iraq, thus provoking a resumption of "risk-off" attitudes? Or did it signal that foreign investors are losing faith in Abenomics and are heading for the exit?

Analysts say this week should provide some answers to the question posed by the 3 per cent drop in Tokyo prices on a day when other markets were largely unchanged despite escalation of fighting in both Iraq and the Ukraine.

What has set alarm bells ringing is the Bank of Japan's official acknowledgment last Friday after its policy board met that export prospects for Japan's still heavily export-dependent economy are not looking bright, at a time when domestic demand is still suffering from the impact of a consumption tax hike several months ago.

Global investors poured into the Tokyo stock market some 18 months ago when Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Liberal Democratic Party came to power, promising aggressive measures to boost Japan's long stagnant and deflation-ridden economy.

More piled in after Mr Abe appointed former Asian Development Bank president Haruhiko Kuroda as governor of the Bank of Japan. Mr Kuroda's massive monetary easing resulted in a 20 per cent depreciation of the yen against the dollar, setting the stage, it seemed, for an export boom in Japan.

The Nikkei 222 stock average duly soared by nearly 60 per cent in value in the year after Mr Abe arrived and what is particularly significant now, is that the percentage of all listed Japanese shares owned by foreign investors surged to over 30 per cent compared with 5 per cent in 1990.

If those investors should begin to lose faith now in Mr Abe's economic policies - known as "Abenomics" - the impact on the Tokyo stock market could be dramatic, some analysts suggest.

This is why, they add, last Friday's sudden drop in the Tokyo market is likely to create a good deal of nervousness this week until it becomes clearer how investors are going to react to last week's adverse news about Japan's immediate export prospects.

Today marks the start of Japan's annual, ancestor-honouring O-bon holiday period, so stock trading by domestic investors could be light, which could exaggerate the impact of any sell-off by foreign investors who nowadays dominate trading activity in the market.

The Bank of Japan was careful to point out last Friday that it is not downgrading its overall assessment of Japan's economic prospects in the short to medium term and, at a special briefing for foreign media last week, officials of Japan's Ministry of Finance sought to strike an upbeat note about the economy.

"Japan's economy is expected to continue its moderate recovery as a trend," the BOJ said. "The effects of the subsequent decline in demand following the front-loaded increase prior to the consumption tax hike are expected to wane gradually."

Ministry of Finance officials meanwhile pointed to what they said were encouraging signs for the Japanese economy, including rising wage and bonus payments which they said should lead to increased personal consumption quite soon.

"Sales are coming back and GDP is expected to grow steadily," one official said. He also brushed aside concerns about the recent weakness in Japan's industrial output and argued that currently low business inventories should lead to an increase in industrial output in coming months.

But the BOJ and the finance ministry admit that "structural changes" in Japan's economy have had a more profound impact than expected. A good deal of manufacturing production has been shifted offshore in response to the strong yen, and the weaker yen now does not help boost exports in the way that it used to.

Meanwhile, financial markets continue to doubt that the Bank of Japan will be able to achieve its targeted inflation goal of 2 per cent by next year, even though nearly two decades of deflation have now been replaced by annual consumer price inflation of around 1.25 per cent on average.

The fact that the yield on the 10-year Japanese government bond (JGB) still stands at around 0.5 per cent, when it should be nearer 2 per cent if the bond market believed that Mr Kuroda's inflation target will be met, shows a lack of market conviction in the BOJ's policies, analysts say.

As Tohru Sasaki, chief foreign exchange strategist at JP Morgan Chase Bank in Tokyo told The Business Times: "There is a major disconnect between where the current long bond rate is and where it should be."

The stock market too, it appears, has begun to become more infected with doubts and this year the Nikkei average has given up some 20 per cent of the soaring gains it achieved after Mr Abe and Mr Kuroda took office.

Lithium batteries' explosion risk higher than thought

Findings raise the safety issue about their use on planes

Published Tue, Aug 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[WASHINGTON] New research shows that lithium batteries can explode and burn even more violently than previously thought, raising questions about their use and shipment on passenger airplanes.

Because many airlines are replacing paper charts with laptops and tablet computers, the Federal Aviation Administration conducted tests on what would happen if one of their rechargeable lithium-ion battery cells ignited. In one test, the cockpit filled with smoke thick enough to obscure instruments and vision out the window for about five minutes.

The FAA's findings, posted on the agency's website, raise an even bigger issue beyond laptops as makers of the battery cells commonly ship the products in bulk in the cargo areas of passenger airplanes. One test found the batteries may blow up, which may render airplane fire-suppression systems ineffective.

Russia seen tapping gold reserves to fight sanctions

It's getting closer to other BRICS nations to be independent of America, Europe

Published Mon, Aug 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

RUSSIA has built up substantial gold reserves which can be used to counter sanctions. In the past 10 years, gold reserves of the Bank of Russia, the central bank, have risen to 1,095 tonnes from 386 tonnes, according to the World Gold Council.

This year alone, the central bank has bought 55 tonnes from the nation's own gold mines to help protect the nation from sanctions. At current gold prices, the reserves, equal to 35.2 million troy ounces, are worth around US$46 billion.

Last week, Russia negotiated more currency swaps of roubles for renminbi, according to the Bank of Russia. It neither disclosed the amounts negotiated with China nor possible strategies of using its gold as collateral for loans from either China or other nations.

site_title: Read all about it: news you can wear
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Read all about it: news you can wear

Published

Sun, Aug 10, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[WASHINGTON] Even if you don't open a newspaper, turn on a television, log on to a computer or pull out a smartphone, you can get news - from wearable technology.

As wearables gain traction, news purveyors are eyeing these devices for their potential to deliver headlines and more to people who want to stay up to date.

Some news apps already have the capacity to deliver news notifications, or full articles, to smartwatches or eyewear such as Google Glass.

"We are going full speed on smartwatches," said Gilles Raymond, the San Francisco-based chief executive of News Republic, a mobile app that delivers news to mobile devices from hundreds of outlets.

Mr Raymond told AFP he expects people will find it useful to get not only headlines but full articles on a smartwatch as the wearable trend revs up.

"When the iPhone came out, people were saying that no one would read news on a phone. Now nobody is saying that," said Mr Raymond.

"People will read articles on a watch. They may not read 300 articles, but people adapt quickly to technology."

Mr Raymond founded News Republic in France and has expanded to other European markets as well as North America and China, aggregating news from hundreds of outlets, including AFP, Al-Jazeera, Reuters and The Associated Press.

Roman Karachinsky, CEO of the news aggregation app News360, also sees a future for wearables, but mainly for quick notifications they might not otherwise see.

"We want to change the formula from one where you go and seek information out to a world where information finds you when it's relevant and useful," Mr Karachinsky said.

He said the newly introduced Android Wear platform for Google allows for News360 alerts to be sent to some smartwatches, and to Google Glass.

These alerts fulfil a need of getting information out quickly - whether it is a sports score, stockmarket action or breaking news - in an unobtrusive way.

"Instead of digging around your pocket for your smartphone, now you can just look at your wrist or glance up to your Google Glass," said Mr Karachinsky. "It's a very transformative experience."

It remains unclear at the moment how fast wearable technologies will catch on, and how people will use the devices. While News Republic's Mr Raymond sees a demand for full articles, he differs from News360 on Google Glass. But he said smartwatches may gain more traction when they become independent of smartphones, allowing people to shed their phones for some of the time.

Roger Kay, analyst at Endpoint Technologies Associates, said news on smartwatches and Google Glass will probably be limited to short items that can be absorbed in a glance.

"The glanceability of it is important," Mr Kay said. "I don't imagine people squinting at their watches to read articles; they have enough trouble reading on their phones." Still, he noted that "a well-written headline can encapsulate an entire story".

For news organisations struggling with the transition to digital, wearables may offer some help, analysts say.

Ken Doctor of the media research firm Outsell said news organisations may be able to bring in more readers with alerts tailored to their interests, by delivering through wearables.

He said major news organisations are now delivering millions of email alerts on important news to readers who register, and that this drives more traffic to the websites. The same could be true for alerts on wearables. - AFP

site_title: National issues
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

National issues

What are the key issues you wish to see addressed in the National Day Rally on Aug 17?

Published

Sun, Aug 10, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Joshua Yim

CEO

Achieve Group

THIS National Day Rally, there are a few issues I wish to hear the Prime Minister address. The first concerns the social fabric of Singapore. Of late, there have been many differing opinions and perspectives from various camps on a host of different matters that underpin social norms and values.

I hope the PM can offer his opinion on these phenomena as we progress as a society against a conservative background, and how the country could steer its course to avoid extreme polarising situations, which might be to the detriment of society.

I believe PM will also talk about what is close to our hearts - the basic needs of all, specifically relating to health care, housing, and cost of living. With Singapore's ageing population, I wish to hear from him about his view of the outlook of a typical Singaporean retiree's life, in terms of financial wellbeing and medical care.

I would also like to hear how he intends to address the issue of Singapore's ageing population, given the phenomenon of fewer marriages and a shrinking local core on the horizon, which makes the country unsustainable in the long run.

I hope that the PM will also address the attitudes of the younger generation of Singaporeans.Globally, Gen Y has been getting a bad reputation for their attitude so I would like to hear how, as a country, we can help inculcate in our younger people a better attitude. These are the future leaders of Singapore and we need to ensure they are not only moulded for material success but also with the right values.

And as our country approaches its 50th anniversary next year, I also want to hear about the PM's vision for the next phase of Singapore's growth story, beyond the next general election. How will Singapore society evolve and sustain itself in the next 50 years?

Ronald Lee

Managing Director

PrimeStaff Management Services Pte Ltd

AS a country, Singapore is still in a transitional phase against the backdrop of a rapidly changing global and business environment. Various pillars of our society have therefore undergone major changes in recent years in a bid to maintain our competitive edge.

In the upcoming National Day Rally, I hope the Prime Minister will go beyond outlining what the government has done for its people and reassuring the public of the country's future in broad strokes. I would like to see more of a blueprint of how we are going to ensure Singapore's success in the years to come.

For starters, what else will be done to finally stabilise the economic restructuring we have been going through?

Next, the rally should address the needs of Singaporeans for stronger social safety nets. It should touch on what more will be done to stabilise the property market to ensure that homes are affordable for all, especially the lower income segment.

Health care is another area of high priority. I believe the PM will touch on the new Medishield Life and I also hope to see what else will be done to tackle the issue of Singapore's ageing population.

With Singapore's changing demographics, the question of the Singaporean identity has emerged. With a lot more foreigners in our midst in recent years, what will be done to ensure social cohesion and a unified Singaporean identity?

I believe these are a few of the themes that will continue to be important concerns in the next few years.

Laletha Nithiyanandan

Managing Director

Talent Design Potential

THIS year's National Day Rally speech should focus more on the future instead of how far we have come.

Specifically I would like our leader to acknowledge that his government needs to transition from playing the role of custodian to embracing a more collaborative and inclusive style of government.

Tell us how he is building a comprehensive plan to get his leaders to focus more on building a Singapore Community, rather than Singapore Inc. Share the blueprint on how his government will focus on simplifying policies that affect the majority of citizens - such as CPF.

And tell us how they will be proactive in reviewing current policies that are biased towards monetary gains only.

And not least, build up a national agenda for critical conversations with citizens and also to act quickly on important issues such as health care, welfare, job creation and cost of living.

Peh Kim Choo

Director

Hua Mei Centre for Successful Ageing (an initiative of Tsao Foundation)

LONGEVITY in Singapore, among the world's highest, reflects our hard-won progress as a society. The government awards it in the Pioneer Generation Package, and there is cause for not just elders but everyone of us to celebrate.

From acknowledging the contributions of our elders, we start the mindset change towards counting all the opportunities that ageing provides rather than takes away from us.

What I wish for our elders and our society is a movement to recognise and honour the critical role that older people play as transmitters of values and culture, and their contributions as mentors in the family, community and workplace.

We need to dare to dream of a home where every age can flourish and benefit from longevity. I hope that we can together create a space for the dreaming to materialise.

Karen Reddington

Regional Vice-President, South Pacific

FedEx Express

AS we approach the 49th National Day Rally, minds will inevitably cast ahead to the country's landmark 50th anniversary, in what will be both a celebration and crossroads for Singapore. Current figures show that growth is tracking at between 2% and 4%, and it is steady growth that is the holy grail for any economy.

We need to focus on removing barriers to trade in order to maintain Singapore's economic trajectory, and fan the flames of long-term growth, a large part of which will be delivered by SMEs.

At the same time, the issue of productivity needs addressing. A careful blend of incentives and policy will be required in order to promote productivity more aggressively and ensure that Singapore remains competitive in the face of future economic headwinds.

Maintaining a focus on growing Singapore's SMEs, combined with greater productivity, will deliver to Singapore the robust platform it needs in order to build on the legacy that was delivered by the nation's founding fathers.

Chris Comer

CEO and Property Developer

Castlewood Group

IN view of the recently launched Pioneer Generation Package (PGP), a related issue will be on most people's minds - what more is being done to make retirement affordable?

With the rising cost of living, it is more and more difficult to maintain a lifestyle, even more so if your income is fixed, as the buying power of your dollar becomes weaker - is even a million dollars enough to retire in Singapore?

While the PGP provides a safety net for retirees who will likely see an increased frequency of medical-related bills as they age, health care is only one aspect of the multi-faceted situations the elderly face. So a discussion on how property can be made affordable for retirees would be welcomed by all.

As property cooling measures are beginning to take effect, attention should be turned to the elderly and what is being done for their housing. In many cases, seniors live alone.

Retirement communities should earn a place on the rally agenda in terms of providing financial assistance to enable the aged to gain access to these living spaces. Senior living facilities can meet the elderly's housing needs, and offer them some much-needed companionship.

Singapore's rapidly ageing population has been a major talking point for the best part of the year, and as we reflect on our past successes as a nation, it is time for us to present a solution to our ever-changing socio-economic needs for the years to come.

David Leong

Managing Director

PeopleWorldwide Consulting Pte Ltd

EVERY National Day, there will be an anticipatory mood among Singaporeans as the Prime Minister sets the tone and direction of government policies, plus spell out some giveaways and takeaways. Over the last year, the government has rolled out programmes for the pioneer generation.

This year, in his ''state of the union'' address, I hope that PM can define the new social compact with Singaporeans - how this government sees its relationship with the people.

The demands of the people on housing, transport, healthcare and education are becoming varied and diverse; how can the government string together this diversity to forge a common goal with Singaporeans.

Despite all the adjustments to its policies in transport, housing, health care and education, Singaporeans are still clamouring for more.

Not only that, they are asking for more civil and political freedom, from gay rights advocacy to how the National Library should choose its books.

The government must set the tone and rationale of its policies and not be seen as responding in an arbitrary, random, passive and reactionary way.

I hope PM can spell out in clear and unambiguous terms how it intends to deal with such issues and how it wants Singaporeans to align themselves with the national agenda for the good of Singapore. Enough never seems enough for Singaporeans.

Joshua Soh

Country Manager

Cisco in Singapore

IF we take a moment to think about what Singapore has achieved over the last 49 years - how our society has progressed and what we have accomplished - it really is incredible.

Let us not forget where we have come from. Instead, let us appreciate our fellow citizens and residents who are working hard to drive our future, together.

The world as we know it is changing every day, and the most important thing for us as a country is to be part of the transformation.

I would like to see the National Day Rally address how Singaporeans and businesses can lift the game so we compete better in the global, inter-connected economy.

Let our 5C's be: support for all our communities; a collaborative workforce using flexible work arrangements; the co-development of innovative solutions; care and respect for our fellow Singaporeans; and the capitalisation of our strengths to make Singapore our home in our hearts and secure our future.

Robin C Lee

Group COO

Bok Seng Group

PLENTY has been done to take care of our senior Singaporeans and assure them that the government has their interests at heart. The introduction of the Pioneer Generation Package and the Medishield initiatives are definitely a move in the right direction.

Let's come back to the much deliberated question of 6.9 million population for Singapore. I believe that this is something that the leadership has put in a whole lot of thoughtful deliberation for the longest time. Although debate on the topic seems to have lost steam somewhat after the initial reactions, it's something that needs to be confronted earlier than later.

It's not just an economics issue but also very much a social one. To be a vibrant and sustainable city, we need a large enough population to churn out the economic activities to support this resource-deficient country.

In my view, just looking at all the infrastructure being planned and the construction work underway, we're all set to go. The issues that need to be addressed sooner rather than later are how do we absorb the population surge while maintaining social cohesiveness?

How do we create hinterlands that Singaporeans can retreat to when they are done fighting in the high-stress, high-cost arena of this city?

As more qualified and wealthier people arrive, how do we ensure that any further widening of the wealth gap be contained? I hope to see these key issues addressed.

Chris Mead

Regional Director

Hays in Singapore & Malaysia

MANY employers in Singapore tell us that skill shortages remain an issue and this is likely to limit the country's potential for economic growth in the future.

The government's decision to push companies to consider locals above foreigners is good for the Singapore economy as a whole, but overseas talent is still needed to fill vacancies where local Singaporeans are in short supply.

We are seeing strong demand for local profiles which is creating a lot of competition for local talent. We expect the shortage of highly skilled professionals to continue so it is critical that Singapore matches the skills of young people with the skills needed in the economy.

By expanding the output and quality of the local education system Singapore can better meet the skills employers want. The supply of people with the right skills is the foundation for every successful organisation and finding the right person for a job makes businesses, economies and societies stronger.

Stephen McNulty

Managing Director - Asia-Pacific and Japan

Progress Software

WITH a robust local startup and software developers' community, the government should facilitate and address the need for a software ecosystem that encourages creative and innovative use of technology across all sectors.

Singapore has been making good progress towards realising the iN2015 vision - it is now time for the government and industry players to think of the nation's ICT strategy and direction beyond the 2015 deadline.

IDA data shows business broadband adoption and households' Internet penetration exceeding 85 per cent in 2013, and expected to continue to grow in the next few years.

As Singapore's Smart Nation vision was unveiled in June, now is the time for the government to discuss the road ahead for the ICT industry and where the country foresees itself to be in the next 10 years.

In line with the iN2015 vision and to promote innovative use of cloud platforms, Progress is focused on working with educational institutions and enterprises to encourage creativity.

Wong Heng Chew

President

Fujitsu Singapore

EVER since Singapore embarked on its plans to be the world's first Smart Nation, there have been reports on different initiatives, such as the test bed at Jurong Lake District and the IoT@Home initiative.

As Fujitsu has always envisioned a future world where ICT is human-centric, these developments have been of particular interest to us. To help create a better standard of living for the elderly, Fujitsu developed a prototype of the Next Generation Cane, a smart walking stick designed to provide directions and track the user's location during emergencies, while monitoring the user's health conditions, such as heart rate and temperature.

As Singapore works towards creating a comfortable and efficient environment for both the young and old, it would be interesting to get further insights on the opportunities available for existing businesses, and how these initiatives will impact businesses and their workers.

As technology continues to advance quickly, I believe there are many businesses that will be keen on helping Singapore attain its goal of becoming a Smart Nation.

Eric Hoh

Vice-President, Asia South & Korea Regions

Symantec

AS we celebrate another year of independence, it's prudent for us to keep in mind the link between Singapore's shift towards a knowledge-based economy and the need for information security. Security is a topic that's not often discussed unless it's for the wrong reasons.

In 2013 we saw a record number of mega data breaches worldwide, where there were eight incidents that each resulted in at least 10 million identities being exposed. High profile incidents of data breaches, information loss and online fraud also emphasise that we are all on the front lines of information security, and reinforcing the Personal Data and Protection Act is a positive first step towards safeguarding our private data.

Symantec wishes Singapore a happy 49th National Day, and looks forward to many more years of supporting our nation's safety and prosperity by enabling confidence in a connected world.

Thirumalai Chandroo

Chairman/CEO

Modern Montessori International Group

AS we welcome Singapore's 49th birthday, we commemorate the triumphs we have achieved and lessons learned from the struggles we overcame as a young nation.

Now we stand on the global stage, alongside the world's powerhouses. Globalisation has achieved this for us. Singapore's open-door policy has created economic success in the last few decades.

As we look towards the future with optimism, we hope to see new inroads created for Singaporeans. Concerns about the high costs of living, declining birth rates and ageing population are the pressing issues of the day.

There is also the need to broaden employment opportunities for our young in rising industries such as the arts, new age technology and social media to keep up with an increasingly sophisticated and tech-savvy world.

Currently the Pioneer Generation benefits pay homage to the hands that built this nation and allay the concerns about rising healthcare costs . Ensuring the long-term wellbeing of our elderly is a priority for our government.

Asia has emerged as a global economic engine and a key player in international politics. These shifts ultimately alter Asia's role with the world. How will the rise of Asian powers such as China and India affect Singapore's growth and its business prospects in the near future?

It will be good to hear about measures to enable local businesses thrive amid the growing external competition. As we progress as a regional hub of knowledge, this National Day is a time to reflect and to ensure that we will keep beating to the heartbeat of success for many more years to come.

Leong Soo Yee

Singapore Head

ACCA

A CONSTANTLY evolving economy and a more complex economic landscape mean that more demands will be placed on the Singapore labour market to provide a wider range of skills and competencies in order for us to retain our global competitive edge.

Advances in technology mean that higher education is now more accessible, via online or distance learning.

Innovative study concepts such as Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) have brought opportunities to many people, both graduates and non-graduates, who want to upgrade their professional knowledge, skills and abilities to reach their full potential. The cost-effective nature and online format provide flexibility and accessibility for potential participants.

However, qualifications are not enough. Professionals of the future will need to possess a combination of both practical and theoretical skills in order to adapt and overcome the challenges of today's global economic landscape.

We look forward to new and innovative models of how we can integrate the study and work environments so that our youth will be better prepared to be the leaders of tomorrow.

Lee Fook Chiew

Chief Executive Officer

Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants

SINGAPORE has been restructuring its economy and making efforts to raise productivity levels through innovation. This is especially important in an increasingly globalised world where competition is intensifying and impacting more business sectors.

As the economy continues to restructure towards higher value activities, there is a need to ensure that companies, especially Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs), continue to be supported to move up the innovation and productivity curve during the economic restructuring journey.

The government has rolled out initiatives to support the shift towards innovation and capability transformation. It would be a boon to the business community and accountancy profession for issues related to productivity and innovation to receive continued government attention and be addressed at the National Day Rally.

Annie Yap

Managing Director

AYP Associates Pte Ltd

THE idea of a wealth tax in Singapore so as to narrow the wealth divide between rich and poor Singaporeans could be a topic for discussion. Singapore's Gini coefficient - which is now at 0.478 - is one of the highest among the advanced economies.

It would be interesting to know how a possible wealth tax can be structured to close the growing wealth gap, yet ensure that Singapore remains attractive for high-earners and workers.

Another issue that can be addressed would be the shortage of staff in the services sector. Reasons why the service industry is not attractive include long hours and poor customer attitudes. Five years ago, GEMS (Go-the-extra mile for Service) was implemented to encourage service staff to improve customer service standards.

It might now be timely for us to also look at how Singaporeans can be better customers so that our service staff can feel appreciated and fulfilled about their work.

Mark Billington

Regional Director, South-east Asia

ICAEW

I HOPE to hear more about how the government will ensure that social mobility remains high on the agenda, and people from all walks of life are able to achieve their career goals and personal dreams.

As a leading knowledge economy, many opportunities will arise but people need to have the correct skills and expertise to take advantage of them. It is therefore important for the government to assist people to develop those skills - and encourage the education pathways to gain and certify them.

In our work globally, ICAEW champions opening access to the financially rewarding accountancy and finance sector to people from all backgrounds. We have learnt that not everyone has the opportunity to go to the right schools nor wants to take the traditional university route.

To this end, we recently embarked on a partnership with Singapore Polytechnic which offered diploma students a route to become chartered accountants.

Our members come from different backgrounds but undertake the same rigorous certification path. They bring a valued diversity to the profession and are highly regarded by their employers.

Rick Scurfield

Senior Vice-President and General Manager

NetApp, Asia-Pacific

THIS August, Singapore celebrates its 49th year of independence since 1965. On this very special day, I would like to congratulate Singapore on the remarkable achievements it has accomplished thus far.

From its humble beginnings to becoming one of Asia's strongest economies, Singapore has come a long way and is often modelled after by other countries.

The Republic has managed to carve out a niche for itself by investing heavily in its human capital; nurturing and building a high-performance workforce.

With its investments in the newest technologies and infrastructure towards improving the country's networked readiness I am confident that we will see the nation reaching greater heights as a world-class data-driven economy.

To the Little Red Dot that has earned its place in the world's stage - here's wishing you many congratulations and may you prosper always. Happy National Day.

He said in an interview with the journal Central Banking published yesterday that policy has to eventually normalise, and that this should be done as soon as practicable so that "people do not think easy money is the new state of affairs and make investment decisions on that basis".

site_title: Singapore's intestacy rules
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Singapore's intestacy rules

Published

Sun, Aug 10, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IN the absence of a valid will, Singapore's Intestate Succession Act determines how a deceased person's estate will be distributed to successors. This applies to Central Provident Fund (CPF) monies as well, unless you make a separate nomination.

We reproduce the rules below, together with a translation into plain English. Disclaimer: Translations are not exact and this is not legal advice.

These rules also do not apply to Muslims, whose estates are governed by Muslim law and the Syariah Court.

One key point to note is that your spouse and children take precedence over your parents, under intestacy law. Your children and spouse will split your assets with nothing left for dependent parents, if you do not make a will stating an alternative distribution.

Rule 1

If an intestate dies leaving a surviving spouse, no issue and no parent, the spouse shall be entitled to the whole of the estate.

Translation:

If you leave behind a spouse and no parents or children, your spouse gets everything.

Rule 2

If an intestate dies leaving a surviving spouse and issue, the spouse shall be entitled to one-half of the estate.

Translation:

If your spouse and children survive, your spouse gets half of your assets. See next rule on children.

Rule 3

Subject to the rights of the surviving spouse, if any, the estate (both as to the undistributed portion and the reversionary interest) of an intestate who leaves issue shall be distributed by equal portions per stirpes to and amongst the children of the person dying intestate and such persons as legally represent those children, in case any of those children be then dead.

Proviso No. (1) - The persons who legally represent the children of an intestate are their descendants and not their next-of-kin.

Proviso No. (2) - Descendants of the intestate to the remotest degree stand in the place of their parent or other ancestor, and take according to their stocks the share which he or she would have taken.

Translation:

Your children will get the other half, split equally among them. If a child is dead, his or her children (your grandchildren) can claim their parent's share.

Rule 4

If an intestate dies leaving a surviving spouse and no issue but a parent or parents, the spouse shall be entitled to one-half of the estate and the parent or parents to the other half of the estate.

Translation:

If you leave behind your spouse, no children, and parents, your spouse gets half and your parents get the other half.

Rule 5

If there are no descendants, the parent or parents of the intestate shall take the estate, in equal portions if there be 2 parents, subject to the rights of the surviving spouse (if any) as provided in rule 4.

Translation:

If you have no children and no spouse, your parents get your assets split equally among them.

Rule 6

If there are no surviving spouse, descendants or parents, the brothers and sisters and children of deceased brothers or sisters of the intestate shall share the estate in equal portions between the brothers and sisters and the children of any deceased brother or sister shall take according to their stocks the share which the deceased brother or sister would have taken.

Translation:

If you have no spouse, children or parents left, your brothers and sisters get their respective portions, split equally.

If there is a deceased brother or sister with children, their children will get the share the deceased would have got.

Rule 7

If there are no surviving spouse, descendants, parents, brothers and sisters or children of such brothers and sisters but grandparents of the intestate, the grandparents shall take the whole of the estate in equal portions.

Translation:

If you have no spouse, children, parents, brothers or sisters or their children left, but your grandparents are still around, they will split your assets equally.

Rule 8

If there are no surviving spouse, descendants, parents, brothers and sisters or their children or grandparents but uncles and aunts of the intestate, the uncles and aunts shall take the whole of the estate in equal portions.

Translation:

If you have no spouse, children, parents, brothers and sisters and their children, or grandparents left, but you have uncles and aunts, they will get your assets in equal portions.

Rule 9

In default of distribution under rules 1 to 8, the Government shall be entitled to the whole of the estate.

Translation:

If you have nobody left to distribute your money to according to the previous rules, the Government takes everything.

Special provision:

If any person so dying intestate leaves surviving him more than one wife, such wives shall share among them equally the share that the wife of the intestate would have been entitled to, had the intestate left only one wife surviving him.

Translation:

If you leave more than one wife behind, your wives split your money.

Another rule

Where a distributive share of the property of a person dying intestate is claimed by a child or any descendant of a child of that person, no money or other property which the intestate may during his life have given, paid or settled to or for the advancement of the child by whom or by whose descendant the claim is made shall be taken into account in estimating such distributive share.

Translation:

The expensive overseas education you gave your child, that $200,000 cash gift, or whatever you did to support him or her, will not be counted when calculating his or her fair share.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Escalating geo-political worries hit stocks

Published

Fri, Aug 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE Singapore stock market was in no celebratory mood yesterday on the eve of National Day as an overnight sell-off on Wall Street, sparked apparently by growing geo-political uncertainties, further dampened sentiment, resulting in the Straits Times Index falling 25.33 points or 0.8 per cent to 3,288.89.

The STI's movements have sometimes not been representative of broad market performance but this was not the case yesterday when the entire market recorded 116 rises against 364 falls excluding warrants, or about three losers for each winner.

Wall Street has been weak for a fortnight now and fell again on Thursday, reportedly because of Russian troop buildup in Ukraine, possible US air strikes in Iraq and the worsening trouble in Gaza, the resulting surge in "geopolitical risk" prompting traders to dump stocks despite the release of a positive US jobless claims report.

Here, the biggest index losers yesterday were the banks DBS and OCBC, and the Jardine group - not surprising since these have been the main drivers of the STI this year. For the week, the index lost 56 points or 1.7 per cent.

Turnover throughout the week has been low, disappointing to many but not really surprising since it has been low for several months now with no sign of improvement other than the spikes seen at the end of each month when the STI gets window-dressed.

In yesterday's session, volume was 1.5 billion units worth S$1.08 billion with the 30 index components contributing S$641 million or 59 per cent of the dollar volume. On July 31, when the STI was ramped up 19 points to 3,373, volume was 1.7 billion units worth S$1.7 billion. Since then, the STI has lost 2.5 per cent.

Among banks, OCBC has been in play lately, apparently because it completed its takeover of Hong Kong's Wing Hang Bank but more likely because traders, having already played with UOB and DBS, had switched their efforts to OCBC.

In yesterday's session though, OCBC fell seven cents to S$10.10 and DBS 33 cents to S$17.81 but UOB managed a five-cent rise to S$22.69.

Macquarie Warrants (MW) said yesterday that the key messages that Macquarie Equities Research (MER) took home after an analyst and media briefing with DBS were a potential pick-up in trade finance volume, fewer concerns and more transparency on China exposures, good asset quality trends and gearing to higher rates, a comfortable funding position and supportive margin trends.

"MER believes that DBS could be a great story for the second half of the year. MER thinks that DBS is in a good strategic position to take market share, particularly in Transaction Banking and SME banking," said MW. "MER has an outperform rating on DBS with a 12-month target price of S$19."

In its assessment of Singapore's economic outlook, DBS Group Research said yesterday in its Daily Breakfast Spread that while expectation of a gradual global recovery remains in place, recent data have been mixed.

"Demand from Asia and the West remains sluggish. Growth expectation for the US has been lowered. This is juxtaposed against a weak eurozone and a slowdown in China," said DBS.

"None of this bodes well for Singapore. The economy continues to be weighed down by the domestic restructuring and external uncertainties. Manufacturing is in doldrums but the services sector is the biggest risk. We expect full year GDP growth to register 3 per cent, which is below Singapore's medium-term potential growth rate of 4 per cent."

site_title: Renault for road and track
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Renault for road and track

The Renault Clio RS is an accomplished hot hatch that is surprisingly affordable. By Samuel Ee

Published

Fri, Aug 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE styling of Renault hatchbacks in general and the Clio in particular has been quirky, to say the least. But the latest edition of this French supermini is decidedly different. Facelifted to show off Renault's new brand identity, it is sharply distinctive.

The front end with its new almond-shaped headlamps now incorporates a bigger and bolder chrome logo set into a sleek black grille for contrast. The rear end is even neater, with its slim tail lights and pleasing proportions. In Clio RS form with the multi-coated Liquid Yellow pearlescent paintwork, it is even more striking.

The Renault Clio RS is the top-of-the-line Clio tweaked by Renault Sport or RS. In its latest iteration, the Clio RS introduces three new features not previously associated with the model - five doors, a 1.6-litre engine, and a dual clutch gearbox.

For the first time, the Clio RS is available as a five-door hatch. But it still looks like a sporty three-door model because the convenience offered by the extra two doors is not obvious with the concealed door handles.

Another first is the downsized turbo engine (from a naturally aspirated 2.0), as well as the pairing with a six-speed dual clutch transmission (from a manual gearbox) to drive the front wheels.

This engine from Nissan (Renault and the Japanese manufacturer are partners) is very strong despite its size. With maximum torque of 240 Newton-metres from just 1,750 rpm, it is so punchy that you can scarcely believe there are only 1,618 cubic centimetres. The only drawback is that a heavy right foot will elicit torque steer. Add a light steering and this may be fun for some but hairy for others. Immediate correction is required and it also means that one of the Clio RS's party tricks - launch control - can be a heart-thumping affair if you don't hang on to the wheel properly. But its playful nature also means it is an entertaining car that is perfectly suitable for track day.

An RS Drive button behind the gear lever offers three driving modes - Normal, Sport and Race. In Normal, the Clio RS is grown-up and well-behaved. Sport turns it into a bit of a bad boy, with the appropriate aural enhancement from the sound pipe, which transmits more of the engine noise into the cabin. Race is available only in manual transmission, which is accomplished using the somewhat flimsy paddle shifts. And because they are column-mounted, changing gears is not a mid-corner option.

An electronic limited slip differential reduces understeer in fast corners by "micro braking" the inside front wheel without reducing engine torque. And it does so before the traction control cuts in, thus increasing driving fun.

The Clio RS can be ordered in two trim levels with their respective chassis options - Sport or the more track-focused Cup, which is five mm lower and 15 per cent stiffer. In Cup setting, the Clio RS's suspension is superb. It is very firm but in true French tradition, never harsh, and you should be able to outcorner almost any other car in a corkscrew because the RS will take it flatter and faster.

Together with a telemetry system to monitor performance data and g-force, the Clio RS promises maximum fun on the circuit for minimal price. The latter shows up in the plasticky faux chrome. But the rest of the cabin makes up for it with tasteful details, like the leather upholstery with red stitching, red accents on the gear lever and air vents, and the familiar top marker on the steering to indicate the straight position.

Add its new styling and newfound useability and the affordable Renault Clio RS suddenly becomes a very interesting alternative.

Norway's wealth fund buys another London property

It acquires a 57.8% stake in a Mayfair estate for £343m

Published Mon, Aug 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[OSLO] Norway's sovereign wealth fund, the world's largest, bought a stake in an estate in London's Mayfair district for £343 million (S$720 million), expanding its property holdings in the UK capital.

The fund bought a 57.8 per cent share in the 1.3-ha Pollen Estate between Regent Street and Bond Street from the Church Commissioners for England, Oslo-based Norges Bank Investment Management said yesterday. The UK Crown Estate bought a 6.4 per cent stake for US$38 million.

"The purchase is according to the fund's strategy to build a global, but concentrated, real estate portfolio," a spokesman said. "Our strategy is to focus our investments on a limited number of large global cities, where we invest in core retail and office properties." The purchase expands Norway's holdings in London after it agreed in 2010 to buy a US$772 million stake in Regent Street from the Crown Estate. The Pollen Estate's 43 properties include office and retail space in a square also bordered by Conduit Street and Burlington Gardens that includes Savile Row. The properties will continue to be managed by the trustee company. The UK Secretary of Defence-Greenwich Hospital also owns 10 per cent, while the Pollen family holds 25.8 per cent.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Childhood memories

Tay Suan Chiang

Published

Fri, Aug 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Wheniwasfour

www.wheniwasfour.com

DO YOU remember what you did when you were four?

Designer Tan Li Ling, 28, remembers a childhood which was "simple with lots of love". Her mum is a housewife, and "we had home-cooked food everyday and we were definitely very well taken care of. Before my sister came along, mum was my playmate too", recalls Ms Tan.

In 2009, together with two other friends, she stared Wheniwasfour, an online shop which retails accessories, T-shirts and tote bags, with designs inspired by childhood memories, such as the five stones game, Potong ice cream and the Hao Gong Ming or Good Citizen logo. The Hao Gong Ming textbooks were a staple in primary school, to teach students how to be good citizens.

Ms Tan now runs Wheniwasfour on her own, and her mum helps with some of the sewing. "Most of the designs are based on my childhood memories, as well as other peoples' memories," says Ms Tan. "Customers, friends and family often share with me what they have seen, used, played, eaten and experienced in the past."

She called her label Wheniwasfour, because, "four is the age when most children start to have first impressions of the many things, people and places around them. I hope to bring back childhood memories through design and various handmade products".

Ms Tan began with just brooches, but following feedback from customers, she has expanded the range to include magnets and keychains. "I used to have only fancy gem biscuit brooches and rings, but customers will start to ask for earrings and necklaces as not all of them will wear pins, so I've added that to the collection as well."

Most of the products are handmade by Ms Tan and her mother. Another friend and her mother helps Ms Tan with the clay products, such as the gem biscuit earrings. Other fabric products are outsourced to local sewing aunties. "Many of the items are made locally, but products such as the tote bags are sewn and printed overseas," says Ms Tan.

The label's best-sellers are the snack pins, gem biscuit related items and the tote bags. Earrings cost S$14.90 while tote bags retail at S$24.

Most of her customers are Singaporeans, who like reminiscing about their childhood days. "They are not that popular with tourists, probably because they can't relate to the design of the items."

For this National Day, be a good citizen, and show some national pride by donning the Hao Gong Ming T-shirt, which retails for S$32.90.

Conveniently available

Published

Fri, Aug 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Cocoloco

YOU'VE just finished a heart-pumping hot yoga class and you want to refuel with some coconut water. But it's 9pm and there isn't a fruit stand open nearby, and it's too much work to pry open one - husks and all - anyway. What do you do?

Well now, thankfully, there's Cocoloco. The svelte bottles of locally bottled fresh Thai coconut juice are the brainchild of young local couple Kelvin Ngian and Jun Hew, who want to make the trendy health drink more conveniently available to the masses.

Their coconut water tastes exactly like what you'd get from a fresh coconut, and is slightly sweeter than most other bottled labels of coconut water. That's because the water is tipped out of coconuts directly imported from Thailand and only filtered but not pasteurised before being bottled, says Mr Ngian. No sugar or artificial sweeteners are added. "Some of the other coconut waters on the market have shelf lives of up to a year, which makes you wonder how much it's been treated," says the 30-year-old, who left his banking job to join his family's coconut import and wholesale business, Siam Coconuts, last year.

Noting the recent increased interest in coconut water - the low-calorie, potassium-rich liquid is said to have anti-ageing, anti-carcinogenic properties - the idea to branch into coconut water was birthed shortly after, and bottle retail kicked off last month, says Mr Ngian. Ms Hew, 29, is a luxury jewellery marketeer by day and helps out with marketing efforts in her free time.

Cocoloco is bottled in Siam Coconut's processing plant in Aljunied on-demand, and are delivered on the same day. The bottles have been lab-tested and stay good for up to a week, though Mr Ngian recommends consuming them within three days.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Enjoying the organisation

The DBS Vickers team has signed up to play every year since 2010. Stories by Justine Moss

Published Fri, Aug 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

DBS Vickers has signed up every year for the BT Corporate Golf League since it started back in 2010 for a number of reasons which includes "great organisation", according to team captain Leonard Lui. "We get to play the best courses in Singapore. The organisation is superb and it's a great event to socialise in. We get to meet up with old friends, in a competitive environment," he explains.

In addition to Mr Lui (handicap 16), the team consists of Lim Kok Ann (13), Henry Lim (17), Eugene Png (13), Frankie Lim (13) and Poh Koon Kiat (13). The team has got off to a flying start, achieving the highest score of 105 on count back during the second round at Tanah Merah Country Club's Tampines Course, which propelled them to third on the table. While they have yet to win the League, DBS Vickers has performed well each year, finishing 15th in 2010 out of 25 teams, 10th in 2011, 9th a year later and sixth last year in Category A. While Mr Lui believes that SunMoon and SPH Sultans of Swing are the teams to watch this year, his team will aim to finish in the top half of the table. Ahead of next week's third round at Tanah Merah Country Club's Garden Course, Mr Lui says: "We will go out to enjoy the game and the course, and to make new friends and if we play well, then it's a bonus."

Forgot the keys again?

Forgetfulness can be brought on by drugs such as statins, and also by invasive diagnostic procedures, poor control of medical conditions and poor quality of sleep, all of which are preventable

Published Fri, Aug 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

HAVE you forgotten where you put your cellphone or did you have difficulty trying to recall the name of the person who just greeted you? As the population here gets increasingly older, medical advances that prolong longevity and preserve one's power of memory become ever more significant.

Dementia is more common among older people, but while many believe it is an inevitable consequence of ageing, medical science has taught us that it is not always so. Do not worry when you have transient lapses in memory. However, understanding more about the mechanisms of memory loss can enable one to take proactive measures to prevent a deterioration in one's power of memory. Having a checklist of the preventable causes of memory impairment will make taking such appropriate preventive measures easier.

site_title: Brit-pop survivors prove solid local favourites
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Brit-pop survivors prove solid local favourites

Dylan Tan

Published

Thu, Aug 7, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT can't be easy being a successful Brit-pop band; just look at the likes of Oasis and Blur. One moment, they were ruling the charts during the height of their popularity in the 1990s, and the next, egos and infighting led to their breakup in the new millennium.

So it becomes almost a feat for a band like Travis to still be around after almost 25 years together - without a single change in their line-up, at that. The secret to the Scottish quartet's longevity probably lies in the fact that they still very much enjoy one another's company and playing together as a band.

That bond was evident last Friday evening when they performed at The Star Performing Arts Centre as bassist Dougie Payne shared a light moment with guitarist Andy Dunlop on drummer Neil Primrose's riser while singer-frontman Fran Healy engaged the 2,000-strong crowd with his in-between-songs banter.

It also helps that the foursome haven't let fame go to their heads and have a reputation of being some of the nicest people in the music business. The show kicked off later than expected at 9.45pm because the interviews taking place backstage overran as Healy and Dunlop made sure everybody's questions were duly answered before they came on 45 minutes later than advertised.

What makes it even more impressive is that they managed to remain so grounded despite the fact that they are one of the biggest-selling bands in the world, and paved the way for other Brit-pop clones like Snow Patrol, Keane and Coldplay, which Travis incidentally co-headlined a double bill with in 2001 at the Singapore Indoor Stadium.

It was the first time both bands played here and even though Coldplay has since overtaken Travis in terms of commercial success, its frontman Chris Martin never forgets the debt he owes and often refers to himself as "the poor man's Fran Healy" in interviews when comparisons between the two acts are made.

While Coldplay has since returned to our shores only once, it was Travis's fourth time here. Touring on the back of last year's Where You Stand, their first album in half a decade, they opened with the mid-tempo Mother, a track off it before playing another four between a 21-song setlist that was heavy on their hits like Pipe Dreams, Driftwood, Love Will Come Through and Flowers in the Windows, which they performed acoustically with no amplification during the encore.

While the new songs sometimes lack the immediate pop hooks of their stadium- sized anthems like Turn and Sing, it showed a new maturity in their songwriting. With all four members now fathers, it's only natural they would write songs about parenthood; like Where You Stand'sReminder, which Healy tells the crowd is a list of things he'd like his seven-year-old son to learn ("Celebrate, don't be late / Finish what's on your plate / Figure out, don't forget / Only love, don't regret").

As always, Travis closed the two-hour show with their signature hit, Why Does It Always Rain on Me, off their biggest-selling album, The Man Who (1999). Ironically, Happy from their debut Good Feeling (1997) appeared on the setlist as an encore but was not performed. Given the smiles that were seen all around when the house lights came on, nobody looked like they were about to complain.

site_title: Indonesian meat, dairy producer launches Singapore IPO
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Indonesian meat, dairy producer launches Singapore IPO

Japfa plans to use S$187.3m net proceeds to develop China dairy business

Published

Thu, Aug 7, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IN spite of the decision by Samudra Energy to pull the plug on its initial public offering (IPO), Indonesian meat and dairy producer Japfa Ltd is moving ahead with its own: its public offer opens today, and the firm expects to make its debut on the mainboard of Singapore Exchange next Friday.

Samudra Energy, an Indonesian oil and gas firm, had cited current market volatility as the reason. Market observers, however, pointed to more company-specific factors, such as the upstream oil and gas sector being unfamiliar to investors in Singapore.

In a press briefing yesterday, Japfa's CEO Tan Yong Nang said the firm is here for the long term, and that "it doesn't really matter" if the share price moves 5-10 per cent in either direction upon listing.

"We believe we're a good company. For a good company, whether it is good times or bad times, there will be interest in you," he said. "Frankly, we're farmers, we don't time the market."

The Singapore-headquartered firm is selling 248 million shares - comprising 231.2 million shares for its international offer and 16.8 million for the public offer - at 80 Sing cents a share. Earlier news reports had put the indicative price range between 75-87 Sing cents a share.

Japfa revealed that it has received "robust demand" from institutional investors, receiving indications of interest amounting to about 5.1 times the international offer.

"We went through a proper price discovery process to come out with this price," said Mr Tan, adding that interest came from a "balanced mix" of investors including long-only funds and insurance firms.

Marubeni Corp, the largest Japanese food commodities trader, will be an anchor investor, Bloomberg reported.

Its current shareholders, the Santosa family in Indonesia, will remain the largest shareholder post-IPO, retaining a 77 per cent stake.

Japfa produces milk, poultry and beef in Indonesia and has replicated the same industrial farming business model in Vietnam, Myanmar and India for poultry, and in China for dairy products.

The vertically integrated group uses its raw milk to produce fresh milk, UHT milk and cheeses under the "Greenfields" brand to consumers in Indonesia, where it holds about 38 per cent of the market by value as a market leader, and other countries such as Singapore, Hong Kong and the Philippines. It also makes processed meat products under the "So Good" and "So Nice" brands in Indonesia and "So Yumm" brand in Vietnam.

The group last year recorded a net profit attributable to shareholders of US$41.8 million, down 22 per cent from 2012's US$53.3 million. Revenue rose 16 per cent to US$2.7 billion.

Japfa intends to use the net proceeds of S$187.3 million - assuming an over-allotment option is not exercised - to develop its China dairy business - where the group's profit margins are the highest - by building a second five-farm hub in Inner Mongolia. The funds raised will also go towards growing its business in China and the Indochina region and paying off borrowings, including pre-prepayment charges.

Going forward, the firm hopes to ride on the growth in Indonesia's middle class which it says will create a bigger appetite for meat and dairy products, and also to replicate its business model to other parts of Asia, in particular at the most profitable parts of the value chain. The consumer food segment, now just a small part of the group (the firm does not provide a breakdown by business segment), will be a key driver for future growth too, said Mr Tan.

"We want to be a pan-Asian company providing all sorts of animal protein food for the masses in Asia," he said.

Credit Suisse (Singapore) and DBS Bank are the joint global coordinators and bookrunners for the deal. Credit Suisse will also be acting as the stabilising manager with the ability to buy up to 37.2 million shares, or 15 per cent of the total offer, in an over-allotment option should Japfa's share price fall.

For January to May, preliminary estimates from the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) show, visitor arrivals declined 1.7 per cent to 6.33 million as visitor arrivals from China plunged some 27 per cent. In contrast, overall visitor arrivals in Singapore were up 7.4 per cent for 2013 as a whole.

site_title: PM Lee reveals tighter forecast
content:
PM Lee reveals tighter forecast

Full-year growth now seen at 2.5-3.5%, which means that H2 expansion won't exceed 3.5%

Published

Fri, Aug 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE economy grew 3.5 per cent in the first half of the year, but the pace is likely to ease in the second.

In disclosing the year-on-year growth figure for January-June in his National Day Message last night, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong also indicated that the official full-year growth forecast has been narrowed from 2-4 per cent to 2.5-3.5 per cent.

This means that economic growth in the remaining July-December months is not expected to exceed 3.5 per cent. And growth for the full year will be below last year's 4.1 per cent.

In his National Day Message last year, Mr Lee also announced a revision of the full-year growth forecast for 2013, from 1-3 per cent to 2.5-3.5 per cent. In any case, private-sector economists have come to expect Mr Lee to give an update of these economic numbers in his National Day Message. This year, they tipped him to narrow the range of the growth forecast.

The economists, who had projected full-year growth at around 3.8 per cent in 2014, saw the move coming after GDP growth tumbled by over half to 2.1 per cent in the second quarter, down from 4.7 per cent in the first quarter.

CIMB's Song Seng Wun, UOB's Francis Tan and Mizuho's Vishnu Varathan expect growth contraints to remain in the months ahead. These include domestic headwinds from restructuring and credit pressures as well as geopolitical risks of the warfare and disease kinds.

Mr Song, who had correctly predicted that the full-year growth forecast would narrow to 2.5-3.5 per cent, pointed out yesterday that it's clear by now the European and American economies are not picking up as fast as expected.

The trade-dependent tech sector, which accounts for a third of manufacturing output, will continue to be a drag on the Singapore economy, he said. And the recent drop in Chinese tourists will only spell more bad news for the domestic services sector, which is already soft.

Weaker growth in the United States, China and several key emerging economies has already led the International Monetary Fund last month to trim its 2014 global growth forecast to 3.4 per cent from 3.7 per cent. Still, 2.5-3.5 per cent growth is not bad - and the growth is needed to produce good jobs and fulfilling careers, according to Mr Lee in his National Day Message to Singaporeans. "We must keep up this growth over the next decade to help you improve your lives."

In his message, Mr Lee also said that the government was studying how to make it more convenient for retirees to get cash out of their flats, "in a prudent and sustainable way". He said that he would speak about how to improve the Central Provident Fund at the National Day Rally next week, in particular, on how to make the CPF better in helping Singaporeans to save for old age.

The anxieties of the old and the aspirations of the young - these are two concerns that took up much of Mr Lee's National Day Message last night. And he pointed out the many efforts that the government is making to assist them.

In helping young Singaporeans to realise their potential, Mr Lee said that it was not just a matter of continuing education and training. "It's also a matter of social values."

Singaporeans should not judge a person by his paper qualifications, but also by his skills, contributions and character. "This is how we keep Singapore a land of hope and opportunity for all," he said. "We are now at a higher level, from which we can scale new heights. Hence, we must reassess our position, review our direction and refresh our strategies."

Published Fri, Aug 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Infuusa

THERE are only two types of drinks people bring to spin class, observes product designer by day and fitness instructor by night Ng Wei Lieh: plain water and energy drinks. The former is a little plain for those who want a bit of kick in their workout drink, and the latter is unnecessary. "It's like driving a Ferrari to the supermarket just to do grocery shopping," he says. "You burn about 300-400 calories in a one-hour spin class, but you're consuming 200 calories from one bottle of energy drink - and it's full of chemicals."

So the 39-year-old decided to come up with a healthier in-between. He first started experimenting with cold-brewed teas - teas made by steeping them in room temperature water for two to 12 hours - which results in a smoother and sweeter taste, and retains more antioxidants, but the wait time proved too impractical his busy lifestyle.

Cargo weakness continues as a drag on Asia-Pacific carriers

European airlines' shares fall the most in July; solid growth seen in air travel volumes globally

Published

Thu, Aug 7, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] European airline share prices took a hit in July, while their Asia-Pacific counterparts were weighed down by the weak cargo sector in the second quarter of the year.

According to the latest report from the Airlines Financial Monitor by the International Air Transport Association (Iata), European airlines' share prices fell the most among their global peers last month - shedding 9 per cent against June.

"In addition to overall market weakness, performance of European airlines' share prices reflects weakness in financial performance of some major carriers, which either declined on a year ago or fell short of meeting investor expectations," the report said.

In comparison, worldwide airline shares were down only 2 per cent month on month, largely in line with the broader market - the FTSE Global All Cap declined 3 per cent.

"Markets have been negatively impacted by a combination of factors, including political tension in various parts of the world," the report noted.

In this region, Singapore Airlines closed five cents lower at S$9.81. In July, the counter peaked at S$10.34 and bottomed out at S$10.08.

Its Hong Kong counterpart, Cathay Pacific, closed unchanged at HK$14.62 yesterday. Last month, its share price hit a high of HK$14.72, after reaching a low of HK$14.22. Down Under, Qantas Airways was up one Australian cent to A$1.30 yesterday. The month before, it hit a low of A$1.205 before rising to a high of A$1.335.

Even as initial second-quarter results showed that airlines worldwide continued to improve their financial performance, a sample of five airlines from the Asia-Pacific region posted an operating profit of US$150 million, a decline from US$254 million in Q2 2013.

This, the report attributed to a combination of cargo revenue weakness, as well as increasing cost pressures for the Chinese carriers which have had to contend with a depreciating local currency.

Globally, air travel volumes, which have benefited from an "improving demand environment", are expected to have solid growth ahead, the report said.
